abstract: LARCENY. -- On Saturday night officer CARROLL arrested JOHN FOLLEN and EDWARD MCBRIDE, a couple of well-known thieves, on suspicion of stealing a gold watch and a sum of money from a passenger on board one of the Jersey City ferry boats. The property was found in the possession of FOLLEN together with some other articles supposed to have been stolen from some soldiers encamped near Jersey City. Yesterday MCBRIDE confessed his complicity in the robbery, and implicated his confederate.

abstract: Judge E.P. BROOKS, of Elmira, presiding in the Sixth Judicial District of this State, has recently given an official opinion to the effect that a person under the age of twenty-one years may not be enlisted directly into the army of the United States without the written consent of his parents, or guardian, or master; but that, if he belongs to the militia of the State he is bound to do military duty in the service of the United States, if he shall be mustered therein in pursuance of a call of the President.

abstract: An agent of the Confederate states Government, says the Louisville Courier, called upon the Banks in Augusta, Ga., requesting to know how much of the Confederacy treasury notes they would take. They promptly answered fifteen per cent. of their capital. The aggregate Bank capital in Augusta is $3,075,000 -which at fifteen per cent. would make $461,250.

abstract: On Saturday evening, information was received a Police Head-quarters that a gang of counterfeiters were engaged in flooding the City with bogus $3 bills on the Hampden Back, at Newcastle, in this State.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday evening, information was received a Police Head-quarters that a gang of counterfeiters were engaged in flooding the City with bogus $3 bills on the Hampden Back, at Newcastle, in this State. The Captains of the several Precincts were immediately informed by telegraph, and fortunately the retail merchants and shopkeepers were made acquainted with the attempt to defraud them before the rogues had fairly commenced their business. A few of the spurious bills were passed off late at night, however, and the Police made some arrests of parties who were attempting it. James Ragan and Charles Hogan, both young men, offered one of them to Casper Schneider, of No. 189 Bowery. Mr. Schneider had been previously notified by the Police, and of course refused the bill, but engaged their attention until an officer came and took them into custody. When the officer made his appearance, they attempted to destroy the bill, which Mr. S. had previously returned to them, but were prevented. Justice OSBORNE committed them for examination. The Police of the Fourth Precinct also made an arrest of three men, named Henry Hunter, Wm. Crosby and Francis Murrill, charged with passing one of the bills in question. They were locked up for a hearing. The paper on which the bills are printed is coarse, and the engraving poorly executed.

abstract: An officer of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad states that their loss will reach two millions of dollars. In addition to the locomotives reported destroyed at Martinsburgh, there were three hundred and sixty freight cars and five passenger cars. The engines prove to be so sprung, from the intense heat of the fire built around them, that they are now worthless. It will cost as much to rebuild them as it will to buy new ones, and the old ones will never be safe.
lead_paragraph: An officer of the Baltimore and Ohio Railroad states that their loss will reach two millions of dollars. abstract: The contest for the Speakership of the House, according to our Washington dispatches, is extremely animated. It lies apparently between Messrs. GROW, COLFAX and BLAIR, all of whom are eminently and perhaps equally qualified for the chair; but as only one can be chosen, the ardor of the competition at this late moment is a spectacle we regret sincerely to witness. Of one thing all the parties concerned may be well assured. The people will tolerate no protracted conflict upon the subject, such as has often postponed the business of legislation for weeks. The work this extra session is to do must be done with all the haste consistent with prudence; and whosoever permits personal ambition to impede the movement of business, will be paid in a most undesirable unpopularity; and the converse of the statement is equally true. There is no cheaper rate at which public gratitude can be bought, than by promptly withdrawing from a contest, which may otherwise be prolonged. Let us ask who of the gentlemen named for the place, will be first to make the sacrifice, and earn its reward?

abstract: Much curiosity has been expressed regarding the whereabouts of Hon. SHERRARD CLEMENS. At a review of the Seventeenth and Nineteenth Ohio Regiments in Wheeling, on the 18th, he made a short speech of great force, welcoming the soldiers in the most cordial terms, assuring them that they would be welcomed by every loyal heart in the State, while he was terribly severe on the Secessionists and people generally of the eastern part of the State. He said that part of the State, and the people, over there, were like the potato -- the best part under ground!

abstract: During the session in Philadelphia, a few weeks since, of the General Assembly of the Old School Presbyterian Church, it was proposed by the venerable Dr. SPRING, of New-York, that that body should
lead_paragraph: During the session in Philadelphia, a few weeks since, of the General Assembly of the Old School Presbyterian Church, it was proposed by the venerable Dr. SPRING, of New-York, that that body should make some formal declaration of sympathy with the National Government in its purpose to suppress the Southern rebellion. The question gave rise to a warm and protracted discussion, which ended with the passage of a series of patriotic resolutions, declaring it to be the religious duty of every member of the Church to sustain the Federal authorities, as ordained of God. Those who opposed this action, did so, professedly, on the ground that it would probably divide the Church, and we find that their prediction is already being verified. The Presbytery of Memphis, Tenn., have unanimously adopted an ordinance of secession from the General Assembly of the Old School Presbyterian Church of the United States, and it is said that the Presbyteries of the other rebel States will take action. In Virginia the following circular is being distributed among the Presbyterians, and is reported as rapidly obtaining signatures:

abstract: We anticipate the sneer with which such a proposition will be received by a department that still adheres to low steam, clumsy engines and other awfully old-fashioned things.
lead_paragraph: We anticipate the sneer with which such a proposition will be received by a department that still adheres to low steam, clumsy engines and other awfully old-fashioned things. We are aware that the public is saturated with the single idea that a shot will tear an iron plate all to pieces, while it will only make a round hole in wood, just as if that, supposing it true, were the only thing to be said about a war-ship, and the conclusion of the whole matter. Just so the public said about English railways -- that they cost a pound where American roads cost a dollar, and that this was the cause of their great comparative economy. It turned out, however, that this otherwise masterly conclusion had one defect -- it was not true; and so it will be with the present conclusions about iron for war-ships. By setting forth a few facts in the case, we shall expect to aid in removing the popular objections to iron hulls; official prejudice, we cannot hope to reach.

abstract: The Philadelphia Inquirer says: "We have good reason to believe that the report alleging that JEFFERSON DAVIS had submitted terms of compromise to President LINCOLN, originated in the fact, which is well authenticated, that Judge MASON, of Maryland, for himself and Ex-Gov. PRATT, applied to the Secretary of War a few days ago for authority to pass the lines of Government troops in Virginia to Richmond, for the purpose, as they alleged, of making an effort to open negotiations for peace. They asserted that the suggestion was their own exclusively, and that no other parties were in any way committed to it. Being known as strong Southern sympathisers, yet much esteemed as men of honor, the suggestion was courteously received by those to whom it was submitted. Still the Secretary refused to entertain it, because it might commit him to the enterprise, and therefore he refused to grant the gentlemen the passes they asked for. As we are informed, the scheme is not yet abandoned."
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Inquirer says: "We have good reason to believe that the report alleging that JEFFERSON DAVIS had submitted terms of compromise to President LINCOLN, originated in the fact, which is well authenticated, that Judge MASON, of Maryland, for himself and Ex-Gov. Still the Secretary refused to entertain it, because it might commit him to the enterprise, and therefore he refused to grant the gentlemen the passes they asked for. As we are informed, the scheme is not yet abandoned."

abstract: The San Francisco Herald of May 31 announces that orders have been received in San Francisco, from the War Department, for the organization of three regiments of volunteers for service in Texas. The troops, 5,000 in number, will be forwarded in steamers to Guaymas, and thence be transported, with the consent of the Mexican Government, across the State of Sonora to the Rio Grande. The object of the expedition is to recapture the forts which have been taken by the rebels, and also to strengthen any Union sentiment which may remain in Texas.
lead_paragraph: The San Francisco Herald of May 31 announces that orders have been received in San Francisco, from the War Department, for the organization of three regiments of volunteers for service in Texas. abstract: A new military department, entitled the Department of Illinois, has been gazetted, as was anticipated some time since. It with consist of the State of Illinois, and be commanded by Brig.-Gen. (late Caot. POPE,) of the regular Army, who, it will be remembered, was ordered for court martial by Mr. BUCHANAN'S Secretary of War.
lead_paragraph: A new military department, entitled the Department of Illinois, has been gazetted, as was anticipated some time since. It with consist of the State of Illinois, and be commanded by Brig.-Gen. (late Caot. POPE,) of the regular Army, who, it will be remembered, was ordered for court martial by Mr. BUCHANAN'S Secretary of War. As there is no doubt of the loyalty of Illinois, the new department has been given almost exclusively to officers and regiments of that State. The War Department has forwarded "the boundaries" to Gen. POPE.

abstract: One ANDREW PALMER, of North Goshen, Conn., raised a secession flag last week on his house. On Monday last some two hundred of the strong Union men of Goshen, Litchfield and Cornwall went to the house, took down and carried off the flag, and arrested five or six Secessionists, who were brought down to the village of Goshen, when they took the oath of allegiance, and were allowed to go free. There were some seven or eight Secessionists present, armed, who undertook to defend the flag of the enemy. Mr. PALMER swore to sustain the flag of the United States. One was put up on his house, which he swore to protect through all hazards.
lead_paragraph: One ANDREW PALMER, of North Goshen, Conn., raised a secession flag last week on his house. On Monday last some two hundred of the strong Union men of Goshen, Litchfield and Cornwall went to the house, took down and carried off the flag, and arrested five or six Secessionists, who were brought down to the village of Goshen, when they took the oath of allegiance, and were allowed to go free. There were some seven or eight Secessionists present, armed, who undertook to defend the flag of the enemy. Mr. PALMER swore to sustain the flag of the United States. One was put up on his house, which he swore to protect through all hazards.

abstract: If there were no other sufficient reason why the Government should persist in its ef forts to suppress the rebellion, that reason is furnished in the duty it owes to the Unionmen of the South.
lead_paragraph: If there were no other sufficient reason why the Government should persist in its ef forts to suppress the rebellion, that reason is furnished in the duty it owes to the Unionmen of the South. Like our revolutionary ancestors, there Southern patriots have staked "life, fortune and sacred honor" upon the issue of the struggle in which they are engaged. Their foes are the most revengeful, infuriate, and blood-thirsty that ever professed the name of Christian; and in intolerant ferocity, these fanatical propagandists of Slavery are only paralelled by the Saracen hordes which followed the banners of Islam in its missionary campaigns for the spread of religion by the Sword. Their hatred of Northern men, whom they regard as Abolitionists, is without bounds, but their detestation of Southern men who are for maintaining the Union, is, if possible, more intense, and the desire to punish them is felt in the same proportion. Men like ANDREW JOHNSTON and EMERSON ETHEREDGE, who have done so much to thwart the plans of the traitors, are no lees abhorred than GARRISON and PHILLIPS, and if caught by them their lives would be forfeited amid the brutal orgies of negro traders and overseers.
headline: {'main': 'A Duty to the Southern Union-men.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Duty to the Southern Union-men.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: OPENING OF MESSRS FREDERICKS' NEW PHOTOGRAPHIC GALLERY. Messrs. CHAS D. FREDRICKS  Co., who rank high among the fine photograph coperators of our City, have found it necessary to remove their premises to No. 587 Broadway, where, on Saturday evening, they threw open a suite of handsome rooms peculiarly fitted for their business.
lead_paragraph: OPENING OF MESSRS FREDERICKS' NEW PHOTOGRAPHIC GALLERY. -- Messrs. CHAS D. FREDRICKS Co., who rank high among the fine photograph coperators of our City, have found it necessary to remove their premises to No. 587 Broadway, where, on Saturday evening, they threw open a suite of handsome rooms peculiarly fitted for their business. The ground floor presents a fine arch to the street, 28 feet in height, and thence sweeps back 100 feet, forming a good gallery for the exhibition of photographic handiwork. The building consists of five stories, and is entirely occupied by Messrs. FREDERICKS, who give employment to thirty three operative artists, salesmen, &c. Being the newest gallery of the kind, it is probably the most convenient for the uses to which it is consecrated. There was a great crowd of invited guest, who expressed themselves delighted with what they saw.

abstract: Washington correspondents are notoriously  accustomed to eke out the meagre information they gather at the departments with conjectural wisdom exclusively their own.
lead_paragraph: Washington correspondents are notoriously accustomed to eke out the meagre information they gather at the departments with conjectural wisdom exclusively their own. To this supplementary talent is to be ascribed the various summaries given by our cotemporaries of the Executive Message to Congress and the reports which are to accompany it; the recommendations of Secretaries, and the measures to be introduced by chairmen of important committees. None of these reports, we venture to say, have the slightest foundation in ascertained fact; and yet their scope is so comprehensive, that it is scarcely possible all of them shall miss the mark. To Secretary CHASE, for example, financial schemes covering every possible method of raising ordinary and extraordinary revenue have been attributed. Treasury notes of various rates of interest; a popular loan; a foreign loan; have been mentioned as the resources to which he is prepared to appeal. To some of these resorts he will of course have to commit himself in his report; and the foresight of the correspondent will inevitably be justified. How can it be otherwise?

abstract: The New-Haven Palladium, of June 26, says: "On Tuesday night, the 18th, the steamer Traveller, plying between this city and New-York, had a little misunderstanding with the revenue cutter which is stationed at the mouth of the Sound, keeping watch of all vessels going in or out. It has been the usual custom for the cutter to hall the steamer, which slackened enough to give her name and destination, and then went on. But the night in question being moonlight, Capt. BOWNS concluded the cutter would recognize him, and went by at his usual speed. The cutter hailed in vain, then fired two blank shots. Still the Traveller pursued the even, tenor of its way. Then the cutter fired in earnest, the result being that a ball struck the steamer a little back of the wheel-house, passing within two feet of a man's head. It is a needless to say that the Traveller immediately came to."
lead_paragraph: The New-Haven Palladium, of June 26, says: "On Tuesday night, the 18th, the steamer Traveller, plying between this city and New-York, had a little misunderstanding with the revenue cutter which is stationed at the mouth of the Sound, keeping watch of all vessels going in or out. abstract: Notwithstanding all the recent statements to the contrary, it is now intimated in our Washington dispatches, that an immediate forward movement of our army in Virginia is probable so immediate, in fact, that the Fourth of July may be
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding all the recent statements to the contrary, it is now intimated in our Washington dispatches, that an immediate forward movement of our army in Virginia is probable so immediate, in fact, that the Fourth of July may be celebrated by driving in the rebel pickets, and clearing the country as far as Fairfax Court-house. Some ground for such a belief may perhaps be found in the fact that Gen. MCDOWELL is to be retained in command -- the statement that he was to be superseded by Gen. DIX being now authoritatively contradicted. Of the movements and intentions of BEAUREGARD and his rebel host, we receive various reports, the most recent of which was brought to Washington by a lady who escaped from Richmond after various vicissitudes. According to her statements, BEAUREGARD openly declares his intention to move towards Washington, and hopes yet to be able to obtain possession of it. His plan is to get as near the Arlington outposts as possible with his main force and to shell the city -- pushing his column on, meantime, to engage our forces, until he sees an opportunity to march upon the Capital with his reserve. This plan might undoubtedly be made to work, were it not for the fact that the Government has within call some seventy or eighty thousand well drilled troops to support a perfect cordon of artillery, which it will be necessary for the rebel forces to pass before they can hope to attain their end.

abstract: The Southern Press is more fierce, if possible, in denunciation of Northern Democracy than of Republicanism. It seems to have cherished the idea that the Democratic Party
lead_paragraph: The Southern Press is more fierce, if possible, in denunciation of Northern Democracy than of Republicanism. It seems to have cherished the idea that the Democratic Party was in favor of the treason of secession, and was ready to unite with the South in overthrowing the Constitution and destroying the Union. The City of New-York was largely Democratic, and the Southern Press and people counted on its earnest and cordial support. They expected to see the forts in the harbor seized, the arsenals plundered, the Sub-treasury dispoiled; that the secession bunting would float from the City Hall, and flaunt from the windows of Tammany and Mozart. There were three hundred thousand Democratic voters in the State, and they reckoned them as three hundred thousand Secessionists, who were as ready as themselves to hew away the pillars of the Republic and topple it into ruins. They could not conceive how a citizen could be loyal to the Union and yet be a Democrat. They could not understand bow he could oppose the success of the Republican Party before the election, and not be ready to take up arms against the Government administered by a Republican President afterwards. Professing to be Democrats themselves, they could not comprehend why treason should not be as cheap and common with Democracy at the North as at the South. Hence, when they opened their eves to the fact that Democracy on this side of Mason and Dixon's line was as true to the Constitution and faithful to the Union as was Republicanism itself, disappointment and mortification intensified their hatred towards those whom they foolishly regarded as their allies. They hate Republicans as their natural enemies, but they execrate and denounce Democrats as deserters from "Southern principles," which, in their rolly, they supposed them to have professed.
headline: {'main': 'Southern Denunciation of Northern Democracy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Southern Denunciation of Northern Democracy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: From one of the members of this corps, who left the camp at Alexandria on Thursday, invalided, we gather some particulars concerning their present condition and position, which have never been published, and which will doubtless be interesting to the many friends of the "lambs."
lead_paragraph: From one of the members of this corps, who left the camp at Alexandria on Thursday, invalided, we gather some particulars concerning their present condition and position, which have never been published, and which will doubtless be interesting to the many friends of the "lambs." On their arrival at Washington, at 8 1/2 P.M., they were formed and marched to the White House, where, after the formal presentation to the President, he passed through the lines, shaking hands with every member, but the general expression of feeling among the boys, was, that they would much prefer to have something to eat instead of such prolonged formalities, for it was 11 P.M. before they started for such quarters as could be had, and, after being turned away from three places, they were fortunate enough to find three others, where they were permitted to rest their weary lambs at 4 A.M.

abstract: THE CONEY ISLAND RAILROAD The first rails for the Coney Island Railroad, were laid on Waterstreet between Fulton and Main streets, last week, and it is expected that cars will be running over the entire route, within sixty days.
lead_paragraph: THE CONEY ISLAND RAILROAD -- The first rails for the Coney Island Railroad, were laid on Water-street between Fulton and Main streets, last week, and it is expected that cars will be running over the entire route, within sixty days. This route is ten miles and one-fourth in length. It commences at Fulton Ferry, passing through Water, Main, York, Prospect, Jay, South, Ninth streets, Tenth avenue to Fifteenth-street, and thence to Coney Island by the way or the Park Road. A double-track will be laid to the city limits, on Fifteenth street, and beyond that point, a single track with turn outs. T.B. WATSON & Co., of Springfield, are now manufacturing the cars for this road. They will be hatched in the best style, and replete with every convenience. When the road is in operation, a car will have Fulton Ferry every seven minutes. The fare to the city line will be five cents, and to Coney Island twenty cents. The President of this company, is D.M. TALMAGE, and Secretary, G.P. REAGAN; the latter is will known by his long connection with the Long Island and Central Railroad Companies.

abstract: A correspondent of the Atlantic (Ga.) Confederacy, gives an intersting account of the contemplated work which lies before Gen. WISE in Northwest Virginia. According to this correspondent, who writes from Richmond on the 10th inst., Gen. WISE
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Atlantic (Ga.) Confederacy, gives an intersting account of the contemplated work which lies before Gen. WISE in Northwest Virginia. According to this correspondent, who writes from Richmond on the 10th inst., Gen. WISE expected to start for the Northwest on the 11th inst., by which time 4,000 men would have been transported by railroad, to Staunton, where he would be joined by several additional regiments, which would swell his army to 10,000 men. From Staunton the General is to proceed on foot, a distance of 100 miles, over a rough turnpike up the Alleghany Mountains. The march will be a laborious one, but the dauntless blood and heroic energy of WISE will overleap all obstacles, and land him in the very midst of his foes.

abstract: Much dissatisfaction prevails amongst military men at the open manner in which the troops, who happen to be quartered at the Park Barracks, are supplied with alcoholic drinks, and the question arises who is responsible for this traffic?
lead_paragraph: Much dissatisfaction prevails amongst military men at the open manner in which the troops, who happen to be quartered at the Park Barracks, are supplied with alcoholic drinks, and the question arises who is responsible for this traffic? We are informed that the contractors Messrs. WRIGHT, NOARIS and BAKER have nothing to do with it, and witness with regret the scenes of intoxication which are now of daily occurrence. The various regiments which are constantly passing through our City, generally take some kind of refreshment at the Park Barracks, and are allowed to rest there for two or three hours before proceeding on their route. Since the bar-room was established, this necessary respite has been turned into a perfectorgy. The men who almost always have some loose change in their pockets, and are not at all unwilling to have a little spree in the Metropolis before leasing for a nights dusty travel crowd the nasty shanty where the raw and lager beer is kept, and quickly dispose of their loose change in exchange for a fevered train and unrest. Yesterday the bar was to full operation -- notwithstanding the Sunday laws. The object of a Barracs is to supply the men with all they need and to protect them especially from the temptation of drinking shops. We trust that Gen. ARTHUR will see to this matter. It is becoming too great a scandal to be longer tolerated.

abstract: Every one  remembers the terrible telegram sent from JEFF. DAVIS' head-quarters about the time that he issued his freebooting proclamation, which announced that there were three hundred...
lead_paragraph: Every one remembers the terrible telegram sent from JEFF. DAVIS' head-quarters about the time that he issued his freebooting proclamation, which announced that there were three hundred thousand applications for letters-of-marque on file in Montgomery, and that the buccaneers were even then waiting with sails set and anchors hoisted, all ready to go aspirating on the high seas. Some skeptical individuals thought at the time that there must be a mistake in the figures, and that three thousand was probably the number intended; while others boldly divided the figures of the gasconading rebels by a thousand, and put down three hundred as still more likely to approximate the truth. But a fleet of even three hundred piratical craft, or even a tenth part of that, well armed and manned by such crews as the blood-and-thunder pirate novels tell about, was sufficiently formidable; and the thought of such a horde of roystering desperadoes, reveling in blood and booty on the old fields of buccaneer exploit in the Gulf of Mexico, doubtless made many a shipowner and importer tremble for their property, and gave a shudder to many a mother and sweetheart, whose bold sailor-boy might perchance be voyaging faraway to India, China or California.

abstract: The Eleventh Regiment of Massachusetts, known letter throughout the Old Bay State as the "Glorious Eleventh." arrived in this City yesterday morning in route for Washington, and after a brilliant reception and dinner went on their marital journey. The regiment commenced recruiting in
lead_paragraph: The Eleventh Regiment of Massachusetts, known letter throughout the Old Bay State as the "Glorious Eleventh." arrived in this City yesterday morning in route for Washington, and after a brilliant reception and dinner went on their marital journey. The regiment commenced recruiting in April last, was mustered into the State service May 7, and into the United States service for the war on the 23d inst. They have been for the last two weeks encamped at Camp Cameron, and are excellently drilled. They have 950 men uniformed in gray trimmed with red, and armed with the smooth bore new pattern Springfield musket. They have 25 ambulance and Company wagons, eighty horses, sixty French tents, forty wall tents, and full camp equipage. On their departure from Boston, they were presented with an elegant flag by Mrs. Capt. C.H. SANDFORD, and other friends of the regiment presented $5,000 and a set of regimental colors. Lieut.-Col. BLAISDELL was presented with a revolver, as was also Major GEO. F. TILESTON, who was formerly of the reportorial staff of the Boston Herald, and received hi six shooter as a testimonial of the good-will of his brother knights of the quill. The following is a full list of officers: Colonel, GEORGE CLARK, Jr.; Lieutenant-Colonel, WM. BLAISDELL; Major, GEN. F. TILESTON; Adjutant, BROWNELL GRANGER; Quartermaster, J.F. abstract: The Arkansas Convention, during the late session, adopted an ordinance to provide revenue for the State, wherein, among other things, it is provided that two millions of dollars in bonds shall be issued, in sums of five dollars and upwards. To redeem these, the public lands of the State, of which there are at least seventeen millions of acres, as well as the taxes of the State, are pledged. This secures them, in the opinion of the Louisville Courier, from any future repudiation or even control by the Legislature. These bonds will be receivable in payment for lands (and in part payment for taxes.) The coupons will be wholly receivable for taxes, and a sufficient amount of specie is, and always will be, reserved to meet the interest and redeem the coupons.

abstract: Brigadier-General PIERCE, says the Boston Journal, has made some valuable additions to his staff. One is ALBERTO C. MAGGI, of New-Bedford, who was educated in the Italian Military Academy, and was one of GARIBALDI's staff. The other is Capt. WILLIAM VON DOEHN, from the New-York Twentieth Regiment, who was educated in the Prussian military service, and has served ten years in the army, though be is now but 28 years of age.

abstract: Special attention is drawn by Mr. RUSSELL, the correspondent of the London Times, to the bewildering variety of costume worn by the rebel troops beleaguering Fort Pickens,
lead_paragraph: Special attention is drawn by Mr. RUSSELL, the correspondent of the London Times, to the bewildering variety of costume worn by the rebel troops beleaguering Fort Pickens, and the fatal accidents likely to accrue in consequence, amid the confusion of a general action. The army we have sent to suppress Southern insurrection is clothed with similar disregard to the vital importance of quick and ready recognition of each other by different parts of a large force, which may be brought in contact whilst moving from detached points towards some central position. How, for instance, can men from Maine or Ohio, when they come suddenly upon the Duryee Zouaves, fell whether they are New-York friends or New-Orleans foes? What, in the eyes of an Indiana rifleman is to distinguish a gaily decked chasseur of this City from his similarly accoutred Virginian prototype? How shall the Western horseman know whether it is a Massachusetts or a South Carolina company of neutral tint that he is riding down? In the existing confusion of clothes, no amount of precautionary instruction can prevent the most disastrous errors of this kind from taking place. Such errors, in the best regulated armies, cannot always be avoided; but, by a very simple arrangement, they may be eliminated from any ordinary list of military casualties.

abstract: In the matter of the habeas corpus for the relief of Frederick S. Littlejohn. -- This writ of habeas corpus seems to be somewhat shrouded with mystery. It is pretty certain that the relator, who is a brother of Ex-Speaker Littlejohn, now Consul at Liverpool, was on Friday last arrested in this City on the change of an attempt to bribe an officer of the Legislature. It is alto certain that Mr. Justice MULLIN issued a writ of habeas corpus for his relief, but where the writ is returnable is not known. The law requires that notice of the return of any writ of habeas corpus in this County shall be served on the District Attorney. That officer, however, has received no such notice, and knows nothing of the matter whatever. After diligent search and inquiry at the place where the writ is to be returned, the fact whether it is or has been returned is not ascertained.

abstract: DEAR UNCLE JOE: My duties here prevent me from coming to Virginia, to make knowm in person my wishes to the Governor; so, departing from my custom, I have to ask that you give the same your personal attention. abstract: For several days previous to the 19th last, the people of Cumberland had been quite reverish in conrequence of repeated rumors that a force of frow three thousand to five thousand Southern troops were in Romney, and intended to burn the bridges at New Creek, and then march upon Cumberland to attack it.
lead_paragraph: For several days previous to the 19th last, the people of Cumberland had been quite reverish in conrequence of repeated rumors that a force of frow three thousand to five thousand Southern troops were in Romney, and intended to burn the bridges at New Creek, and then march upon Cumberland to attack it. On the previous evening, special messengers arrived in the train confirming the worst reports, reporting that heavy forces were then on their march for the bridge, and would arrive some time in the night. The excitement was immediately on the increase, and the night wore away anxiously and fearfully with many. At between 5 and 6 o'clock in the morning, a train arrived from the bridge, reporting all safe, and no enemy heard of.

abstract: The Superintendent of the American Telegraph Company, in Boston, has been experimenting in night telegraphing by means of calcium lights. By the interposition of a thin piece of metal, placed in front of the lens of the apparatus for producing the light, it is made to flicker or is entirely shut off. The variations correspond with the different motions by which telegraphic characters are made. The operators at either end can comprehend what is intended to be communicated as readily as they can read a message by the clicking of the telegraph. With the aperture reduced to an eighth of an inch, the light was distinctly seen at Hull from Boston.
lead_paragraph: The Superintendent of the American Telegraph Company, in Boston, has been experimenting in night telegraphing by means of calcium lights. abstract: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRS. WINSLOW? we will simply say that she is a lady who, for upwards of 39 years, has untiringly devoted her time and talents as a female physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, so generally overlooked or carelessly treated by the faculty in too many instances; and, as a result of this effort, and practical knowledge obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health, and is, moreover, cure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article, Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children do certainly RISE UP and bless her; especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grave by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn will share its benefits and unite in calling her blessed. No MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it, mothers -- TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: The remains of the late Commander WARD arrived here from Washington on Sunday evening, in the custody of Capt. RINGGOLD and seven marines from the steamer Freeborn. They were conveyed to the...
lead_paragraph: The remains of the late Commander WARD arrived here from Washington on Sunday evening, in the custody of Capt. RINGGOLD and seven marines from the steamer Freeborn. They were conveyed to the Navy-yard, where they reposed in state on board the North Carolina, late his post of command. Under the direction of Capt. MEAD, who succeeds Capt. WARD, the poop deck was neatly fitted up for the reception of the body. The sides of the awning which inclosed the deck were draped with American flags. A cross of red bunting was hung at the head of the coffin, with colors covered with crape; wax tapers burned at the head and foot of the coffin, on which rested the sword, chapeau and coat of deceased. A beautiful cross, formed of flowers rested upon the lid of the coffin, and on an open vase was a wreath of white flowers, grouped by Mrs. Captain MEAD. The plate, in form of a cross, bore the following inscription:

abstract: We are about to send a small army to Canada. This is just one of those steps upon which it is most difficult to pronounce an opinion, because we cannot suppose we have all the facts before us. In the present disturbed state of America...
lead_paragraph: We are about to send a small army to Canada. This is just one of those steps upon which it is most difficult to pronounce an opinion, because we cannot suppose we have all the facts before us. In the present disturbed state of America reasons may exist for such a step which we cannot even guess, and we therefore approach the subject with hesitation and uncertainty. We do not deny that there may be excellent reasons for sending 3,000 men to Canada which we do not know; but we certainly can point to no reasons arising out of the existing state of things, so far as we are acquainted with them, which would lead us to such a conclusion. There is no doubt that America is in arms from the St. Lawrence to the Gulf of Mexico; that the authority of the State and National Executive, never very strong, is shaken, and in many places suspended; that the passtons of a Democracy which can ill brook the slightest contradiction have been stung almost to frenzy by open revolt, and that for some unknown reason it has pleased the Northern States to empty all the vials of their wrath on the English nation It is also certain that, in accordance with their habit of blustering against an unoffending neighbor, England is threatened with undying hatred and condign punishment, because, in obedience to the first law of humanity and justice, we have declined to treat the people of the Southern States, carrying on war with the people of the Northern States, as pirates. This, according to the headlong logic of Democracy, is equivalent to a recognition of their independence, and although the Northern States themselves must be compelled in a very few weeks to make this very same admission. It is an offence never to be forgotten or forgiven. We are, besides, fully aware that Canada has a long and a very vulnerable frontier, and that threats have been uttered which point not obscurely to an invasion, not of sympathizers, as in 1837, but of free and enlightened citizens, who would come to punish us for not sufficiently sympathizing in their internal brawls. Nor are we ignorant that it is an old and often-tried policy in America to seek to heal internal discord by exciting popular hatred against England. In Canada itself affairs are by no means satisfactory. The relations between the English majority and the French minority cannot long continue as they are. Public confidence is shaken by the ill-success of the Grand Trunk Railway, by the vast amount of debt accumulated for municipal purposes, or, as it is said, in order to bribe majorities, and by the return to the antiquated practices of Protection. In all these things, the force of which we by no means wish to extenuate, many may see a sufficient justification for the despatch of 3,000 men to Canada, but, for our part, if there are no better reasons than these, we regret that the step has been taken.

abstract: We arrived here on the 26th of May, from Pensa- cola, to blockade this Pass. On the 28th we captured a bark called the H.E. Spearing, from Rio Janeiro, loaded with 4,625 bags coffee, and sent her to Key West,...
lead_paragraph: We arrived here on the 26th of May, from Pensa- cola, to blockade this Pass. On the 28th we captured a bark called the H.E. Spearing, from Rio Janeiro, loaded with 4,625 bags coffee, and sent her to Key West, in charge of our Boatswain and one Midshipman, and nine of our crew. We have news from New-Orleans to-day. The English, French and Bremen Consuls were on board. New-Orleans is in a dreadful state; no business whatever is going on. The National Government has stopped all provisions from coming down the river, and the people along the lower part of the river are in a state of starvation. The saucy Brooklyn is the only ship here, and we don't care for all the secession army and navy. The Powhatan is blockading the Southwest Pass, about 60 miles from here, and nothing can go in there or here on any consideration. We let some ships go to sea, and there are some eight or ten on the Bar, fast in the mud, cotton loaded, which can go away as soon as they can get off.

abstract: There is much very foolish discussion of the right of petition in connection with the seizure of a paper circulating in the City, demanding a peaceable dissolution of the Government. The Superintendent of Police, moved by representations that the document was obtaining signatures upon a false statement of its purport, caused a copy to be seized; and a reference of the matter to the signers proves that a very large proportion had given their names in entire ignorance of the contents. It is highly probable that when the list has thus been purged of names which have no business there, Mr. FREDERICK GUION will be permitted to recover his paper, and proceed in the obviously slow business of collecting names. It is well, in the meantime, to have it understood that it is not the right of petition these persons are clamoring for; but the right to petition for unconstitutional, detestable, and unjustifiable objects, without incurring the publicity and consequent infamy their enterprise merits.

abstract: Having passed several sleepless nights, disturbed by the agonies and cries of a suffering child, and becoming convinced that Mrs. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply for the child. On reaching home and acquainting his wife with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Homoeopathy. That night the child passed in suffering, and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following, the father found the baby still worse, and, while contemplating, another sleepless night the mother stepped from the room to attend to some domestic duties, and left the father with the child. During her absence he administered a portion of the SOOTHING SYRUP to the baby, and said nothing. That night all hands slept well and the little fellow awake in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delightedwith the sudden and wonderful change, and although at first offended at the deception practiced upon her, has continued to use the Syrup, and suffering, crying babies and [???] nights have disappeared. A single trial of the Syrup never yet failed to relieve the baby, and overcome the prejudices of the mother.

abstract: The steamer Champion, of the Vanderbilt line, sailed for Aspinwall yesterday with 400 passengers and a very heavy California freight, among which was a large quantity of butter. In order to be ready for the pirates, the steamer will give a wide berth to all suspicious vessels, and in case of close work has two Dahlgren six-pounders and about 200 small arms, which will serve to do some defensive duty. The Engineer's department might also assist in scalding some of the pirates under favorable circumstances, so considering all things the crew feel quite confident of arriving safely with the ship, passengers and cargo. As to the rumor that a number of rebels had conspired to take passage and seize the ship at the first opportunity, that will be prevented by due caution as to allowing passengers to carry arms, or to hold suspicious conferences. The Commodore has no idea of furnishing ships to the rebels gratis.

abstract: The London Saturday Review is one of the most vehement of the British assailants of the Government of the United States.
lead_paragraph: The London Saturday Review is one of the most vehement of the British assailants of the Government of the United States. It evinces a delightful rancor, -- an intense and unmistakable hatred, in all its comments on the efforts of our Government to crush rebellion, which leaves no room to doubt the sincerity of its sympathy with the Slave-trading conspiracy which has taken up arms against us. Its issue of the 8th of June devotes three articles to the service of the Confederates; -- one of which discusses the subject of Privateering, from the point of view which an active, unscrupulous agent of JEFF. DAVIS might be expected to take. Its text is the dispatch of Mr. SEWARD, announcing the adhesion of our Government to the abolition of privateering decreed by the European Powers at the Conference of Paris; and the drift of its article is, first, to show that this adhesion will not be of the slightest validity against the South; and second, that it will be of the utmost value to England against the Government of the United States. Its argument is worthy of attention.

abstract: Preparations for the great movement which is expected soon to take place in Virginia, are steadily progressing at Washington.
lead_paragraph: Preparations for the great movement which is expected soon to take place in Virginia, are steadily progressing at Washington. Troops continue to arrive by thousands, and the grand army across the Potomac is swelled proportionably. The great desideratum now appears to be means of transportation adequate to the wants of the greatest body of men which has ever been collected on this Continent, and this want is being rapidly supplied. By the time Congress is ready to legislate for the army, the army will be ready to move for the nation.

abstract: A number of gentlemen interested in the suppression of the African Slave-trade met on Saturday at the residence of Lord BROUGHAM, in Grafton-street, for the purpose of taking into consideration the present state of the African Slave-trade to Cuba, and conferring as to what measures for its suppression might be suggested to her Majesty's Government. The Conference was summoned by the Committee of the British and Foreign Anti-Slavery Society, and amongst those who attended were Lord Brougham, Lord Stratheden, Mr. Briscoe, M.P.; Mr. S. Gurney, M.P.; Mr. C. Buxton, M.P., Mr. W.E. Forster, M.P., Mr. E. Baines, M.P., Mr. Consul Gabriel, Mr. Consul Hanson, Dr. Hodgkin, Dr. Norton Shaw, Rev. J. Burnett, Rev. Dr. Campbell, Rev. Dr. Carlisle, Rev. H. Richard, Mr. F. Buxton. Mr. R. Alsop, &c. Letters of apology for unavoidable absence, but expressing sympathy with the object of the meeting, were mentioned as having been received from the Bishop of Oxford, the Bishop of St. Asaph, Lord Stanley, M.P., Viscount Enfield, M.P., Hon. A. Kinnaird, M.P., Mr. C. Gilpin, M.P., Mr. Hanbury, M.P., Mr. Kershaw, M.P., Mr. W. Ewart, M.P., and others. Mr. Dhameroozow, the Secretary, read a statement compiled from various official sources, showing the present state of the African Slave trade, which it was averred was now attributable entirely to the demand for slaves for the Cuban market, the cost of the suppressive measures adopted by Great Britain, and the effect of commerce, protected by consular appointments, upon slave traffic generally. A long and interesting discussion followed, in which Lord STRATHEDEN and Mr. BUXTON intimated that they, intended simultaneously to move in both Houses of Parliament for a restoration of the consularship of Mozambique. Various suggestions were made, as to the course which it is desirable for Her Majesty's Government to pursue in reference to the Cuban trade, and ultimately a series of resolutions were adopted, strongly condemnatory of the conduct of Spain in violating her slave-trade treaty obligations, recommending the suspension of diplomatic intercourse with her till she abolished the Slave trade, and calling upon the British Government to reestablish the consularship at Mozambique and other places on the coast of Africa for the encouragement and protection of native commerce. The resolutions also referred to the Washington treaty, by which the United States Government is bound to unite with Britain "in all becoming representations and remonstrances with any and all Powers within whose dominions slave markets are allowed to exist," and expressed the opinion that a convenient opportunity should be taken to obtain the cooperation of the United States for that purpose. It was stated that a deputation would shortly wait upon Lords PALMERSTON and RUSSEEL with a copy of there resolutions. A vote of thanks to Lord BROUGHAM terminated the proceedings.

abstract: "Progress is stronger than we are," was the reply of an eminent European statesman to certain timid people, who demanded a change of his policy for fear of its results upon the financial condition of the country.
lead_paragraph: "Progress is stronger than we are," was the reply of an eminent European statesman to certain timid people, who demanded a change of his policy for fear of its results upon the financial condition of the country. It furnishes a capital answer to the timid people of the present day, who talk of compromise and demand peace. This war is emphatically a war of progress, the elements of which have been at work for more than a third of a century, and there is but one condition on which it can be terminated. The statesmen of the last generation saw its shadow on the horizon; and while they hoped for a peaceful solution of the dangers looming on their vision, yet that a revolution of some kind was inevitable they never for a moment doubted. They saw how the Southern States by their solidarity, by making their peculiar institutions a bond of political union, wielded the power and shaped the policy of the Government, and they saw how restive the Northern millions were under their domination. They calculated the time when the constantly increasing numbers in the Free States, asserting the might vested in majorities, would seize the reins of Government and control its action with reference to what they regarded the great interests of civilization and the best good of the whole country, rather than with reference to the institutions and special interests of the South. They saw that the time would come when twenty millions of people in the Free States would refuse to submit to the dictation of eight millions in the Slave States, and that the passing of political power from one to the other, would be likely to be attended by convulsions such as had never been known in the history of this country. They postponed the evil days by temporary concessions, by compromises, in the permanency of which they had little faith, and which they felt certain would some day be powerless to defer the crisis which they saw impending. They noted the increasing arrogance of the South consequent upon the possession of power, and foresaw how deep its humiliation would be when the great constitutional principle which grants to majorities the right to govern, should remove the sceptre from its hand. They hoped that that principle would be respected, and that the minority would yield to an inevitable destiny; but in the character and temper of that minority they saw the possible germs of upheaval and rebellion against the Union. They saw that the pernicious doctrine of nullification was ripening into secession, and that a reckless ambition might seize upon it as a pretext for revolt, giving to treason towards the Constitution and the Union a semblance of patriotism under the guise of loyalty to the State.

abstract: The remains of the late Commander WARD arrived here from Washington on Sunday evening, in the custody of Capt. RINGGOLD and seven marines from the steamer Freeborn.
lead_paragraph: The remains of the late Commander WARD arrived here from Washington on Sunday evening, in the custody of Capt. RINGGOLD and seven marines from the steamer Freeborn. They were conveyed to the Navy-yard, where they reposed in stats en board the North Carolina, late his post of command. Under the direction of Capt. MEAD, who succeeds Capt. WARD, the poop deck was neatly fitted up for the reception of the body. The sides of the awning which inclosed the deck were draped with American flags, A cross of red bunting was hung at the head of the coffin, with colors covered with crape; wnx tapers burned at the head and foot of the coffin, on which rested the sword, chapeau and coat of deceased. A beautiful, cross, formed of flowers rented upon the lid of the coffin, and on an open case was a wreath of white flowers, grouped by Mrs. Captain MEAD. abstract: We arrived here on the 26th of May, from Pensacola, to blockade this Pass. On the 28th we captured a back called the H.E. Spearing, from Rio Janeiro, loaded with 4,625 bags coffee, and sent her to Key West,...
lead_paragraph: We arrived here on the 26th of May, from Pensacola, to blockade this Pass. On the 28th we captured a back called the H.E. Spearing, from Rio Janeiro, loaded with 4,625 bags coffee, and sent her to Key West, in charge of our Boatswain and one Midshipman, and nine of our crew. We have news from New-Orleans to-day. The English, French and Bremen Consuls were on board. New-Orleans is in a dreadful state; no business whatever is going on. The National Government has stopped all provisions from coming down the river, and the people along the lower part of the river are in a state of starvation. The saucy Brooklyn is the only ship here, and we don't care for all the secession army and navy. The Powhatan is blockading the Southwest Pass, about 60 miles from here, and nothing can go in there or here on any consideration. We let some ships go to sea, and there are some eight or ten on the Bar, fast in the mud, cotton, loaded, which can go away as soon as they can get off.

abstract: Com   plaints from the neighborhood of Fortress Monroe, of depredations committed by our troops upon private property, have been so...
lead_paragraph: -- Complaints from the neighborhood of Fortress Monroe, of depredations committed by our troops upon private property, have been so numerous, and apparently so well authenticated, that it is scarcely possible to doubt their accuracy. These complaints charge more than mere depredation upon private property. They embrace personal outrages, which disgrace the loyal army, and dishonor civilized warfare. We know how difficult it is to prevent entirely this kind of wrong, but every effort should be made to do so. There are legitimate horrors enough attending war in its most humane aspects, without adding to them those of unauthorized outrage or private plunder.

abstract: In his last letter in the Dublin Catholic Telegraph, the Rev. Doctor writes: "It is a singular sight to me, an Irishman born and educated under the penal laws and the oppressive Government of England, to look at the embodiment of the several volunteer...
lead_paragraph: In his last letter in the Dublin Catholic Telegraph, the Rev. Doctor writes: "It is a singular sight to me, an Irishman born and educated under the penal laws and the oppressive Government of England, to look at the embodiment of the several volunteer corps of this country. Thousands of young fellows meet in companies, select their captains, and form a regiment, in fact, in the week. The greatest rivalship is evinced to see who can be the first in the new corps; and those are wretched who come too late when the number is filled up, and when they cannot be received in a favorite regimen. An enthusiasm which cannot be understood in a monarchical Government seizes on an entire city when the drums beat for volunteer recruits; when accomplished officers are selected; and when a proper Colonel is named for the command. The bands, the uniforms, the polished arms, the gallant companions, the orderly march under bristling steel, awaken an involuntary feeling like an electric shock; and set thousands of men half mad for the coming fight. All classes seem wild withpatriotism, with liberty, and with the glorious love of their own free country. Tailors fling away the lapboard;shoemakers leave aside the last; carpenters lock up the ruler and the compasses; clerks abandon their desk; and the whole town seems to forget everything except the rifle, the sword, and the battle, for their own Constitution and their own soil!

abstract: Last evening, about 8 o'clock, a very sad occurrence happened in West Fifteenth-street, resulting in the murder of JOHN P. MCAUSLAND, a lad 13 years of age, by THOMAS J. RODEN, a youth two years his junior. The boys had been playing together at No. 112 West Fifteenth-street, when a dispute arose with reference to their game. As the quarrel progressed, RODEN became very much enraged, and finally drew his pocket knife, which be thrust into his companion's breast. The blade penetrated the lad's heart, and he fell dead almost in a second. Officer JEWETT, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, took RODEN into custody, and MCAUSLAND'L remains were carried to the residence of his parents, No. 113 West Fifteenth-street. The parents of both boys are respectable.

abstract: The time has passed  for fine writing and fine speeches in discussing abstract ideas upon questions of Government; we are now dealing with stern realities, and the people expect their rulers to deal
lead_paragraph: The time has passed for fine writing and fine speeches in discussing abstract ideas upon questions of Government; we are now dealing with stern realities, and the people expect their rulers to deal with them in a manner worthy of a young and energetic nation. The masses are terribly in earnest, and will tolerate no temporizing policy. Their patience has already been severely tried in this respect, and it will be a dangerous experiment for politicians to experiment too far. It must be remembered that it was the last straw that broke the camel's back. The hour for compromising is gone -- no patched-up peace will be accepted by the people of this country, no matter how much it may please the cotton-spinners of England. Our people want the question of secession this time definitely settled, settled beyond the contingency of any future hair-splitting or metaphysical speculation. Its advocates have chosen the mode by which they wish to settle it, and as they have selected the sword, and appealed to the God of Battles, let the prayer of the patriot Minister of old, of "Oh, Lord, if our enemies will fight us, let them have fighting enough," be answered. The industry of the people of the United States is of rather too much importance to have it periodically disturbed by the freaks of a class of Southern chivalry who neither toil nor spin.

abstract: -- A lithographic likeness of Col. ELMER E. ELLSWORTH, dedicated to the firemen of New-York, which in accuracy and finish surpasses any representation of the youthful hero we have yet seen, has just been published by Mr. C.Q. COLTON. The engraving, which is from a photograph taken just before Col. ELLSWORTH left the City with his regiment, was executed by CROW, THOMAS & Co., No. 37 Park-place. As a superior specimen of lithography, it is worthy of a place among the best collections of the art, and as a life-like picture of the lamented Colonel, it will be especially prized by those who intimately knew him.

abstract: The proceedings of the Union Convention of East Tennessee wilL be found in another column of the TIMES. It will be seen that every County but one was represented, and the deliberations were harmonious.
lead_paragraph: The proceedings of the Union Convention of East Tennessee wilL be found in another column of the TIMES. It will be seen that every County but one was represented, and the deliberations were harmonious. The Unionists of East Tennessee have adopted a course, marked at once by prudence and the utmost fairness towards the rest of the State. They ask that East Tennessee may be allowed peaceably to "secede" from the Middle and Western divisions that have voted by such heavy majorities to join JEFF. DAVIS' Confederacy.

abstract: Correspondents with California and Oregon should remember that the mails to the Pacific, via the ocean steamers, ceased absolutely on the 30th June; and that all letters destined for those States, or for Washington or Nevada Territories, go henceforth overland from St. Joseph, Mo., every day in the week, except Sundays. Many persons dropped their letters in the Post-office, yesterday, evidently supposing that they would be forwarded by steamer. They should know that all these have been sent via St. Joseph. The Pony Express rates, via Overland route, from and after this date, are reduced to only one dollar per half ounce, with the ten cents United States postage added.
lead_paragraph: Correspondents with California and Oregon should remember that the mails to the Pacific, via the ocean steamers, ceased absolutely on the 30th June; and that all letters destined for those States, or for Washington or Nevada Territories, go henceforth overland from St. Joseph, Mo., every day in the week, except Sundays. abstract: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRS. WINSLOW? we will simply say that she is a lady who, for upwards of 30 years, has untiringly devoted her time and talents as a female physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, so generally overlooked or carelessly treated by the faculty in too many instances: and, as a result of this effort, and practinal knowledge obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this-article, Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children do certainly RISE UP and bless her especially is this the case in this City, Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grave by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn will share its benefits and unite in calling her blessed: No MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, is our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it, mothers -- TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: We have at last received some definite information relative to the movements and intentions of Gen. PATTERSON and that portion of the Grand Army under his command.
lead_paragraph: We have at last received some definite information relative to the movements and intentions of Gen. PATTERSON and that portion of the Grand Army under his command. The whole column, embracing eighteen full regiments and several detached corps of cavalry and artillery, is under orders to march at three o'clock this morning, and to-day this large body of men will cross the Potomac, and probably stay on the Virginia side. Ten days' rations are to be taken in bulk. Everything was in readiness for crossing yesterday, but the intention was abandoned until to-day, on account of a difficulty in fording at the point selected. The rebels are reported to be erecting earthworks and planting cannon to obstruct the advance of our troops, and sharp work is expected before the Fourth passes, unless the rebel forces retreat. Shots were exchanged yesterday at Sheppard's Ford, but with what result is not known.

abstract: As has already been announced, Mr. EVERETT will deliver an oration on "The Great [???] now before the Country," at the Academy of Music, on the afternoon of the Fourth of July, commencing at 2 o'clock, the doors being opened at 1. It will be a great treat to all who gain admission. Mr. EVERETT devotes the entire net proceeds to the relief of the families of the New-York Volunteers. This fact alone should induce thousands to attend. Rev. Dr. SPRING, a choir from the Institution for the Blind, and the Band of the Seventh Regiment, will take part in the exercises. The scope and purport of the oration of Mr. EVERETT may be gathered from the following passage in his letter accepting the invitation of the Committee: "The Anniversary of the great Declaration would certainly be an appropriate occasion, for an attempt to vindicate the principles, now so formidably assailed, in which the Inpendence of the United States as [???] PEOPLE was originally asserted." There most be thousands in New-York who have not yet given anything to aid the volunteers, and who would gladly give the small sum which this oration calls for. Such have now the opportunity. The advertisement, which will be found in our columns, gives full particulars of the proposed exercises.

abstract: The most frequent argument that is used against the prosecution of war by the National Government for the suppression of rebellion in the Southern States is, that it is
lead_paragraph: The most frequent argument that is used against the prosecution of war by the National Government for the suppression of rebellion in the Southern States is, that it is wrong to compel a people to live in alliance with us when their hearts are so alienated that the Union cannot be cordial or fraternal. The continuance of political relations under circumstances of force on one side and inability to resist on the other, it is held, is incompatible with the theory of Republican institutions. Republican government becomes merely military despotism.

abstract: The Richmond (Va.) Examiner of the 29th ult., says that "an agent of the French Government is buying tobacco in that market." Nothing more likely. It is cheap now, for Virginians can do nothing with it. But "commerce follows the flag," and the first thing done by President LINCOLN, after Gen. SCOTT and the Grand Army reach Richmond a month hence, will be to raise the blockade of all the Virginia ports; and the "French Government" will ship its tobacco freely -- making a prodigious good thing out of the verdant Virginians. Let the Examiner put this in its pipe and smoke it.

abstract: A great step has been made toward securing well-cooked and digestible food for the volunteer regiments. At the earnest request of the United States Sanitary Commission, Gov. MORGAN has authorized the engagement of Mr. JAMES M. SANDERSON to take charge, experimentally, of the cooking department of one or two regiments at Washington, and Mr. SANDERSON has already entered on his duties, taking with him a couple of experienced assistants. Should this experiment succeed, the Sanitary Commission will probably employ Mr. SANDERSON permanently, to go through all the camps, and organize in each a system by which a supply of wholesome food can be secured. This is an important movement in the right direction, and we trust that the Commission will be enabled, by public liberality, to carry out to the fullest extent this and other much needed measures of sanitary reform.

abstract: Yesterday (Monday) afternoon, a riot occurred at the foot of Weehawken hill, on the road leading to Hackensack, between a number of quarrymen and a man named MICHAEL ROACH, keeper of a low grogshep, in which two of the quarrymen were shot, (one tatally,) and a woman was so badly beaten that it is thought that she will not recover.

abstract: It is idle to attempt a suppression of the fact that the public universally regards the administration of the War Department as surrounded with corrupt influences.
lead_paragraph: It is idle to attempt a suppression of the fact that the public universally regards the administration of the War Department as surrounded with corrupt influences. Contracts have notoriously been made in disregard of all the usual dictates of prudence and economy. Transports have been hired at monthly rates double the entire value of the vessels; arms and munitions have been bought at prices which only cease to seem excessive when we learn that one-fourth the cost passed into the pocket of the purchasing agent; the most worthless of trash has been received from favorites and paid for as if fully up to contract requirements; and in every transaction connected with our war-like preparations of the Government there has been the taint of peculation and dishonesty. For these phenomena, the Chief of the War Department is popularly regarded as responsible, and, at all events, upon him will rest the responsibility of disproving them.

abstract: A question of momentous interest will be presented to the Congress just about to assemble. It is no less than this: Shall the legislative body interfere in any way, either
lead_paragraph: A question of momentous interest will be presented to the Congress just about to assemble. It is no less than this: Shall the legislative body interfere in any way, either by regulation or advice, in the conduct of the present war; or shall it be committed solely to the power and discretion of the Executive? Subordinate to this vital question is the inquiry hardly less important: How far shall Congress exert any power or make any effort to regulate or diminish the cost of the war?

abstract: Our Washington correspondenceof this morning gives some items of a startling character touching life in Arizona. It is now something more than ten years since our frontier line has been thrown from the western limit of the great valley of the Mississippi, to those regions known as the Rocky Mountain slopes, bounded by the British possessions on the north and by Mexico on the south. During the early period of the California emigration, when emigrants in large bodies rushed across the country, we heard little of Indian depredations. But later, when civilization attempted to make a stand in sections of the intermediate countries, and emigrants in small bodies wound their slow and weary way over a variety of routes, the wild Indian commenced his systematic course of plunder and butchery. Our correspondent states that he estimates the number of white settlers and emigrants killed by the Indians in our frontier regions, at one thousand per annum. This is a fearful estimate, and but for our confidence in the knowledge and accuracy of our informant, we should be disposed to consider his calculation as highly extravagant.
lead_paragraph: Our Washington correspondenceof this morning gives some items of a startling character touching life in Arizona. It is now something more than ten years since our frontier line has been thrown from the western limit of the great valley of the Mississippi, to those regions known as the Rocky Mountain slopes, bounded by the British possessions on the north and by Mexico on the south. During the early period of the California emigration, when emigrants in large bodies rushed across the country, we heard little of Indian depredations. But later, when civilization attempted to make a stand in sections of the intermediate countries, and emigrants in small bodies wound their slow and weary way over a variety of routes, the wild Indian commenced his systematic course of plunder and butchery. Our correspondent states that he estimates the number of white settlers and emigrants killed by the Indians in our frontier regions, at one thousand per annum. This is a fearful estimate, and but for our confidence in the knowledge and accuracy of our informant, we should be disposed to consider his calculation as highly extravagant.

abstract: The United States vs. Nathaniel M. Gordon.  This case of the Captain of the slaver Erie, in which the jury disagreed a few days ago, was called again for trial.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. Nathaniel M. Gordon. -- This case of the Captain of the slaver Erie, in which the jury disagreed a few days ago, was called again for trial. Mr. Joachimssen and Judge Dean appeared for the prisoner, and applied to have the case postponed on account of the absence of a witness and of Judge Dean's engagement to deliver a Fourth of July oration at Chatham Four Corners, in Columbia County. The motion to postpone was opposed by the District-Attorney and was denied by the Court. Judge Dean then applied for a short time to determine whether he would go on with the trial, or turn it over to other counsel. On the expiration of the time the defendant's counsel interposed a challenge to the array of jurors, which, as will be recollected, has been summoned from Columbia County, on the following grounds:

abstract: Ward School No. 33, in Twenty-eighth-street, near Ninth-avenue, presented on Monday a scene of rare loveliness, it being the occasion of their usual semi annual "reception". The large hall was well adorned with flags and flowers; the teachers and pupils presented their most presentable holiday appearance, and the very large audience seemed to be in their gayest good-nature. The exercises, consisting of recitations, original compositions, songs, duetts, chorusses, calisthenics, &c., were exceedingly creditable to the children, and to their excellent principal; Miss CLARA M. EDMONDS. The music, under the direction of the veteran COLBURN, was choice, and well done, and the whole affair a credit to the gentlemen who manage school matters in this Ward. At the close of the exercises short addresses were made by Dr. LIVINGSTON, Judge WATERBURY and others, friends of education in the Twentieth Ward.

EDMONDS. The music, under the direction of the veteran COLBURN, was choice, and well done, and the whole affair a credit to the gentlemen who manage school matters in this Ward. At the close of the exercises short addresses were made by Dr. LIVINGSTON, Judge WATERBURY and others, friends of education in the Twentieth Ward.

abstract: The Fourth will be celebrated in a very appropriate manner at this beautiful encampment. It is proposed to fire the National Salute at sunrise; have a grand dress parade at 11 o'clock, after which the Brigade will march by column of companies to the place designated for the exercises of the day, which will he opened by prayer, followed by music, reading of the Declaration of Independence, music, and Gen. SICKLES will address the Brigade. At 4 o'clock a grand parade and review will take place, and at 8 o'clock fireworks, prepared with reference to the times, will be displayed, after which a grand ball will be given. As the grounds and accommodations are ample the Brigade doubtless expect many patriotic friends. Thirty-three companies have already been mustered into the United States service in this Brigade.

abstract: Having passed several sleepless nights, disturbed by the agonies and cries of a suffering child, and becoming convinced that Mrs. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply for the child. On reaching home, and acquainting his wife with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Homoeopathy. That night the child passed in suffering, and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following, the father found the baby still worse, and, while contemplating another sleepless night, the mother stepped from the room to attend to some domestic duties, and left the father with the child. During her absence he administered a portion of the SOOTHING SYRUP to the baby, and said nothing. That night all hands slept well, and the little fellow awoke in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delighted with the sudden and wonderful change, and although at first offended at the deception practiced upon her, has continued to use the Syrup, and suffering, crying babies and resteles nights have disappeared. A single trial of the Syrup never yet failed to relieve the baby, and overcome the prejudices of the mother.

abstract: The schooner Savannah, privateer No. 1, and the ship Nightingale, slaver, were sold yesterday forenoon, by the United States Marshal, at Allantic Dock. SIMEON DRAPER acted as auctioneer. The privateer was put up first and was sold to MCCREADY, MOTT & Co. for $1,275; her gun and ammunition bringing $75. The small arms, including twelve old flint-lock muskets, and some half dozen rusty cutlasses, brought $20, Total, $1,370. It was generally considered a high price. The ship brought $13,000, exclusive of lading and stores. She was valued at about $20,000. It is rumored that the Government will fit out both vessels for their own use.
lead_paragraph: The schooner Savannah, privateer No. 1, and the ship Nightingale, slaver, were sold yesterday forenoon, by the United States Marshal, at Allantic Dock. SIMEON DRAPER acted as auctioneer. The privateer was put up first and was sold to MCCREADY, MOTT & Co. for $1,275; her gun and ammunition bringing $75. The ship brought $13,000, exclusive of lading and stores. She was valued at about $20,000. It is rumored that the Government will fit out both vessels for their own use.

abstract: Harlequin utters one of his profoundest Plum-Guttural growls at the police for interfering with the right of petition. It is of course needless to say there has been no such interference; but that an ingenious attempt to mislead public opinion by fraud, misrepresentation, and forgery, has very properly been defeated, and the offenders exposed. Since the Superintendent of Police, with questionable propriety, saved the skipper of Plum-Gut from mob-law, the Herald has much mitigated its treatment of the Department. But when the energies of the Chief begin to be turned from the protection to the punishment of traitors, the venerable mountebank resumes his fears, and will doubtless pour out his malignity henceforth as unsparingly as in other days he uttered his daily puffs of Potosi. Let the Superintendent arm himself in triple brass, and with an extra baton or two, as preparation for this threatened war-fare.
