abstract: The People, ex rel. Joseph H. Reynolds, vs. Daniel E. Sickles. -- Pursuant to appointment, Justice BARNARD proceeded to the camp-grounds of Camp Scott, Staten Island, to investigate the troubles of the forty men who had petitioned for their release upon a writ of habeas corpus. The writ, after the argument of counsel on both sides, was dismissed. In regard to the writ issued upon the petition of Lieut. Ahl, for the release of upwards of eighty men, the particulars of which case were stated in full in the TIMES of Saturday, the Judge also dismissed it, no one appearing to prosecute the writ on the part of petitioner.

abstract: Intimations reach us from various sources, having access to official information, of an immediate advance of the main body of our army.
lead_paragraph: Intimations reach us from various sources, having access to official information, of an immediate advance of the main body of our army. It is stated that unless the enemy prefers retreat to a collision, a general engagement will certainly be had before Monday next, for before that day, Gen. SCOTT, at the head of his forces, designs to occupy Fairfax Court-house and Manassas Junction, at the cost, if necessary, of a battle. The probability, however, is that no battle will occur. There is every reason to believe that the rebels are not in sufficient strength to hazard a general action; since all authorities concur in numbering the advance commanded by BEAUREGARD, and consisting of detachments at the Court-house, the Junction, at Centreville, and at Culpepper, as not exceeding an aggregate of 25,000 men, very imperfectly prepared for a conflict with thrice that force which Gen. SCOTT is able to fling upon them. The policy of the rebel leaders, judging from the laborious efforts they are making to fortify Richmond, is to fall back to the James River, and make their stand under the shadow of the rebel Capital. Gen. SCOTT will probably urge his southward march along the Potomac, until, by placing MAGRUDER's corps between himself and Gen. BUTLER, he will compel that body of rebels to surrender; and then, cooperating with Gen. BUTLER, his army will approach Richmond upon both banks of the James simultaneously. In the meantime, Gen. PATTERSON will continue to advance along the foot of the Blue Ridge, until he effects a junction with a portion of Gen. MCCLELLAN's force, emerging from the valley at Charlottesville; and the rebels will thus be so nearly surrounded as to be forced to give battle.

abstract: Among extracts from London journals, reproduced on another page, one drawn from the Shipping and Mercantile Gazette, a first-class commercial authority, indicates that England begins to grow restless under the stoppage of American cotton supplies.
lead_paragraph: Among extracts from London journals, reproduced on another page, one drawn from the Shipping and Mercantile Gazette, a first-class commercial authority, indicates that England begins to grow restless under the stoppage of American cotton supplies. After a vain attempt to persuade herself that the plant could be grown as successfully and abundantly in her own colonies as in the United States, she turns despairingly to the old sources; and absolutely clamors with covetous impatience as she sees piled upon the levees of New-Orleans, and the wharves of Charleston, those bales of "floceulent matter," for the want of which her millions must presently perish. The Gazette demands that measures be taken to induce the National Government to relax the blockade so far as to permit the exportation of cotton. To achieve this concession it suggests a joint application of the British and French cabinets; and after hinting at arguments which might be brought to bear upon Mr. LINCOLN, if refractory, leaves the alternative adoption of force clearly presented.

abstract: "The French exploring expedition which left this city in April, to cross the Isthmus at the Darien, with the view of making further investigations as to the practicability of opening a ship canal, returned on the 17th inst., having been unable to effect their object owing to the heavy rains.
lead_paragraph: "The French exploring expedition which left this city in April, to cross the Isthmus at the Darien, with the view of making further investigations as to the practicability of opening a ship canal, returned on the 17th inst., having been unable to effect their object owing to the heavy rains. The expedition got as far as the river Chuquinaca, after having gone 19 miles up the Sabana and nine up the Lara, during which time they had to overcome a great many difficulties, and put up with a good deal of hardship. They met with no elevation more than 40 metres above the level of the sea. We understand they communicated with the Indians, who have expressed their willingness to allow the expedition to prosecute their journey unmolested. The party intend returning to France at once, and coming out again in December, so as to follow up their plans in the dry season of 1862.

abstract: INDEPENDENCE DAY IN BROOKLYN. The only notice to be taken by the authorities of this day will be by a display of fireworks on Fort Greene, in the Eastern District, and at Greenpoint, the firing of national salutes and the ringing of bells, for which purpose $4,000 has been appropriated.
lead_paragraph: INDEPENDENCE DAY IN BROOKLYN. -- The only notice to be taken by the authorities of this day will be by a display of fireworks on Fort Greene, in the Eastern District, and at Greenpoint, the firing of national salutes and the ringing of bells, for which purpose $4,000 has been appropriated. The Seventieth Regiment, Col. SAMUEL GRAHAM, the only regiment not at the seat of war, will parade through some of the principal streets in the morning, after which the command will be dismissed for the day. Some public spirited citizens in the Eastern District have secured the services of Hon. GEORGE H. FISHER to deliver an oration in Rev. Dr. PORTER's Church, Fourth street. There will be other interesting exercises at the same place. A battalion of the Eastern District Home Guard will also parade in the morning. In the Western District the regiment of Juvenile Zouaves will parade in the morning. This command is at present composed of six companies, and commanded by the following officers: Colonel, S.J. Quimby; First Company, South Brooklyn Union Zouaves -- Captain, S. Baldwin; Second Company -- Captain, A.W. Jackson; Lexington Guards -- Captain, D. Lynch, Jr.: Seventy-first Junior Zouaves -- Captain, H. Crocker; Union Zouaves -- Captain, L. Jerome. The corps will fall in at 9 o'clock A.M., on South-street near Carroll Park, and will march through Hoyt street, Fulton-avenue, DeKalb-aveaue to Fort Greene, Myrtle-avenue, Fulton-street, Clinton street to Carroll-street. At 4 o'clock P.M. there will be a flag raising at the Central Congregational Church, Ormond place, near Fulton-avenue, when several addresses will be made, and the oath of allegiance will be administered. The fireworks in the Western District will be displayed on Fort Greene, and will consist of the following pieces: 1, Illuminated Yew Tree; 2, Cascade; 3, Star of America; 4, Persian Rose; 5, Polka Dance and Colored Battery; 6, Triple Cross of Malta; 7, Fairies Frolic; 8, Emblem of Freedom; 9, Indian Palmetto; 10, Emblem of Industry; 11, Our Army; 12, The American Coat of Arms.

abstract: The celebration of the Fourth of July now going on in almost every State of the Union, is about the only act of veneration for past memories that the North and South can perform in common.
lead_paragraph: The celebration of the Fourth of July now going on in almost every State of the Union, is about the only act of veneration for past memories that the North and South can perform in common. It is the last link of the Union that treason has spared. The Flag which was the honored and renowned symbol of the cause that was consecrated on the Fourth of July eighty-six years ago, has been torn down and trampled upon by an unhallowed rebellion. The Constitution, which was the common ark in which North and South deposited their sacred liberties, so nobly declared to the world on the Fourth of July, 1776, and so bravely won on the fiery fields of battle that followed, has been rejected as a weak and worthless compact, by unworthy sons of sires in whose wisdom it had birth.
headline: {'main': 'The Day We Celebrate.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Day We Celebrate.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: There is, no doubt, a class of men among as there may be in the Government who have a vague expectation of a final separation between the North and the South, and who begin to think a peaceable dissolution would be better than this waste of wealth, this slow destruction of property and business.
lead_paragraph: There is, no doubt, a class of men among us -- there may be in the Government -- who have a vague expectation of a final separation between the North and the South, and who begin to think a peaceable dissolution would be better than this waste of wealth, this slow destruction of property and business. We do not mean that these people are numerous. They scarcely show themselves, either in private or public. Still they do exist, and their unexpressed desires and vague hopes of a peace or truce, which should bring separation, ought to be met. This grand uprising of the Free States has been in part based on an instinct -- the instinct of nationality; but as is often true of popular instincts, it is really coincident with the highest interest. The vast country stretching from the Atlantic and the Gulf to the Rocky mountains must he inhabited by one people and governed by one government.
headline: {'main': 'What is Peaceable Disunion?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'What is Peaceable Disunion?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The expected movement of Gen. PATTERSON's column of the Grand Army across the Potomac took place on Tuesday morning, and was followed by a battle with Gen. JOHNSTON'S rebel forces, ten thousand strong, near Martinsburgh, which resulted in the defeat of the rebels and their precipitate retreat, with considerable loss, while our loss was but three killed and wounded, according to a brief official dispatch from Gen. PATTERSON to the War Department, announcing his victory.
lead_paragraph: The expected movement of Gen. PATTERSON's column of the Grand Army across the Potomac took place on Tuesday morning, and was followed by a battle with Gen. JOHNSTON'S rebel forces, ten thousand strong, near Martinsburgh, which resulted in the defeat of the rebels and their precipitate retreat, with considerable loss, while our loss was but three killed and wounded, according to a brief official dispatch from Gen. PATTERSON to the War Department, announcing his victory. Scouting parties were sent over on Monday night, and brisk firing was heard all night between the scouts and the rebel pickets. The advance of the main body took place before daylight, the post of honor being assigned to Capt. MCMULLIN's Independent Rangers, and the First Wisconsin and Eleventh Pennsylvania Regiments. The advancing column was met by the enemy in force at Porterfield's Farm, on the turnpike road near Hainesville, where the conflict was fierce for a time; but the rebels were finally compelled to give way, and then retreat soon became precipitate. They left behind them numbers of their dead and wounded, and a great many articles of value, and Gen. PATTERSON subsequently occupied their camp. So confident were the enemy of an easy victory over the National troops, that they had leveled the fences on both sides of the turnpike, in order that they might the more readily cut off the retreat towards the Potomac.

abstract: The assembling of Congress in extraordinary session for causes, too, extraordinary, will make this anniversary of National Independence 2s memorable as the original day, which it is a part of our popular religion to observe.
lead_paragraph: The assembling of Congress in extraordinary session for causes, too, extraordinary, will make this anniversary of National Independence 2s memorable as the original day, which it is a part of our popular religion to observe. Our National life is to be lived over again; our freedom and unity are to be reconquered by the struggle of a great uprisen people; and while the Executive is the instrument we use, it is for Congress to direct how its use may be made most effectual. Coming, too, more recently from the people, it will reflect much more perfectly the popular will than it has thus far been reflected by the Administration; so that we may expect, from it a new and powerful impulse to the prosecution of the war.

abstract: INDEPENDENCE DAY.?The "Glorious Fourth" will be celebrated in this City and its environs, today, with all the outward display, and much more of the inward spirit, that has characterized its observance in years gone by.
lead_paragraph: INDEPENDENCE DAY. -- The "Glorious Fourth" will be celebrated in this City and its environs, today, with all the outward display, and much more of the inward spirit, that has characterized its observance in years gone by. The dangers which now threaten their liberties, have revived in the hearts of the people the patriotism that animated their forefathers, and many an old fogy who has been wont to regard the great gunpowder festival as a nuisance and a bore, will to day enter with spirit into, the festivities, and smile approvingly upon the "noise and confusion" with which Young America seeks to honor the great natal day of our independence. The military display will not be so large as usual, in consequence of the absence at the seat of war of the larger portion of the militia of this Division; but to make up for the deficiency a novel and not less interesting feature will be introduced in the marshaling of over 6000 of the boys belonging to the public schools, who will be dressed in uniform and join in the military parade. The line will be formed in Fourteenth-street and University-place, at 7 1/2 A.M., and will move as laid down in the published programme. Among the indoor celebrations the great feature of the day will be the oration of Hon. EDWARD EVERETT at the Academy of Music, for the benefit of the families of volunteers. Rev. E.H. CHAPIN will also deliver an oration at the Cooper Institute, for the benefit of the "Ladies' Society for the relief of Volunteers" The ancient Tammany Society will celebrate the day in their usual style Gen. HIRAN WALLBRIDGE being the orator of the occasion. There will also be a celebration, with music and addresses, &c., at the Dutch Reformed Church in Twenty-third-street, west of Sixth-avenue. The day will be observed in the customary manner at the public institutions on the Islands. In Brooklyn, Jersey City, Staten Island, &c., the occasion will be appropriately observed. Numerous pleasure excursions to the various places of resort in the vicinity of the City have been planned, for the details of which we refer the reader to our advertising columns. There will be a brilliant display of fireworks in the evening at the City Hall Park, Madison-square, Tompkins-square. Washington Parade-ground, and the other parks in the City.

abstract: Lieut. BANKHEAD, attached to the recruiting rendezvous in Cedar-street, has left for Washington, it is supposed on official business. He is one of the loyal officers whose Southern birth has prevented his promotion, while many of his juniors are advanced.
lead_paragraph: Lieut. BANKHEAD, attached to the recruiting rendezvous in Cedar-street, has left for Washington, it is supposed on official business. He is one of the loyal officers whose Southern birth has prevented his promotion, while many of his juniors are advanced. He belongs to the Fifth Infantry, entered that regiment after a severe course at West Point, in 1850, and has been doing duty as a first lieutenant for six years. Were he rewarded like some even of his own regiment, he would be a major now.

abstract: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRS. WINSLOW? we will simply say that she is a lady who for upwards of 30 years, has untiringly devoted her time and talents as a female physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, so generally overlooked or carelessly treated by the faculty in the many instances: and, as a result of this effort, and practical knowledge obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article, Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children do certainly RISE UP and bless her; especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grave by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn will share its benefits and unite in calling her blessed. No MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it, mothers -- TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: The Stock Exchange continued very dull and prices showed a drooping tendency. Consols on the 21st decline 1/8, closing at 89 3/4@89 7/8 for money, and 90@90 1/8 for account. In the discount market the demand was rather brisker. Best bills, 5 3/4@6 cent. The applications at the Bank showed an increase. Gold was flowing to the Bank largely in excess of the withdrawals for America. The weekly statement shows an increase in the bullion of L383 889. BARING BROTHERS & Co. quote Bar Silver 5s. 3/8d.; Dollars, 4s. 10 7/8d.; Eagles, 77s., nominal.

abstract: The annual Fourth of July regatta took place on Charles River, at Boston, on Thursday, and drew together a large concourse of spectators, among whom was a large sprinkling of carsmen and other lovers of the sport, from New-York, Poughkeepsie and Newburgh.
lead_paragraph: The annual Fourth of July regatta took place on Charles River, at Boston, on Thursday, and drew together a large concourse of spectators, among whom was a large sprinkling of carsmen and other lovers of the sport, from New-York, Poughkeepsie and Newburgh. Prizes to the amount of $680 were offered by the city to be contended for in four races, viz.: single sculls, two prizes, $75 and $30; double sculls, $100 and $50; four-oared boats, $125 and $50; six-oared boats, $175 and $75.

lead_paragraph: The musical world in the United States has never, perhaps, sustained a greater loss than the occasioned by the death of the celebrated baritons, whose sudden and premature decease, while on his voyage from Venezuela to Philadelphia, has lately been announced to us. He will be much regretted as well by the frequenters of the opera, with whom he was an universal favorite, as by an extensive circle of private friends, to whom he was endeared by his amiable qualities.

abstract: THOMAS BRIDGET, a bar-tender, was arrested by Officer HERBERT, of the Fifteenth Precinct Police, at 2 o'clock on Thursday morning, for stabbing FRANCIS PARSONS with a pocket-knife in the breast and left arm. The affray occurred in front of the Eagle ...
lead_paragraph: THOMAS BRIDGET, a bar-tender, was arrested by Officer HERBERT, of the Fifteenth Precinct Police, at 2 o'clock on Thursday morning, for stabbing FRANCIS PARSONS with a pocket-knife in the breast and left arm. The affray occurred in front of the Eagle Concert Saloon, No. 650 Broadway. PARSON's was going home with JANE NIGHTINGALE, one of the waiter girls, who was formerly the wife of BRIDGET, and this was the cause of the dispute. The wound was dressed by Surgeon JANES, of the Police, and the injured man was sent to his residence, No. 77 Forsyth-street. BRIDGET was locked up for examination.

abstract: The National Anniversary of American Independence--the eighty-fifth and most momentous of our history--was celebrated yesterday. With what sincerity and heartiness the detailed accounts which we publish elsewhere will testify.
lead_paragraph: The National Anniversary of American Independence -- the eighty-fifth and most momentous of our history -- was celebrated yesterday. With what sincerity and heartiness the detailed accounts which we publish elsewhere will testify. To the majority of those who assisted in the various exercises of the occasion it was something more than a mere holiday. The aspect of the day was that of a great National Thanksgiving -- of a pious opportunity for recognizing a great political fact, rendered peculiarly impressive by the circumstance that for the moment it has been blindly, madly forgotten by our brothers in a portion of the still smiling land. In the social world there are gatherings of kindred, where amidst congratulations, kindly greetings and jovial good fellowship, there is still a thought for the absent ones. A deep and sincere hope brims the heart that they may be with us next year. So was it yesterday. There was a tacit understanding, a mute regret that some we loved were away; that many who have heretofore shared our triumph were no longer by our side to great us with the vital grasp of a great national brotherhood. Thoughts like these were in the minds of the people, and gave to the day an earnestness and significance which has never before been demanded or experienced. We live in the midst of the most pathetic history ever vouchsafed to a free people. Quick, electrical, finely strung as are our masses, they are peculiarly susceptible of being overwhelmed with generous emotion. Who can forget the great sob of mingled pride and joy that came from them when the first volunteers passed from our sight to struggle for the glorious traditions of the day which yesterday we celebrated. And when the day itself reached us, there was an effusion of rapture which has only been paralleled in the greatest moments of our national existence.

abstract: When, therefore, the pedigree of King Cotton is traced, he is found to be the lineal child of the Tariff; called into being by a specific duty; reared by a tax laid upon the manufacturing industry of the North, to create the culture of the raw material in the South. The Northern manufacturers of America were slightly protected in 1789, because they were too feeble to stand alone. Reared into magnitude under the restrictive system and the war of 1812, they were upheld in 1816 because they were too important to be sacrificed, and because the great staple of the South had a joint interest in their prosperity. King Cotton a one, not in his manhood, not in his adolescence, not in his infancy, but in his very embryo state, was pensioned upon the Treasury -- before the seed from which he sprang was cast "in the lowest parts of the earth." In the book of the Tariff "his members were written, which were fashioned in countenance when as yet there were none of them."

abstract: The day was appropriately celebrated in Flushing, under the auspises of a Committee of public-spirited citizens. The Sabbath-schools of all the churches, including the Catholic, the fire engine companies, with their machinery beautifully decorated; a portion of the military, under Gen. HAMILTON, who was Grand Marshal of the day, and citizens and strangers joined in the procession, which marched through the town to PARSON's grove, where an eloquent oration was pronounced by THEODORE TILTON. JOHN W. LAWRENCE, Esq., as President of the day, occupied the Chair during a portion of the ceremonies, but abruptly vacated it towards the close, on account of an unpleasant feeling. Hon. LUTHER C. CARTER then took the Chair, and did the honors during the remainder of the ceremonies. The exercises were concluded by a handsome display of fireworks in the evening.

abstract: The Tribune, a day or two since, published in its editorial columns several of the reasons urged by CYRUS H. McCORMICK for the renewal of his patent for improvement in grain reaping-machines. Readers will remember ...
lead_paragraph: The Tribune, a day or two since, published in its editorial columns several of the reasons urged by CYRUS H. McCORMICK for the renewal of his patent for improvement in grain reaping-machines. Readers will remember that a few months ago the patentee made no pretence of relying on the Press, or upon public sentiment consolidated by the Press, for the extension of his burdensome and oppressive monopoly. His reliance then was on the acting chief of the Patent Bureau, whose conduct foreshadowed so clearly his determined purpose to extend the McCormick patent, right or wrong, that Congress stepped in, and by special legislation wrested the case from his hands, and transferred the question to the new Administration for its decision. That decision is soon to be rendered, and the patentee and his agents are bringing every possible effort to bear to delude the new Commissioner of Patents into extending a monopoly against which the entire farming interest protests earnestly, and with good reason. We had supposed even the inventive genius of MCCORMICK unequal to the task of securing any positive aid in his schemes from the Tribune, a journal which especially claims to be regardful of the farmer's interests. We have not forgotten that when a corrupt Administration seemed just on the eve of renewing the monopoly in question for seven years more, our neighbor had no word of remonstrance; but we could not anticipate that it would lend its columns directly to the work of bolstering an extension project which has already taxed the farming interest about fifty dollars on each and every reaper manufactured.

abstract: Many casualties are reported, mainly among boys, by the careless use of firearms. Fourteen persons, injured in this manner, were received in the New-York Hospital during Wednesday night and Thursday, and about the same number were taken to Bellevue Hospital.
lead_paragraph: Many casualties are reported, mainly among boys, by the careless use of firearms. Fourteen persons, injured in this manner, were received in the New-York Hospital during Wednesday night and Thursday, and about the same number were taken to Bellevue Hospital. Some of the wounded are very much disfigured by the explosion of gunpowder, while at least a dozen were injured so seriously as to make amputation of the fingers or portions of the hands necessary.

abstract: Among the enthusiastic celebrations of the present Fourth of July, that at Mamaroneck is worthy of especial notice. The Methodist Church in which the exercises took place, was well filled with a patriotic audience. After a prayer by Rev. W.F. WATKINS, and the reading of the Declaration of Independence by Rev. CHARLES FLETCHER, the Hon. ALEXANDER W. BRADFORD, the orator of the day, delivered a fine and an impressive address. He was particular happy in contrasting the present war with the war of Independence, in showing that while we fight for the same principles as our fathers, we do so under far happier auspices. The war he thought the instrument of future good. The audience were evidently opposed to all compromise, and responded with unanimous applause when the speaker urged the necessity of prosecuting the war with energy, and in no spirit of compromise.

abstract: The Pilot of Plum Gut is a most delightful enemy. His suavity survives all sense of wrong, and his deep interest in the welfare of his foe makes the latter believe that it is a real happiness to be brought to grief by the Herald.
lead_paragraph: The Pilot of Plum Gut is a most delightful enemy. His suavity survives all sense of wrong, and his deep interest in the welfare of his foe makes the latter believe that it is a real happiness to be brought to grief by the Herald. Who does not remember how the harlequin persecuted in his paper, day after day, month after month, and year after year, the arrogant policy of the Cotton States in regard to the National Government? How he opposed their repeal of the Missouri Compromise, their Kansas outrages, their Lecompton villainy, their Congressional bullying, and their constant threats of disunion, until by the persistence and vehemence of his opposition to their schemes, the harlequin was hailed as the most distinguished defender of "Southern rights" in the North?

abstract: The authorities having neglected to give any special head to the celebration of the Anniversary of our National Independence, there was no organized observance of the day, but the people seemed to have determined, nevertheless not to let this fact cool their ardor, and the private demonstrations of patriotism ...
lead_paragraph: The authorities having neglected to give any special head to the celebration of the Anniversary of our National Independence, there was no organized observance of the day, but the people seemed to have determined, nevertheless not to let this fact cool their ardor, and the private demonstrations of patriotism were fully equal to any previous occasion of the kind. The day was ushered in by the ringing of all the bells in the city, and the firing of National salutes, both in the Eastern and Western District, and the same tokens of rejoicing were repeated at midday and sunset. At 7 o'clock the Seventieth Regiment, Col. SAMUEL GRAHAM, paraded through some of the principal streets with full ranks, and after passing in review in City Hall Square, were dismissed for the day. The Juvenile Zouaves, Col. S.J. QUIMBY -- six companies -- formed at the rear of Carroll Park, at 9 o'clock A.M., and marched about the City. Their gay uniform and good discipline attracted very general attention.

abstract: It is common to herald a President's Message to the world as an important document. And often it is so. But never was a Message ...
lead_paragraph: It is common to herald a President's Message to the world as an important document. And often it is so. But never was a Message less important than the one transmitted yesterday to Congress by President LINCOLN, of which a report will be found in the TIMES to-day, although the occasion is the most extraordinary that ever occurred in our country for the writing of a Message. The telegraph, or some strange fate that presided in the transmission and reprint of the document, has apparently coincided in this view of its value, for never before have we had a more painful jumble from which to extract the pith and meaning, the statement and sequence of a State paper.

abstract: The steamboat Catiline was burned the other day near Fortress Monroe, thereby giving occasion for a Congressional inquiry, which we earnestly hope will not be lost; for such inquiry, we are assured, will bring out the following facts: The boat in question was old and unsea worthy, and its outside value, fixed by competent judges, was $7,500. It was hired by Government as a transport, at the rate of $10,000 a month; with a clause in the contract that in the case of casualty, such as has just overtaken it, the owners were to be indemnified by Government, in the sum of $50,000. If the improbable story told by telegraph, that underwriters had been found to take a risk of $25,000 upon the boat, which, if taken, must have been predicated not upon the worth of the vessel, but the prospective value of its earnings, under so munificent a charter, it appears that what with monthly pay, indemnity, and insurance, the proprietors have realized one hundred and five thousand dollars for what three months ago would have brought with difficulty five thousand dollars. Into the history of this business, and into the parties to the distribution of the profit, an investigation should be made unsparingly.

abstract: The time-honored celebration of the glorious Fourth by the disciples of St. Tammany, was remembered yesterday by all who worthily bear the name in this City. The occasion was one of more than the usual enthusiasm and significance, and was attended ...
lead_paragraph: The time-honored celebration of the glorious Fourth by the disciples of St. Tammany, was remembered yesterday by all who worthily bear the name in this City. The occasion was one of more than the usual enthusiasm and significance, and was attended by a large gathering of the members, as well as citizens, without respect to party. The National Guard Band added greatly to the attraction, and enlivened the proceedings.

abstract: The Academy of Music was filled to overflowing on Thursday, on the occasion of Hon. EDWARD EVERETT'S oration on "The Issues of the Day." The orator was escorted to the building by the Veterans of 1812, and received with most aproarious demonstra-... tions of welcome.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Music was filled to overflowing on Thursday, on the occasion of Hon. EDWARD EVERETT'S oration on "The Issues of the Day." The orator was escorted to the building by the Veterans of 1812, and received with most aproarious demonstrations of welcome. The veterans were likewise well received. Judge SLOSSON presided, and the opening prayer was uttered by the venerable Dr. SPRING. The stage was quite filled with distinguished guests, the Veterans, and the pupils from the Institution of the Blind. The patriotic songs of the latter elicited unbounded approbation, while the singing of Dr. HOLMES' Army Hymn by the entire audience, was most impressive.

abstract: At 3 P.M., the large hall of the Cooper Institute was well filled with ladies and gentlemen, drawn thither by the announcement that the distinguished orator and Divine, Dr. E.H. CHAPIN, would deliver an oration for the benefit of the "Ladies" Army Relief Association."
lead_paragraph: At 3 P.M., the large hall of the Cooper Institute was well filled with ladies and gentlemen, drawn thither by the announcement that the distinguished orator and Divine, Dr. E.H. CHAPIN, would deliver an oration for the benefit of the "Ladies" Army Relief Association." The ball was appropriately decked with the National colors, and with portraits of WASHINGTON, WEBSTER, SCOTT, ANDERSON, PERRY and others, and the Seventh Regiment Band kindly lent its services for the occasion. On one side of the speaker's desk was planted a brass cannon, with a secession flag lying across its muzzle, and on the other side a stack of muskets belonging to the Seventh Regiment, surmounted with the Star Spangled banner. Ex-Mayor HAVEMEYER presided on the occasion, and upon the platform were seated a large number of ladies and gentlemen, representing many of the most prominent names in New-York society.

abstract: The National Anniversary was observed in Jersey City, yesterday, more generally and with much more enthusiasm than for many years. Notwithstanding that the streets were filled all day and evening with pleasure-seekers and persons brimfull of ...
lead_paragraph: The National Anniversary was observed in Jersey City, yesterday, more generally and with much more enthusiasm than for many years. Notwithstanding that the streets were filled all day and evening with pleasure-seekers and persons brimfull of patriotism, there was no serious breach of the peace, and, as far as could be ascertained, there was no accident worthy of note. About a dozen persons, who were overpowered by the heat and the effects of a too-free indulgence in stimulants, were taken care of for the night at the Police Station. The day was ushered in by a salute of thirty-four guns, fired at sunrise, at the foot of Warren-street, by the Hudson County Artillery. A national salute was fired at noon, and at sunset thirteen guns were fired.

abstract: At the close of the afternoon, the promiscuous restless, roving throng, which had been visible in the Park during the day, began to assume an appearance of stability as they gathered around the City Hall and carefully selected, and pertinaciously maintained, favorable positions from which to witness the grand.
lead_paragraph: At the close of the afternoon, the promiscuous restless, roving throng, which had been visible in the Park during the day, began to assume an appearance of stability as they gathered around the City Hall and carefully selected, and pertinaciously maintained, favorable positions from which to witness the grand pyrotechnic display, announced as the entertainment for the evening. As the time wore on arrivals became more frequent, and the open space gradually became peopled with groups both sexes, until at length the whole area was completely covered with an expectant and eager multitude. With the nearer approach to darkness, came additional spectators, who joining their predecessors, made the concourse so vast that every inch of standing room was taken, and ingress through the lower gates seemed almost impossible. Every available place that could afford a glimpse at the brilliant exhibition was speedily occupied, not excepting the numerous trees, whose branches, in many instances, sustained such a tremendous pressure, that they were momentarily in danger of giving way and precipitating their living burdens to the ground. Park Row and a portion of Broadway were nearly blocked by the immense crowd, and the windows and roofs of the surrounding buildings showed a dense mass of human faces and forms. In the Park a chain was placed a few yards from the steps leading to the Hall, and inclosed a large area, which was occupied principally by holders of tickets and privileged persons. A guard of police were stationed at intervals round the circle, who succeeded admirably in preserving order and preventing any encroachments from without. A staging was erected a short distance from the Hall, upon which was stationed Shelton's Band of twelve pieces, who discoursed patriotic music from the commencement to the end of the exhibition. The fireworks were manufactured by Messrs. J.G. & I. EDGE, of Jersey City and proved a complete success.

abstract: The steamboat New-World, which left here on Wednesday evening for Albany, when about three miles this side of New-Baltimore, struck a sunken coal barge, (which had foundered the day previous,) which carried away the stern and filled. She how lies sunk with water up to her guards -- is easy and in good position. Her passengers were transferred to the steamer Rip Van Winkle.

abstract: Owing to the majority of our City militia being off at the war, the display yesterday was of not so imposing an appearance as those of previous years. The regiments paraded turned out with great force, with the exception of the Seventh, which was not more than 500 strong. At 7 1/2 o'clock the line formed on Fourteenth-street. Gen. HALL, with true military punctuality, started at the exact moment mentioned in his order. After marching round Union-square, saluting the statue of WASHINGTON as they passed, they proceeded down Broadway to the Park, where they were inspected. One of the most noticable features in the parade was the marching of several companies of boys belonging to the Public Schools; they marched excellently well, and were frequently applauded along the route. The Madison and Fifth-avenue Zouaves, both of which are composed of boys, also marched in the parade. The following is a list of the regiments that turned out, and by whom they were commanded: Seventh Regiment, Lieut.-Col. POND; Fifty-fifth, Lieut.-Col. LE CLARE; Eleventh, Col. MAIDHOFF; Fourth, Col. HINCKEN; Third, Col. POSTLEY; First, Lieut.-Col. DEVIN.

abstract: There were fourteen steamboat excursions to West Point, on Thursday, the Fourth of July. Starting at seven, eight and nine o'clock, the crowded steamers, gaily decked with patriotic bunting, skimmed swiftly up the river, vieing with each other in speed, cheering crowds, and soul-inspiring music.
lead_paragraph: There were fourteen steamboat excursions to West Point, on Thursday, the Fourth of July. Starting at seven, eight and nine o'clock, the crowded steamers, gaily decked with patriotic bunting, skimmed swiftly up the river, vieing with each other in speed, cheering crowds, and soul-inspiring music. The Teutonic and Celtic elements of our population were particularly well represented, and for their entertainment, wheezy bands, barrels of lager and tables loaded with doughnuts, krullers and lemonade were provided, so that all things combining to please, there should be nothing less than Elysium on the day.

abstract: On Saturday, Prince ALFRED drove quietly through the town, making purchases at several shops; and the people seeing him thus occupied with business, forebore to mob or interrupt him, though eagerly curious crowds gathered here and there to see him. At 4 o'clock P.M., his Royal Highness left town. Accompanied by his governor, Major COWELL, he was driven to the railway-station, at Point St. Charles, in Gen. WILLIAM's carriage, the General and staff and heads of military departments being in attendance. Mr. ELLIOTT, Secretary, and Mr. BAILEY, Assistant Superintendent, were in attendance on behalf of the Railway Company, were presented to his Royal Highness, and attended him to the carriage. A large crowd of citizens also filled the platform, and saluted his Royal Highness with loud cheers, which he gracefully acknowledged. The Prince pronounce himself much pleased with his tour through Canada; and we are sure he carries with him the kindest wishes of the people of this great dependency of the empire for his future happiness. -- Montreal Gazette, July 1.

abstract: Congress assembled in special session on Thursday, and immediately proceeded to the business of Vice-President HAMLIN at noon, and the newly elected Senators from Kansas, Illinois and California appeared, and took the customary oath. There were forth-three members present. The Senate did no business on the first day,...
lead_paragraph: Congress assembled in special session on Thursday, and immediately proceeded to the business of Vice-President HAMLIN at noon, and the newly elected Senators from Kansas, Illinois and California appeared, and took the customary oath. There were forth-three members present. The Senate did no business on the first day, but Mr. WILSON, of Massachusetts, gave notice of his intention to introduce various bills rendered necessary by the condition of the country, a list of which may be found in our report of the proceedings. Yesterday, GEORGE T. BROWN, was elected Sergeant-at-Arms on the first ballot. Mr. CHANDLER, of Michigan, gave notice that he should introduce a bill to confiscate the property of leading rebels in the South, the proceeds to be applied to the indemnification of Union men who may have suffered losses on account of the acts of such rebels. Notice having been received of the organization of the House, a committee was appointed to wait on the President, and notify him of the readiness of Congress to proceed to business, and a short recess was taken. On reassembling, the President's Message was received and read. We publish this important document in full elsewhere. In the House on Thursday, almost the first business after the roll had been called was the election of Speaker. But one ballot was had -- the contest being between Messrs. GROW, of Pennsylvania, and BLAIR, of Missouri. Mr. COLFAX would not suffer his name to be used, and so announced to his friends. When the vote was taken it was found there was no choice, when Mr. BLAIR withdrew, and his vote was transfered to Mr. GROW -- thus electing that gentleman. Mr. GROW, on taking the Chair, made an earnest and telling address of thanks. The members were then sworn in by delegations. Some objection was made to the Virginia delegation by Mr. BURNETT, of Kentucky, but the objection was overcome. Some other trifling delay was occasioned by cases of contested election, when the House proceeded to the choice of Clerk, and the first ballot resulted in the election of Mr. ETHEREDGE, of Tennessee. Mr. VALLANDIGHAM, of Ohio, gave notice of his intention to introduce a bill to repeal the Tariff act of 1861, and substitute that of 1858 with revisions. Yesterday Ex-Congressman BALL was chosen Sergeant-at-Arms; IRA GOODENOW, of New-York, Doorkeeper, and Rev. Mr. STOCKTON, Chaplain. The President's Message was received and read, portions of it being greeted with applause from the floor and galleries. Mr. STEVENS, of Pennsylvania, gave notice of a bill to repeal all laws creating ports of entry in the rebellious States, and a bill providing for the holding of a United States Court in Wheeling. The House soon afterwards adjourned.

abstract: There never has been, probably, within the memory of living citizens, so general a demonstration in the way of flag flying as there was yesterday on the shipping of the harbor, and upon all public and private buildings in the City.
lead_paragraph: There never has been, probably, within the memory of living citizens, so general a demonstration in the way of flag flying as there was yesterday on the shipping of the harbor, and upon all public and private buildings in the City. At the firing of the sunrise salute, when the Star Spangled Banner was run up on board of the vessels-of-war, and upon the different military posts, the vessels in the harbor, as if by one common impulse, hoisted, first the old flag of the Union to their mastheads, and then brought out their international codes and the flags of all nations, by way of giving additional significance to the display. All the ferry-boats on the East and North Rivers, the arriving steamers, ships at anchor in the stream, and vessels at the wharves, large and small, American and foreign, each vied with the other in seeing which could make the finest display of bunting. The Cunard steamers at Jersey City, as if anxious to fully express the cordial sympathy of their Government with our own, were early dressed out in their gayest holiday costume. The same was true of all the foreign sailing vessels and steamers lying in the East and North Rivers. The ferry boats flitting across the bay with their decks crowded with passengers, and decorated with flags, was a very inspiring spectacle. The excursion steamers, of which there were a large number, were handsomely decorated with bunting.

abstract: The prompt organization of the House of Representatives of Congress on the day of meeting is an earnest of the direct and practical views that govern the people's Representatives. Mr. COLFAX, who had strong support for the Speakership, withdrew his name before the balloting commenced.
lead_paragraph: The prompt organization of the House of Representatives of Congress on the day of meeting is an earnest of the direct and practical views that govern the people's Representatives. Mr. COLFAX, who had strong support for the Speakership, withdrew his name before the balloting commenced. And Col. BLAIR, who had the voice of the country so much in his favor, withdrew his name after the first ballot, so that the election of Mr. GROW might be unanimous. The contest seemed to be not so much who should be Speaker, but rather who should contribute most to the immediate organization of the House. In this view of the case, which the facts justify, Messrs. COLFAX and. BLAIR lose no prestige, but if anything are strengthened in the popular regard by their course in the canvass.

abstract: A report has born in circulation for some days, that an order had been issued by Justice LEONARD, at the instance of Mr. Frederick Gulon, for the arrest of Surperintendent Kenredy and Mr. James B. Taylor, on an allegation of false imprisonment, growing out of the seizure of the peace petition. Upon inquiry, we learn that such was not the fact. The error probably grew out of an application for such an order, which the Judge promptly refused.
lead_paragraph: A report has born in circulation for some days, that an order had been issued by Justice LEONARD, at the instance of Mr. Frederick Gulon, for the arrest of Surperintendent Kenredy and Mr. James B. abstract: It was an oversight, we think, that the patriotic hymn or national airs, advertised for by some of our enterprising citizens, was not brought out on the Fourth of July.
lead_paragraph: It was an oversight, we think, that the patriotic hymn or national airs, advertised for by some of our enterprising citizens, was not brought out on the Fourth of July. Certainly the effervescence of patriotism and champagne on such a day is best calculated to buoy up into at least momentary success a production doomed otherwise to an imperfect birth and immediate oblivion. While advertising, therefore, for patriotism, poetry and music, all done up in one parcel, and warranted to please the nation, it would have been well to advertise also for a fast reader, who could peruse in a week all the pieces offered in competition, hum and thrum the music, and select infallibly what the nation would approveand adopt. Money is quite as capable of securing the agencies for an immediate selection of the national hymn as of securing the hymn itself.

abstract: Matter of Andrew J. Hackley. -- Upon the convening of the Court, Mr. Hackley was called, but did not answer. His counsel, William Fallerton, Esq., read the affidavit of one Bliss, setting forth that Mr. Hackley was sick at Bergen Point. The District-Attorney, not being exactly satisfied with the affidavit, cross-examined Mr. Bliss, and the witness related a series of incidents connected with Hackley's illness. Witness had seen him a week before he lert the City, at a house corner of Broadway and Twenty-eighth-street, sick, and attended by two physicians. Witness last saw Hackley on the Fourth at Bergen Point. He was then too ill to come to the City, being a part of the time confined to his bed.

abstract: We fully recognize the duty of all patriots, in the present national crisis, to give to the President of the United States all the respect due to his office, and all the support that he...
lead_paragraph: We fully recognize the duty of all patriots, in the present national crisis, to give to the President of the United States all the respect due to his office, and all the support that he can justly claim of good citizens, in the perilous work he has to perform. We shall strive to strengthen his Administration in its efforts to suppress the gigantic rebellion that threatens the existence of the Government, with all the means and influence in our power. We do this from personal, from political, and from national and patriotic considerations.

abstract: We present in our columns this morning the Report of the Secretary of the Navy, with an abstract of that of the Secretary at War. Both documents exhibit more than ordinary...
lead_paragraph: We present in our columns this morning the Report of the Secretary of the Navy, with an abstract of that of the Secretary at War. Both documents exhibit more than ordinary intelligence and ability. Mr. WELLES recounts with much clearness the course of events in his branch of the service since the commencement of hostilities, throwing light on transactions which have greatly needed it, and pointing to measures which his experience and information suggest. These are generally judicious and advisable. For any permanent enlargement of the Navy, however, to dimensions answering in any degree to the European standard, the country is unprepared. Reckoning, as we have a right to do, upon the decided and energetic tone of the President's Message, and the response of Congress, as proofs that the war is to be a short one, and knowing what secondary part frigates and gun-boats play, where in the absence of a hostile Navy mere transports are mainly needed, we may reasonably hesitate to witness what may be regarded as a needless addition to our very great public burdens. If, as we are told, the Southern ports are now perfectly blockaded, Mr. WELLES' own tabulation of our war shipping shows there is a residuum quite strong enough to make the seas unsafe for privateering.

abstract: The telegraph announces the sudden death of JOHN, LORD CAMPBELL, Chancellor at England, a nobleman equally distinguished as a jurist and as a, litterateur. Lord CAMPBELL was the son of a Scottish clergyman; was born in 1781, and was educated for the Church. After graduating at St. Andrew's, in the same class as Dr. CHALMERS, he abandoned clerical studies, and, going to London devoted himself to law and to reporting for the morning Press. For several years he was parliamentary reporter and dramatic critic upon the Morning Chronicle. After his call to the Bar, in 1806, he rapidiy acquired a prominent position in the profession, but was shut out from political preferment because of his liberal sentiments; and it was only after the death of Lord ELDON that he attained the dignity of King's Counsel. His first appearance on the floor of the House of Commons was in 1830; two years later he was appointed Solicitor-General, and subsequently Attorney-General in the Whig Ministry. In 1841, Mr. CAMPBELL was made Lord Chancellor of Ireland, and a peer of England. The same year, however, witnessed the overthrow of the Whigs; and thus, suddenly endowed with leisure, Lord CAMPBELL surrendered himself to literary pursuits, by commencing the preparation of that highly interesting work," The Lives of the Lord Chancellors." Later in life, he added to this valuable series of biographies another, which has likewise become a professional classic, "The Lives of the Chief Justices." When, in 1846, the Whigs returned to power, Lord CAMPBELL took the post of Chancellor of the Duchy of Lancaster, and in 1850 succeeded Lord DENMAN as Chief Justice of England. It was when the same party resumed their places, after the Derbyite episode, that Lord CAMPBELL reached the elevated position he held at the moment of his death. Lord CAMPBELL was married to a daughter of Lord ARINGER, the famous Sir JAMES SCARLETT.

abstract: Having passed several sleepless nights, disturbed by the agonies and cries of a suffering child, and becoming convinced that Mrs. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply, for the child. On reaching home, and acquainting his with with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Homoeopathy. That night the child passed in suffering, and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following, the father found the baby still worse, and, while contemplating another sleepless night, the mother stepped from the room to attend to some domestic duties, and left the father with the child. During her absence he administered a portion of the SOOTHING SYRUP to the baby, and said nothing. That night all hands slept well, and the little fellow awoke in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delighted with the sudden and wonderful change, and although at first offended at the deception practiced upon her, has continued to use the Syrup, and suffering, crying babies and resteles nights have disappeared. A single trial of the Syrup never yet failed to relieve the baby, and overcome the prejudices of the mother.

abstract: With an energetic individual or people, a clear and distinct purpose or policy is the very next door to success. The proper means always present themselves to the intelligent....
lead_paragraph: With an energetic individual or people, a clear and distinct purpose or policy is the very next door to success. The proper means always present themselves to the intelligent hand, which confidence in the result keeps cheerfully and successfully at work. We have, most emphatically, in this great contest this prime condition to success. We simply aim to restore what has been subverted and overthrown -- to reconstruct an edifice which has been partially destroyed, but of which the model and plan still remain. We do not seek to improve upon the past, except so far as to curb and repress those tendencies which have involved us in civil war. Our people desire no better Government than that under the fostering care of which they have made a progress which is really the marvel of the world. The restoration of the Government to an authority as wide as that of our domain, is a proposition upon which the loyal States are already united to a man, and for which our people are prepared to make the last of all sacrifices -- that of life itself. Such a purpose commands universal sympathy and support, and, carefully adhered to, will preserve us from discontent at home, and from those factions and partisan cabals which are often more to be feared than a formidable army in the field. It is not what we may be called upon to endure that we have to fear, but that we may not have an adequate motive to sustain us in our trial. With such, the satisfaction resulting from the maintenance of a principle is always in proportion to the difficulties encountered. We are never so contented and cheerful as under the sacrifices we are called upon to make, provided these are sanctified and ennobled by a great purpose.

abstract: The business of Congress yesterday was principally of a preliminary character. In the Senate, after the election of ISAAC BASSET as Assistant-Doorkeeper, Mr. WILSON presented the several bills of which he gave notice on Thursday. The bill to Promote the Efficiency of the Army was referred to a Special Committee, consisting of Messrs. Wilson of Massachusetts, Hale of New-Hampshire, Latham of California, Sherman of Ohio, Powell of Kentucky, Cowan of Pennsylvania, King of New-York, Kennedy of Maryland, and Howe of Wisconsin, and the other bills were referred to the Military Committee. A message was then received from the President, and the Senate went into executive session. In the House the death of Mr. SCRANTON, of Pennsylvania, was announced, and appropriate remarks were made by several members; after which the House adjourned, in accordance with the usual custom on such occasions.

abstract: The very large and steadily increasing circulation of the TIMES gives constant occasion for remonstrance as to the tardiness with which it is delivered to subscribers in New-York and Brooklyn. The attention of the proprietors has for some time been directed to obviating, this defect. They are now enabled to announce that in the course of a few days such arrangements will be perfected as will cause a much earlier delivery of the entire morning edition, and thus remove all ground of complaint.

abstract: The Company Commanders of the Garibald Guard, have read with pain an article which appeared in the Courier des Etats Unis some ten days ago, stating that the members of the French...
lead_paragraph: The Company Commanders of the Garibald Guard, have read with pain an article which appeared in the Courier des Etats Unis some ten days ago, stating that the members of the French Company were ill provided with clothing and shelter, and were overrun with vermin; and we feel very keenly the unjust reproach which the publication of such an article casts, not only upon our regiment, but in an equal degree upon the Union Defence Committee and upon the many friends of the regiment, who have generously provided our soldiers with all that conduce to their comfort -- to such an extent, indeed, that the chief complaint of the men is, that they have more to carry than they can stow in their knapsacks.

abstract: A day's proceedings of Congress are enough to show the determination of the majority to devote themselves earnestly and patriotically to work, and of a factious minority to throw...
lead_paragraph: A day's proceedings of Congress are enough to show the determination of the majority to devote themselves earnestly and patriotically to work, and of a factious minority to throw every possible obstacle in the way of business. Such men as BRECKINRIDGE, POWELL and POLK in the Senate, and BURNETT and VALLANDIGHAM in the House, are there for no other purpose than to embarrass the Government and 'obstruct legislation.' It is one of the rights of a minority that they may do this; but while the nuisance is to be submitted to, as the highest evidence of the injustice of the Southern libelers, who rant about the tyrannous temper of the Northern majority, care should be taken that the privilege be not abused to the detriment of the public service. It is quite possible that in the eagerness to expedite necessary measures, and in the impatience of such mischievous opposition, less deliberation will be given to the various bills which Congress will have to pass than they demand. For such haste there is no occasion. The obvious requirements of the moment should be met promptly; but seeing that occasions will constantly occur when the Executive must need the assistance or the advice of the legislative branch, it may not be undesirable for both Houses to maintain a quorum until the developments of the campaign may show their presence to be unnecessary.

abstract: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRS. WINSLOW? we will simply say that she is a lady who, for upwards of 36 years, has untiringly devoted her time and talents as a female physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, so generally overlooked or carelessly treated by the faculty in too many instances: and, as a result of this effort, and practical knowledge obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic-giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article, Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children do certainly RISE UP and bless her, especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grave by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn will share its benefits and unite in calling her blessed. No MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, is our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it, mothers -- TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City,

abstract: The President's Message was transmitted from Washington to New-York, Boston, Philadelphia and Baltimore, over the American Telegraph Company's wires, with extraordinary celerity. Every energy of the operators was bent to the accomplishment of their task. In view of the great speed with which the message was transmitted, it is as wonderful as it is creditable to all concerned that the document, as published, suffered from no mutilation.

abstract: A statement went the rounds of the Press some weeks ago, giving an exaggerated and false statement of the resources of the rebels, as it regards their means of subsisting an...
lead_paragraph: A statement went the rounds of the Press some weeks ago, giving an exaggerated and false statement of the resources of the rebels, as it regards their means of subsisting an army. It was made to appear that the South is richer than the North in agricultural resources of every kind, including the number and value of cattle and horses, and the quantity of the cereals produced. It was also assumed, as a matter of course, that the South was a unit, and that whatever is produced in the Slave States is to be put down as among the resources of the rebels. It is quite easy to show that in both these assumptions the sympathizers with treason have drawn upon their imaginations for their facts.

abstract: An inquest was held on Friday, by Coroner SCHIRMER, upon,the body of JOHN HOLMES, late a member of the Seventy-ninth Regiment, who was murderd at...
lead_paragraph: An inquest was held on Friday, by Coroner SCHIRMER, upon,the body of JOHN HOLMES, late a member of the Seventy-ninth Regiment, who was murderd at Georgetown, D.C., on the night of the 2d inst. An inquiry was made into the case by the Coroner at Georgetown, and evidence casting suspicion upon two of the comrades of deceased was elicited, but it was not of so clear a character as to warrant their arrest. There were four knife or bayonet wounds on the body. The jury rendered a verdict of death from stabs received at the hands of some person or persons to them unknown. Those having charge of the remains forgot to bring a burial certificate from Georgetown, thus making it necessary to hold another inquest here. The deceased was a native of Scotland, 26 years of age. He lived at No. 108 Eighth-avenue, where he has left a family.

abstract: The new play of "Suspense" has been the only attraction at the Winter Garden during the past week. Neither the Press nor the public have felt very enthusiastic about it, but the houses, notwithstanding...
lead_paragraph: The new play of "Suspense" has been the only attraction at the Winter Garden during the past week. Neither the Press nor the public have felt very enthusiastic about it, but the houses, notwithstanding have been moderately good. The coming week will be devoted mainly to benefits. Mr. SOUTHERN's engagement will terminate on Saturday next. He will be succeeded, we understand, by Mr. and Mrs. FLORENCE.

abstract: Secretary CAMERON commences his report by briefly referring to the seizures of arsena's, forts, c., by the rebels. Then, allading to the treachery of Twiees, which he contrasts with the heroic patriotism...
lead_paragraph: Secretary CAMERON commences his report by briefly referring to the seizures of arsena's, forts, c., by the rebels. Then, allading to the treachery of Twiees, which he contrasts with the heroic patriotism of ANDERSON, he speaks in eulogistic terms of the conduct of Major SLEMMER at Fort Pickens, and of Lieut. JONES at Harper's Ferry. Mr. CAMERON then alludes to the generous outpouring of volunteers, which greatly exceeds the demands of the Government, and sums up as follows the number now in the field. His estimate, he says, is not altogether accurate, as the officers commanding regiments have delayed making the returns called for. Mr. CAMERON says:

abstract: Five years ago the Border-Ruffians of Mis- souri, aided by the Ruffians of the far South, scoured the Territory of Kansas with fire and sword carrying desolation and slaughter...
lead_paragraph: Five years ago the Border-Ruffians of Mis- souri, aided by the Ruffians of the far South, scoured the Territory of Kansas with fire and sword -- carrying desolation and slaughter through the Free-State settlements. The infant towns were sacked, the printing-presses demolished, the cabins of the pioneers given to the flames, and they themselves hunted over the prairies and destroyed like wolves. STRINGFELLOW and ATCHISON and their blood-thirsty cohorts glutted their demoniac fury without mercy and without pause. "Men of the South!" shouted Senator ATCHISON, to his Bowie-knife ruffians, at Lawrence, on the memorable 21st of May, 1856:

abstract: Thomas Galway et al. vs. The United States Steam Sugar Refining Company et al. In this caso, the plaintiff obtained an injunction restraining the defendants from making any confession of judgment, and from any alienation of the property of the Com-...
lead_paragraph: Thomas Galway et al. vs. The United States Steam Sugar Refining Company et al. -- In this caso, the plaintiff obtained an injunction restraining the defendants from making any confession of judgment, and from any alienation of the property of the Company. He also obtained an injunction restraining all creditors from commencing any action against the Company, together with an order to show cause why a receiver should not be appointed. These injunctions, and the order to show cause, were obtained upon the allegation that the Company was insolvent, and would not go into voluntary dissolution, and that about half of the indebtedness matured on the 14th of June, and that creditors were about commencing suits.

abstract: We learn from an entirely reliable source, that a most shocking tragedy took place in Ithaca on Wednesday night last, which has plunged two highly respectable families into the deepest distress.
lead_paragraph: We learn from an entirely reliable source, that a most shocking tragedy took place in Ithaca on Wednesday night last, which has plunged two highly respectable families into the deepest distress. On the day mentioned, a young lady about 16 years of age -- whose name we did not learn -- informed her sister that she had agreed to walk out on Wednesday evening with her suitor, a young man named CORNELL, about 18 or 19 years old, and that they had agreed that he should first shoot her and then himself, and thus end their existence together. The sister was shocked, and started to inform their father, when the first one affected to have been "fooling," as she said, and thus quieted the alarm of her sister.

abstract: "Fifty Home Guards under Capt. Cook, from De Soto and Hopewell, proceeded Sunday night by rail to Irondale, where they arrived Monday morning at 9 o'clock and marched towards Farmington in...
lead_paragraph: "Fifty Home Guards under Capt. Cook, from De Soto and Hopewell, proceeded Sunday night by rail to Irondale, where they arrived Monday morning at 9 o'clock and marched towards Farmington in search of contraband arms, &c., reported to be in the neighborhood of that place. They passed through Farmington about three miles eastward towards the river, but finding nothing, were returning home, when about six miles west of Farmington they were attacked by a body of some 250 to 300 well armed and mounted Secessionists, who were in ambush. Their fire resulted in "nobody hurt."

abstract: Thirty-three regular men-of-war celebrated the Fourth of July on the American coast this year. This is the first time so large a naval fleet honored the day. Every full Commodore or flag-officer, bred a national salute.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-three regular men-of-war celebrated the Fourth of July on the American coast this year. This is the first time so large a naval fleet honored the day. Every full Commodore or flag-officer, bred a national salute. Off Fort Monroe, the Minnesota, Cumberland, Roanoke and Santee, all discharged at neon, with splendid effect. The Niagara at Pickees, the Wabash at Charleston, the Mississippi at Mobile, the North Carolina at New-York, the Ohio at Boston, the Marion at Portsmouth, and the St. Lawrence off Philadelphia, all made a Union demonstration, covering a very wide area.

abstract: The Traveller says that a letter received in Boston from Mobile states that Capt. WILSON, the commander of the brig Minnie Schiffer at the time she rescued and brought to Boston the passengers of the burning steamship Connaught, is now fitting out at Mobile the pilot-boat Florida as a privateer. She will carry four broadside guns and one pivot gun. Capt. WILSON was for some time commander of the privateer Calhoun, of New-Orleans, which captured several Northern vessels.

abstract: Brother MASLIN: I send you a five dollar bill on a Missouri bank, which you will credit to my account. Alas! for Illinois; our money is nearly all dead in our pockets. You should have had all I owe you, but the rags died on my hands. If your own money is dead, bury it and preach its funeral sermon, but do not charge the expenses to me, but to the Secessionists. I hope Gen. LYON will catch Tory JACKSON, and hang him on the first tree he comes to. Union men ought to arm themselves from head to heels, and shoot down every traitor they come to. If God will have mercy on me, I would rather die than that this glorious Government should be overthrown. If we must be destroyed, I hope the Lord will do it, and not give us into the power of tories. The army worm is making a dreadful sweep of our meadows, wheat and corn. We are threatened with drouth here. We have had no rain for four weeks. If the Union men need help to kill traitors, call on Illinois. We can send you twenty thousand good men and true. Rivers of blood will flow, but this Union must stand, though the heaven fall.

abstract: Of all the States that have escaped the curse of secession, there is not one that has so much cause for rejoicing as Missouri. Her normal position is in connection with the Free States. Her climate, soil, productions, her immense mineral resources, the development of which will one day place her among the richest States of the Union, all unmistakably indicate that her prosperity will always depend upon the employment in the main of free, and not of slave labor. Bordered, too, as she is, on three sides by Free States, exposing her continually to the inroads of free sentiments, and the direct influence of free institutions, slave property would cease to be desired or profitable, while its liability to escape would always render it too insecure for investment. Though the sympathies and prejudices of a large portion of her people were, for the present, with the South, yet the inexorable logic of events was linking all her interests indissolubly with the North and the East. The construction of railroads, connecting her immediately with the Eastern cities and the commerce of the ocean, relieved her from dependence on the Gulf by means of the Mississippi, which not many years ago was the great and only thoroughfare of northwestern trade and travel. Merchandise purchased in New-York, Boston or Philadelphia, found its way to St. Louis by New-Orleans, whence it was reshipped some fifteen hundred miles up the current of the Mississippi to that city. Goods purchased in New-Orleans had, in the main, been purchased by the New-Orleans merchant in New-York or New-England, and the consumer in Missouri had thus to pay the double profits of the two sets of jobbers through whose hands they had passed. With the construction of Railroads came a great change in the currents of Missouri commerce and trade. It set with a continually increasing volume towards the Atlantic instead of the Gulf cities. Not only was Missouri looking to the East for a market wherein she could make her purchases, but she was sending a large proportion of her surplus products in that direction to be sold. Every year increased the amount of this reciprocal trade, and another decade will connect her as indissolubly with the Northern Atlantic States as is Ohio, Illinois or any other Western or Northwestern State. With a kindly feeling, which late events have strengthened, rather than diminished, the North and the East will pour a continually increasing tide of hardy emigration into her fertile valleys, and Northern and Eastern capital and enterprise will aid in developing the unexampled richness of her mineral resources. Had she permitted herself to be entangled with secession it is easy to perceive how fatal it would have been to her material prosperity. She would have surrounded herself with enemies instead of friends. She would have thrown away the advantages of position, of intercourse and commerce with those to whom she was united by the bonds of a common interest, surrendered her prestige as the great State of the West, and shut her gates against an immigration of labor and capital so necessary to the development of the mighty sources of wealth hidden in her mountains, and in the unequaled richness of her soil.

Not only was Missouri looking to the East for a market wherein she could make her purchases, but she was sending a large proportion of her surplus products in that direction to be sold. Every year increased the amount of this reciprocal trade, and another decade will connect her as indissolubly with the Northern Atlantic States as is Ohio, Illinois or any other Western or Northwestern State. With a kindly feeling, which late events have strengthened, rather than diminished, the North and the East will pour a continually increasing tide of hardy emigration into her fertile valleys, and Northern and Eastern capital and enterprise will aid in developing the unexampled richness of her mineral resources. Had she permitted herself to be entangled with secession it is easy to perceive how fatal it would have been to her material prosperity. She would have surrounded herself with enemies instead of friends. She would have thrown away the advantages of position, of intercourse and commerce with those to whom she was united by the bonds of a common interest, surrendered her prestige as the great State of the West, and shut her gates against an immigration of labor and capital so necessary to the development of the mighty sources of wealth hidden in her mountains, and in the unequaled richness of her soil.

abstract: Brother MASLIN: I send you a five dollar bill on a Missouri bank, which you will credit to my account. Alas! for Illinois; our money is nearly all dead in our pockets. You should have had all I owe you, but the rags died on my hands, if your own money is dead, bury it and preach its funeral sermon, but do not charge the expenses to me, but to the Secessionists. I hope Gen. LYON will catch Tory JACKSON, and hang him on the first tree he comes to. Union men ought to arm themselves from head to heels, and shoot down every traitor they come to. If God will have mercy on me, I would rather die than that this glorious Government should be overthrown. If we must be destroyed, I hope the Lord will do it, and not give us into the power of tories. The army worm is making a dreadful sweep of our meadows, wheat and corn. We are threatened with droath here. We have had no rain for four weeks. If the Union men need help to kill traitors, call on Illinois. We can send you twenty thousand good men and true. Rivers of blood will flow, but this union must stand, though the heaven fall.

abstract: The New-Orleans Crescent, of the 24th, contains several dispatches from Mississippi City, Pass Christian, Ocean Springs -- all on the coast between the months of the Mississippi and Mobile -- which seem to have thrown New-Orleans into a perfect tumult of excitement. From these dispatches, we learn that a National steamer, three smaller vessels, and tender, were inside of Ship Island; that the Sound was vigorously blockaded; that the mailboat to Mobile was fired at eight times, and obliged to put back to New-Orleans; that three schooners had, been taken, etc., etc. If SCOTT would send his whole fleet to threaten different portions of the Gulf coast, the rebels would have something else to do than feed on the fat and enjoy the cool breezes of Virginia. The Cotton States caused the war; let them enjoy some of the damage and discomforts it occasions. A few landings on South Carolina, Georgia and Alabama coasts would bring BEAUREGARD's army scampering home again to keep down their own slaves.
