abstract: Sojourners at Saratoga Springs during the month of August last will perhaps remember a spare, sinewy, lithe-framed little man who was daily visible in the parlors and promenades of one of the principal hotels of that place.
lead_paragraph: Sojourners at Saratoga Springs during the month of August last will perhaps remember a spare, sinewy, lithe-framed little man who was daily visible in the parlors and promenades of one of the principal hotels of that place. With singularly self-possessed manners, yet of modest and unassuming deportment withal, and keen and searching black eyes, which neither wavered nor fell in conversation; beyond these there was nothing to distinguish their possessor from the great crowd of idlers who yearly go down to the Spa to seek a shelter from the scorching sun of Summer, and lave their throats with its pleasant waters. That lithe little man was DU CHAILLU -- the author of the volume before us -- a man who has carried the touch of exploration where it has never before been borne -- penetrated the veil which shrouds the burning heart of Africa, and left his footprints on the summits of mountains, whose very existence was before but a matter of conjecture. During the four years which embraced these explorations -- to use the author's own very modest summary of his exploits and adventures -- he traveled (always on foot and unaccompanied by any other white man) about 8,100 miles. He shot, stuffed, and brought home over 2,000 birds, of which more than 60 are new species; and killed upward of 1,000 quadrupeds, of which 200 were stuffed and brought home, with more than 80 skeletons. Not less than 20 of these quadrupeds are hitherto unknown to science. He suffered fifty attacks of the African fever, taking, to cure himself, over fourteen ounces of quinine. Of famine, long-continued exposures to the heavy tropical rains, and attacks of ferocious ants and ravenous flies, our author does not think it worth while to speak, though those of us who shrink from the bite of our own mitigated mosquitoes will incline to think, that from these multiplied martyrdoms alone he has claims upon our sympathies. If DU CHAILLU ventures to visit Saratoga again, we predict that his presence there will be known, and that those who have an opportunity of looking into the eyes that have undauntedly faced death in a thousand different forms will make "a note of it."

abstract: FOURTEENTH REGIMENT RECRUITS. This recruits (two hundred and fifty-six) for the Fourteenth Regiment, now in Virginia, did not leave for the seat of war on Friday, as was anticipated, owing to a vexatious delay about their uniforms.
lead_paragraph: FOURTEENTH REGIMENT RECRUITS. -- This recruits (two hundred and fifty-six) for the Fourteenth Regiment, now in Virginia, did not leave for the seat of war on Friday, as was anticipated, owing to a vexatious delay about their uniforms. Lieut.-Col. FOWLER, therefore, quartered his men at the State Arsenal on Portland-avenue, and will keep them there until they are fully equipped, which will be about the middle of the week. On Saturday, this corps were presented 100 shirts, 100 towels, 100 needle-books, 100 handkerchiefs, and 100 pairs stockings, by the ladies of the Central Presbyterian Church. Rev. Dr. ROCKWELL. A donation was aim received from the Monroe-place Presbyterian Church Rev. Dr. ELLS, pastor.

abstract: The Traveller says that a letter received in Boston from Mobile states that Capt. WILSON, the commander of the brig. Minzie Schiffer at the time she rescued and brought to Boston the passengers of the burning steamship Connaught, is now fitting out at Mobile the pilot-boat Florida as a privateer. She will carry four broadside guns and one pivot gun. Capt. WILSON was for some time commander of the privateer Calhoun, of New-Orleans, which captured several Northern vessels.

abstract: Three companies of Natchez Howitzers left Richmond on Wednesday, by the early train, for the intrenched camp on the top of the Blue Ridge. They have nine cannon, which, added to those already at the camp, make the total of 23. Two regiments arrived from Georgia, one infantry and one rifle -- 1,900 man, and encamped at Buchanan Springs. They go to Camp Steuben, ready to meet the National troops, though they are only armed with old flint muskets. The Twenty third Regiment of Louisiana Infantry wore dispatched in great haste to Weldon to meet the enemy. This Company is very handsomely equipped, and will perform a first-rate service. Thirteen columbiads were shipped for Warwick, and forthwith put in position.

abstract: It is remarkable, in view of our civil war, that the current of foreign immigration continues to flow hitherward in full volume, unchecked, so far, either by the political commotions or by the commercial disturbances which, in some localities, are producing such serious disaster.
lead_paragraph: It is remarkable, in view of our civil war, that the current of foreign immigration continues to flow hitherward in full volume, unchecked, so far, either by the political commotions or by the commercial disturbances which, in some localities, are producing such serious disaster. During the half year just closed the immigration from Europe has been nearly as great as it was for the corresponding period of last year, and considerably greater than for the same months of the two years preceding last The whole number of immigrants landed at Castle Garden from the beginning of the year to the close of last month, (as registered on the books of the Emigration Commissioners,) amounts to 43,637, as against 49,388 for the first six months of last year -- being a diminution of only 5,751. There is known, however, to be an unusually large number of emigrant ships now on their way here from Hamburg, Bremen and other German and Northern European ports -- so that it is anticipated that the emigration of the present year will equal, if it does not exceed, that of any year since 1857. Only last week the steamship Hammonia came into this port filled with industrious and intelligent German emigrants, who had been compelled to take that means of conveyance from Hamburg, because all the sailing vessels in that port, or about to arrive there, were already engaged for the transport of passengers impatient to get on their way to the promised land of America.

abstract: The very large and steadily increasing circulation of the TIMES gives constant occasion for remonstrance, as to the tardiness with which it is delivered to subscribers in New-York and Brooklyn. The attention of the proprietors has for some time been directed to obviating this defect. They are now enabled to announce that in the course of a few days such arrangements will be perfected as will cause a much earlier delivery of the entire morning edition, and thus remove all ground of complaint.

abstract: In this Court yesterday, before Recorder HOFFMAN, a motion was made to quash the indictment against Dr. ERNEST BAGNIASKY, formerly a surgeon in the Austrian army, for forgery. The Doctor was formerly put on trial for false pretences, in defrauding a midwife of a large sum of money, but was acquitted on technical grounds. As the fraud was accompanied by the utterance of worthless paper as security, a new indictment was found against the Doctor for forgery, which is now sought to be quashed on technical grounds. The motion was argued by Mr. Clegg for the prisoner, and by the District Attorney for the Government, and a decision was reserved.

abstract: "The act passed at the extra session of the Legislature, authorizing the raising and equipping of fifteen regiments, to be held as a reserve corps in the State, has been nearly compiled with. In a few weeks Pennsylvania will have 16,000 troops, fully armed, and in all respects ready for service, in the field, in addition to those she has already sent forward at the call of the National Government. A portion of those troops are now on duty on the border line between this State and Maryland. They moved in the direction of Cumberland, for the double purpose of protecting our own frontier from invasion, and reinforcing Col. WALLACE's Indiana Regiment, should that be found necessary.
lead_paragraph: "The act passed at the extra session of the Legislature, authorizing the raising and equipping of fifteen regiments, to be held as a reserve corps in the State, has been nearly compiled with. abstract: Is it not a humiliating fact for the gallant, the indomitable, the invincible chivalry of the Gulf States, who were born almost with rifles in their hands, who practiced gunnery and horsemanship in swaddling clothes, and grew up...
lead_paragraph: Is it not a humiliating fact for the gallant, the indomitable, the invincible chivalry of the Gulf States, who were born almost with rifles in their hands, who practiced gunnery and horsemanship in swaddling clothes, and grew up into such walking arsenals, that each man of them could laugh a siege of ten Yankees to scorn; who were to be such thunderbolts in war that they would sweep victorious over every battle-field, sack Philadelphia, seize the money chests of New-York, and encamp their armies on the three hills of Boston -- we say, is it not humiliating to find these terrible sons-of-thunder retreating everywhere before their long-despised and villified enemies, and crying pitifully before the world that all they want is "peace" -- all they want is to be "let alone?"

abstract: That military operations of a decisive character will be much longer delayed seems improbable, in view of the active movements hourly occurring, which can have no other object in view.
lead_paragraph: That military operations of a decisive character will be much longer delayed seems improbable, in view of the active movements hourly occurring, which can have no other object in view. Since Friday last upwards of thirty rifled cannon have been sent into Virginia, besides other important paraphernalia of war; and in addition to the great body of troops already there, the New York Thirty-eighth and Greene's United States Battery went over yesterday, the Second Rhode Island was expected to go last night, and the New-York Twenty-third is under orders to move over this morning. The intrenchments across the Potomac are now almost entirely completed, and the batteries of frying artillery are taking their places at the right, left and centre of the lines, preparatory to a general advance. We may expect soon to hear stirring news from our Army opposite Washington.

abstract: Edward R. Wanderer vs. Thomas R. Foster et als. -- This was an action by the master of the ship Flora, to recover a balance of $3,787 90, claimed to be due him for wages and disbursements, during a three years' voyage of the ship. The master claimed that he had rendered his accounts and vouchers, and as alleged, the defendants refused to pay him, or to point out their objections to the account. The defendants therefore deny the whole account, and set up various counter claims, the principal one being that the master had brought the vessel home in ballast, instead of bringing home a cargo, which, it is alleged, he might have done with every facility. The motion is now made to compel the defendants to point out the portions of the account objected to, and to set up fully the items of the counter-claim. Decision reserved.
lead_paragraph: Edward R. Wanderer vs. Thomas R. Foster et als. -- This was an action by the master of the ship Flora, to recover a balance of $3,787 90, claimed to be due him for wages and disbursements, during a three years' voyage of the ship. The master claimed that he had rendered his accounts and vouchers, and as alleged, the defendants refused to pay him, or to point out their objections to the account. The defendants therefore deny the whole account, and set up various counter claims, the principal one being that the master had brought the vessel home in ballast, instead of bringing home a cargo, which, it is alleged, he might have done with every facility. The motion is now made to compel the defendants to point out the portions of the account objected to, and to set up fully the items of the counter-claim. Decision reserved.

abstract: The New-Orleans Crescent, of the 24th, contains several dispatches from Mississippi City, Pass Christian, Ocean Springs -- all on the coast between the mouths of the Mississippi and Mobile -- which seem to have thrown New-Orleans into a perfect tumult of excitement. From these dispatches, we learn that a National steamer, three smaller vessels, and tender, were inside of Ship Island; that the Sound was vigorously blocked; that the mailboat to Mobile was fired at eight times, and obliged to put back to New-Orleans; that three schooners had been taken, etc., etc. If SCOTT would send his whole fleet to threaten different portions of the Gulf coast, the rebels would have something else to do than feed on the fat and enjoy the cool breezes of Virginia. The Cotton States caused the war; let them enjoy some of the damage and discomforts it occasions. A few landings on South Carolina, Georgia and Alabama coasts would bring BEAUREGARD's army scampering home again to keep down their own slaves.

abstract: PUTNAM, to his elegant edition of IRVING, adds Bonneville, a narrative of the adventures of that famous Captain in the Rocky Mountains and the Far West.
lead_paragraph: -- PUTNAM, to his elegant edition of IRVING, adds Bonneville, a narrative of the adventures of that famous Captain in the Rocky Mountains and the Far West. Over the prairies we follow the gallant Captain and through the mountain fastnesses, now chasing Indians and anon being chased by them. It is needless to say that of the two exciting employments the former is by far the most pleasant. Many of the adventures are marvelous, and occasionally the reader will involuntarily raise an eyebrow; but the heresy is momentary and inadvertent. Who would deliberately doubt a story told by that veracious Diedrich Knickerbocker, whose history of New-York has become a standard book of reference both at home and abroad.

lead_paragraph: "A gentleman just arrived from Washington, describes having met there a lady who has recently come there from her home near Columbia, South Carolina, and who gave him a terrible picture of the condition of affairs there. abstract: In estimating the cost of the war that the National Government is now waging for its own existence against a most nefarious insurrection, our people are sometimes startled by the vast amount of money needed, and insidious traitors among us intrude the in- quiry, Is the reduction of the Southern hostility to the Government really worth the immense sum that will be required?...
lead_paragraph: In estimating the cost of the war that the National Government is now waging for its own existence against a most nefarious insurrection, our people are sometimes startled by the vast amount of money needed, and insidious traitors among us intrude the in- quiry, Is the reduction of the Southern hostility to the Government really worth the immense sum that will be required? But the loyal citizens of the country have not shrunk from the task of suppressing the rebellion, great as the task is, and although it may cost four hundred or six hundred millions of dollars, or even double these sums; and they have not stopped to consider whether the whole amount of the immense war debt will have to be paid out of the property and resources of the loyal States alone.

abstract: Why Brigadier BRAGG encamped before Fort Pickens these three weary months, while great reinforcements have been thrown into it, and its armament has been made complete, and a fleet has been added to its defences, has not made the long threatened attack, is one of those anomalies which puzzles others than London correspondents.
lead_paragraph: Why Brigadier BRAGG encamped before Fort Pickens these three weary months, while great reinforcements have been thrown into it, and its armament has been made complete, and a fleet has been added to its defences, has not made the long threatened attack, is one of those anomalies which puzzles others than London correspondents. The reason, we are taught to believe, is extremely simple. The South, by the confession of its journals and leaders, is almost destitute of gunpowder. It has men, and courage, and guns; it has no objection to sacrificing that pure Southern blood which we of the North, unworthy, seek to spill; it is not holding back in the hope of a compromise; nor has any angel of mercy spiked the eager cannon. None, indeed, of the manifold reasons which have been interpleaded to account for the indisposition of ex-Capt. BRAGG to spend a little more grape, or shell, or round shot, meets the case. It is simply the want of the fatal grain which brings all things to a pause. The holiday bombardment of Fort Sumter cost the very life blood of the rebel warfare. Fifty or a hundred tons of gunpowder are not to be had on demand at the retail groceries of Florida, or even in Virginia; and the difficulty is enhanced when the required article is to be of a specific kind, for which no substitute is admissible.

abstract: Thirty-three regular men-of-war celebrated the Fourth of July on the American coast this year. This is the first time so large a naval fleet honored the day. Every full Commodore or flag-officer, fired a national salute.
lead_paragraph: Thirty-three regular men-of-war celebrated the Fourth of July on the American coast this year. This is the first time so large a naval fleet honored the day. Every full Commodore or flag-officer, fired a national salute. Off Fort Monroe, the Minnesota, Cumberland, Roanoke and Santee, all discharged at noon, with splendid effect. The Niagara at Pickens, the Wabash at Charleston, the Mississippi at Mobile, the North Carolina at New-York, the Ohio at Boston, the Marion at Portsmouth, and the St. Lawrence off Philadelphia, all made a Union demonstration, covering a very wide area.

abstract: OPEN-AIR PREACHING. The New-York Evan- gelical Alliance initiated, yesterday, a series of openair Sabbath meetings, similar to the in-door meetings of last Winter. They propose to have these assem- blages, on fair days, in various portions of the City,...
lead_paragraph: OPEN-AIR PREACHING. -- The New-York Evan- gelical Alliance initiated, yesterday, a series of openair Sabbath meetings, similar to the in-door meetings of last Winter. They propose to have these assemblages, on fair days, in various portions of the City, and have the promise of addresses from clergymen of acknowledged ability, including Dr. TYNG, Dr. HAIGHT, Rev. ASA SMITH, Dr. HAGGERTY, Dr. THOMPSON, and others of various denominations. Dr. TYNG, who is President of the Alliance, made the opening address, yesterday, to a crowd of several hundred, in Astor place, in the shade of the Library Building, and in close proximity to St. Ann's Roman Catholic Church. Dr. TYNG explained the objects of the meeting, made an appropriate prayer and a stirring address. A number of patriotic arts religious songs were sung from the Union hymn-book. Rev. Mr. GOSS and others participated in the services.

abstract: War brings home to every household a certain degree of deprivation, and a certain obligation to self-denial. The wealthy feel its pressure in the form of a compulsory and unaccustomed economy; the poor realize it in the suspension of business, the absence of employment, and the want of the scanty wages upon which they have been content to sustain life.
lead_paragraph: War brings home to every household a certain degree of deprivation, and a certain obligation to self-denial. The wealthy feel its pressure in the form of a compulsory and unaccustomed economy; the poor realize it in the suspension of business, the absence of employment, and the want of the scanty wages upon which they have been content to sustain life. Suffering at such epochs is the rule rather than the exception; and if the grace of charity grows torpid and inactive, it is because benefactors and beneficiaries are equally subjected to conditions, to which they are unused, and which are big with a momentous uncertainty. We freeze up our hearts and clasp our purses, because we know nothing of the exigencies of our own circumstances to-morrow, the next day, and the next.

abstract: Having passed several sleepless nights, disturbed by the agonies and cries of a suffering child, and becoming convinced that Mrs. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply for the child. On reaching home, and acquainting his wife with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Homoeopathy. That night the child passed in suffering and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following, the father found the baby still worse, and, while contemplating another sleepless night, the mother stepped from the room to attend to some domestic duties, and left the father with the child. During her absence he administered a portion of the SOOTHING SYRUP to the baby, and said nothing. That night all hands slept well, and the little fellow awoke in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delighted with the sudden and wonderful change, and although at first offended at the deception practiced upon her, has continued to use the Syrup, and suffering, crying babies and restless nights have disappeared. A single trial of the Syrup never yet failed to relieve the baby, and overcome the prejudices of the mother.

abstract: The Government  of Spain, following the example of that of England and France, has cut off its citizens from the privilege of privateering under the authority of JEFF. DAVIS' Confederacy, and ...
lead_paragraph: -- The Government of Spain, following the example of that of England and France, has cut off its citizens from the privilege of privateering under the authority of JEFF. DAVIS' Confederacy, and has also forbidden the privateers who may take the risks of that calling, from remaining in Spanish ports or selling any stolen property there. This decree shuts up Cuba, Porto Rico and San Domingo, which were the most desirable markets for Southern buccaneers, and leaves the rebels with exceedingly, small margin for piratical operations. If Mexico should now give them the cold shoulder, and the Barbary States join, the crusade of civilization against them, the chivalric sons -- all gentlemen -- of the South, will conclude that this is indeed an uncharitable and inhospitable world.

abstract: "During July, of last year, the bark Mary Ann, Capt. CHAS. WILCOX, left New-Bedford for a whaling cruise. About six months from the time of sailing, while lying at anchor off Florida Keys, in company with some Provincetown vessels, she was seized by a privateer from the Confederate States, and taken to New-Orleans, in company with the other vessels seized. Capt. WILCOX, being a native of Georgia, was released, as also several subordinate officers and men. Those who belonged north of the Slavery line were thrown into prison. After remaining there for some considerable time, Master HENRY W. KELLY, a youth 14 years of age, a cabin-boy on board the Mary Ann, in company with two of his shipmates, escapedfrom jail by leaping from the window outside the yard, a distance of more than thirty feet. They started for the Free States without a cent of money in their pockets, sleeping in the woods nights, and begging food along the way. Master KELLY's two companions left him in New-York State, having traveled on foot the distance between New-Orleans and Albany, occupying, as near as they can calculate, two month. Young KELLY left Taunton in the morning train, to-day, for his home in New-Bedford. His appearance abundantly confirms the truth of his story. His apparel was extremely dilapidated, and the long journey had worn off the flesh from his body, giving him a skeleton-like appearance. He informed us that he suffered considerably from the pangs of hunger, and that he was often refused food on the journey, and ill-treated by those into whose hands he fell. He thinks he will remain at home during the remainder of the war."

abstract: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRS. WINSLOW? we will simply say that she is a lady who for upwards of 30 years, has untiringly devoted her time and talents as a female physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, so generally overlooked or carelessly treated by the faculty in too many instances; and, as a result of this effort, and practical knowledge obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article. Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children do certainly RISE UP and bless her; especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grave by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn will share its benefits and unite in calling her blessed. No MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it, mothers -- TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: It is a proof how wholly  unprepared was the last Congress for the direction events have taken since the 4th of March, that it failed to pass the bill of Mr. BINGHAM, authorizing the President to collect ...
lead_paragraph: -- It is a proof how wholly unprepared was the last Congress for the direction events have taken since the 4th of March, that it failed to pass the bill of Mr. BINGHAM, authorizing the President to collect the revenue at the Southern ports, or to close them. The omission has left foreign Powers at liberty to discuss the blockade in the light of international law, and to decide whether or not they would respect it, as if they were the interpreters of the code; whereas, had the ports been declared closed as a purely domestic measure, connected with the interests of the revenue service, the question would have been decided by ourselves, and so definitively, that for a European ship to enter a Southern port, even in the absence of a blockading fleet, would expose its officers arid crew to the penalties of smuggling. To place, the question in this position at the earliest possible moment is clearly our duty, and Congress cannot too promptly, authorize the President to take the necessary steps.

abstract: Up to the great rebellion, the civilization of the United States has been mainly a borrowed one. The early colonists reenacted the laws to which they had been trained, with slight ...
lead_paragraph: Up to the great rebellion, the civilization of the United States has been mainly a borrowed one. The early colonists reenacted the laws to which they had been trained, with slight modifications to adapt them to their new surroundings. The war of the Revolution was not to change, but to maintain these laws, sought to be subverted and overthrown by the British Crown. There was nothing new in the formation of the Confederation or of the Federal Government. This was simply the union of the several Colonies for mutual profit and protection. One has only to read the debates in the Convention for the formation of the Constitution, and the arguments to which the proposition gave rise, to see how sedulously every precedent was examined; to furnish guides for deliberation and action. Up to the adoption of the Constitution only a slight divergence of sentiment had prevailed between different parts of the country. A common necessity had imposed common occupations and common objects to all -- contests with savage tribes, and with a powerful nation which, for a long time, held the larger and fairer, portion of our country, and the incessant labor necessary to subdue a continent, and to provide the means for supporting life. The people were too poor to be luxurious, and too much engrossed in their labors to plot mischief either against each other or the Government. The white man worked by the side of the slave. The vicissitudes of frontier life preserved the whole people in energy and vigor. The only discordant element in the horizon was Slavery, and it was believed that this blot would soon disappear before the working of those beneficent principles announced in the Declaration of Independence, and embodied in the Constitution.

abstract: It would seem as if some potent Spirit of Evil had cast its incurable curse upon the War Department of this country. During a period of eight long years, that office has been ...
lead_paragraph: It would seem as if some potent Spirit of Evil had cast its incurable curse upon the War Department of this country. During a period of eight long years, that office has been administered in the exclusive interests of treason and corruption. In it were contrived the wicked plans for the subjugation of the struggling freemen of a whole persecuted State; in it high officers of the Army have been, one by one, suborned and corrupted, until, for a time at least, the very name of the Army conveyed with it the idea of possible infidelity and dishonor; in it financial frauds, wrongs and robberies, have been concocted on a scale so gigantic that all the frauds and defalcations of the past have been either forgotten or almost forgiven, in comparison with those which, during these eight years, have burst out of that hot-bed of wickedness and corruption. Around this Department have circulated characters whom honest men shun as the timid avoid the leprous; men whom it would be felt to be discreditable to know, and with or near whom no one careful of his reputation would willingly be seen. The names of DAVIS and FLOYD; the wrongs and blood of the persecuted people of Kansas; the robberies perpetrated upon the trust funds of the Indians; millions of dishonored acceptances; the sale of public property for nominal considerations, and its purchase by the corrupt associates of the Secretary; the treachery of officers of the Army as the only passport to official favor; perjury, bribery and desertion -these are the names, the acts and the facts with which the War Department has been closely associated in all this long period of Official degradation.

abstract: It is now becoming evident that the eleven new regiments ordered for the United States regular army cannot be raised in any seasonable time by the usual recruiting system.
lead_paragraph: It is now becoming evident that the eleven new regiments ordered for the United States regular army cannot be raised in any seasonable time by the usual recruiting system. The number of accepted men at all the rendezvous opened thus far -- and for each regiment there are four or five, and often more, offices -- do not exceed 140 per day, and at this rate it would require nearly half a year to organize the 19,000 soldiers required. There is an impression that ultimately the idea of these permanent regiments will be abandoned, there being already apparent a very formidable opposition to the retention. The regular army, if these were added to it, would consist of lit-less than 40,000 soldiers.

abstract: That Congress is disposed to push through the special business for which it was called together, in the shortest possible time, will be sufficiently evidenced by a perusal of the report of yesterday's proceedings.
lead_paragraph: That Congress is disposed to push through the special business for which it was called together, in the shortest possible time, will be sufficiently evidenced by a perusal of the report of yesterday's proceedings. The temper of the members is not to be mistaken. In the Senate a joint resolution was offered by Mr. WADE, of Ohio, and referred to the Committee on Finance, providing for the remission of all duties on arms imported for use in the suppression of rebellion. The joint resolution legalizing all the recent acts of the President, and the bill authorizing the employment of volunteers in enforcing the laws, were referred back from the Committee on Military Affairs, and laid over under the rule. They will probably be passed to-day. In the House, the Standing Committees were announced, and after some trifling changes the members went to work in good earnest. A disposition being shown by several to introduce unnecessary business to attention, the House adopted a resolution, introduced by Mr. HOLMAN, of Indiana, providing for the consideration only of those bills and resolutions concerning military and naval appropriations, and other financial affairs -- all other bills and resolutions to be referred without debate to the appropriate Committees, to be considered at the next regular session of Congress. This resolution was subsequently amended by adding a clause providing for the consideration of general questions of a judicial character, and thus stand for the guidance of legislation. Mr. LOVEJOY, of Illinois, offered a series of resolutions declaring against a return of fugitive slaves; instructing the Judiciary Committee to inquire into the expediency of repealing the Fugitive Slave Law, and censuring the authorities for restoring Major EMORY to the Army; but they were tabled, 87 to 62. The various branches of the President's Message were referred to the appropriate Committees, and the contested election cases were referred to the Committee on Elections. Mr. VAN WYCK, of New-York introduced a bill increasing the pay of soldiers, and providing for Government retrenchment by the reduction of salaries and other means; also, a resolution, which was adopted, providing for the appointment of a Special Committee to inquire into the matter of contracts. Among other important motions adopted, was one made by Mr. LOOMIS, of Connecticut, instructing the Judiciary Committee to prepare and report a bill to confiscate the property of all office-holders found in arms against the Government. An address was presented by Mr. DIVEN, and referred to the Judiciary Committe, declaring the determination of the Government to replace the flag of the Union over the whole Republic.

abstract: The expediency of an increase of the regular army of the United States is generally admitted, and the steps taken by President LINCOLN to augment that branch of the service by ...
lead_paragraph: The expediency of an increase of the regular army of the United States is generally admitted, and the steps taken by President LINCOLN to augment that branch of the service by the addition of 25,000 men will, no doubt, meet the ready approval of Congress. The entire number of the regular army will then be 42,000 men; and so far from attracting attention as a large force, we are sure it will generally be regarded as quite too small; considering the proportions the rebellion has attained, and the probability of extensive and lingering conflicts ahead.

abstract: This superb German regiment took its departure yesterday for the seat of war. When it is inspected by the practiced eye of Gen. SCOTT, it will, we are persuaded, win from the veteran a generous meed of ...
lead_paragraph: This superb German regiment took its departure yesterday for the seat of war. When it is inspected by the practiced eye of Gen. SCOTT, it will, we are persuaded, win from the veteran a generous meed of praise, which has not been exceeded by any other regiment from this State. The men are drawn from our best industrial classes. They are tough and tenacious of pupose, but well-informed and infinitely above the ordinary run of volunteers. The temper of the regiment has been formed by the officers, who are men of experience and social position. The Colonel, LEOPOLD VON GILSA, was educated in the military school of Germany, having commenced his studies at the age of ten years. He has seen service, and in the war of Schleswig-Holstein was decorated three times upon the field of battle. The Major (HOLMSTEAD) was an officer in our Mexican war, and returns to arms with the feelings of a victor. The Lieutenant-Colonel (DUYSING) is a Hessian by birth and a soldier by profession. The first company was formed by this officer, who may therefore be regarded in some degree as the father of the regiment. The Captains and Lieutenants are nearly all men who have seen active service. One of the number was mapograp r of the Geographical Society, and another was recently Assistant Engineer of the Central Park. Amongst the men are many who have seen from eight to ten years' service in European armies.

abstract: "A few weeks since, the United States Marshal seized thirteen of Colt's Navy revolvers at the express office in Cincinnati, which were found in two barrels of dried apples.
lead_paragraph: "A few weeks since, the United States Marshal seized thirteen of Colt's Navy revolvers at the express office in Cincinnati, which were found in two barrels of dried apples. The Enquirer says that the apples were sent on to Louisville to the parties to whom consigned. The pistols were claimed by M.J. MILLER, Esq., of Owensboro, Ky., who alleges that arms were purchased by him in the East to be distributed in his town for home protection; that he is a true, loyal citizen of the Union, and that as an insurrection among the negroes was apprehended in his neighborhood, the pistols were purchased to be used if such an event occurred. The District-Attorney filed an information in the United States District Court before Judge LEAVITT, on Thursday, asking that usual process be issued, confiscating the thirteen pistols to the use of the United States. Mr. MILLER, in his answer, sets forth that the pistols were purchased solely for himself and citizens of Owensboro, who are loyal to the Government of the United States, in the defence of the families and property of said town from negro insurrection and marauding parties. The case was supported on each side by evidence of witnesses and depositions. One witness stated that in Owensboro the Union men and Secessionists were equally divided; that he, with others, were apprehensive of an attack from Secessionists; that many Knights of the Golden Circle resided there, and were regarded as dangerous citizens, and that Owensboro was in JACKSON's district, recently elected to Congress who had proclaimed that he would vote men and means to sustain the Government of the United States. The case was continued for further hearing."

abstract: On the 3d inst., while in the act of arresting a horse that had become suddenly frightened at the blowing of a locomotive whistle, Mr. BARNUM was thrown violently upon his right shoulder, crushing the cap bone. His in jury, though severe, it will not prove fatal, but it must be several weeks before he can recover, as his nervous system is considerably affected by the severe injury.

abstract: The Charleston Courier, of July 1, has the following: "The South Carolina schooner Petrel, E.O. MURDEN commanding, left South Edisto on Saturday afternoon at 3 o'clock, passed North Edisto at 4 o'clock, and made Stono at 5 1/2 P.M. The officers report that they saw in sight two men-of-war, one a large man-of-war ship, and the other a barque-rigged vessel. These were seen about twenty miles to the northeast of Charleston bar. The Petrel ran in over the bar, passing the blockaders, was brought to by a shot from Fort Sumter when nearly abreast of Fort Johnson, and a few moments afterwards was hailed with another shot from Fort Moultrie. This occurred about 8 o'clock on Saturday evening, and no doubt gave rise to the current rumor that a boat from the blockading vessels, in attempting a landing, had been fired at from Sumter. The Petrel anchored in the stream off the battery yesterday morning, giving a salute as she dropped anchor. An officer on board reports the blockading vessels, on Sunday morning, immediately off the bar. The Petrel, while on service, seems to have been quite a mark for artillerists. During the action of Fort Sumter she was fired at several times from Fort Sumter, whilst engaged in carrying dispatches between Morris' and Sullivan's Islands, and thus keeping up communication."
lead_paragraph: The Charleston Courier, of July 1, has the following: "The South Carolina schooner Petrel, E.O. MURDEN commanding, left South Edisto on Saturday afternoon at 3 o'clock, passed North Edisto at 4 o'clock, and made Stono at 5 1/2 P.M. The officers report that they saw in sight two men-of-war, one a large man-of-war ship, and the other a barque-rigged vessel. These were seen about twenty miles to the northeast of Charleston bar. The Petrel ran in over the bar, passing the blockaders, was brought to by a shot from Fort Sumter when nearly abreast of Fort Johnson, and a few moments afterwards was hailed with another shot from Fort Moultrie. This occurred about 8 o'clock on Saturday evening, and no doubt gave rise to the current rumor that a boat from the blockading vessels, in attempting a landing, had been fired at from Sumter. The Petrel anchored in the stream off the battery yesterday morning, giving a salute as she dropped anchor. An officer on board reports the blockading vessels, on Sunday morning, immediately off the bar. The Petrel, while on service, seems to have been quite a mark for artillerists. During the action of Fort Sumter she was fired at several times from Fort Sumter, whilst engaged in carrying dispatches between Morris' and Sullivan's Islands, and thus keeping up communication."

abstract: The very large and steadily increasing circulation of the TIMES gives constant occasion for remonstrance as to the tardiness with which it is delivered to subscribers in New-York and Brooklyn. The attention of the proprietors has for some time been directed to obviating this defect. They are now enabled to announce that in the course of a few days such arrangements will be perfected as will cause a much earlier delivery of the entire morning edition, and thus remove all ground of complaint.

abstract: The Wheeling Intelligencer of July 8 says: "From a gentleman who arrived in this city on Saturday evening, from Roane County, and from letters received from Mason, we learn that the rebel troops in the Kenawha Valley are continually arresting and outraging Union men, and destroying their property. There is no doubt but that WISE is in the vicinity of Charlestown, in command of a force of 4,000 men, which is augmenting daily. A minister reports that he saw him in his carriage between Lewisburgh and Charlestown, traveling in the direction of the latter place, one day last week. A young man was arrested in Charlestown, week before last, was discharged on the Saturday following, and arrived at Point Pleasant on Sunday. He says he saw the Ex-Governor there when he left. The young man made various other statements as to the movements of the rebel cavalry towards Jackson and Roane Counties, which movements are known from other information to have actually been made. O. JENNINGS WISE is the leader of the marauding party in Jackson County.

abstract: If rumors are not altogether unfounded, there has been no little dissatisfaction felt and expressed in high quarters at Washington, with the determined vigor and rapidity of Gen. LYON'S movements in Missouri against
lead_paragraph: If rumors are not altogether unfounded, there has been no little dissatisfaction felt and expressed in high quarters at Washington, with the determined vigor and rapidity of Gen. LYON'S movements in Missouri against the Secessionists. Having been left, necessarily, to a certain degree of discretion, Gen. LYON looked at the patent fact that his Government was at war with traitors; that the public enemies were active and untiring in their malevolence, and let no opportunity slip to deal a foul blow to the country. And Gen. LYON followed only the faithful soldier's impulse, in such circumstances, to disarm the enemy whenever he could, and whip him when he could not.

abstract: John Fowler vs. John Hecker, et al. -- This was a motion to show cause why an execution should not be set aside which had been issued upon a judgment entered in this Court. Affidavits were read showing that the defendants had duly issued a writ of error to the Supreme Court, and had given security on the appeal. Plaintiff claimed that no writ of error had been left for him in the Clerk's office, but the defendant showing that the writ had been served on the defendant personally, after hearing counsel the Court ordered that all proceedings on the Judgment be staved.
lead_paragraph: John Fowler vs. John Hecker, et al. -- This was a motion to show cause why an execution should not be set aside which had been issued upon a judgment entered in this Court. abstract: COMMON COUNCIL. -- A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen was held Monday evening, when considerable routine business of no general interest was transacted. A resolution, presented by Alderman STRONG, directing that a drill-room be hired for the Washington Grays, now being raised in the Eastern District, was adopted. On motion of Alderman J.G. TAYLOR, PETER GREEN was appointed Deputy Comptroller, at a salary of $1,000 per annum.

abstract: The business of Congress, yesterday, was cut short by the announcement of the death of Senator DOUGLAS, notwithstanding which, however, a number of important measures were acted upon in both Houses. In the Senate, a motion made
lead_paragraph: The business of Congress, yesterday, was cut short by the announcement of the death of Senator DOUGLAS, -- notwithstanding which, however, a number of important measures were acted upon in both Houses. In the Senate, a motion made by Mr. FESSENDEN, of Maine, that all petitions not necessarily connected with war matters be laid on the table, was carried. The bill to refund and remit duties paid on arms imported by loyal States, was reported back from the Finance Committee and passed. The bill to increase the Army was reported back from the Military Committee, with an amendment increasing the old regiments to the same number as the new. Action on this was postponed for the eulogies on Senator DOUGLAS, which were pronounced by Senators TRUMBULL, MCDOUGALL, COLLAMER, and others. In the House, the first business was the passage of a bill appropriating six millions for the payment of the militia and volunteers recently called into service. A Loan bill was reported from the Committee of Ways and Means, and will be called up to-day. The Committee on Commerce was instructed to inquire if any further legislation is necessary to secure the forfeiture and condemnation of piratical vessels. The same Committee reported a bill, which was ordered to be printed and recommitted, further to provide for the collection of duties on imports, etc. This bill is designed to close the ports of entry in the seceded States, to make ports of delivery ports of entry in certain cases, and to provide for the collection of duties on shipboard whenever it may be necessary. Mr. LOVEJOY, of Illinois, introduced a resolution, which constituted one of the series introduced by him on Monday, declaring that it is no part of the duty of soldiers of the United States to capture or return fugitive slaves. Mr. LOVEJOY demanded the previous question on this resolution, and it was passed -- 92 to 55. The death of Judge DOUGLAS was then announced, and no further business was done.

abstract: Judge GEO. W. THOMPSON, of Wheeling, has written a bitter protest against the movement recently inaugurated in Western Virginia. He denounces the
lead_paragraph: Judge GEO. W. THOMPSON, of Wheeling, has written a bitter protest against the movement recently inaugurated in Western Virginia. He denounces the "present usurped and tyrannical despotism in Western. Virginia;" declares his belief "that an agent of the Wall-street Virginia bondholders was, during the sittings of the Convention, in Wheeling, promoting the scheme for reorganization of the State, with the countenance and support of the Administration, whose confidential communications he bore, and who, upon his arrest in Western Virginia, was discharged on the order of a high functionary at Washington."

abstract: Having passed several sleepless nights, disturbed by the agonies and cries of a suffering child, and becoming convinced that Mrs. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply for the child. On reaching home, and acquainting his wife with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Homoeopathy. That night the child passed in suffering and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following, the father found the baby still worse and, while contemplating another sleepless night, the mother stepped from the room to attend to some domestic duties, and left the father with the child. During her absence he administered a portion of the SOOTHING SYRUP to the baby, and said nothing. That night all hands slept well, and the little fellow awoke in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delighted with the sudden and wonderful change, and although at first offended at the deception practiced upon her, has continued to use the Syrup, and suffering, crying babies and restless nights have disappeared. A single trial of the Syrup never yet failed to relieve the baby, and overcome the prejudices of the mother.

abstract: A story which reaches us from our well-informed correspondent at Paris shows that the cause of the Confederate rebels is as desperate in the Old World as it is in the New. Failing in acting upon the sympathies and self-interest of England through the cotton crop; hopeless of securing European recognition without military successes, they are conscious they can never obtain; disappointed by the very marked and universal reprobation and discouragement their projected system of privateering receives where they had expected approval and connivance, if not open aid, they have at last been brought to play their last card, which is certainly a court-card of very high apparent value. To a member of the BONAPARTE family they have offered the crown of the Southern Empire, on condition of his assuming the command of their armies, and making good his independence of the National Government. The fact that this sublime proposition was as sublimely declined is a matter of very little moment. But the important point is that all the superb expectations the conspirators founded upon the good seed of their European diplomacy have culminated in this utter and final defeat.
lead_paragraph: A story which reaches us from our well-informed correspondent at Paris shows that the cause of the Confederate rebels is as desperate in the Old World as it is in the New. abstract: A meeting of "The Association for the Increase and Extension of American Commerce" was held in the American Exchange Bank Building, corner of Broadway and Cedar-street, on Tuesday, July 9, 1861. JAMES GALLATIN, Esq., President of the Association, occupied the Chair. The meeting was held to consider a report on the present state of the commerce of the United States, and its most urgent necessities. The report was submitted by the President, on behalf of the Committee, consisting of James Gallatin, Wllliam A. Booth, Samuel B. Ruggles, George D. Lyman and John Eadie, and was unanimously adopted.

abstract: Kentucky's aggregate Union majority on the 20th ult. exceeded 50,000 it was nealry or quite 60,000. abstract: It seems to me that there is much misapprehension regarding the risks our soldiers are likely to run in consequence of exposures in a hot climate. I have traveled extensively in the Southern States at all seasons of the year, and have consequently had excellent opportunities for making observations on this subject, and am fully convinced that such of our forces as are at all fitted to endure the fatigue of a soldier's life will be much better fitted to endure the hot climate than those in the rebel ranks.

abstract: The Mobile Register says: "We have reason to know that the Confederate Government is in possession of dispatches from its Commissioners in Europe as late as May 24. We are betraying no secret of the Government at Richmond, because our information does not come from any member of it. At the date alluded to Mr. YANCEY was in London; Judge ROST was in Paris, and had had two interviews with the Emperor. The particulars of those interviews we should not state if we could. But there is no harm in saying that the result was of a character highly gratifying to our Commissioners and to the friends of their country. The French Emperor understands the questions at the bottom of the American revolution far better than LINCOLN or any of the Northern rulers who are now running the 'old wreck' high and dry ashore with all their might. 'Set a beggar on horseback,' says the old proverb, 'and he will ride to the devil.' LINCOLN and crew are beggarly statesmen, and, before many moons, will be a 'stench in the nostrils' of all civilized men, as they are now in those of the people of the South, and growing daily to be in those of Europe. In England the Southern cause hourly gains strength and friends. Every step of the Lincoln Government has damaged it abroad. SEWARD's braggadocia dispatches and CASSIUS M. CLAY's silly letter to the London Times have prejudiced their authors and helped the South.

abstract: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRS. WINSLOW? we will simply say that she is a lady who for upwards of 30 years, has untiringly devoted her time and talents as a female physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, so generally overlooked or carelessly treated by the faculty in too many instances; and, as a result of this effort, and practical knowledge obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article. Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children do certainly RISE UP and bless her, especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grave by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn will share its benefits and unite in calling her blessed. No MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it, mothers -- TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: A friend, says the Baltimore American, has handed us a letter found in the pocket of an officer in the Confederate forces, written to a friend in Richmond. He was, with several others, surprised near Great Bethel by some of Gen. BUTLER'S scouts, and escaped,
lead_paragraph: A friend, says the Baltimore American, has handed us a letter found in the pocket of an officer in the Confederate forces, written to a friend in Richmond. He was, with several others, surprised near Great Bethel by some of Gen. BUTLER'S scouts, and escaped, leaving their coats hanging on the limb of a tree. In speaking of the New-Orleans Zouaves, which he calls "JEFF. DAVIS' Pet Wolves," he says: "They were here only about twenty-four hours, and in that time killed only four cows, together with sheep and pigs too numerous to mention; they are without doubt the hardest set I ever saw." He continues: "We have been getting on quite comfortably here, as we manage to get a few extras occasionally by buying them. But we have not received anything in the way of meat from the Commissary except salt bacon, and most of the time the most abominable flour you ever saw; in fact, the bread made from it is so heavy that it is dangerous to go swimming after a meal, for fear of sinking."

abstract: Our news to-day is that Gen. BRAGG is exceedingly uneasy before Fort Pickens, fearing an attack from the National forces, and that he has sent to Richmond for 4,000 troops to enable him to maintain his position. Perhaps he will get them; but we are of opinion that the people about Richmond will never feel less inclined to send away 4,000 men than just now; and then, would it not be unhealthy down there in dog-days?

abstract: It is very much to be regretted that South Carolina, the front and origin of our National woes, and the saucy provocator of the war, should be exempted from the immediate punishment her people well deserve. Retributive
lead_paragraph: It is very much to be regretted that South Carolina, the front and origin of our National woes, and the saucy provocator of the war, should be exempted from the immediate punishment her people well deserve. Retributive justice exacts that the horrors she has scattered over the Border States should be sent home to the place of their nativity, and the chivalrous descendants of convict sires should be made to suffer the extreme penalty of guilt which thirty years of persistence has made inveterate and incurable. Up to this moment she has had nothing but prosperity in crime. The military prestige of the campaign, until Gen. LYON started in pursuit of a runaway Governor of Missouri, was entirely hers. Her soldiers passed northward into Virginia flushed with the opening victory of the war. Ruin, to be sure, has fallen upon her material interests; her railroads are unemployed; banking capital is idle or squandered in Confederate bonds; her warehouses and wharves are deserted; but these calamities she suffers in common with all the Stakes, including those whose loyally would have saved them from such evils but for this pestilent little member of the Union. What we have a right to demand is some special allotment of punishment to fall heavily upon the originators of this National trouble. The people chafes at the sight of the tranquility and apparent comfort of the community, which has destroyed quiet and comfort everywhere else; and wants to know if steps are not to be taken to bring the delinquent to special and vindictive justice. And any termination of the war, which should fail to place the National flag upon Sumter, not as the result of compromise and concession, but of absolute submission, would certainly provoke an irrepressible outburst of popular indignation.
headline: {'main': 'South Carolina Not to Go Unpunished.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'South Carolina Not to Go Unpunished.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Within a few days unmistakable evidence has been forced upon us from every quarter, that Secession is really in its last throes. Hereafter, it is to oppose no formidable resist- ance at any given point, the peculiar institution requiring all the able-bodied men in every portion of the South to remain at home as a local police. Even in the great strait in which...
lead_paragraph: Within a few days unmistakable evidence has been forced upon us from every quarter, that Secession is really in its last throes. Hereafter, it is to oppose no formidable resist- ance at any given point, the peculiar institution requiring all the able-bodied men in every portion of the South to remain at home as a local police. Even in the great strait in which Virginia is placed, with a hundred thousand National troops upon her soil, and upon the eve of a battle which is to decide the fate of Secession, the South Carolina regiments recently stationed at Manassas Gap are on their way home. Nothing can be more significant than this of the condition of affairs in that State. Not even the recent announcement of Gov. PICKENS to the Confederate Government that no more of its troops can be sent beyond its own limits. The battle to be fought in Virginia concerns South Carolina as much as if it was to be fought on her own soil. The Confederate Government, of which she is really the author, and with the maintenance of which secession is identified, is located at Richmond. If driven from this place, the cause is utterly lost. Yet, in this crowning emergency, South Carolina, the great author of the rebellion, and which is to be disgraced and ruined if this rebellion is crushed, can render no further aid. All her soldiers are required for the preservation of domestic order, to repress insurrections of slaves. Georgia is in a similar condition. Her Governor has just announced that no more of her soldiers can be sent to other States, not even to poor Virginia, which has so adroitly been made the battle-field. Alabama is stated to have made a similar order in reference to the troops of that State. The recent proclamation of the Governor of Mississippi, in reference to the arming of that State with double-barreled shot-guns shows that the emergency there is a negro insurrection, not the repelling of the National troops, who are not to be driven back by such weapons.

abstract: We have received frequent complaints from masters of vessels arriving at this port, of the unofficial and ungentlemanly conduct of the United States Consul at Matanzas, Dr. HUGH MARTIN. abstract: "It will be remembered that last week Lieut.-Col. BLOOD'S battalion, of Col. BLAND'S regiment, went to Pilot Knob, and thence to Farmington, Francois County, Mo. At 5 o'clock Saturday evening a party returned from the battalion, bringing four prisoners,
lead_paragraph: "It will be remembered that last week Lieut.-Col. BLOOD'S battalion, of Col. BLAND'S regiment, went to Pilot Knob, and thence to Farmington, Francois County, Mo. At 5 o'clock Saturday evening a party returned from the battalion, bringing four prisoners, who are now at the Arsenal. The party consists of Adjutant GANTT, Major WALKER. (Surgeon.) W.F. MCCHESNEY, hospital steward, and two privates.

abstract: We have already, in its proper place, announced the death of ABRAHAM B. SANDS, Esq., who was widely known throughout our country as a merchant of high standing, and who, by his energy and business qualifications, accumulated a large fortune. But it was in this City that he was known and appreciated for his moral and social qualities, and for his earnest cooperation in benevolent Christian enterprises. While possessing a modest and retiring spirit, he was placed by others in positions of great responsibility and trust, requiring all the tact of the business man with the unction of the Christian. He was for a number of years a vestryman of Trinity Church, and as a financier he will long be missed by that body, which has, within the last few years, done so much in the care of Trinity's munificent endowments. Mr. SANDS was also for some time a member of the Board of the Protestant Episcopal Sunday School Union, and oftentimes sent its publications to the remotest parts of our globe. Of our great charitable institutions, he was probably more attached to St. Luke's Hospital than to any other. He was active in the foundation of this much needed charity, and was one of the Board of Managers. From its inception until the day of his death he was ever vigilant with his fellow-managers in promoting its efficiency. "The good citizen, the devoted husband, and the kind father," are stereotyped terms of obituary, but in their fullest sense they may be applied to Mr. SANDS, with the addition of the highest term in our language, he was a faithful Christian.

abstract: A majority of the Committee of the State Convention of Missouri, charged with the duty of convening that Convention at such time prior to the third Monday in December, 1861, and at such place as they may think the public exigencies require, have just issued a call for the Convention to meet at Jefferson City, on the 22d day of the present month. We are authoritatively informed that the programme agreed on for the Convention is to depose Gov. JACKSON, Lieutenant-Governor T.C. REYNOLDS, and the State Legislature now in office, and proceed to elect, by the Convention, a new set of Executive officers. ROBERT WILSON, of AndrewCounty, (the county next north of Buchanan, in which St. Joseph is situated,) is spoken of as the probable new Governor. JOHN B. HENDERSON, of Pike County, (on the Mississippi River, south of Hannibal,) is also mentioned very favorably in this connection. Mr. WILSON is a farmer, of the old Clay school of politics, and has been long prominent and much honored among all parties of Missouri. Mr. HENDERSON is a much younger man, a lawyer of ability, and was a warm Douglas Democrat in the late Presidential campaign. Both gentlemen are decided and unconditional Union men, and both members of the present Missouri State Convention.

abstract: The branch office in the Fourth-avenue, belonging to the Union Defence Committee, and which was opened expressly for the relief of the families of volunteers, remained closed yesterday. All families who wanted immediate relief were told to go to the Ward Committees. The proceeds arising from Mr. EVERETT's oration at the Academy of Music amounted to $1,300; out of this $200 is due for the use of the Academy. The trustees have been written to by Mr. EVERETT, and asked to remit the amount and add it to the fund. The only aid that volunteers' families can receive is from this source, until another appropriation is made by the City, or until the State or General Government refunds some of the money that has been spent on different regiments by the Committee.

abstract: We learn that the steamer Chester, Capt. E.S. L. YOUNG, was taken possession of at her wharf at 4 o'clock yesterday morning, by order of Provost Mar
lead_paragraph: We learn that the steamer Chester, Capt. E.S. L. YOUNG, was taken possession of at her wharf at 4 o'clock yesterday morning, by order of Provost Marshal KENLY, for an expedition to the mouth of the Potomac which admitted of no delay. The Chester was firing up for her usual trip to Charlestown, and was ready for immediate service. She proceeded directly to Fort McHenry, where Gen. BANKS had in readiness an armament of two 24-pounders, an artillery company, an infantry company, and a posse of police officers, under Lieut. CARMICHAEL and Officer HORNER, which were soon placed on board, and she steamed down the river. Orders were also immediately given to stop all the bay steamers that usually start at an early hour, to prevent any possibility of information being given that might temp to the defeat of the purposes of the expedition.

abstract: If the telegraphic reports from the West are to be credited, there has been fought in Missouri by far the most serious battle of the war. The account is that on last Friday, as GOV. JACKSON, with from ten thousand to
lead_paragraph: If the telegraphic reports from the West are to be credited, there has been fought in Missouri by far the most serious battle of the war. The account is that on last Friday, as GOV. JACKSON, with from ten thousand to thirteen thousand secession troops, was marching southward towards Carthage, the county seat of Jasper County, a southwest border county of Missouri, pretty near to the Indian Territory, he was met by Col. SEIGEL, of the United States forces, at the head of about fifteen hundred men. The collision occurred about seven miles north of Carthage. Col. SIEGEL gave battle, and the Secessionists fell back, suffering greatly, Gov. JACKSON, or his officers, ordered a retreat, but his flanks did not hear the order, and the advancing United States troops soon found themselves nearly surrounded, and were obliged to retire. They retreated slowly, keeping up the fight, the artillery making "fearful havoe" in the secession ranks. The battle continued until dark, when Col. SEIGEL reached Carthage, where he had 400 reserves. Col. SEIGEL's total loss, in this day's work, is reported to be five killed and two mortally wounded, with, of course, an average of minor casualties. The secession loss is reported to be very large, but as they advanced and occupied the field of battle at the close, no correct account of it can be given. One informant reports having seen between seventy and eighty wounded in houses by the wayside.

abstract: At a special meeting of the Board, held at 1 o'clock yesterday, a report was received from the Spe- cial Committee appointed to provide for the relief of the families of volunteers, in which the Committee
lead_paragraph: At a special meeting of the Board, held at 1 o'clock yesterday, a report was received from the Spe- cial Committee appointed to provide for the relief of the families of volunteers, in which the Committee believe that the $250,000 recommended by them, in a former report, to be raised by issuing County revenue bonds, can be appropriated much sooner by using the unexpended balance of last year's County fund. It appears that the total amount appropriated for County purposes last year was- $3,651,247 53, of which only $3,371,590 58 has been expended, leaving in the Treasury a balance of $279,656 95, and the Committee advised the using of this balance for the benefit of the families. Of the unexpended fund it had been designed to appropriate for arrearages, $9,382 06; for Harlem Bridge, $220 64; for Coroners fees $7. 143 48; for County contingencies, $17,232 08; for election expenses, $11,675 99; for lighting, cleaning, and supplies, $4,027 13 : for officers and witnesses' fees, $1,746 36; for rent, $5,343 34; for repairs, $5,398 90; for new Court-House, $100,000. It was not thought advisable that the families should be compelled to wait for aid, simply because the Board were in doubt as to their power to sue revenue bonds. Attached was a resolution authorizing the Comptroler to draw his warrant for the sum of $163,070 18 -- amount of balances of the appropriations for the support of the County Government for 1860 -- and tender the same to the Union Defence Committee, to be used exclusively for the support of the families of volunteers from the City and County of New-York, and that the said Committee be required to report the disposition of the fund when called upon for that purpose by the Board.

abstract: The brig Triton, captured as a slaver off the Coast of Africa on the 20th of April last, arrived at this port on Tuesday, having been sent home by the United States ship Constellation, with the captain and five of the crew of the Triton. The officer sent home in charge of the prisoners, anchored the brig off the Navy-yard, about one hundred yards from the receiving ship North Carolina, and, as he says, called upon the Commodore for assistance to take charge of his prisoners while he reported his arrival to the United States Marshal, which the Commodore refused. At any rate, while the officer was off reporting the case to the Marshal, three of his prisoners escaped from the brig, and have not since been heard of. Among those who escaped was the captain of the Triton, who, when captured, gave his name as JAMES PERCY, and JOHN WILLIAMS and JOHN MORRIS. The other three prisoners, named HOWARD, ALLAN and CONNER, were yesterday taken in charge by United States Marshal MURRAY, and locked up in the Tombs to await examination.
lead_paragraph: The brig Triton, captured as a slaver off the Coast of Africa on the 20th of April last, arrived at this port on Tuesday, having been sent home by the United States ship Constellation, with the captain and five of the crew of the Triton. Among those who escaped was the captain of the Triton, who, when captured, gave his name as JAMES PERCY, and JOHN WILLIAMS and JOHN MORRIS. abstract: WINTER GARDEN. If those from whom we expect gallantry were not absent at the war, we should feel disposed to cavil at the slight which a pretty and talented lady experienced last night when she ap-
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- If those from whom we expect gallantry were not absent at the war, we should feel disposed to cavil at the slight which a pretty and talented lady experienced last night when she appealed to her friends and admirers for that support which an actress rarely fails to secure at the close of an arduous season. Mrs. CHANFRAU, whose benefit we are referring to, did not meet with the hearty compliment to which she is fairly entitled. The house was moderately filled; it ought to have been crowded. Under ordinary circumstances we are sure that this result would have been attained, but in times like these who can tell what fate has in store even for her favorite?

abstract: We are not of those who think it is by any means very probable that the present conflict in this country will involve us immediately in a foreign war. But it has unfortunately been
lead_paragraph: We are not of those who think it is by any means very probable that the present conflict in this country will involve us immediately in a foreign war. But it has unfortunately been made only too apparent to the American public, that the most free, as the most powerful nation of the Old World -- the one of all others for whose kind sympathies and moral support we should have naturally, if not confidently, looked, in the pending struggle between the hostile principles of Freedom and Despotism on this continent -- has shown a forward inclination to favor the Southern rebellion in its matured effort to divide and destroy our peaceful and, perhaps, too prosperous country.

abstract: The trial of Charles Jefferds for the murder of his stepfather, Mr. John Walton, on the night of the 30th of June, 1860, commenced in this Court yester- day. A good deal of interest was excited in the public
lead_paragraph: The trial of Charles Jefferds for the murder of his stepfather, Mr. John Walton, on the night of the 30th of June, 1860, commenced in this Court yester- day. A good deal of interest was excited in the public mind by this murder at the time of its occurrence, and the circumstances attending it, as brought out on the Coroner's Inquest, are no doubt still fresh to most readers. The unusual delay in bringing the case to trial has been the subject of much comment, and not a little complaint from the friends of the prisoner; but the peculiarity of the case, presenting as it did so many points indicating the probable guilt of the prisoner, and yet lacking almost entirely that kind of evidence which would be likely to convict him before a jury, has furnished a reason and perhaps a justification to the District-Attorney for putting off the trial of the case, in hopes that new evidence might come to light which would render the prisoner's conviction more sure, or, if acquitted, that his innocence might be less doubtful.

abstract: Another important battle, or rather brace of battles, has been fought in Missouri. The dis- patches announcing these occurrences are con- tradictory, and evidently of an exaggerated char
lead_paragraph: Another important battle, or rather brace of battles, has been fought in Missouri. The dis- patches announcing these occurrences are con- tradictory, and evidently of an exaggerated character; but making all due allowances for exaggerations, and steering carefully between the contradictions, we arrive at a tolerably fair idea of the truth. Gov. JACKSON -- who, it appears, did not fly to Arkansas as reported -- and Gen. RAINS, at the head of at least ten thousand State troops, were met on Friday last at Brier Forks, near Carthage, by Col. SIEGEL, at the head of only fifteen hundred National troops, who immediately gave them battle. The State troops, notwithstanding their immense numerical superiority, were driven back, and the order was given to retreat. Col. SIEGEL, finding that in following the enemy his command was likely to become surrounded, ordered his command back, and then retired slowly, keeping up a murderous fire of artillery all the while. In this way Col. SIEGEL continued retiring until he received a reinforcement of two hundred men, when he again assumed the offensive, and drove JACKSON's forces back with great slaughter. The National loss in this affair appears to have been inconsiderable, while that of the State troops, it is thought, cannot be less than from three to five hundred. A later dispatch states that Col. SIEGEL's force, while encamped on the succeeding night, was attacked by Gov. JACKSON and severely cut up. This, however, we consider improbable, from the fact that on the 6th he was reported to have been reinforced by Gen. SWEENEY with his entire force, and to be in pursuit of JACKSON's army near Vernon. JACKSON had announced his intention to fortify himself at Carthage, and to await the arrival of Gen. PRICE and BEN. MCCULLOUGH from Arkansas, with reinforcements, when he would act on the offensive, and "enforce the laws of the State." He has probably by this time changed his mind.

abstract: Orders were received at the head-quarters of the army on Monday to send on to the seat of war at once the company of the First Artillery part of the Fort Sumter garrison which remained at Fort Hamilton. Instructions were immediately sent down to
lead_paragraph: Orders were received at the head-quarters of the army on Monday to send on to the seat of war at once the company of the First Artillery part of the Fort Sumter garrison which remained at Fort Hamilton. Instructions were immediately sent down to the brave fellows, who were under arms for the road in a few moments. The old ensign of Sumter went along with them, as they believed "there would be no luck in the company without it."

abstract: We are advised by telegraph that Mr. LOVEJOY, of Illinois, introduced a resolution on Tuesday to the effect, that "in the judgment of the House, it is no part of the duty of sol-
lead_paragraph: We are advised by telegraph that Mr. LOVEJOY, of Illinois, introduced a resolution on Tuesday to the effect, that "in the judgment of the House, it is no part of the duty of soldiers of the United States to capture or return fugitive slaves." Mr. MALLORY (Unionist, of Kentucky,) moved to lay the resolution on the table. Mr. CARLISLE (Unionist, of Virginia,) unsuccessfully sought to submit an amendment. But under the operation of the previous question, which cut off all debate, the resolution was passed by a vote of 92 to 55.

abstract: Baron RICASOLI presented in the Chamber of Deputies the diplomatic correspondence of France and Italy relative to the recognition of the new kingdom.
lead_paragraph: Baron RICASOLI presented in the Chamber of Deputies the diplomatic correspondence of France and Italy relative to the recognition of the new kingdom. The following is a summary of the French note. The Emperor, on the demand of VICTOR EMANUEL, recognizes him as the King of Italy, but by this recognition he does not approve of the past policy of the Cabinet of Turin, nor does he encourage the enterprises of a nature to compromise the peace of Europe. The Emperor regards the principle of non-intervention as a rule, but declines the responsibility of any project of aggression. The French troops will continue at Rome as long as the interests which took France to Rome are not covered by guarantees.
