abstract: The speech of Mr. MALLORY, of Kentucky, delivered yesterday in the House of Representatives, will attract general attention and applause. Mr. MALLORY represents the Louisville District. He was elected by about ten thousand majority, and he delivered just such speeches in his canvass before the election, as he has now uttered at Washington. Mr. MALLORY's remarks were in reply to the intimation of his secession colleague (BURNETT,) of a factious opposition to het war policy of Mr. LINCOLN. Mr. MALLORY gave notice that he was prepared to support the Government by voting all the men and all the money that might be required to crush the rebellion against it. We are happy to believe that Mr. MALLORY expresses the sentiments not only of all his colleagues in the House, except BURNETT, but of the 60,000 majority of Union votes in Kentucky, who returned them to their present seats. Mr. MALLORY is a Virginian by birth, but a loyal Union man and patriot of the HENRY CLAY school.

abstract: Daniel G. Bacon et al. vs. William Hickock and six others The action in this case is brought upon a bond of indemnity, conditioned to pay the amount of $7,927,71, the gross amount of three several promissory notes, made by the Damascus Iron Company.
lead_paragraph: Daniel G. Bacon et al. vs. William Hickock and six others -- The action in this case is brought upon a bond of indemnity, conditioned to pay the amount of $7,927,71, the gross amount of three several promissory notes, made by the Damascus Iron Company. The bond of indemnity was given by the defendants, pursuant to an agreement containing several recitals, among which were the following: "And the said obligees (plaintiffs) have consented to discontinue said suit, and extend such time of payment by taking new notes, as hereinafter mentioned, provided the above-named obligors will become individually and personally bound to said obligees as indorsers on such new notes, to which condition the obligors have assented, except that they prefer to fix their liability in this behalf by a bond of indemnity, instead of indorsements, to which preference the said obligees have yielded their assent." Then follows the obligation in these words: "Now, therefore, the condition of the above obligation is such, that if the said Company shall well and truly pay the three several promissory notes given herein, when they become due, and if the obligors shall well and truly, indemnify the said obligees of and from all loss and damage, by reason of such non-payment, then the obligation to be void." The Company failed to pay. An action was brought on the bond, for the non-payment of one of these notes. The complaint did not show that there had been any notice of demand on the notes given to the defendants, as indorsers, and it did not show that the plaintiffs had endeavored to collect the money of the Company, and had failed to collect it. The defendants demurred to this complaint, and assigned as their objections -- that, although the security was in the form of a bond, the liability of the defendants was strictly that of indorsers, and they were entitled to be treated in all respects as such, before they could be made liable on the bond. Counsel further contended that actual loss and damage must be averred before the plaintiffs could recover of the defendants. Such a loss was best shown by proving an attempt to collect the notes of the makers.

abstract: Lieut. REDDING left on Tuesday evening for the seat of war with a detachment of 150 recruits for the seat of war with a detachment of 150 recruits for the Fourteenth Regiment, Col. A.M. WOOD, now stationed at Arlington Heights. Lieut-Col. FOWLER, of
lead_paragraph: Lieut. REDDING left on Tuesday evening for the seat of war with a detachment of 150 recruits for the seat of war with a detachment of 150 recruits for the Fourteenth Regiment, Col. A.M. WOOD, now stationed at Arlington Heights. Lieut-Col. FOWLER, of the same Regiment, remains yet at the State Arsenal in this City, to receive 100 more recruits. The last detachment was composed of as fine a body of men as has yet left Brooklyn. They are well clothed and thoroughly equipped, and will give a good account of themselves in the field. The recruiting for this Regiment has gone on very briskly, and the officer on duty here could have enlisted a whole regiment had he accepted all who applied; but to the contrary, he accepts only those who are sound in every way, and from these he selects the best. The Fourteenth, Col. WOOD, is one of the regular State Militia regiments, and first offered their services under the three months' call, but too late to be accepted, when they gallantly offered their services for three years unless sooner discharged, and were accepted. It is now said to be one of the best drilled and one of the best disciplined regiments in the service.

abstract: The News from St. Domingo is important, a bloody reaction having taken place against the inva- sion by Spain. The Kingston (Jam.) Journal, of the
lead_paragraph: The News from St. Domingo is important, a bloody reaction having taken place against the inva- sion by Spain. The Kingston (Jam.) Journal, of the 8th of June, in reference to affairs in St. Domingo, says that Gen. SANTANA has succeeded in establishing a reign of terror in the Republic, similar in its features to that which prevailed in France, during the first revolution. A system of the severest espionage has been inaugurated, and upon the slightest suspicion of disaffection to the new order of things, the Police unceremoniously force their way into the private dwellings of the citizens. Numerous arrests of suspected persons, several of them of high social position have been made, and a great many of those who are obnoxious to him have been summarily condemned and shot by his orders.

abstract: Having passed several sleepless nights, disturbed by the agonies and cries of a suffering child and becoming convinced that Mrs. WINSLOW's SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply for the child. On reaching home, and acquainting his wife with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Homeopathy. That night the child passed in suffering and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following, the father found the baby still worse and, while contemplating another sleepless night, the mother stepped from the room to attend to some domestic duties, and left the father with the child. During her absence he administered a portion of the SOOTHING SYRUP to the baby, and said nothing. That night all hands slept well, and the little fellow awoke in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delighted with the sudden and wonderful change, and although at first offended at the deception practiced upon her, has continued to use the Syrup, and suffering, crying babies and restless nights have disappeared. A single trial of the Syrup never yet failed to relieve the baby, and overcome the prejudices of the mother.

abstract: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRS. WINSLOW? we will simply say that she is a lady who for upwards of 30 years, has untiringly devoted her time and talents as a female physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, so generally overlooked or carelessly treated by the faculty in too many instances; and, as a result of this effort, and practical knowledge obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article, Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children do certainly RISE UP and bless has especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grave by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn will share its benefits and unite in calling her blessed. No MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of MRS. WINSLOW's SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it mothers -- TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: MURDEROUS AFFRAY AT A BEER GARDEN. Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday held an inquest at No. 25 Avenue C, upon the body of GEO. ANDREW JINNEMAN, a German, 35 years of age, whose death had resulted from violence. The following facts were
lead_paragraph: MURDEROUS AFFRAY AT A BEER GARDEN. -- Coroner SCHIRMER yesterday held an inquest at No. 25 Avenue C, upon the body of GEO. ANDREW JINNEMAN, a German, 35 years of age, whose death had resulted from violence. The following facts were elicited: the deceased was engaged, with several other persons, on the 4th inst., to furnish music at a beer garden in Guttenburg, N.J., of which E. EISLES is proprietor. The band did all it could to please the patrons of the establishment, but after a while some of the dancers became dissatisfied, owing, perhaps, to their copious libations, and insisted that the music was not sufficient, either in quality or quantity. Meanwhile, the pleasure-seekers were receiving continual accessions to their numbers, and fresh sets took the floor, until it was apparent that the band and their instruments were blown to an unendurable degree, and the music ceased. This turn of affairs was not at all to the liking of the dancers, who loudly demanded that the music should be continued, and after a short respite, the band made another effort, which only resulted in an undignified break-down. The sudden stop which this put to the amusements infuriated the Tentons, and after much introductory quarreling, they went to fighting. In the melee JINNEMAN was beaten so badly that his death resulted from the injuries, after he had languished several days in intense pain. The jury declared that he came to his death from peritonitis, brought on by injuries received at the hands of persons to them unknown.

abstract: -- JACK WILLIAMS, one of the sailors who escaped from on board of the brig Triton, was yesterday arrested in the Park by a United States Deputy Marshal. WILLIAMS was on an extensive bender, by way of celebrating his lucky escape from the custody of the Marshal. He was committed for examination by United States Commissioner HENRY. There are now two others at large, viz.: JOHN MORRIS and Capt. VERAM LOCKE. He is about five feet eight inches in height, of dark complexion, dark auburn hair, a hair-mole on his right cheek, and having small, blue eyes. His hands have been very much scarred. He is about 35 years of age. The Triton left Norfolk Feb. 18, 1861, arrived in the Congo River April 10, was seized as a prize May 20, arrived at Ascension on the homeward trip June 7, where the vessel was partially cleansed; crossed the Equator June 14, and arrived here July 9. The vessel, with her slave-deck still on board, lies at the Union stores, Atlantic Dock.
lead_paragraph: -- JACK WILLIAMS, one of the sailors who escaped from on board of the brig Triton, was yesterday arrested in the Park by a United States Deputy Marshal. WILLIAMS was on an extensive bender, by way of celebrating his lucky escape from the custody of the Marshal. He was committed for examination by United States Commissioner HENRY. There are now two others at large, viz.: JOHN MORRIS and Capt. VERAM LOCKE. He is about five feet eight inches in height, of dark complexion, dark auburn hair, a hair-mole on his right cheek, and having small, blue eyes. His hands have been very much scarred. He is about 35 years of age. The Triton left Norfolk Feb. 18, 1861, arrived in the Congo River April 10, was seized as a prize May 20, arrived at Ascension on the homeward trip June 7, where the vessel was partially cleansed; crossed the Equator June 14, and arrived here July 9. The vessel, with her slave-deck still on board, lies at the Union stores, Atlantic Dock.

abstract: The Pocket is the grand test of confidence among men whose relations to each other are  only of a public or a business character. Nay, even among friends and relatives, is not the...
lead_paragraph: The Pocket is the grand test of confidence among men whose relations to each other are only of a public or a business character. Nay, even among friends and relatives, is not the willingness to open the purse regarded as an unmistakable evidence of interest and affection? and is not a trust reposed in regard to the material interests of life, justly looked upon as one of the surest indications of faith in capacity and trustworthiness, by those who are bound together by the very bonds of blood? The "confidence man" won his name find gained his plunder by boldly and adroitly playing upon this sentiment. He deceived his victims as to his identity, and then benefited by the reliance which they placed in his supposed trustworthiness.

abstract: Before theTIMES is put to press to-morrow morning, there is every reason to believe we shall have tidings of two decisive battles in Virginia, fought on different sides of the Alleghanies. Our latest reports from Gen. MCCLELLAN's Division, in Western Virginia, represent that very competent commander as in the act of advancing his force, in two bodies upon the enemy, who was in his immediate neighborhood intrenched, and awaiting the assault. As the National force is believed to be superior to its opponent, and composed of men who have given the most splendid proofs of intrepidity, there can hardly be a question upon whose eagles victory will perch. To-day is the latest fixed for the advance of Gen. PATTERSON's column upon the position of the rebel, Gen. JOHNSTON, who so ingloriously retreated from Hainesville. Allowing the utmost latitude for the tales of large reinforcements received by JOHNSTON through Manassas Gap, the odds of numbers are no doubt on the side of PATTERSON; and this,with the same prestige of courage and success which attended the Western Army, must turn the scale of the conflict in our favor. The battle in the Valley of Virginia will perhaps excite a greater local interest here, as several of our favorite regiments, including the Twelfth Militia, are in the army of Gen. PATTERSON.

abstract: For some years past a lady named Mrs. PECK has been residing in Bennington, Vt. She was the widow of a druggist, and lived quite retired, but appeared to be in quite easy circumstances, and to have an extensive command of money. Quite often she visited Troy, where she had a number of friends, and in which city she seemed to have great confidence. She made large investments in Troy bonds, and often spoke to her acquaintances and advisers concerning institutions in this city, among them the Young Men's Association, Hospital, Marshall Infirmary, Orphan Asylum, &c. She had no relative, except a step-daughter, with whom she had lived for many years.

abstract: The telegraph, which seldom leaves a sensation story to the slower movement of the mails, has certainly done so in regard to the conflict between the National and rebel forces in the vicinity of Carthage, Mo. As we now receive the official report of the struggle, as carried to St. Louis by private hands, the credit due to Col. SIEGEL and his command can hardly be excessive. Encountering a force three times his strength, and better provided with artillery, that officer brought off his force with very trilling loss, while pouring destruction upon the enemy, defeated all the attempts of the rebels to outflank him, or cut off his retreat, and by the instant employment of an ingenious military resource, in a moment of capital danger, dissipated a body of hostile cavalry, which must otherwise have decimated his gallant little army. A well-conducted retreat is more creditable in such circumatances than a victory; and even the glory of a victory certainly belongs in this instance to the combatant, who, with numbers so inferior, inflicted such tremendous damage upon his adversary.
lead_paragraph: The telegraph, which seldom leaves a sensation story to the slower movement of the mails, has certainly done so in regard to the conflict between the National and rebel forces in the vicinity of Carthage, Mo. abstract: We some days ago gave the resources of the rebels in grain, showing that they were less than half those at the command of the Government, to say nothing of the hay crop,...
lead_paragraph: We some days ago gave the resources of the rebels in grain, showing that they were less than half those at the command of the Government, to say nothing of the hay crop, which alone is equal in value, for the maintenance of an army in the field to the grain crop of the South. The Irish potato crop of the loyal States is about double that of the sweet potato crop of the rebel States, and fully equal the latter, together with their pea crop. Of seven and three-quarter millions worth of orchard products, less than a quarter of a million belongs to the rebel States. Of five and a quarter millions worth of market garden products, less than half a million belongs to the rebels. Of 313,267,000 pounds of butter, worth some fifty millions dollars, only about 40,000,000 pounds, or less than one-seventh, belongs to the Confederates; and of 105,535,219 pounds of cheese, only three-quarters of a million, or about the one-hundred and fortieth part, falls to the share of the rebels.

The attendance of spectators was not large, and less than the bsual interest was manifested, even the prisoner himself showing little doncern at the result. abstract: The anomalous state of the nation, pro- duced by the rebellion, promises to illustrate a variety of hitherto untried theories in politics and economy.
lead_paragraph: The anomalous state of the nation, pro- duced by the rebellion, promises to illustrate a variety of hitherto untried theories in politics and economy. A very marked and interesting example is furnished by the deliberations of Congress. Political writers are almost unanimous in the opinion that for the safe and thorough discussion of public measures, it is indispensable to have the deliberative body pretty equally divided between opposing parties, whose zeal in advocating or resisting specific acts of legislation will be sure to throw the largest volume of light upon the topic considered. There are others who recognize in the rigidity of party discipline reasons to apprehend that the light thus elicited has no chance to act upon the result of the debate, which, whatever the reasoning on the two sides, is finally decided by their numerical strength. The present extra session of Congress will do much to clear up this matter. There is practically only one party in Congress. Whatever measures are reported by the Committees proceed to a vote without discussion, and are accepted by a majority, which is almost tantamount to unanimity. Measures which involve millions of men and money, which inaugurate or abolish systems of revenue and administration, which create armies and navies, and give to the Executive the plenary powers requisite in such grand National emergencies, are hastened from the committee-room to the engrossing clerk with a rapidity which, in ordinary time, would suggest the idea of the Legislature having surrendered all but the formal exercise of its constitutional functions.
headline: {'main': 'Congress and its Legislation', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Congress and its Legislation', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The soul of TANEY, C.J., is now probably tranquilized. Mr. JOHN MERRYMAN is no longer a prisoner in defiance of a writ of habeas corpus; but having been indicted for sundry acts of treason, flagrant in character, by a jury of his fellow-citizens, is transferred to the less tenacious grasp of civil authority. The course of trial and appeal may in due time carry the cause for a rehearing before the venerable Chief Justice himself, when we may expect to have some as edifying and satisfactory views of the law of treason as we have received from the same authority in regard to the rights of slaveholders and the habeas corpus. Expedite your case, Mr. MERRYMAN, and let us get at the law and the testimony.

abstract: After two or three days' severe skirmishing between Gen. McCLELLAN'S forces and the rebels at Laurel Hill, it is probable that a desperate battle was fought there yesterday.
lead_paragraph: After two or three days' severe skirmishing between Gen. McCLELLAN'S forces and the rebels at Laurel Hill, it is probable that a desperate battle was fought there yesterday. A courier who left the camp of the National forces at 3 o'clock yesterday morning, states that they had been divided into two Divisions, and had started with the purpose of surrounding the rebels, who were represented to be strongly fortified. The main body of Gen. MCCLELLAN's force, had been for two days within a mile and a half of the rebel intrenchments, and a fire of artillery, more or less constant, had been kept up. The rebels, however, had only 6-pounder cannon, while ours were double that calibre, and did good execution at long range. On the afternoon of Wednesday a considerable body of the enemy, which proved to be a regiment from Georgia, came out of the intrenchments with the purpose of driving in our skirmishing parties, but after a sharp action of short duration the Crackers were utterly discomfited.

abstract: Yesterday forenoon an old resident of Jersey City, named JAMES HOWE, while engaged painting on the second story at No. 17 York-street, was precipitated to the ground in consequence of the temporary staging giving away and was instantly killed. Upon an inquest being held by Coroner GAFNEY, it was found that the skull was fractured and the neck dislocated.

abstract: We have been permitted to see a letter from an officer in the squadron blockading the Chesapeake, from which the following is an extract. It is corroborative of the opinion entertained by merchants...
lead_paragraph: We have been permitted to see a letter from an officer in the squadron blockading the Chesapeake, from which the following is an extract. It is corroborative of the opinion entertained by merchants and underwriters as to the increased danger incurred by vessels navigating the Chesapeake Buy. It occurs to us that some of the vessels reported ashore between Cape Henry and Cape Hatteras, may have been run ashore intentionally, for the purpose of landing their cargoes for the benefit of the rebels. At any rate, it might be well for the Government to be watchful of such proceedings.

abstract: For some years past PETER VAN BUSKIRK, of this city, aged 99 years, who has been upon the revolutionary pension rolls as a private, at $5 per month, for many years, has been prosecuting a claim for arrearages of pension as an Assistant Forage-Master, which, if allowed, entitled him to receive a total pension of $50 per month, instead of $5, the amount heretofore paid to him. His claim was more than once rejected for want of testimony. Recently he has found and presented the necessary testimony, and yesterday his claim was duly allowed, with an award of $16,200 back (arrearages of) pension. This s, we believe, the largest back pension ever obtained from the Treasury of the United States. The officers of the bureau, though believing him entitled to be placed on the roll as an. Assistant Forage-Master, could not previously allow his claim for want of the requisite legal evidence to substantiate it. -- Washington Star, July 10.

His claim was more than once rejected for want of testimony. Recently he has found and presented the necessary testimony, and yesterday his claim was duly allowed, with an award of $16,200 back (arrearages of) pension. This s, we believe, the largest back pension ever obtained from the Treasury of the United States. The officers of the bureau, though believing him entitled to be placed on the roll as an. Assistant Forage-Master, could not previously allow his claim for want of the requisite legal evidence to substantiate it. -- Washington Star, July 10.

abstract: Simultaneously with the reception of the order of Gen. SCOTT prohibiting the transmission of telegraphic dispatches relative to army movements, we are placed in possession of New-Orleans papers of the 5th inst., containing full reports by telegraph from every important location of the National forces. While the Secessionists experience apparently no difficulty in thus obtaining the fullest information of the movements on foot against them, the Government is in reality aiding them in their efforts, to keep news of their Army operations from reaching the North. All the Southern papers of any importance have telegraphic and mail correspondence regularly from the North, and it would seem to be at least fair, in point of courtesy, to say nothing of patriotic motives, to see that the loyal are not less favored than Southern journalists, who are openly in rebellion.

abstract: A sad accident,which proved fatal yesterday forenoon, befel Mrs. FANNY LONGFELLOW, wife of Prof. HENRY W. LONGFELLOW, at their residence in Cambridge, on Tuesday afternoon. While seated at her library table, making seals for the entertainment of her two youngest children, a match or piece of lighted paper caught her dress, and she was in a moment enveloped in flames. Prof. LONGFELLOW, who was in his study, ran to her assistance, and succeeded in extinguishingthe flames, with considerable injury to himself, but too late for the rescue of her life. Drs. WYMAN and JOHNSON, of Cambridge, and HENRY J. BIGELOW, of this city, were summoned, and did all that surgical skill could do. Both of the sufferers were under the influence of ether through the night, and yesterday morning Mrs. LONGFELLOW rallied a little, but at 11 o'clock she was forever released from suffering. Mrs. LONGFELLOW was a gifted and accomplished lady, the daughter of Hon. NATHAN APPLETON. She leaves five children to mourn, with their father, their common loss.
lead_paragraph: A sad accident,which proved fatal yesterday forenoon, befel Mrs. FANNY LONGFELLOW, wife of Prof. HENRY W. LONGFELLOW, at their residence in Cambridge, on Tuesday afternoon. abstract: The United States Arsenal at Frankford, Pa., has just sent to the ammunition head-quarters a tremendous cargo of caps, primers,  This establishment is one of the largest of the kind in the United States.
lead_paragraph: The United States Arsenal at Frankford, Pa., has just sent to the ammunition head-quarters a tremendous cargo of caps, primers, This establishment is one of the largest of the kind in the United States. It covers about 60 acres of ground, and is surrounded by a wall ten feet high, and front 12 to 18 inches thick. Some 15,000 muskets have been forwarded the house for repairs. About 120,000 percussion caps are manufactured every 24 hours, the machines running night and day. Sundays not excepted. Thirty men and boys are employed in the department where friction primers are made, and turn out daily about 8,000 of them. These primers have worked up in them $200 worth of material every 24 hours, and 3,000 lbs. of acid are required to make the 3,000 lbs. of powder used in making them. The manufacture of the Marquari primers has been stopped by the Government. There are 30,000 lbs. of powder in the Frankford magazine.

abstract: John S. Farran vs. Charles Shonnard.--This was a motion made on behalf of one George Kitching, a purchaser of two lots in Cherry-street, under a de- cree in partition.
lead_paragraph: John S. Farran vs. Charles Shonnard.--This was a motion made on behalf of one George Kitching, a purchaser of two lots in Cherry-street, under a de- cree in partition. The sale of these premises was to have been closed on the 21st of March last. Two objections are now made to the title. First, that a mortgage dated in 1816 was still unsatisfied of record: Since the service of the motion papers, however, that mortgage has been satisfied, but the purchaser still objected to take title, on account of his having lost an opportunity to get a lessee for the premises on account of the mortgage being in the way. The second objection was that the personal representatives, said Chessman & Brown, surviving executors of Robert Brown, deceased, who held a further mortgage upon the property, were not made parties in the partition suit, it being contended that prima facie the mortgage belonged to said Chessman & Brown, individually, and not to the estate of which they were executors, and that the purchaser was entitled to have this title perfect upon the record. On the part of the plaintiff it was contended that the mortgage of 1816 must be presumed to have been paid, after the lapse of twenty years. And as to the mortgage alleged to belong to said Chessman and Brown, it was contended that there could be no dispute about it; it was proved satisfactorily that it belonged to the estate and not to the personal representatives individually. Decision reserved.

abstract: Prompt action has already been taken by Congress upon the bill making provision for the payment of Volunteers from the time they were called into service by the President till the close of last month.
lead_paragraph: Prompt action has already been taken by Congress upon the bill making provision for the payment of Volunteers from the time they were called into service by the President till the close of last month. Two other measures, relating to the compensation of the National Army, are now before Congress. One of them is put forth in the bill introduced on Monday by Mr. VAN WYCK, of this State, providing for the increase of the pay of private soldiers to $15 a month, to lake effect from, May 1,1861; and the other is contained in the bill offered by Mr. HOLMAN, of Indiana, on the same day, which provides that each officer and private, either in the Army or Navy, who shall have enlisted since the 12th of April, and remained in service for a period of not less than sixty days, and then been honorably discharged, (referring to the three months' volunteers,) shall be entitled to receive a bounty warrant for 160 acres of land, to be selected from any public lands duly surveyed and subject to sale; and further provides that every officer and private who shall have been mustered into service prior to August 1, 1861, and shall continue therein until the extraordinary forces are disbanded, or who shall have been previously honorably discharged, (referring to the volunteers for three years or the war,) shall be entitled to receive a warrant for 320 acres of land, to be selected in a similar manner.

abstract: We have received a copy of the Mesilla (Arizona) Times, dated May 17, from which the following extracts are taken. There is too much truth in the complaint that Arizona has been neglected by the...
lead_paragraph: We have received a copy of the Mesilla (Arizona) Times, dated May 17, from which the following extracts are taken. There is too much truth in the complaint that Arizona has been neglected by the General Government relative to the great question of Slavery, now in issue between the North and the South. Our entire frontier regions, from the British possessions to Mexico, feel but little real interest, as the practical application of the system of slave labor in all that immense extent of territory is know into be impossible. The universal disloyalty to the Government of the United States manifested on our frontiers must be attributed mainly to the entire want of anything like genuine interest or sympathy on the part of our Government for emigrants or pioneers. The great interests of our widely-extended frontier regions have been left in the hands of the army and of the Indian Agencies, who have too generally prostituted their official position and power to their own selfish purposes, regardless of the general interests of the country and the special welfare of those of our hardy pioneers who pave the way to empire. We are now reaping the bitter fruits of such culpable and unfortunate management on the part of our rulers and their agents.

abstract: The attention lately granted by the Powers of Europe to the firearms designed for military services, and the numerous improvements introduced in that branch of the national service, clearly...
lead_paragraph: The attention lately granted by the Powers of Europe to the firearms designed for military services, and the numerous improvements introduced in that branch of the national service, clearly indicate what we ought to do ourselves, if we wish to retain the rank we occupy among great nations. Those improvements are so much the more desirable, that they do not simply imply a desire of becoming a warlike people, but also of attenuating the direful effects of war, by making it shorter, more decisive and less bloody than before. A general belief, confirmed by statistical tables of mortality, is that the destruction of armies is in an inverse ratio with the progress in the science of war, and that the more perfect the weapons used by the soldiers, the smaller the losses. Look, for instance, at the battles fought in India by the English, in Africa and Italy by the French, and compare them with those fought half a century ago, and you will arrive at the conclusion that the number of deaths in the Army has decreased with the increase of range and accuracy in firearms.

abstract: The Collector of this port has received from the Department of State, Washington, two elegant telescopes which the British Government have presented to Capt. FREDERICK ILSLEY, master, and Mr. NEWELL T. BOWEN, mate, of ship George Turner, of this port. They are presented as a mark of gratitude for the noble services of the master, mate and crew of the George Turner, in rescuing the officers and crew of the British Brigantine Escape, of Hornoway, in the English Channel, in February last.

abstract: The agents of the New-York Board of Underwriters, at Newport, in a dispatch to Mr. WALTER, state that the ship mentioned in the above dispatch as the John Goodwin, should be the Mary Goodell. The latter vessel belongs to Messrs. R.P. BUCK & Co., of this City, and was cleared hence, recently, for Montevideo, S.A. She carried an assorted cargo, which was no doubt overhauled, and such parts of it appropriated as suited the wants of the pirates. The Mary Goodell is a ship of only 717 tons register, with a draft of water of nineteen feet, which, it seems, was an insuperable difficulty in the way, since she could not be taken into any of the Southern ports which remain accessible.

abstract: The Joint Special Committee, consisting of three members of each branch of the Common Council, appointed to meet with the prominent and influential citizens, for the purpose of ascertaining the best course to be adopted by the City authorities, tending to relieve the condition of our working classes, and aiding the families of volunteers, met in the Chamber of the Board of Councilmen at 3 o'clock yesterday. The Committee consisted of Aldermen CHIPP, DAYTON, and FREAR, and Councilmen CLEVELAND, GROSS and LONG, who were present, excepting Messrs. FREAR and LONG. The Chairman, Mr. CHIPP, called the meeting to order, and presented a communication from Ex-Mayor TIEMANN, in which that gentleman stated that his engagements were such as to prevent him from being present in person. He approved of the object of the meeting, and would do all in his power to aid the cause.
lead_paragraph: The Joint Special Committee, consisting of three members of each branch of the Common Council, appointed to meet with the prominent and influential citizens, for the purpose of ascertaining the best course to be adopted by the City authorities, tending to relieve the condition of our working classes, and aiding the families of volunteers, met in the Chamber of the Board of Councilmen at 3 o'clock yesterday. The Committee consisted of Aldermen CHIPP, DAYTON, and FREAR, and Councilmen CLEVELAND, GROSS and LONG, who were present, excepting Messrs. FREAR and LONG. The Chairman, Mr. CHIPP, called the meeting to order, and presented a communication from Ex-Mayor TIEMANN, in which that gentleman stated that his engagements were such as to prevent him from being present in person. He approved of the object of the meeting, and would do all in his power to aid the cause.

abstract: A few days ago a report was received in Richmond, Va., that Capt. BAKER, of the privateer Savannah, had been tried and convicted of piracy, in New-York, and would be hung. Whereupon, according to the Enquirer, the Davis Government took the immediate resolution to inform President LINCOLN that if such sentence should be executed on BAKER, a fearful retaliation would follow on any officers or men of the United States that might be in their hands.

abstract: -- It is a fact -- however unpalatable -- that but few of the regiments leaving this City for. the seat of war have departed with full ranks. In some, a total lack of discipline has caused hundreds fully equipped men to stray and become permanently detached, while in others, the full quota has never been collected. Accordingly, our corps presents a superfluity of officers and a deficiency of men. This fact should be borne in mind by the authorities in accepting more regiments. Let the ranks in every case be full.
lead_paragraph: -- It is a fact -- however unpalatable -- that but few of the regiments leaving this City for. the seat of war have departed with full ranks. abstract: The sudden activity of the rebel privateers, as demonstrated by the news this morning, shows, among other things, that the blockade of the Southern coast is extremely imperfect. These vessels have evidently just put to seat. or their appearance and mischievousness on the great highway of traffic would have been earlier reported; and the statement accompanying our present information, that they merely rob, without seizing, vessels of draft too deep to enter the secondary Southern harbors, shows that they count on no difficulty in running our ineffectual cordon. From New-Orleans, also, we have intelligence that the Confederate war-steamer Sumter, fully manned and armed, had set forth on a cruise, doubtless pursuit of the California treasure-ships, passing to sea as freely as if no blockade existed: while it is well known that communication between New-Orleans and Galveston proceeds without interruption. Another trick of the rebels, if not in some way prevented, will destroy all hope of cutting off supplies from abroad. The masters of vessels, who find the Southern port to which they are declined closed against them, run their vessels ashore at some convenient point where the cargo can be safely landed. The Richmond papers, in reporting one instance of this kind, speak as if it were not the first.

abstract: The Sons of Massachusetts met at the Astor House, at 9 o'clock yesterday morning, for the purpose of making suitable arrangements to receive the Massachusetts regiments, as they pass through the City from time to time, on their way to the seat of war. Mr. FRANK E. HOWE was appointed Chairman, and Mr. RICHARD D. WARREN, Secretary. In explaining the object of the meeting, Mr. FRANK G. ELDRIDGE stated that before the first regiment from Massachusetts cam came on Committee of the Sons of that State was appointed to receive them, and the duties of that Committee expired really when the regiment had left the City, and it was deemed proper that some permanent arrangements should be made for the future. On motion. William E. Everets, M.H. Grinnell, Rev. S.H. Tyng, George C. Ward, Wm. C. Bryant, F.E. Howe, Charles N. Emerson, Frank G. Eldridge, F.A. Farley, and Elisha Bacon, were appointed a General Committee to make proper arrangements for the reception of all Massachusetts regiments that may pass through the City, and a committee of five; consisting of Richard D. Warren, Wm. E. Crocker, Baylis Sandford, John W. Candler, and Frank E. Howe, were appointed to receive the Seventh Massachusetts Regiment on their arrival this morning. The Committee will proceed to Pier No. 18 North River at 5 o'clock, and escort the regiment to the City Hall, where a welcoming address will be made by Richard D. Warren, after which the troops will breakfast at the Park Barracks, and the officers, with the Committee, at the Astor House.

abstract: Some surprise has been manifested at the appointment of Right Reverend Father in God, the Bishop of Louisiana, to the post of Brigadier-General in the Army of the insurrection, and at his ready acceptance of the same. But there is no reason for this astonishment. The appointment is quite in order, and in entire accordance with well-established ecelesiastical precedent. The history of the dark ages is
lead_paragraph: Some surprise has been manifested at the appointment of Right Reverend Father in God, the Bishop of Louisiana, to the post of Brigadier-General in the Army of the insurrection, and at his ready acceptance of the same. But there is no reason for this astonishment. The appointment is quite in order, and in entire accordance with well-established ecelesiastical precedent. The history of the dark ages is illuminated with many instances in which the professed apostles of Him, the meek and lowly, whose kingdom was not of this world, sought upon the battle-field that excitement and distinction which they could not obtain in the cloister; and shall the shining example of these venerable fathers not be followed by prelates in like circumstances now-a-days? True, the practice was productive of some inconvenience. There was the English bishop, of whom WALTER SCOTT tells us, who, in an interview with a royal envoy, being robed in his pontifical investments, laid his hand solemnly upon his breast as he asseverated "upon his conscience" that he had taken no part in a certain very recent skirmish. But the self-imposition of the Episcopal hand produced such a clash of breast-plate, gorget and vantbrace underneath the robes of peace, that the Envoy at once exclaimed, "My Lord, I fear your conscience clatters." Then there was the Bishop of Beauvais, whom RICHARD the lion-hearted, encountered among other captains, in his last war upon PHILIP of France, armed cap-a-pie, leading a division of the French forces against him, and whom, with a sacrilegious disregard of his holy office, the royal crusader did most thoroughly beat and take prisoner. Then was Pope CELESTIN wrathful, and demanded the liberty of the prelate, whom he claimed as his spiritual son, threatening direful things if he were not immediately restored to the paternal embrace. But, in reply, RICHARD, all of whose wit was not in his big battle-axe, sent to his Holiness the coat of mail which the bishop had worn in battle, and which was all besmeared with blood as Joseph's coat was; and the King said to the Pope, in the terms used by Joseph's brothers to their father: "This have we found; know now whether it be thy son's coat or no."' This, in the lawyer's phrase, concluded the pontiff; and if he imitated the patriarchal recognition of the bloody garment, the fact is not recorded.

abstract: It will require but a short argument now to convince, not only all the capitalists who have money in manufactures and commerce, but every man who employs money in any business of life, that it is as imperative duty and a duty in the sense of self-intrest to contribute a liberal portion to the United States loan now about to be raised. All busi-
lead_paragraph: It will require but a short argument now to convince, not only all the capitalists who have money in manufactures and commerce, but every man who employs money in any business of life, that it is as imperative duty -- and a duty in the sense of self-intrest -- to contribute a liberal portion to the United States loan now about to be raised. All business is now paralyzed, and money produces only limited returns. When will business revive and flourish again? Assuredly not till the war closes. Capital that is idle and profitless must therefore fight its way out to fields of activity. The more men and money the Government can raise, the more surely is its triumph established, and peace insured. The more quickly the money is got, the more quickly will these results be attained.

abstract: One of the favorite theories of the secession school of Southern politicians, is the superiority of a system of direct taxation for raising the revenue needed for the support of Government, over the more popular method of obtaining it through duties on imports. Indeed, to obtain this great benefit, it has been earnestly set forth by the rebel leaders of South Carolina, as one of the prominent motives for the wicked rebellion which was inaugurated by her Convention. It will, therefore, be a subject of gratification to the statesmen of that almost forgotten Republic, to learn that on this particular and sensitive point, our present practical Secretary of the Treasury, as we understand his report, proposes to accommodate them. The demands upon the Treasury required to meet the ordinary expenses of Government, the interest on the increased public debt, and to allow a margin for a small sinking fund, are estimated at the aggregate of eighty millions of dollars. Of this sum the Secretary proposes to raise sixty millions from duties on imports and other ordinary sources of revenue; and then submit to Congress the propriety of resorting to either direct taxation, or to the alternative plan of an excise, for procuring the remaining sum of twenty millions.

abstract: The severe thunder storm of Monday, which, to many people, promised so grateful a relief from the hot and sultry atmosphere of preceding days, was attended by a tornado that swept over Northern Illinois with fearful severity. We have already reported some of the damage done at Rockford, and elsewhere, but the storm seems to have covered a wider extent of country than at first supposed. From all along the line of the Galena and Chicago Railroad we get reports of the same tenor. Its presence was felt and feared everywhere, for the tornadoes of the past two seasons have caused a gathering of dark clouds to be watched with an uneasiness and dread quite new in this latitude. The gale swept from southwest to northwest, and spent its greatest force for a half hour about noon. Torrents of rain fell and the lightning constituted no small portion of the display. At Dunleith the steamboat freight-house was partly unroofed, and the upper works of the wharf-boat destroyed. At Galena and Belvidere no great damage was done. The storm seems to have been most destructive to buildings and town property at Freeport and Rockford, in which places the aggregate damage is put at not less than $150,000.

abstract: Several months ago, it will be recollected that the brig Wm. R. Kibby was picked up by a United States vessel off the coast of Cuba, having on board three negro boys, the remnants of a cargo of slaves that had evidently been just landed on the coast. The boys were brought to this City, where they excited considerable attention, and were the occasion of the famous assault of Capt. RYNDERS -- then, unhappily, Marshal of this District -- upon LEWIS TAPPAN, who had called upon the Marshall to make inquiries about the juvenile Africans. The boys have since been sent back to Africa by the Colonization Society, but their captors -- the officers and crew of the bark Wm. R. Kibby -- have hitherto not bean heard of since their desertion of their craft on the coast of Cuba, until their arrest by the United States Marshal on Thursday afternoon. The Wm. R. Kibby sailed from the port on the 20th of February, 1860, having escaped, as many had doubtless done before her, the extra-ordinary vigilance of Marshal RYNDERS, and immediately proceeded to the coast of Africa, where, after being several times suspected and overhauled by United States vessels on that station, she succeeded in making her escape with a cargo of 500 Africans, which she landed, as before mentioned, on the coast of Cuba -- overlooking, in the hurry of the landing, the three infantile contrabands which had stowed themselves away in the hold. The captain of this successful slave-cruiser was THOMAS H. BURNS, an American, hailing from New-Orleans, where, as appears from an inspection of his baggage since his arrest, he keeps a respectable bank account. Marshal MURRAY has been on the look-out for him for five weeks past, and on Thursday he succeeded in catching him in Wall-street. On his first arrest the captain attempted to laugh it off as a good joke, but after sleeping a night in the Tombs he seems disposed to regard the matter in a more serious light. Yesterday the Marshal succeeded in arresting the first and second mates of the Kibby -- the former of whom he found in Water-street, and the latter in the upper end of Cherry-street. The first mate's name is HILDERBRAND, a German, who hails from Antwerp; the second mate is an American named PARTONS.

abstract: We have intelligence of two important battles as Western Virginia One st Laurel Hill, where Gen. McCLELLAN commanded the National forces in person, and the other at Rich Mountain, where our forces were commanded by Gen. ROSENORANZ. The former, according to our dispatches, was fought in pursuance of the plan foreshadowed in the latest advices received on Thursday night.
lead_paragraph: We have intelligence of two important battles as Western Virginia -- one st Laurel Hill, where Gen. McCLELLAN commanded the National forces in person, and the other at Rich Mountain, where our forces were commanded by Gen. ROSENORANZ. The former, according to our dispatches, was fought in pursuance of the plan foreshadowed in the latest advices received on Thursday night. Gen. MCCLELLAN turned the enemy's position at Laurel Hill, and gained a most decided victory, capturing the entire camp -- guns, tents, wagons, etc., and many prisoners, among whom were several officers. The loss of the enemy is reported to be severe, while ours was very small -- a fact probably attributable to the superiority of our artillery. The other battle was fought on Thursday afternoon, two miles east of Roaring River, in Randolph County. The rebels, numbering about two thousand, under command of Col. PEGRAM, were strongly intrenched. Gen. ROSENCRANZ had under his command portions of the Eighth, Tenth and Thirteenth Indiana, and the Nineteenth Ohio Regiments. He made a difficult march of seven or eight miles from Roaring River, cutting a road through the woods, and succeeded in surrounding the enemy, when a desperate fight took place, lasting about an hour and a half, and resulting in the total rout of the rebels, who left behind them six cannon, a large number of horses, wagons, camp equipage, etc., and lost sixty killed and a large number wounded and taken prisoners, the latter including several officers. The loss of the National forces was about twenty killed and forty wounded -- proving it to have been the most desperately contested battle which has yet been fought.

abstract: The latest dispatches from Missouri announce that Gen. J.S. RAINS, one of Gov. JACKSON's Brigadiers, came to his death in the fight with Col. SIEGEL. RAINS made himself very useful to his rebel chief, and raised more men than any other of his Brigadiers. But yet his death would be no serious loss. He is not a military man at all, but a fussy, Fourth-of-July sort of politician, in Southwest Missouri. He was a Bell-Everett supporter in the late canvass for the Presidency; and was run by the "Union" men of his district against Hon. J.S. PHELPS in the late election for Congress. He was confident of success till election day, when he found himself some 2,000 votes behind. He sought an early opportunity to vindicate his Union principles, by becoming a Secessionist of the most ultra type, and was rewarded for his treachery by Gov. JACKSON in a commission as Brigadier-General.

abstract: The Ohio and Indiana Volunteers seem to be distinguishing themselves by most splendid fighting in Western Virginia. We have an account this morning, of a decisive victory, gained by a detachment of these volunteers, under Col. ROSENCRANZ. They assaulted a well-fortified position of the rebels, who were about 2,000 strong, under Col. PEGRAM, (undoubtedly Capt. PEGRAM, late of the United States Army, in New-Mexico,) and after a fierce fight of an hour or two, drove the latter from their intrenchments, and captured most of their artillery and munitions, besides inflicting on them very severe loss in killed and wounded.

abstract: Three of the United States Revenue Cutters which have been at anchor off the Battery for several days, received orders yesterday afternoon to get under way and proceed to sea. The three vessels weighed anchor together about 4 1/2 o'clock P.M., and commenced to beat down the Bay, when the steam-transport Mercury took one after the other in tow, and at 5 1/2 o'clock all three were noticed passing through the Narrows. It is supposed they have been thus suddenly dispatched for the purpose of capturing the privateer which was yesterday reported to have captured vessels near the South Shoal of Nantucket. Capt. BENNETT's Yacht Revenue Cutter meantime does duty as home guard for the Collector.

abstract: Deputy Marshal BORST yesterday arrested JOHN MORRIS, one of the crew of the slaver Triton, who escaped on the day of the arrival of the brig at this port, while Midshipman BORCHERT was off reporting his arrival to the United States Marshal. Another of the escaped prisoners, named JOHN WILLIAMS, was arrested by the same officer on Thursday. MORRIS is well known to the pilots of this port, having for many years served here as a pilot himself. The remaining prisoner who made his escape, Capt. PERCY, of the Triton, is supposed to have gone to Boston. The United States Marshal at Boston, has been telegraphed, and will no doubt speedily effect his arrest.

abstract: The country will read with much pleasure the accounts, from St. Louis, of Judge CATRON'S unflinching fidelity to the Constitution and Union. In his charge to the Grand Jury, he repudiated the pretended right of a State to secede, and held that all citizens of the United States, no matter under what pretence, found in arms against the Government, are guilty of treason,
lead_paragraph: -- The country will read with much pleasure the accounts, from St. Louis, of Judge CATRON'S unflinching fidelity to the Constitution and Union. In his charge to the Grand Jury, he repudiated the pretended right of a State to secede, and held that all citizens of the United States, no matter under what pretence, found in arms against the Government, are guilty of treason, and should be so dealt with. Some of the would-be martyrs of the Camp Jackson capture, who are at the Arsenal in durance, and who applied to Judge CATRON for release by habeas corpus, were refused, and must take their chances elsewhere of purging themselves of treason.

abstract: We learn from Col. HARCOURT, that the steamer New World, which sunk near Stuyvesant, on the morning of the 3d, was successfully pumped out, and raised early this morning. Contrary to the general belief, she was found to have been but little broken, and when lifted up, the timbers pressed back very nearly to their proper positions. The machinery is somewhat thrown out of line, but Col. H. is of opinion that the steamer can be put in running order in two weeks. -- Albany Evening Journal, July 11.

abstract: PROBABLE MURDER IN JERSEY CITY About 11 o'clock, on Friday night, an affray occurred at a larger-bier saloon, No.150 Prospect-street, Jersey City, during which the proprietor, WILLIAN BUSH received induries at the hands of half a dozen sailors, belonging to an English vessel, which will undoubtedly terminate fatally.
lead_paragraph: PROBABLE MURDER IN JERSEY CITY. -- About 11 o'clock, on Friday night, an affray occurred at a larger-bier saloon, No.150 Prospect-street, Jersey City, during which the proprietor, WILLIAN BUSH received induries at the hands of half a dozen sailors, belonging to an English vessel, which will undoubtedly terminate fatally. It appears that the men went into the saloon, and after taking drinks, refused to pay for them. BUSH attempted to turn them out, when he was attacked, and fearing serious bodily harm, went behind the counter and took down a sabre, with which to defend himself. He was immediately overpowered; and one of the men, gaining possession of the sabre, attempted to run him through, but BUSH avoided the blow. They then got him down and jumped several times upon his chest, also beat and choked him. They then went away, and subsequently three of them were arrested by Officer SLOAN, and taken to the Station-house. BUSH went down and made a complaint, but on returning was suddenly prostrated, and experienced great pain in the chest and neck. Dr. STRYKER, assisted by Dr. BOUTON, attended the injured man, and found him suffering severely from internal injuries, to such an extent that they were of the opinion that he could not survive many hours. This (Saturday) forenoon Recorder MARTINDALE took BUSH's deposition, which was in substance as above stated. It was only by the greatest effort and the assistance of stimulants that he was able to give a disconnected statement of the affair. The prisoners, who gave their names as JOHN MCCLENNEN, FRANK REYNOLDS and JAMES EDWARDS, were committed to prison by the Recorder, to await result of the injuries.

abstract: The London Post should have credit for a suggestion in regard to the Cotton supply of the world, which will be found republished in our columns to-day. The Post has been diligently studying the several acts of the Montgomery Congress, and it finds one prohipiting, under heavy penalties, the exportation of cotton or cotton yarn "except through the seaports of said Confederated States."
lead_paragraph: The London Post should have credit for a suggestion in regard to the Cotton supply of the world, which will be found republished in our columns to-day. The Post has been diligently studying the several acts of the Montgomery Congress, and it finds one prohipiting, under heavy penalties, the exportation of cotton or cotton yarn "except through the seaports of said Confederated States." Inasmuch as all these seaports are blockaded by what the Post is pleased to style the "Navy of the North" -- it has forgotten there is such a country as the United States -- and a strict prohibition of inland traffic, prevails, it appears there is small hope for the escape of cotton from the Southern States.

abstract: The Seventh Regiment of the Massachusetts Volunteers enlisted for the war arrived early yesterday morning, in the steamer Commodore, and a large portion of the baggage came on the Commonwealth. As they only struck tents at Taunton at 11 A.M. of Friday, and came via Groton, their early arrival caught the Massachusetts Reception Committee napping. The news soon spread, however, and at 7 ...
lead_paragraph: The Seventh Regiment of the Massachusetts Volunteers enlisted for the war arrived early yesterday morning, in the steamer Commodore, and a large portion of the baggage came on the Commonwealth. As they only struck tents at Taunton at 11 A.M. of Friday, and came via Groton, their early arrival caught the Massachusetts Reception Committee napping. The news soon spread, however, and at 7 1/2 o'clock the Committee of Arrangements met at the Astor, and proceeded thence to the steamer, moored at Pier No. 18. The Committee set forth eloquently their happiness at meeting the soldiers, and pictured in glowing terms the princely preparations that had been made to receive the regiment, breakfast the men at the Park Barracks, and dejeuner the officers at the Astor. Col. COUCH was, however, inexorable; and, in spite of the smoking breakfast, and Mr. WARREN's contemplated oration, absolutely refused to allow his men to land, or to dine at the Park Barracks, or to partake of the Astor House comestibles, or to hear the oration. He was desirous of departing immediately, and meant to transfer his men forth with. The Committee therefore acceded, with as good a grace as possible under the circumstances. There was, however, a breakfast served for the men on board the Kill Von Kull, which boat conveyed men, baggage, and horses to Elizabethport, en route for Harrisburgh.

abstract: The only change at the two remaining theatres of the Metropolis is at the Winter Garden, where Mr. and Mrs. FLORENCE commence a short Summer season on Monday, producing for the occasion the drama of "Handy Andy," and the protean farce called "Lessons for Husbands." These artists are well-liked by...
lead_paragraph: The only change at the two remaining theatres of the Metropolis is at the Winter Garden, where Mr. and Mrs. FLORENCE commence a short Summer season on Monday, producing for the occasion the drama of "Handy Andy," and the protean farce called "Lessons for Husbands." These artists are well-liked by our public, and will, we think, succeed, despite the hard times, especially as elsewhere we find no novelty to oppose them. At LAURA KEENE's the programme is the same as heretofore. At BARNUM's the young "Wizard of the North" is holding forth to good audiences, and stepping in his father's shoes with great comfort and success. Here the record is at an end. In the way of minstreisy, Mr. GEORGE CHRISTY continues to delight his patrons at the elegant little establishment opposite Bond-street. His programmes are always fresh and amusing.

abstract: The diplomacy of the Secessionists has at length achieved a triumph of so much consequence to the United States that we are happy to aid the Secession organs in spreading a knowledge of it among our own people and in other nations. We learn from the Galveston News, of the 25th of June, that Mr. J.A. ECHOLS, Secretary of the Commissioners sent by the Texas Convention to the Indian Nation, had returned, bringing with him the gratifying news that the Chickasaw Legislature had passed an ordinance of Secession (from the United States Government) by a unanimous vote. A Convention of the Choctaws was to be held on the 14th inst. for the same purpose, and there is no doubt that nation has also seceded." The Creek Nation held a Convention, but they sat "with closed doors." Their action is not certainly known, but "they elected Delegates to the Montgomery Congress," from which fact the Texas papers draw conclusions favorable to Secession. Mr. ECHOLS, we are further informed, brought to Austin, Texas, copies of the treaties he had formed with the Chickasaws and "five wild tribes west of the civilized Indians." The Kickapoos, the Delawares, the Keechies, &c., "bind themselves to cooperate with the Southern Confederacy in the present war with the Lincoln [United States] Government."

abstract: THE MAYOR AND HIS FRIENDS. Our readers will remember that, in 1859, under the authority of the City Inspector, a vigorous effort was made to suppress the abominable nuisance of pigstys, which were then quite numerous in the upper Wards. The ordinance in that case requires that all keepers of swine should have the express warrant of the Mayor or City Inspector.
lead_paragraph: THE MAYOR AND HIS FRIENDS. -- Our readers will remember that, in 1859, under the authority of the City Inspector, a vigorous effort was made to suppress the abominable nuisance of pigstys, which were then quite numerous in the upper Wards. The ordinance in that case requires that all keepers of swine should have the express warrant of the Mayor or City Inspector. Mayor TIEMANN then filled the civic chair, and as he could not be induced to soil his robe of office with the filth of swine, the ordinance at that time was enforced with little difficulty. Supported by a force of policemen, the City inspector compelled the pig-owners to remove their piggeries, while those who showed a refractory spirit were dealt with in a summary way. The matter excited much comment at the time, and it was hoped that the evil was permanently abated. But a new King arose in Egypt, and in him the keepers of swine have found a friend. In view of the intensely hot weather, the Sanitary Police have been diligently looking up the filthy and health-destroying objects of the City, and prominently among their reports we find mentioned the hog-pens which abound in the Nineteenth, Twenty-first and Twenty-second Wards. The number of these so far reported is from sixty to seventy, with from three to fifteen hogs in each. Any one who is familiar with the habits of the animal, may fancy that five or six hundred hogs are no desirable addition to the live stock of a limited territory. The huts in which the owners live are little superior to the stys. and before each of them a cauldron is stationed, which receives the garbage obtained from gutters and swillpails, and this reeking mass is kept boiling for hours daily. The exhalations from this villainous mixture cannot be described, but the atmosphere is infected by them for blocks around. Hogs are proverbially unclean, but the horrid, putrid filth in which these hogs revel must be be seen to be believed. On the representations of the Sanitary Police, the Magistrates issued summonses within a few days past to all the parties implicated, requiring them to appear for examination on the charge of having violated the City Ordinance concerning the keeping of swine. This action of the Justices fell like a thunderbolt among the dismayed swineherds, but after obtaining the advice of "distinguished counsel," they rushed to Mayor WOOD and obtained from him a permit to keep swine, in number unlimited and in filth incomparable. Thus protected they answered the summonses, and of course were acquitted. The Mayor in this matter, may be doubtless actuated by a desire to become a terror to evil-doers, and a praise to those who do well, but the Police Commissioners and the Sanitary Squad do not see it in that light.

abstract: The fact that the Government is understood to have ordered six hundred wrought-iron rifled cannon a number not exceeded in any European field armament is satisfactory evidence that it appreciates what must be, in modern warfare, the strong arm of assault and defence. But it is unfortunate, for several reasons, that such an immense order was given to one Pennsylvania house.
lead_paragraph: The fact that the Government is understood to have ordered six hundred wrought-iron rifled cannon -- a number not exceeded in any European field armament -- is satisfactory evidence that it appreciates what must be, in modern warfare, the strong arm of assault and defence. But it is unfortunate, for several reasons, that such an immense order was given to one Pennsylvania house. First, wrought-iron is acknowledged by all military authorities to be vastly inferior to steel as a cannon metal; second, "built-up" cannon, besides being quite as expensive, by reason of the extra amount of labor required, as solid cast-steel guns, are, and must be, from the nature and state of the art less sound, on the average, than guns made of one homogeneous piece. The whole history of failure in wrought structures, made of tolerable and average materials, is simply a history of bad welds, either in the pile from which the forging was made, or in the junction of the several parts of the completed work. This is a cardinal fact in iron-working, which no practitioner will attempt to deny, and which is so simple and well known as to be patent to the public at large. It is true that blacksmiths, with careful heats and manipulations, and hammers ten or twenty times heavier than ordinary trip-hammers, in proportion to the work, can generally make sound welds; but welding large masses, under the comparatively light pressure of common hammers and rolls, is universally distrusted and avoided as far as may be, while an excess of size is always given to large welded parts which are subjected to great strain. Not one-tenth part of railway bars are as sound in the weld as through the homogeneous parts, which accounts for their rapid destruction by lamination and peeling. In designing wrought iron work, the good engineer avoids welds in light working parts whenever he can, and in locomotive and steamboat practice, he frequently goes to the expense of bronze castings, the best of which will average as strong as wrought iron, and even prefers iron castings, in some cases, to welds. And in making large forgings, the great modern improvement has been the reduction of the number of pieces in the pile from which the forging is made, by increasing the size of the slabs forming the pile, and the use of heavier rolls and hammers, chiefly for the purpose of reducing the number of welds and increasing the soundness of those that cannot be avoided. If this is the practice under ordinary strains, what are the risks of welds under the terrific and instantaneous force of gun-powder?

abstract: SUSQUEHANNA. -- One of the assistant engineers on board this steamer, in a letter to a relative in this city, writes: "We sailed from Boston on Wednesday morning, and arrived off Cape Henry at 2 1/2 P.M. on Saturday. At 4 o'clock on that afternoon we broke our starboard shaft, which was twenty inches in diameter, where it goes outboard. We shall have to return North for a new one, and are now awaiting orders from Washington. There was no fraud about this breakdown, as about forty per cent. of the break was an old flaw, and could not have been discovered, unless some one could be found small enough to crawl through the pores of the iron. We were going very slow at the time of the break, and the water was very smooth. If the shaft had broken in a storm the sea would have torn the wheel out of the ship." -- Boston Traveller, July 12.
lead_paragraph: SUSQUEHANNA. -- One of the assistant engineers on board this steamer, in a letter to a relative in this city, writes: "We sailed from Boston on Wednesday morning, and arrived off Cape Henry at 2 1/2 P.M. on Saturday. We shall have to return North for a new one, and are now awaiting orders from Washington. There was no fraud about this breakdown, as about forty per cent. of the break was an old flaw, and could not have been discovered, unless some one could be found small enough to crawl through the pores of the iron. We were going very slow at the time of the break, and the water was very smooth. If the shaft had broken in a storm the sea would have torn the wheel out of the ship." -- Boston Traveller, July 12.

abstract: Fortune has at last favored the brave. I will not discuss the legitimacy of his cause, thouth I do think that haste in action has perhaps been his only fault, yet one thing cannot be denied, MOSQUERA he has shown himself a good general, an energetic and presevering chief. I take it that on such as these it is that fortune bestows her choicest smiles.
lead_paragraph: Fortune has at last favored the brave. I will not discuss the legitimacy of his cause, thouth I do think that haste in action has perhaps been his only fault, yet one thing cannot be denied, MOSQUERA -- he has shown himself a good general, an energetic and presevering chief. I take it that on such as these it is that fortune bestows her choicest smiles. We are advised, then, that after being in the outskirts of Bogota, and sustained a siege almost as long as that of Troy, at last he has accomplished the feat of entering the city, creating such a feeling in the true hearts of the conservative old "Bogotanos" as might be felt only by a Celestian at seeing an honest Abbetonian plenipotentiary patting his grand Tycoon on the back, and telling him that he is a "regular brick." But in order that you may better understand events as they have transpired, I will condense for you the communication of the Secretary of War to the Governor of Candinamarca, dated Handa, June 10.

abstract: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRS. WINSLOW; we will simply say that she is a lady who for upwards of 30 years, has untiringly devoted her time and talents as a female physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, so generally overlooked or carelessly treated by the faculty in too many instances; and, as a result of this effort, and practical knowledge obtained in a lifetime spent at nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article, Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children do certainly RISE UP and bless her especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grave by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn will share its benefits and unite in calling her blessed. No MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it, mothers -- TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

lead_paragraph: WILLIAMSBURGH DISPENSARY. -- During the last month 645 persons were treated in this Dispensary, classified as follows: Males, 237; females, 408. Nativity -- United States. 376; Ireland, 226; England, 25; Germany, 17; Scotland, 1. 639 prescriptions were gratuitously dispensed. The diseases were as follows: injuries, 16; nervous, 27; skin, 78; head, 38; abdomen, 144; eye and ear, 11; heart, lung and throat, 44; minor surgery, 74; rheumatism, 12; urinary, 3; abscess, 4; fever, 6; vaccinated, 213. The ages of those treated were as follows: under 1 year, 115; between 1 and 5, 141; between 5 and 10, 74; between 10 and 30, 163; over 30, 152.

abstract: The Washington correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer writes: "I am in possession of some facts which may throw some light upon the mysterious movements connected with the visit of Hon. HENRY MAY to Richmond. It is an undeniable fact, that at the time Mr. MAY was a candidate for Congress in Baltimore, he received the votes not only of Republican Union men, but also of Union men who did not take ground in favor of the war, and also the votes of many whose sympathies were with the South. It is certain, too, that his election was regarded with pleasure at the South. So far as Mr. MAY himself is concerned, I am positive in saying that he is ardently and sincerely attached to the Union, and wishes it reconstructed. But he is opposed to the war, which he believes to be unjust and unnecessary. He believes, too, that the war will never cause or result in a reconstruction of the Union; but that the longer it is continued, the more impossible will Union become. Mr. DAVIS, knowing these to be his views, invited him to Richmond, hoping that through his influence in Congress the door of reconciliation might be again opened.
lead_paragraph: The Washington correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer writes: "I am in possession of some facts which may throw some light upon the mysterious movements connected with the visit of Hon. HENRY MAY to Richmond. It is an undeniable fact, that at the time Mr. MAY was a candidate for Congress in Baltimore, he received the votes not only of Republican Union men, but also of Union men who did not take ground in favor of the war, and also the votes of many whose sympathies were with the South. It is certain, too, that his election was regarded with pleasure at the South. So far as Mr. MAY himself is concerned, I am positive in saying that he is ardently and sincerely attached to the Union, and wishes it reconstructed. But he is opposed to the war, which he believes to be unjust and unnecessary. He believes, too, that the war will never cause or result in a reconstruction of the Union; but that the longer it is continued, the more impossible will Union become. Mr. DAVIS, knowing these to be his views, invited him to Richmond, hoping that through his influence in Congress the door of reconciliation might be again opened.

abstract: The seven New-York companies of this regiment will be mustered into the United Stated service on Tuesday morning, by Capt. HAYMAN, of the Seventh United States Infantry. Col. McREYNOLDS returned...
lead_paragraph: The seven New-York companies of this regiment will be mustered into the United Stated service on Tuesday morning, by Capt. HAYMAN, of the Seventh United States Infantry. Col. McREYNOLDS returned from Washington on Friday, with the requisite authority for obtaining uniforms and arms, and also with his commission as Colonel of the regiment, he having been sworn into service while in that city. Government has concluded to purchase the horses for this regiment, and contractors arc now sending them to Washington as fast as they can be purchased. The regiment will be mounted as soon as they arrive in that city. This regiment of cavalry -- the only one accepted from this State -- comprises many men who have been in active service, and is commanded by an experienced officer, whose services in the Mexican war are duly recorded in the War Department. It was at the special request of Gen. SCOTT that Col. MCREYNOLDS was appointed to the command. Seven of the twelve companies of the regiment have been raised in this City, and as they are officered by experienced military men. New-York will expect much from them. A more respectable-looking body of men than have enrolled their names in the Lincoln Cavalry have not left this City. During the weary weeks of delay they have devoted themselves attentively to drill, and are not only well posted in company evolutions, but have become quite expert with the sabre. After being mustered into service, they will go into camp near the City to await their arms and uniforms. The three Pennsylvania and two Ohio companies have already been mustered in and are in camp. The entire regiment will, by order of the War Department, be in Washington within ten days. A few active, experienced horsemen will be received, also two or three buglers, wagoners and blacksmiths, on applying at DISBROW's Riding Academy, or at No. 648 Broadway.

abstract: The Charleston Courier, of July contains reports of the manner in which Fourth of July was celebrated in that city. Picnics seem to have been the distinguishing feature of the day, military displays being dispensed with, perhaps because they had not soldiers enough to make a respectable parade. The Seventy-six Association also celebrated the day with a supper. Mr. SAMUEL L. HAMMOND was among the speakers. The style of his oratory is fairly represented in the following extract:

abstract: The very large and steadily increasing circulation of the TIMES gives constant occasion for remonstrance as to the tardiness with which it is delivered to subscribers in New-York and Brooklyn. The attention of the proprietors has for some time been directed to obviating this defect. They are now enabled to announce that in the course of a few days such arrangements will be perfected as will cause a much earlier delivery of the entire morning edition, and thus remove all ground of complaint.
