abstract: Now that this dreaded disease is skulking on our byways and secretly holding sway in higher places, vaccination becomes a serious duty, to be overlooked only by those who would nurse a pestilence. It maybe obtained with ease and propriety, from pure sources, by the humblest in our midst, through the excellent arrangements to that end which have lately been effected. Crowds gather daily at the different station-houses and dispensaries, and a visit to some of them gives one an extra peep down into mysterious human nature. The class who form the majority of applicants at the Eastern Dispensary are descendants of generation upon generation of low intelligences, so that they present their case and questions all at once; this, too, without the smallest intention of being understood, or of comprehending in return, until after several repetitions; said repetitions becoming pathetic, belligerent, or comic in their advanced stages, according as they seem to affect the auditor. The resident physician having had a long experience with this demonstrative class, has a way of getting along peculiar to himself. He hears the whole story, curtailing it or not as the case may be, and after replying to it settles himself for the repetitions; -- in the meantime tips the wink to an aid at his elbow to take up the cho business. It is rather heavy on the lungs, often ad to the eye and repellant to every sense, but a most excellent school for the cultivation of patience. Interspersed with these are many of a very different type from that just referred to. The once opulent and luxurious, the refined economist, the educated poor come here in lowly garb, with modest request for medical advice and assistance. The healthy and hardy German and Swiss population of our City depend almost wholly upon this institution for the vaccination of their infants; and their superior cleanliness, together with the customary presentation of their offspring previous to dentition, renders the virus obtained from them unexceptionable in character, and therefore is largely used by the practitioners of this institution, who have sufficient overplus to abundantly supply many physicians throughout the City. Thirty-eight regiments have been supplied with matter from this institution: beside requisitions being filled from Miss DIX for the Washington Hospital, the Albany Military Hospital, and the volunteers at the New-York Hospital. Dr. LOINES, resident physician here, operated upon three thousand of the five thousand six hundred and fifty-three patients, which composed the total number vaccinated by all the Dispensaries in this City during the month of May. The rush is not so great during the advanced Summer mouths, and gradually falls off to a small average in the Fall, owing to a popular superstition that when the sap runs up the tree in the Spring, the blood is best prepared to take the vaccine.

abstract: Yesterday morning Gen. McCLELLAN ordered four regiments, the Eighth, Tenth and the Thirteenth Indiana Volunteers, and the Nineteenth Ohio Volunteers, to proceed along the line of the hills, southeast of the enemy's intrenched camp, to the Beverly Road where it crosses Rich Mountain, two miles east of the enemy's position, with orders to advance along the Beverly road and attack the east side of the works, Gen. McCLELLAN being prepared to assault ...
lead_paragraph: BEVERLY, Randolph Co., Va., Saturday, July 13.
headline: {'main': 'THE WAR IN WESTERN VIRGINIA.; DETAILS OF THE BATTLE AT RICH MOUNTAIN.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE WAR IN WESTERN VIRGINIA.; DETAILS OF THE BATTLE AT RICH MOUNTAIN.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The rebels are utterly discomfited in Western Virginia -- their position is such as to render it extremely improbable that they will venture another battle, unless they are driven to it. Full and reliable details of the battle at Rich Mountain, and the events which followed it, lead inevitably to this conclusion. Gen. MCCLELLAN's dispatches to the War Department state that his success is all that he could desire. He captured six brass cannon, of which one is rifled, and all the enemy's camp equipage, even to his cups -- about two hundred tents, and more than sixty wagons. The enemy's loss in killed and wounded was fully one hundred and fifty, with at least one hundred prisoners. Gen. MCCLELLAN immediately followed up this most complete victory by by pushing on and occupying Beverly, within a few miles of which GARNETT, at the head of about ten thousand rebels, was encamped. GARNETT hearing of the approach of the National forces, precipitately left, and at last accounts was retreating in confusion on the road to St. George, with Gen. MORRIS in full pursuit, and with a good prospect of his retreat being cut off by Gen. HILL, who has been stationed at Rowlesburgh, and who was instructed to move immediately to intercept GARRETT. Gen. MCCLELLAN closes his dispatch with an intimation that by this time, probably, Gen. COX has driven Gen. WISE and his rebels out of the Kanawha Valley, thus making the work in Western Virginia complete.

abstract: When a person is overboard, and in the act of sinking, it is hardly the time to discuss the cost of the means by which he is to be rescued. We have no disposition to refer, except by way of approval, to the vast sums so promptly voted at Washington to put down the great rebellion and to restore our national unity. But in all this are we not in great danger of establishing a precedent, or habit, which we shall never shake off after peace is secured? In the administration of their finances all nations of modern times seem incapable of reforming an expense or office. Once created they are never abolished. Such is our own history; but much more striking illustrations of this fact are to be found in the experience of France and England. The annual expenses of the Government of each of these countries, upon a peace footing, cannot now be reduced much below $400,000,000. The rate of their increase, particularly of France, appears to be limited only by the ability to borrow, or to devise some new and cunning mode of taxation whereby another slice may he taken from the profits of the industry of the people.

abstract: The Speaker laid before the House, this afternoon, a communication from the Postmaster-General, made in compliance with the law which requires him to state the reasons for discountinuing the mails in the so-called seceded States. He says the events for this course on his part are so well known as to render a detailed statement unnecessary. It seemed more necessary for him to explain why the transportation of the mails was continued therein so long.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Saturday, July 13.

abstract: A clegyman from Virginia, now on a visit to a friend in this city, says the Newark Mercury, gives a doleful picture of the condition of the rebels in that State. The troops in many places are down with the typhus fever and other diseases, and all suffer much from the insufficiency of the commissariat. Widespread insubordination exists among the men, and discipline seems out of the question. A good proportion of the troops are but poorly armed, while some are not armed at all. The leaders, convinced of the weakness of their cause, are growing desperate, and the people would hail with joy any army that would deliver them from their oppressors.

abstract: The paths of "own correspondents" and "special artists," although peculiarly pleasant in peaceful times, seem to lead over singularly rough roads now that the drum beats -- especially in the revolted States. Some time ago the HARPERS, -- with a view, undoubtedly, to their own glorification and the exaltation of their journal, -- announced to the world that they had dispatched a "special artist" to the South in behalf of their Weekly, and that he was then traveling in company with W.H. RUSSELL, LL.D., Barrister at Law, and special correspondent of the London Times. On a copy of the Journal containing this announcement finding its way South, Mr. RUSSELL was waited upon by a committee, who expressed a desire to obtain possession of the person of this young artist, that they might confiscate it for the benefit of the Confedrate States. Thereupon Mr. RUSSELL published, a card in the Mobile Register, denying that any artist was traveling with him in behalf of Harper's Weekly, whereupon the proprietors of the latter journal, to justify themselves from the charge of misrepresenting their business arrangements to the public, reiterated the assertion, and continued to publish sketches "taken by our special artist, traveling in company with W.H. RUSSELL, LL. D., Barrister-at-Law." Subsequently, on the return of Mr. DAVIS -- the artist referred to -- and on his representing that the card in question was only published by Mr. RUSSELL with the amiable design of averting from the whole party an enforced reception of the hospitalities commonly bestowed by Southerners upon guests suspected of unfriendliness to the "peculiar institution," the Weekly published a portrait of Mr. RUSSELL, with a flattering sketch of his "life and works." To vindicate the course which they have taken, and the statements which they have made, the Messrs. HARPER lately called upon their artist to use his pen in their behalf as he has before used his pencil. In this week's issue of the Journal of Civilization he does so, stating that he met Mr. RUSSELL in Washington, and communicated his desire to travel South in his company, at the same time reading to him a note which he had received from his employers containing instructions. Mr. RUSSELL's reply to the proposal was in substance:

Thereupon Mr. RUSSELL published, a card in the Mobile Register, denying that any artist was traveling with him in behalf of Harper's Weekly, whereupon the proprietors of the latter journal, to justify themselves from the charge of misrepresenting their business arrangements to the public, reiterated the assertion, and continued to publish sketches "taken by our special artist, traveling in company with W.H. RUSSELL, LL. D., Barrister-at-Law." Subsequently, on the return of Mr. DAVIS -- the artist referred to -- and on his representing that the card in question was only published by Mr. RUSSELL with the amiable design of averting from the whole party an enforced reception of the hospitalities commonly bestowed by Southerners upon guests suspected of unfriendliness to the "peculiar institution," the Weekly published a portrait of Mr. RUSSELL, with a flattering sketch of his "life and works." To vindicate the course which they have taken, and the statements which they have made, the Messrs. HARPER lately called upon their artist to use his pen in their behalf as he has before used his pencil. In this week's issue of the Journal of Civilization he does so, stating that he met Mr. RUSSELL in Washington, and communicated his desire to travel South in his company, at the same time reading to him a note which he had received from his employers containing instructions. Mr. RUSSELL's reply to the proposal was in substance:

abstract: Having passed several sleepless nights, disturbed by the agonies and cries of a suffering child, and becoming convinced that Mrs. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply for the child. On reaching home, and acquainting his wife with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Homeopathy. That night the child passed in suffering and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following, the father found the baby still worse and, while contemplating another sleepless night, the mother stepped from the room to attend to some domestic duties, and left the father with the child. During her absence be administered a portion of the SOOTHING SYRUP to the baby, and said nothing. That night all hands slept well, and the little fellow awoke in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delighted with the sudden and wonderful change, and although at first offended at the deception practiced upon her, has continued to use the Syrup, and suffering, crying babies and restless nights have disappeared. A single trial of the Syrup never yet failed to relieve the baby, and overcome the prejudices of the mother.

abstract: From what has preceded, it cannot be doubted that the Declaration of Independence was a covenant of National unity with all the foreign Powers who aided the people of the colonies in its achievement.
lead_paragraph: From what has preceded, it cannot be doubted that the Declaration of Independence was a covenant of National unity with all the foreign Powers who aided the people of the colonies in its achievement. It would have been a violation of this solemn covenant, and a mockery of the faith with which they had encouraged the martyrs of the revolution not only, but also the whole civilized world, to confide in its integrity, had any one of them thereafter broken away from its sacred obligations. It was in this National capacity, comprehended under the designation of United Colonies or States, that they procured the treaties of amity and commerce and of alliance with France; that they secured the sympathy and friendship of Spain and Holland; that they procured loans to carry on the war by which they achieved their independence. It was in this capacity that their Ministers and Ambassadors were received and respected abroad. And it was in this capacity alone that their union received the sacred and irrevocable seal of perpetuity under the Confederation.

abstract: Death has been playing sad havoc lately with men in high position. First, Count CAVOUR, then Senator DOUGLAS, then Lord CAMPBELL, and now the Sultan, have paid the debt of nature. The late ABDUL MEDJID, a mild and intelligent Prince, gave himself up to intemperance and the pleasures of the seraglio, and thus has died from exhaustion at the early age of thirty-eight.
lead_paragraph: PARIS, Friday, June 28, 1861.

abstract: "It was thought no possible feat of physical endurance could equal that "night march to Phillippa." We still think it unsurpassed. Col. TYLER thinks "what man has done man can do." He adds five miles to the march, but has no rain. When it was found that there was $30,000 in gold, in Weston, likely to be taken by WISE, Gen. MCCLELLAN started for Clarksburgh, 23 miles from Weston, to send Col. TYLER and his regiment to get the money. TYLERnever sleeps, and seems full of the idea that his office is to be no sinecure. He anticipated the order, and parading his men on a highland near the depot at which MCCLELLAN was to arrive, he told them to keep an eye on him when the train arrived, and if the word from MCCLELLAN was march, hewould wave his handkerchief, and they could show Clarksburgh their heels. The train arrived, and Gen. MCCLELLAN rushed up to Col. TYLER as he sat on his horse, and asked, 'Col. TYLER, how soon can you march for. Weston?' 'I'll show you soon if you will look yonder,' and waving his handkerchief, the whole regiment struck a double quick and disappeared like the hosts of RODERICK DHU. Major CASEMENT started with two horses, but in a few hours was tugging away on foot, both his horses loaded with soldiers whose physical strength had given out, and when they entered Weston, both 'JACK' and his horses were loaded with muskets so as to favor poor exhausted soldiers. We are ready to go our pile on the gallant Seventh Regiment.
lead_paragraph: "It was thought no possible feat of physical endurance could equal that "night march to Phillippa." We still think it unsurpassed. Col. TYLER thinks "what man has done man can do." He adds five miles to the march, but has no rain. When it was found that there was $30,000 in gold, in Weston, likely to be taken by WISE, Gen. MCCLELLAN started for Clarksburgh, 23 miles from Weston, to send Col. TYLER and his regiment to get the money. TYLERnever sleeps, and seems full of the idea that his office is to be no sinecure. He anticipated the order, and parading his men on a highland near the depot at which MCCLELLAN was to arrive, he told them to keep an eye on him when the train arrived, and if the word from MCCLELLAN was march, hewould wave his handkerchief, and they could show Clarksburgh their heels. The train arrived, and Gen. MCCLELLAN rushed up to Col. TYLER as he sat on his horse, and asked, 'Col. TYLER, how soon can you march for. Weston?' 'I'll show you soon if you will look yonder,' and waving his handkerchief, the whole regiment struck a double quick and disappeared like the hosts of RODERICK DHU. Major CASEMENT started with two horses, but in a few hours was tugging away on foot, both his horses loaded with soldiers whose physical strength had given out, and when they entered Weston, both 'JACK' and his horses were loaded with muskets so as to favor poor exhausted soldiers. We are ready to go our pile on the gallant Seventh Regiment.

abstract: There is good reason to believe that since the mouth of the Chesapeake has been closed, the ingenuity of the rebels has found another and safer route by which to obtain the beef, pork and flour necessary to feed their guerillas on the western shore of Virginia and the Potomac.
lead_paragraph: There is good reason to believe that since the mouth of the Chesapeake has been closed, the ingenuity of the rebels has found another and safer route by which to obtain the beef, pork and flour necessary to feed their guerillas on the western shore of Virginia and the Potomac. The eastern shore of Virginia and Maryland is separated at several points by only some seven miles from the Atlantic side, and there are several barred harbors which are easily accessible by vessels of light draft, through which provisions are stealthily introduced at night, without the fear of detection. The principal of these to Chincoteague Inlet, with nine feet it low tide; Towpink's Inlet, ten feet; Watchapoenque, eight feet; Hog Island, twelve feet; Sandshoes, eight miles South of Hog Island, with twelve feet at low water; and Ship Shoal Inlet, between Sand Shoal and Smith Island, with five feet entrance at low tide. Into these out-of-the way places, quantities of provisions, it is believed, are nightly introduced, and after being transported over the peninsula of Eastern Virginia and Maryland, are conveyed across the Chesapeake in some of the innumerable pongys which abound in the rivers on the opposite shore.

abstract: THE CASK OF CHRISTIAN EBLE. Coroner GAMBLE on Satur a closed the inquest in the case of CHRISTIAN EDLE, the German, whose remians were found about ten days since in a pond of stagnant water, at be corner of Sixty-third-street and Broadway, without having been able to ascertain the circumstances attending his death; and the jury rendered a verdict of "death from hemorrhage conse-...
lead_paragraph: THE CASK OF CHRISTIAN EBLE. -- Coroner GAMBLE on Satur a closed the inquest in the case of CHRISTIAN EDLE, the German, whose remians were found about ten days since in a pond of stagnant water, at be corner of Sixty-third-street and Broadway, without having been able to ascertain the circumstances attending his death; and the jury rendered a verdict of "death from hemorrhage consequent upon wounds in the breast, inflicted with a knife or other sharp instrument, at the hands of some person or persons unknown." The evidence elicited does not by any means warrant the belief that deceased was murderer, but rather that he had committed suicide. One of his friends testified that when EDLE left home a day or two before his body was found, he remarked that in case he never returned his watch should be given to one of his acquaintances, whom he designated. A jack-knife was found on his person, and with it the wounds could have been inflicted, while their nature and direction indicated that they had been made from within the shirt bosom. The deceased, it was likewise shown, was of intemperate habits, and had been some time out of employment. Dr. BEACH, who made the post-mortem examination, inclines to the theory of suicide, and in support of his belief mentions that the clothing of the deceased was undisturbed, and the position in which the body was found indicated that it had fallen into the pond.

abstract: The victory of Gen. MCCLELLAN is even more complete than the first dispatches intimated. The enemy was not only beaten, with the loss of one hundred and fifty killed, and of his artillery, baggage and camp equipage, but has since surrendered, thus placing 600 prisoners in the hands of the National commander. The effect of a triumph so important must be decisive of the war beyond the Alleghanies. The main body of the rebels, 10,000 strong, under Ex-Congressman GARNETT, was in full retreat at our last accounts; while upon the position of Gen. WISE, at Charleston, a strong detachment of Ohio troops was advancing up the Kanawha. The rout of Colonel PEGRAM, an accomplished officer, graduated at West Point, must tend to dishearten GARNETT and WISE, who bring no military knowledge to their business; while the fearful loss of life among his men must strike terror to the common soldiery. Besides, with every new collision between the rebels and the National forces, the illusions with which the Southern war spirit has been fed, are destroyed. The Northern soldier is found not only not to luck courage, but to possess it in connection with a skill and steadiness before which the rebels cannot for a moment stand. These phenomena will also brace up the nerves of the Union men of Virginia and Tennessee, who will know they are no longer left to the oppression of WISE and PILLOW. Our only regret, as we witness these successes of our arms beyond the Alleghanies, is that they provoke no emulation at Washington and Martinsburgh.

abstract: Upon the English statute books are a great number of laws once in harmony with the spirit of the times, and in full force, but which, upon changes in public sentiment and in the structure of society, have long since been practically, though not formally, repealed.
lead_paragraph: Upon the English statute books are a great number of laws once in harmony with the spirit of the times, and in full force, but which, upon changes in public sentiment and in the structure of society, have long since been practically, though not formally, repealed. The habiliments of a previous generation no longer fit the present, and they are hung up in some out-of-the-way closet, awaiting a possible contingency, instead of being thrown to the clothes-gatherer or rag-man. The United States are a young people, yet old enough to have outgrown, in the same way, laws inherited from our English ancestry, and which still have a conspicuous place in our Constitution and codes of law. Among these obsolete laws is that against Treason. Under the old English Constitution, from which our own was borrowed, the laws against treason were cruel and sanguinary, and in the hands of the Courts, backed as they usually were by compliant juries, were instruments by which the head of every person obnoxious to the Crown could be easily brought to the block. We admit that rulers in olden times were compelled to carry a firm hand. Society had not been learned that as a general rule, the greater the freedom the more perfect the public order. In popular idea, the Government was the State, and to conspire against one was to conspire against the other. In the safety and security of the former was that of the latter. In the safety of the King was the salvation of the people. For a conspiracy against the former, no punishment could be too severe. In olden times, treason was the more severely dealt with, because it was an attack upon private as well as public rights. Then the power to govern exercised, was not by virtue of popular appointment, but as a matter of prescriptive right. Treason was thus a conspiracy against persons as well as the State, and the law against it was pursued with all the energy with which a man defends himself from a personal assault. But England has grown more lenient and humane. Treason there is rarely plotted. The Tower is the show-place for the curious relics of the middle ages, no longer the pen for the suspected or convicted. Government has nothing to fear from Treason, and when fears are not aroused, punishments are never cruel or excessive.

abstract: Thomas Galway et al. vs. The United States Steam Sugar Refining Company et al. -- This case was fully stated in the TIMES of July [???] The plaintiffs obtained an injunction restraining the defendants from making any confession of judgment, and from any alienation of the property of the company. He also obtained an injunction restraining all creditors from commencing any action against the Company, together with an order to show cause why a receiver should not be appointed. These injunctions and the order to show cause were obtained upon the allegation that the Company was insolvent, and would not go into voluntary dissolution, and that about half of the indebtedness matured on the 14th of June last, and the creditors to that amount were about commencing suits. Upon the return to the order to show cause the defendants denied all the allegations of the plaintiffs that they, the defendants, had made any attempts to prefer creditors. They claimed to be doing a good business, and to be perfectly solvent. Their affidavits tended to show that their whole indebtedness was about $200,000, while their real estate was worth $500,000, subject only to a mortgage for $195,000. Upon these papers the defendants' counsel denied the right of a creditor at large, before obtaining judgment and execution, and while the real estate of the Company was lying open, to any relief in a Court of Equity, and contended that the Court had no power under its general jurisdiction in equity, or by virtue of any statute, to sequestrate the property of the Company and appoint a receiver in such a case.

abstract: Our correspondent at Havana announces the arrival at Cienfuegos of the Sumler, a steamer of the rebel Navy, bringing six prizes, the results of a short predatory cruise. A seventh had been burned at sea.
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent at Havana announces the arrival at Cienfuegos of the Sumler, a steamer of the rebel Navy, bringing six prizes, the results of a short predatory cruise. A seventh had been burned at sea. This Sumter was in other times a mail steamer plying between Havana and New-Orleans, with the title, Habana; but seized by the rebel government, she was converted into a man-of-war, and well-armed and manned, put to sea the other day from New-Orleans, in saucy defiance of what the journals of that city properly describe as the paper blockade. The news of her departure has barely reached us when it is hotly pursued by this later news of her success. It is true the insular authorities have reclaimed the six prizes, because they had been captured within Spanish waters; but the fact of seizure shows the power for mischief possessed by the cruiser in question, and renders it almost certain that if any of these released vessels hereafter depart for their ports of destination in the United States, they will be exposed to serious danger of recapture and condemnation. Moreover, the Sumter, sailing from Cienfuegos has doubtless placed herself in the path of the Aspinwall steamers, with their millions of California treasure. Much pains have been taken by the steamship company to put their packets in a thoroughly defensible condition; and it is possible they may be able to contend successfully against privateers. But the Sumter, according to the New-Orleans papers, is far more perfectly armed and equipped than any privateer; and if the treasure ship crosses its track, the odds are fearfully against an escape. These facts and dangers are the first fruits of the laxity with which the blockade is enforced at the mouth of the Mississippi.

abstract: The defeat of the rebel forces at Rich Mountain by Gen: MCCLELLAN, and the subsequent occupation of Beverly by the latter, have been followed by one of the most complete and humiliating blows which have yet fallen upon the head of this rebellion. Gen. MCCLELLAN has reporter to Gen. SCOTT, under date of the 13th inst., that Col. PEGRAM has...
lead_paragraph: The defeat of the rebel forces at Rich Mountain by Gen: MCCLELLAN, and the subsequent occupation of Beverly by the latter, have been followed by one of the most complete and humiliating blows which have yet fallen upon the head of this rebellion. Gen. MCCLELLAN has reporter to Gen. SCOTT, under date of the 13th inst., that Col. PEGRAM has surrendered himself, his officers and the entire remnant force under his command, some 600 men, -- extremely penitent, they say, and determined never again to take up arms against the General Government. This swells the number of Gen. MCCLELLAN's prisoners to 900 or 1,000, while the rebel loss in the battle, according to the latest accounts, was one hundred and fifty in killed alone. We expect next to hear that GARNETT, who, with his rebel force, was last heard of in full retreat from Beverly, has been cut off by Gen. MORRIS, and between the two forces of MORRIS and MCCLELLAN, has been either defeated or forced, like PEORAM, to surrender. A dispatch from Beverly, dated yesterday, announces that the advance division of Gen. MCCLELLAN's army is moving rapidly towards the Cheat Mountain Pass. The rebels have burned the bridges at Huttonsville, and were expected also to burn the one at Cheat Mountain, but this would not delay the advance an hour.

abstract: No just of prudent Government will ever borrow money on permanent loan, to pay its current yearly expenses. A community which has no means of revenue sufficient to sustain its ordinary political existence, should disband at once, and join some stronger body.
lead_paragraph: No just of prudent Government will ever borrow money on permanent loan, to pay its current yearly expenses. A community which has no means of revenue sufficient to sustain its ordinary political existence, should disband at once, and join some stronger body. A people unable or unwilling to pay the expenses of their Government, are not fit to govern themselves, nor is it possible for them to do so for any considerable time. Exigencies, however, do arise where Governments may properly borrow money to provide for extraordinary expenses, which are only temporary.

abstract: When JOHN SHERMAN, of Ohio, was agreed on by the Republican members of the late Congress, as their candidate for Speaker, he was met by the secession Democracy of the House with perhaps the most violent and un- scrupulous opposition that ever assailed an honorable man who was a candidate for that office. This opposition was led by the Hon.
lead_paragraph: When JOHN SHERMAN, of Ohio, was agreed on by the Republican members of the late Congress, as their candidate for Speaker, he was met by the secession Democracy of the House with perhaps the most violent and un- scrupulous opposition that ever assailed an honorable man who was a candidate for that office. This opposition was led by the Hon. JOHN B. CLARK, of Missouri, then representing the Third Congressional District of that State; or rather, it was begun by CLARK; for, as little self-respecting as the Democratic members of that Session were, they would never have admitted that the semi "border-ruffian" CLARK was their leader.

abstract: When, after the fall of Sumter, the President called for seventy-five thousand volunteers, the whole country was startled at the vastness of the proposed Army. Such a prodigious force had never before taken the field on this continent; and the proclamation calling it out struck many persons -- particularly, it was said, Mr. JEFF. DAVIS' Cabinet -- as a bit of ridiculous though perfectly harmless braggadocio. The chivalry laughed consumedly at the idea of seventy-five thousand of even the poorest troops being raised from among the vulgar mudsill Democracy of the Free States; and our English co-temporaries also ridiculed the assumption that the peaceful and commercial people of the North would ever raise such an Army to fight for so shadowy a thing as the unity of the Republic, particularly when no dollars were to be made by it. It was seriously feared by some, too, that Congress would hardly ratify the President's action in calling to arms such an unprecedented force.

abstract: The very large and steadily increasing circulation of the TIMES gives constant occasion for remonstrance as to the tardiness with which it is delivered to subscribers in New-York and Brooklyn. The attention of the proprietors has for some time been directed to obviating this defect. They are now enabled to announce that in the course of a few days such arrangements will be perfected as will cause a much earlier delivery of the entire morning edition, and thus remove all ground of complaint.

abstract: The first peal of cannon at Fort Sumter called a nation to arms. Soldiers have sprung up from every glen and hillside, from farms and villages and the streets of populous cities. Contributions have been made with a liberal hand to uniform and equip the soldier, to minister to his wants, and to cherish in his absence those that the holds dear. Arsenals, armories and dock-yards are busy. The clergyman offers his prayers, the lawyer his pen, and the physician his skill in the common cause, while women and our children have sat their fingers in motion to shape a tunic or fashion a havelock.

abstract: BROOKLYN, CENTRAL AND JAMAICA RAILROAD. ?The old railroad from the South ferry, Brooklyn, to Jamaica, under its present management, is operated efficiently, successfully, and to the satisfaction of the traveling public.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN, CENTRAL AND JAMAICA RAILROAD. -- The old railroad from the South ferry, Brooklyn, to Jamaica, under its present management, is operated efficiently, successfully, and to the satisfaction of the traveling public. Cars now leave almost hourly, and arrive at Jamaica in time to connect with the trains of the Long Island Railroad going East and West. This new, regular, and frequent operation of the old South ferry route, is a very great convenience to the public, as is daily shown by the increasing travel over the road. The running time from South ferry to Jamaica is less than one hour, and the fare has been reduced to twenty cents. Persons visiting Rockaway will find the old South ferry route not only convenient, but speedy. We understand that permanent arrangements have been made so that stages will connect with the cars of the Company at Jamaica, and so that there will be no mistake or delay in reaching or returning from Rockaway.

abstract: On Saturday afternoon, Officer CLARK, of the Seventh Precinct, rescued a man who had fallen into the water, at the foot of Catharine-street, East River, but he did not long survive the immersion, having expired on the way to the station-house. The deceased has not been identified. Another unrecognized man died on Saturday afternoon, in the hands of the Ninth-Precint Police, from exhaustion, consequent upon falling off the pier into the river, at the foot of West Tenth-street. He was intoxicated when the accident befel him. Coroner SCHIEMER will hold inquests.

abstract: Gen. McCLELLAN is disposed to indemnify the country for the inaction at Washington by superhuman activity in Western Virginia. A victory a day is certainly as much as can be demanded even Napoleonic skill and energy; and in this proportion does the Western leader furnish his achievements.
lead_paragraph: Gen. McCLELLAN is disposed to indemnify the country for the inaction at Washington by superhuman activity in Western Virginia. A victory a day is certainly as much as can be demanded even Napoleonic skill and energy; and in this proportion does the Western leader furnish his achievements. The defeat of PEGRAM is followed on the ensuing day by the surrender of that leader, with the remnant of his force; and another day announces the utter discomfiture of GARNETT, with the main body of the rebel army, and the death of that commander. This energy and success are what the nation demands of its military servants. Had they been exhibited on the Potomac and the James, three months ago, the war, there is the best reason to believe, would now be practically ended by the expulsion of the insurgents from Virginia.
headline: {'main': 'The Victories in Western Virginia.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Victories in Western Virginia.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Our dispatches this morning verify our anticipations of yesterday, that the measures taken by Gen. MCCLELLAN to intercept the retreat of the rebel forces, under Gen. GARNETT, would prove entirely successful. A dispatch from Gen. MCCLELLAN, received by the War Department, dated on Sunday, gives the particulars in brief of a battle which took place on Sunday morning, which resulted in the total route of the rebel forces, and the death of GARNETT himself, at the hands of an Indiana soldier. The battle, precisely in accordancewith the plan announced in a previous dispatch from Gen. MCCLELLAN, was fought by the National forces, under Gen. MORRIL, a few miles from St. George, with a loss of only thirteen killed and about forty wounded on our side, while the rebels had some fifty killed and a great, number taken prisoners. The remnant of the rebel Army is now quite likely to be captured by the National forces under Gen. HILL, when the enemy will be entirely annihilated in Western Virginia, and secession -- there, at least -- will be dead. The troops defeated in the recent engagements there are the best regiments of Eastern Virginia, aided by Georgians, Carolinians and Tennesseeans.

abstract: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRS. WINSLOW? we will simply say that she is a lady who for upwards of 30 years, has untiringly devoted her times and talents as a female physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, so generally overlooked or carelessly treated by the faculty in the many instances; and, as a result of this effort, and practical knowledge obtained in a lifetime spent a nurse and physician, she has compounded a Stoothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article, Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children do certainly HUNG UP and bless here especially is this the case in this City. Fast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grave by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn will share its benefits and unite in calling her blessed. No MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it, mothers -- TRYIT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: Judge P.B. MUIR, of our Circuit Court, in a case before him, involving the question of the legality of the Government's blockade of our railroad to Nashville, has this morning decided the blockade to be legal. His decision, if carried to the Court of Appeals, will probably be confirmed. The President, JAMES GUTHRIE, and the Union Directors of the road, will submit to it, and Kentuckians generally will.

abstract: The force intrenched at Laurel Hill evacuated their position on last Friday night, leaving their camp equipage and sick and wounded, taking the road towards Beverly. abstract: A STRIKE AMONG THE SHOEMAKERS. About sixty of the "jour" shoemakers in the employ of Mr. HARMON, No. 30 Dey-street, New-York, yesterday started on a "strike" for higher wages, and immediately called at the establishment of Mr. HARSHAW, corner of Fulton and Nassau streets, Brooklyn, where about 100 men of their craft are employed...
lead_paragraph: A STRIKE AMONG THE SHOEMAKERS. -- About sixty of the "jour" shoemakers in the employ of Mr. HARMON, No. 30 Dey-street, New-York, yesterday started on a "strike" for higher wages, and immediately called at the establishment of Mr. HARSHAW, corner of Fulton and Nassau streets, Brooklyn, where about 100 men of their craft are employed They urged the workmen to quit work unless paid higher wages, but Mr. HARSHAW made a speech to them, stating that he was paying as high prices as he could afford to pay under his contract, and the men concluded to remain at their work for the present. The men say they have been receiving only 44 cents a pair for making soldiers' shoes, (of which they can make but one pair a day,) and have to find their own thread, wax, bristles and pegs.

abstract: The United States mail transport Cahawba, Capt. J.B. BAKER, arrived at her dock yesteaday at 9 o'clock. The Cahawba sailed from Fort Pickens on the morning of the 5th inst., at 7 o'clock, and from Key West on the morning of the 9th inst., at 7 o'clock, having run into that port for water, &c. At Pickens all remains quiet, and the idea of a fight coming off is almost given up; yet one visiting the fort will find everything in perfect readiness for action. The New-York Sixth Regiment (Wilson's Zouaves) arrived safely from the steamer Vanderbilt, and encamped on Santa Rosa Island, distant about one and a half miles from Fort Pickens, and directly in sight of the rebel camp, near the Navy-yard. We made a visit to the camp before sailing, and found all as busy as bees, picking out camp-ground, pitching tents, pitching into mosquitos, (of which there was any quantity) &c. As for the camp, we cannot say much for it. The Island of itself is perfectly barren, and covered with sand, from six inches to eight feet deep. While in conversation with Col. WILSON, we inquired how his men liked Pickens. He replied that all were satisfied.

abstract: It is now more than half a year since Florida, with an air of ridiculous pomposity worthy of the State from which the bulk of her population is drawn, announced to the world that she "solemnly withdrew herself from the existing government of the said United States; and that the State of Florida is hereby de- clared a Sovereign and Independent Nation."
lead_paragraph: It is now more than half a year since Florida, with an air of ridiculous pomposity worthy of the State from which the bulk of her population is drawn, announced to the world that she "solemnly withdrew herself from the existing government of the said United States; and that the State of Florida is hereby de- clared a Sovereign and Independent Nation." Unfortunately for Florida, however, it is one thing to declare for an independent nationality and quite another thing to achieve it; and while the three tailors of Tooley-street, or the three dozen traitors of Tallahassee can easily enough assemble in Convention and put forth the most defiant programmes -- it is not so easy for the former to whip the Horse Guards, or for the latter to reduce Fort Taylor, Fort Jefferson and Fort Pickens, and to sink, burn and destroy the cruisers of Uncle Sam, which keep watch and ward round her whole coast-line, from St. Mary's to the Perdido. The fact is, that is a piece of work which the Tallahassee Sovereign Convention never thought of. The Floridians had so often seen the dough-faced Yankee Congressmen cower and quake before the threatenings of YULEE and MALLORY, that they fancied the Government would be glad to secure their friendship on any terms -- even though it had to be purchased at as high a price as we gave a few years ago for their territory.
headline: {'main': 'The Case of Florida.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Case of Florida.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: --In consequence of the present straitness in money matters, there will be less traveling this Summer than heretofore. The proprietors of hotels at Saratoga. Niagara Falls and the White Mountains will probably be able to furnish their guest with less crowded accommodations. Everybody expects, when starting upon a Summer tour, to find at the hotels, after a fatiguing journey, pleasant, airy rooms; but those who have not spoken in advance are told upon arrival that the best that can be done is a bed upon the parlor floor. Many are intending to recreate this Summer who are now seeking a place for their families where the City can be reached in a short time, if business requires it. The beautiful places upon the Hudson are always sought after by such, and the town of Nyack has deservedly met with large patronage. The most prominent building at Nyack, seen from the river, is the Tappan Zee House, of which Messrs. L.D. & C.F. MANSFIELD are the proprietors. This house, with the exception of ten weeks in the Summer, is occupied by young ladies from all parts of the country, under the tuition of the Messrs. MANSFIELD, who have won a fine reputation for their school in all its departments. On the 1st of July school-books are put away; the young misses return their parents and friends, and the house is made ready for the numerous friends of the proprietors. It is delightfully situated, commanding a view of the Hudson from Hastings to Peekskill. Riding, boating and bathing, with other healthful exercises, are amply provided for. The Messrs. MANSFIELD have, in view of the times, made material reduction in their charges for board. We take pleasure in commending their house to our readers. -- Independent.

abstract: Hon. NATHAN APPLETON, who died in Boston on July 14, was born in Ipswich, N.H., on Oct. 6, 1779. A collegiate course which he commenced at Dartmouth was interrupted that he might become a partner with his brother in a mercantile undertaking in Boston, and in this branch of business he spent a large part of his life, amassing an extensive property. About the year 1821 Mr. APPLETON became deeply interested in the manufacture of cotton, and was one of the three individuals who founded Lowell. From 1831 to 1833 he was a member of the Massachusetts Legislature, and in 1842 was elected a Representative to Congress. He resigned his seat, however, before the close of the term, and remained in private life until his election to the present Congress. A number of pamphlets and essays on Currency, Banking and the Tariff from his pen have been published at intervals during the past few years, and have attracted extended attention.

abstract: Either the British nation is entirely misrepresented by its leading Presses, or it is the most insolent and conceited nation on the face of the earth, the Chinese not excepted; and to these characteristics it adds an ignorance with regard to the affairs of the United States which, if not willful, is unaccountable, and which in either case is disgraceful in regard to a country with whose fate it has such vast interests involved, and to the discussion of whose concerns it gives so much attention. We believe that in both cases our first alternative is the true, or in a great measure the true one. That is, that to a certain degree, at least, the people who "Never, never, never, never shall be slaves," are misrepresented by the journals that profess to speak for them, and that those journals are willful in their ignorance. Prominent among these papers is the Saturday Review, which attained some distinction in the early part of its career by the cleverness and smartness with which it discussed all matters, from a Royal speech to a flunkey's neck-tie. For some time past, however, it has been not smart, but smartish -- not clever, but ratherish clever. An early decrepitude has soured its disposition. Its attic salt has been replaced by British bile -- its lively wit has succumbed to what old BURTON would call a windy melancholy -- its hearty, well-bred, contagious laugh has degenerated into a silly giggle -- and its manly, out-spoken rebuke into an ill-natured snarl -- so that, at last, it has well earned at home the nickname of the Saturday Reviler.
lead_paragraph: Either the British nation is entirely misrepresented by its leading Presses, or it is the most insolent and conceited nation on the face of the earth, the Chinese not excepted; and to these characteristics it adds an ignorance with regard to the affairs of the United States which, if not willful, is unaccountable, and which in either case is disgraceful in regard to a country with whose fate it has such vast interests involved, and to the discussion of whose concerns it gives so much attention. We believe that in both cases our first alternative is the true, or in a great measure the true one. That is, that to a certain degree, at least, the people who "Never, never, never, never shall be slaves," are misrepresented by the journals that profess to speak for them, and that those journals are willful in their ignorance. Prominent among these papers is the Saturday Review, which attained some distinction in the early part of its career by the cleverness and smartness with which it discussed all matters, from a Royal speech to a flunkey's neck-tie. For some time past, however, it has been not smart, but smartish -- not clever, but ratherish clever. An early decrepitude has soured its disposition. Its attic salt has been replaced by British bile -- its lively wit has succumbed to what old BURTON would call a windy melancholy -- its hearty, well-bred, contagious laugh has degenerated into a silly giggle -- and its manly, out-spoken rebuke into an ill-natured snarl -- so that, at last, it has well earned at home the nickname of the Saturday Reviler.

abstract: The very large and steadily increasing circulationof the TIMES gives constant occasion for remonstrance as to the tardiness with which it is delivered to subscribers in New-York and Brooklyn. The attention of the proprietors has for some time been directed to obviating this defect. They are now enabled to announce that in the course of a few days such arrangements will be perfected as will cause a much earlier delivery of the entire morning edition, and thus remove all ground of complaint.

abstract: There is great difficulty in dealing with a people who are children in intelligence, and barbarians in the excess of their conceit. There is no schoolmaster in such case but a thorough drubbing. The most astonishing arrogance and exalted notions of their power led the Confederates into rebellion.
lead_paragraph: There is great difficulty in dealing with a people who are children in intelligence, and barbarians in the excess of their conceit. There is no schoolmaster in such case but a thorough drubbing. The most astonishing arrogance and exalted notions of their power led the Confederates into rebellion. Every hypothesis upon which success was to be realized has utterly and totally failed, yet they are as stark mad as ever. The divisions at the North were to secure an easy victory. The North is an unit, moving with tremendous energy and power. The war was to be on Northern soil. Not a single Confederate has dared to show his face on. Northern soil. They are scattered like sheep when attacked on their own. One "Southron" could flog five Yankees. Col. SIEGEL's command in Missouri has shown that one United States soldier is a match for five rebels. England and France were to eagerly recognize their independence and open Southern ports. They refuse to do either. To support the war a loan of $15,000,000 was brought out with great flourish of trumpets, based on an export duty on cotton. Nothing could equal, in the opinion of the Confederates, the excellence of such a security. Some forced loans were made upon it, but, according to Mr. RUSSELL, of the London Times, they are now worth only 10 or 15 cents on the dollar in New-Orleans. In three months more they will not be worth as many mills. The whole thing has utterly collapsed. The cotton which was to be taxed to pay the interest and principal of the loan, is not going forward without the consent of the Government they are seeking to destroy. When this loan could no longer be forced, another of $50,000,000, based on some other kind of moonshine, was brought out, but never heard of after the first announcement. In the meantime Confederate soldiers were unpaid, badly clothed and armed, and, as a necessary consequence, disorderly and discontented. Some new system must be thought of, or the rebellion was at an end. The South had no money -- in fact, it never had any except in a return for the crop, which was always anticipated. In this dilemma the Confederates have come to the last resort of all barbarous people, which is, to contribute a portion of what each one raises to the support of the war. Indians, in such case, contribute wampum and beaver skins, -- the South, raw cotton. By the "spontaneous enthusiasm" of the people, the Confederate Government is to become possessed of one-half of the coming crop, say 1,500,000 bales, worth 875,000,000. This is to be offered to England and France at very low prices, provided they will raise the blockade. The South is completely electrified with this new scheme, which owes its paternity, we believe, to the illustrious Mr. COBB. Mr. Vice-President STEPHENS is now stumping the State of Georgia in its behalf, with such success, the Southern papers tell, as bids fair to secure the whole amount called for The planters of Louisiana have caught the infection and are subscribing sugar; those of the low districts of South Carolina, rice. All is to go, Mormon fashion, to the Government, which is to become a colossal broker -- is to send it all to Europe, not a pound to the United Statesbring home oceans of money, with which to drive back the perfidious Yankees to their inhospitable homes.

abstract: The following appeal appeared lately in our columns, but owing no doubt to the great excitement of the public mind on the all-absorbing topic of the day, it failed to attract that general attention which under more propitious circumstances it would have secured. We reproduce the appeal in our issue of to-day, assuring the benevolent and well-disposed among our readers that the subject of our remarks is in every respect emphatically deserving of their consideration and sympathy.

abstract: The problem regarding prisoners of war can be put off no longer. Gen. MCCLELLAN has a thousand of the article on hand, who cannot be carried with him, and who should not be dismissed. How to dispose of them Government will have to determine. If precedents thus far established in the campaign be followed, these people will be made to take the oath of allegiance, and will then be sent about their business. That business we have no hesitation in saying will in nearly every case be a resumption of hostilities against the Government. It can hardly be otherwise. Returning to their homes the men will find themselves without employment; they will find a rabid community contemptuous of their recreancy; and determined, if persecution and unfriendly looks can do it, to drive them anew to the field; and ever ready casuists who will prove the superior obligation of State authority over that of the General Government, and the inefficacy of an oath uttered under compulsion. To such inducements the stoutest will yield, and the weaker will yield with much less provocation. Let these prisoners, therefore, be retained as a check upon the rebels, when they succeed in making retaliatory captures, and let them be transported in the meantime to points where their labors may be made available in executing engineering works, the digging on rench ments, or the erection of heavy seacoast defences.

abstract: Having passed several sleepless nights, disturbed by the agonies and cries of a suffering child, and becoming convinced that Mrs. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply for the child. On reaching home, and acquainting his was with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Homoeopathy. That night the child passed in suffering and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following, the father found the baby still worse and, while contemplating another sleepless night, the mother stepped from the room to attend to some domestic duties, and left the father with the child. During her absence he administered a portion of the SOOTHING SYRUP to the baby, and said nothing. That night all hands slept well, and the little fellow awoke in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delighted with the sudden and wonderful change, and although at first offended at the deception practiced upon her, has continued to use the Syrup, and suffering, crying babies and restless nights have disappeared. A single trial at the Syrup never yet failed to relieve the baby, and overcome the prejudices of the mother.

abstract: The Captain General of Cuba seems to have studied neutrality in a rare text-book. The Sumter, of the Confederate Navy, carried into a port of the island half a dozen, prizes captured within three maritime leagues of the shore, and therefore within the dominions of Spain. For this act the proper penalty would have been the seizure and detention of the offending vessel, especially as it sailed beneath a flag which was wholly unrecognized by Spain. So far from taking this eminently righteous course, the Viceroy permitted the sinning cruiser to take in fuel and supplies, and put to sea, following the permission promptly with orders that the captured vessels should also sail immediately. This is very much the neutrality and hospitality which the man would exhibit, into whose house a flock of lambs had been pursued by a wolf, and who after stimulating the appetite of the ravenous creature, should turn both prowler and prey out into the night. The subject invites inquiry. Possibly the belligerent Palinurus of the Herald may add Spain to the category of great powers with whom it is our business to institute war out of hand.

abstract: Capt. WHITE, of the bark Louisa Kilham, captured by the privateer Sumter, writes to his owners here that he was captured July 6, the day he sailed from Cienfuegos, with 550 tons of sugar on Spanish account, and bound for Falmouth, Eng., for orders. He also states that it is the opinion of the Governor here that the Spanish laws will not let him hold us. We expect to hear from Havana to-day.

abstract: The numerous complaints from the New-York and other volunteers with regard to the quality and quantity of their rations, which at first attracted mere passing notice, as being the natural expression of inexperienced soldiers lately separated from home comforts, has now assumed a more specific character. It has become the insufferable grievance of men who enlisted fully prepared to undergo all necessary privations, and who are far above any whimsical discontent. If the well suffer, the sick are yet worse off, if left to the tender mercies of the Government for hospital comforts; for with volunteer regiments the same provision is not available as in the Regular Army, where a Hospital Fund is established, made by the savings of the surplus rations.
lead_paragraph: The numerous complaints from the New-York and other volunteers with regard to the quality and quantity of their rations, which at first attracted mere passing notice, as being the natural expression of inexperienced soldiers lately separated from home comforts, has now assumed a more specific character. abstract: THE MURDEROUS AFFRAY ON BOARD THE STEAMBOAT DANIEL DREW. -- PHILIP ELMENDORF, the captain of the steamboat Daniel Drew , ALONZO COLYER, the clerk, and two or three others belonging to the vessel, appeared, yesterday, before Justice KELLY, at the Tombs, in reference to the charges pending against them, of having feloniously assaulted Lieut. TIMOTHY DONOHUE, and three privates of the 36th Regiment, on the trip from Newburgh to New-York, last Friday. The substance of the complaint has been already published in the TIMES. The Lieutenant, who is a native of Newburgh, got on board the boat at that place, having three men under his care, who were on their way to join their Regiment, now stationed at Washington. Before the boat arrived at West Point, a difficulty occurred between Lieut. DONOHUE and the officers, regarding the payment of the fare, but its precise nature has not yet become known. The dispute resulted in an assault upon the soldiers, all of whom were brutally mauled with handspikes by the employes of the boat, and at West Point they were set on shore. Soon afterwards the attention of the officers of the military academy was attracted to their helpless condition, and after having received information respecting the merits of the case, a telegram was dispatched to Superintendent KENNEDY calling for the arrest of the Drew's officers and crew. This was done, and on Saturday afternoon the three privates were sent down from west Point -- and, upon their affidavits, Capt. ELMENDORF, Mr. COLYER and the others were required to give bail to answer at the General Sessions. Lieut. DONOHUE, who had been placed in the hospital at West Point, was found to be in too weak a state to admit of his removal to the City, and Justice KELLY has received letters from the physicians having charge of him, dated last Sunday, stating that his skull is fractured, and that the chances against his recovery are five to one. Under these circumstances the examination of witnesses was not taken up yesterday, the counsel for the prisoners preferring to await the result of DONOHUE's injuries. It is said that the excitement which the affair has occasioned at Newburgh is very great. DONOHUE is well known and much respected there, and his friends declare vengeance upon the officers of the boat. On her trip to Albany on Saturday morning, it was deemed inadvisable to land there, as a threatening crowd of from three to four thousand had assembled at the pier, and the passengers for that place were transferred to the Armenia, which conveyed them to their destination.

abstract: One of the most exciting matches of the season took place yesterday at the Union Course, Long Island, between Ethan Allen and mate, S. McLOUGHLIN, and Flora Temple, J.D. McMANN, for $1,000, mile heats, best 3 in 5. Flora was the favorite, previous to starting, at the rate of $100 to $70.
lead_paragraph: One of the most exciting matches of the season took place yesterday at the Union Course, Long Island, between Ethan Allen and mate, S. McLOUGHLIN, and Flora Temple, J.D. McMANN, for $1,000, mile heats, best 3 in 5. Flora was the favorite, previous to starting, at the rate of $100 to $70. A large amount of money changed hands. JOHN MORRISSEY, the backer of Ethan Allen, won $10,000. Flora cut her quarter badly in the second heat; indeed, she was overmatched, as Ethan Allen had nothing to do but trot, while his mate, Socks, pulled the weight and wagon. The result was as follows:

abstract: Ma. Gen. JOHN C. FREMONT was waited upon yesterday at the Astor House, by a committee of officers of the Fremont Regiment, U.S.V., now in progress of formation. The deputation was introduced by Dr. JUSTUS ADELBERG, of California, the well-known geologist. Gen. FREMONT expressed himself much satisfied with the intent and purposes of the regiment, and promised his active support in procuring a speedy acceptance of the same by the authorities in Washington.
lead_paragraph: Ma. Gen. JOHN C. FREMONT was waited upon yesterday at the Astor House, by a committee of officers of the Fremont Regiment, U.S.V., now in progress of formation. The deputation was introduced by Dr. JUSTUS ADELBERG, of California, the well-known geologist. Gen. FREMONT expressed himself much satisfied with the intent and purposes of the regiment, and promised his active support in procuring a speedy acceptance of the same by the authorities in Washington. This regiment is rapidly increasing, and promises fairly to equal any other till now sent to the seat of war. It consists entirely of citizens of German birth, and is commanded by R. ROSA, Esq., formerly a military engineer in the Prussian service. The place of Lieutenant-Colonel is filled by GERMAIN MUTTERNICH, Esq., well known by his military exploit in the revolution of 1848. Head-quarters, Humbolds Hall, Nos. 55 and 57 Forsyth-street.

abstract: Capt. SEYMOUR, of Fort Sumter, who left Fort Hamilton last week, in command of the Fort Pickens Company, for Washington, will enter the field at once in command of a heavy battery, for which horses have been assigned since he reached Washington. It is understood that Capt. SEYMOUR chose this position, rather than be transferred from the artillery to the infantry service, with immediate promotion, as was the case with several of the officers of the Fort Sumter command. Capt. SEYMOUR's high reputation as an officer and artillerist is a sufficient warrant that "Seymour's Battery" will make its mark upon the Confederates.

abstract: Hon. NATHAN APPLETON, who died in Boston on July 14, was born in Ipswich, N.H., on Oct. 6, 1779. A collegiate course which he commenced at Dartmouth was interrupted, that he might become a partner with his brother in a mercantile undertaking in Boston, and in this branch of business he spent a large part of his life, amassing an extensive property. About the year 1821 Mr. APPLETON became deeply interested in the manufacture of cotton, and was one of the three individuals who founded Lowell. From 1831 to 1833 he was a member of the Massachusetts Legislature, and in 1842 was elected a Representative to Congress. He resigned his seat, however, before the close of the term, and remained in private life until his election to the present Congress. A number of pamphlets and essays on Currency, Banking and the Tariff from his pen have been published at intervals during the past few years, and have attracted extended attention.
lead_paragraph: Hon. NATHAN APPLETON, who died in Boston on July 14, was born in Ipswich, N.H., on Oct. 6, 1779. A collegiate course which he commenced at Dartmouth was interrupted, that he might become a partner with his brother in a mercantile undertaking in Boston, and in this branch of business he spent a large part of his life, amassing an extensive property. About the year 1821 Mr. APPLETON became deeply interested in the manufacture of cotton, and was one of the three individuals who founded Lowell. From 1831 to 1833 he was a member of the Massachusetts Legislature, and in 1842 was elected a Representative to Congress. He resigned his seat, however, before the close of the term, and remained in private life until his election to the present Congress. A number of pamphlets and essays on Currency, Banking and the Tariff from his pen have been published at intervals during the past few years, and have attracted extended attention.

abstract: We give elsewhere the new Tariff bill now before Congress. It is simply a war measure, and differs from the preceding Tariff chiefly by taking tea and coffee from the free list, and increasing largely the duties on luxuries, such as distilled liquors, wines, sugars and segars. The duty on salt is largely increased. Black teas are to the taxed at the rate of ten cents per pound, green fifteen and coffee five cents. The duties on wines and distilled liquors are increased fifty per cent.; on cigars, very nearly in the same ratio. On sugars the duties are increased from three-fourths of a cent, to two and a half cents per pound on raw; to three cents on clayed, and four cents on white and refined. Molasses pays six cents per gallon instead of two. White lead $2 25 per 100 pounds instead of $1 25. There is some increase on other unimportant articles, but not enough to add materially to the revenue. In textile fabrics there is little change. A slight reduction is made on iron and steel -- the duty on merchant bar being reduced from $15 to $15 per ton; on railroad iron from $12 to $10 per ton. As the previous duties were nearly, if not quite prohibitory, this reduction is for the benifit of the revenue. With the exceptions named, the Morrill Tariff remains substantially untouched. It was not to be expected that Congress, at its present session, would undertake a revision of our system, or make any change that did not promise to add largely to the revenue. It did not assemble nor had it time for such objects. The long and regular session commences in a little over four months, when, there will be ample opportunity for deliberation. At the present moment the country trails for action, and will undoubtedly heartily respond to any measure that will provide the means for putting down the great rebellion, even at the cost of a heavy tax upon luxuries which, for a generation almost, were duty free. We are for several years, at least, to have an expensive Government, and we must follow in the wake of the nations of the Old World, who not only have no source of revenue untaxed, but who leave ascertained by experience the kinds of taxation which will produce the largest revenue. Taxes may be increased to almost any extent when paid in small sums, and which are daily and hourly levied. England finds no difficulty in raising annually $100,000,000 by duties on tea, coffee, sugar and tobacco; and $85,000,000 by an excise duty on malt and distilled liquors. They are paid in uniform sums every day in the year, and in such trifling amounts each time that the burden is only slightly felt. In no other manner could such enormous revenues be collected.

abstract: Mr. DUNNIGAN, keeper of a liquor shop, No. 80 West-street, was arraigned yesterday for the murder of JOHN KIEVAN, on the evening of the 23d of March, 1860. It appears that a party of 'longshoremen had been drinking at the above place, when a general fight ensued, during which two men, named KIEVAN and WM. HICKEY, were so severely injured that they subsequently died. DUNNIGAN is charged with having caused the death of KIEVAN, by stabbing him with a knife. The case has been once tried before the Court of Oyer and Terminer, when the jury disagreed.

abstract: While the American public, relying on occasional extracts from foreign newspapers, as to the terrible destruction of iron targets by steel projectiles, ridicules the idea of armorclad ships, and even doubts the utility of iron hulls as compared with wooden walls, the English and French Governments are so far satisfied by the absolute, necessity of such protection against modern projectiles, that they are constructing a large number of new mailed ships, and are plating some old and some partially completed vessels. The discussion about improving this system is, indeed, continued, .and will, of course, grow warmer as improvements are introduced, like similar discussions about the railway and the telegraph; out the system of plating war ships is just as much established and decided upon as are the systems of transporting goods by steam and intelligence by electricity. But the experiments even do not justify the American conclusions in the matter; a number of trials, some years ago, by the late ROBERT L. STEVENS, the acknowledged father of the scheme, and others, some of them quite recent, by various Americans, and the late English trials by Capt. HALSTED, R.N., and by the Admiralty, as well as by private individuals, all prove four and a half inch steel-plates to be practically proof against round shot of any size up to ten inches diameter, and a very great protection against the most improved elongated rifle projectiles.

abstract: Having passed several sleepless nights, disturbed by the agonies and cries of a suffering child, and becoming convinced that Mrs. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply for the child. On reaching home, and acquainting his wife with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Homeopathy. That night the child passed in suffering and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following, the father found the baby still worse and, while contemplating another sleepless night, the mother stepped from the room to attend to come domestic duties, and left the father with the child. During the absence administered a portion of the SOOTHING SYRUP to the baby, and said nothing. That night all hands slept well, and the little fellow awoke in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delighted with the sudden and wonderful change, and although at first offended at the deception practiced upon, her, has continued to use the Syrup, and suffering, crying babies and restless nights have disappeared. A single trial of the Syrup never yet failed to relieve the baby, and overcome the prejudices of the mother.

abstract: The army in Virgina to-day took up the line of march for Richmond, via Fairfax and Manassas. The force starting to-day was fully fifty thousand strong, the number reaching by actual count about fifty-three thousand. These, as I wrote yesterday, are about three thousand Regular Infantry, Cavalry.

abstract: The revenue-cutter Corwin, on Monday, observed a schooner of suspicious appearance passing towards the Narrows, bound to sea. She fired a shot across her bows and thus brought her to. She had no name on her stern, and was ordered back to the City to be overhauled. What she had on board, or where she was going, has not yet transpired.

abstract: The Grand Army under Gen. MCDOWELL was yesterday further strengthened by the Rhode Island Regiments, the New-York Seventy-first, the Second New-Hampshire, a detachment of Marines, and a considerable body of regular artillery, which marched over Long Bridge in the afternoon. And within the two preceding days the Fourteenth, Seventeenth and Twenty-first of New-York, the Second New-Jersey, the Seventh, Ninth and Eleventh Massachusetts, and the Fourth Michigan Regiments, together with GRIFFIN's Battery, had gone over to swell the great corps d'armee, now numbering in the vicinity of fifty-five thousand, effective men, splendidly appointed, and ready in every way to meet the enemy. The hour for which Gen. SCOTT has been patiently waiting is evidently near at hand, if it has not already arrived. Indeed, our dispatches from Washington state, almost positively, that Gen. MCDOWELL commenced his advance yesterday afternoon, and information from other sources leads us to hope that we shall soon hear of the occupation of Fairfax Court-house and Manassas Junction by our victorious troops. At Alexandria, on Sunday, the Ohio regiments received orders to pack everything but their guns, uniform, canteens, and one blanket each -- indicating an expectation of work ahead, in which it would be unwise to be burdened with too much baggage. One thousand axes have also been distributed among the troops destined to take the advance, for the purpose of clearing away the obstructions which have been placed in the roads in the vicinity of Fairfax, and between that point and Manassas by the rebels. We may expect stirring news from across the Potomac to-day.

abstract: A detachment of United States Cavalry was sent from this City a few days ago, to Carlisle, Penn. Soon after their arrival a draft of two hundred was made up for the war, and forwarded on to the National Capital, in compliance with orders from the Commander-in-Chief. They are quartered in the Seventh-street Park. Recruiting for this branch of the army is getting tolerably brisk.

abstract: The Hopkinsville Mercury reports that Quartermaster ALLENWORTH, of the Tennessee troops, stated there Thursday that 500 of the Kentucky State guard were mustered into the Tennesse service a few days ago. abstract: Be it enacted by the Senate and House of Representatives of the United States of America in Congress assembled, That from and after the fifteenth day of July, eighteen hundred and sixty-one, in lieu of the duties heretofore imposed by law on the articles hereinafter mentioned, and on such as may now be exempt from duty, there shall be levied, collected and paid, on the goods, wares and merchandise herein enumerated and provided for, imported from foreign countries, the following duties and rates of duty, that is to say: First. On raw sugar, commonly called Muscovado or brown sugar, not advanced above number twelve, Dutch standard, by claying, boiling, clarifying, or other process, and on syrup of sugar, or of sugar-cane, and concentrated molasses or concentrated melado, two and a half cents, and on white and clayed sugars, when advanced beyond the raw state by claying, boiling, clarifying or other process, and not yet refined, three cents per pound; on refined sugars, whether loaf, lump, crushed or pulverized, four cents per pound; on sugars after being refined, when they are tinctured, colored, or in any way adulterated, and on sugar candy, six cents per pound: Provided, That all syrups of sugar or of sugarcane, concentrated molasses or meledo, entered under the name of molasses or any other name than syrup of sugar or of sugar cane, concentrated molasses or concentrated melado, shall be liable to forfeiture to the United States; on molasses six cents per gallon; on molasses when tart or sour, four cents per gallon; on confectionery of all kinds not otherwise provided for, thirty per cent ad valorem.

abstract: DEATH OF THE PPOPRIETOR OF TAMMANY HOTEL. Mr. CHARLES BROWN, who for a number of years was proprietor of Tammany Hotal, in this City, died suddenly, on Monday night, at his residence, No. 114 East Eighteenth-street, of disease of the heart. Mr. BROWN was born in Bradford, England, where he lived until his eleventh year, at which time he came, with his parents, to this City.
lead_paragraph: DEATH OF THE PPOPRIETOR OF TAMMANY HOTEL. -- Mr. CHARLES BROWN, who for a number of years was proprietor of Tammany Hotal, in this City, died suddenly, on Monday night, at his residence, No. 114 East Eighteenth-street, of disease of the heart. Mr. BROWN was born in Bradford, England, where he lived until his eleventh year, at which time he came, with his parents, to this City. He was soon engaged in the old Tontine Coffee House, where he remained for a long time, and became very popular with the patrons of that once favorite house. Subsequently, he was engaged in Lovejoy's Hotel, and afterward, having acquired an enviable reputation as a business man, became associated with Mr. HOWARD, a junior proprietor of Tammany Hotel. When Mr. HOWARD retired from business he left the proprietorship with Mr. BROWN, who continued in that position until the time of his death. His anxiety for the comfort of his patrons, many of whom had known him for years, led him to over exertion, which, it is believed, brought on the disease of which he died. He was forty-five years of ago, and leaves a wife and eight children, the oldest of whom is the wife of Mr. CHAS. WALKE, of the Seventh Regiment. Mr. BROWN was a member of Manhattan Lodge, Free and Accepted Masons; of the Order of Odd Fellows,and also of the Veteran Corps of the Twelfth Regiment, Independence Guard. Few men die leaving more warm personal friends behind them. The funeral will take place from his residence, on Thursday, at 3 P.M. The hotel will for the present be managed by Mr. ERASTUS JOHNSON, who has long and efficiently been the chief officer of the hotel.
