abstract: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRS. WINSLOW? we will simply say that she is a lady who for upwards of 30 years, has untiringly devoted her times and talents as a female physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, so generally overlooked or carelessly treated by the faculty in too many instances; and, as a result of this effort, and practical knowledge obtained in a lifetime spent of nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article, Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children do certainly RISE UP and bless her, especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grave by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn ill share its benefits and unite in calling her blessed. No MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it, mothers -- TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: The Free Academy authorities, undertook last evening the difficult task of having twenty young gentlemen deliver orations and declamations, interspersing the exercises with music, and winding up with the customary prize presentations and conferring of degrees. Warned by previous experience, the exhibition was commenced at the early hour of 6 P.M., and yet extended to such unconscionable length that midnight was close at hand ere the last plaudit had gone forth from indulgent friends, or the last bouquet smashed to fragments in its perilous flight to the stage. But "Commencement comes but once a year," and the aforesaid indulgent mends were expected to stand it, and they did nobly. Every available point of hearing, and likewise every stand-point of vision, was filed, while hundreds of the disappointed, who could neither hear or see, passed the time pleasantly in the lobby in audible chit-chat and merry flirtation.

abstract: Katharine Thompson vs. James Lainey. -- This action was brought to recover $1,500 for the non-performance of a contract for the stone work of four, houses on Thirteenth-street, in this City. The answer denied any default on the part of the defendant, averring that the said contract was obtained through fraudulent representations, and that owing to other contractors for the same work being in possession of the buildings for the same work under the plaintiff's authority, the defendant was prevented from performing.

abstract: A special meeting of the Board was held last evening, to consider the amendments of the Board of Councilmen to the resolution appropriating $500,000 for the relief of the families of volunteers. On motion, all other business was suspended for that purpose, and the resolution was read. Alderman BOOLE was sorry that the Councilmen had seen fit to amend the ordinance; at the same time, for the purpose of making it a law, so that the Comptroller could proceed to issue bonds and get the money, he would move that the Board concur with the Board of Councilmen in the amendments. The Board then concurred.

abstract: Some interesting experiments were yesterday commenced at West Point with WIARD's rifled cannon and the HOTCHKISS projectile. The firing was with a six-pound shot at a target one mile distant, quantity of powder eight and twelve ounces. Several of the shots pierced the target, exhibiting great accuracy in range. The only drawback was, a discovery made too late to be remedied, that the projectile was too small for the bore of the gun. The party dined at Capt. ROE's West Point Hotel, and returned to the City by the evening train. To-day the large twelve-pound gun is to be tried.

abstract: The formation of regiments of Sharp-shooters as a branch of the military service, is attracting special attention. Rifle, or sharp-shooters as it is termed in the military parlance of the day, is a science of fine and numerous combinations of a high order, more so than is generally conceived. The various weapons in use, their size, weight and calibre, and sights, the shape and weight of lead they carry, the quantity and quality of powder they require, whether breech or muzzle loading, their accuracy and range, besides other peculiarities, are points which admit of extensive diversity of opinion. In alluding to the subject, we have no design to enter into the discussion of these undetermined points; but simply to consider by the light of European practice, and the experience of our own troops upon the frontier, the form in which, a valuable arm of the service can be made most effective.

abstract: Capt. SEYMOUR, of Fort Sumter, who left Fort Hamilton last week, in command of the Fort Pickens Company, for Washington, will enter the field at once in command of a heavy battery, for which horses have been assigned since he reached Washington. It is understood that Capt. SEYMOUR chose this position, rather than be transferred from the artillery to the infantry service, with immediate promotion, as was the case with several of the officers of the Fort Sumter command. Capt. SEYMOUR's high reputation as an officer and artillerist is a sufficient warrant that "Seymour's Battery" will make its mark upon the Confederates.

abstract: William Casey vs. J. & C. Fischer. -- This was an application for an order of arrest. It was claimed on behalf of the plaintiff that the defendants sold to a person introduced by him a piano-forte, for part cash and part credit, and afterwards attesting that they were not satisfied with the purchaser's responsibility, the plaintiff settled the claim on the agreement that the defendant would receive the amount of the bill from the purchaser, in case of payment for the benefit of the plaintiff. That the purchaser, at the expiration of the credit, paid the balance due, amounting to one hundred dollars, but the defendants failed to pay over on request. An order of arrest was granted.

abstract: This brigade, which is encamped at Camp Scott, Staten Island, is composed of five regiments. The First is commanded by Lieut.-Col. DWIGHT; the Second by Col. GEORGE B. HALL; the Third by Col. TAYLOR; the Fourth (Fire Zouaves) by Col. FAIRMAN, and the Fifth by Col. GRAHAM. Forty out of the fifty companies constituting this brigade have already been mustered into the service of the United States; the other ten will be mustered in as speedily as possible. Thirty-six companies have received their uniforms, which is the same as that worn by the Regular Army. Arms have been supplied to 2,707 men, and equipments to 4,207.

abstract: Capt. RICE, of the ship Siam, arrived yesterday morning from Jarvis Islands, reports that on the 10th inst., Cape Henry bearing west by south, sighted several ships and two steamers. At 7 P.M. was spoken by the U.S. frigate Sautee, notifying of the blockade, and ordering the Siam off. On the 12th, when in lat. 37° 53', lon. 74° 30', received a pilot from the boat Mary E. Fish, No. 4. July 13, saw two ships-of-war, steering southward and westward. At 1 P.M. saw Absecom light; 2 P.M., passed a sunken vessel, mast-heads just above water, bearing from Absecom light S.E. by S. 1/2 S., distant forty-five miles.

abstract: -- For some time past the residents in the vicinity of South Fourth and Grove streets, Jersey City, have been very much annoyed by a gang of boys who congregate on the corners there, and conduct themselves in a disorderly manner, insulting passers, and especially unprotected females. Yesterday, on complaint being made before Recorder MARTINDALE, of Jersey City, he issued a warrant for the arrest of thirteen of them, and the police took five into custody during the day. They were held to bail for good behavior.

abstract: SEVENTIETH REGIMENT. -- Considerable of a flutter was created yesterday among the members of the Seventieth Regiment, Col. SAMUEL GRAHAM, by a requisition from the Secretary of War for 100 cavalry from this efficient command, to depart immediately for the seat of war to engage in scouting duty. When the first call was issued for troops, Col. GRAHAM tendered the services of his command, composed of artillery and cavalry, but was told that no corps thus organized would be accepted. The Colonel, notwithstanding his hopes were thus dashed, proceeded to place the regiment on a war footing, and consequently, now that a call has been made for a portion of his force, there is some difficulty in deciding who shall have the privilege of going. To prevent hard feelings, it is suggested that the chances be drawn for, and if this is done no one can have a semblance of excuse for finding fault if he does not win the coveted privilege. The corps of 100 men, under efficient officers, will be moved at an early day.
lead_paragraph: SEVENTIETH REGIMENT. -- Considerable of a flutter was created yesterday among the members of the Seventieth Regiment, Col. SAMUEL GRAHAM, by a requisition from the Secretary of War for 100 cavalry from this efficient command, to depart immediately for the seat of war to engage in scouting duty. When the first call was issued for troops, Col. GRAHAM tendered the services of his command, composed of artillery and cavalry, but was told that no corps thus organized would be accepted. The Colonel, notwithstanding his hopes were thus dashed, proceeded to place the regiment on a war footing, and consequently, now that a call has been made for a portion of his force, there is some difficulty in deciding who shall have the privilege of going. To prevent hard feelings, it is suggested that the chances be drawn for, and if this is done no one can have a semblance of excuse for finding fault if he does not win the coveted privilege. The corps of 100 men, under efficient officers, will be moved at an early day.

abstract: Some interesting experiments were yesterday commenced at West Point with WIARD's rifled cannon and the HOTCHKISS projectile. The firing was With a six-pound shot at a target one mile distant, quantity of powder eight and twelve ounces. Several of the shots pierced the target, exhibiting great accuracy in range. The only drawback was, a discovery made too late to be remedied, that the projectile was too small for the bore of the gun. The party dined at Capt. ROE's West Point Hotel, and returned to the City by the evening train. To-day the large twelve-pound gun is to be tried.

abstract: A detachment of United States Cavalry was sent from this City a few days ago, to Carlisle, Penn. Soon after their arrival a draft of two hundred was made up for the war, and forwarded on to the National Capital, in compliance with orders from the Commander-in-Chief. They are quartered in the Seventh-street Park. Recruiting for this branch of the army is getting tolerably brisk.

It is now four months since the crew of this vessel has been paid off the men always having received their pay monthly. Indeed...
lead_paragraph: This steamer is now undergoing thorough repairs in her machinery and armament, and will be ready for sea in a week. The families of a number of her crew complain greatly of the delay which there has been in paying off. It is now four months since the crew of this vessel has been paid off -- the men always having received their pay monthly. Indeed they shipped with that understanding. It seriously incommodes them. The wife of one of the men has been turned into the street for non-payment of her rent, and others are in as destitute a condition. It appears to be a matter of "red tape." The ship belongs to the revenue service, and has been loaned to the Navy. On application for funds the Collector of the port says they are in the Navy, and when calling on the Naval Paymaster he says she belongs to the Revenue; and thus between them the families of the crew are in want. This is all wrong. The ship has done excellent service the past three months havingbeen several times in action, and the men should at least receive their pay, if not be rewarded.

abstract: THE STEAMER NEW WORLD. -- We are glad to learn that the steamer New World, belonging to the People's Line, has been safely towed from Stuyvesant, where she lately grounded, to New-York. On being put into the Section Dock there, her injuries were found to be much less than was apprehended. It was thought at the office of the line, that from $8,000 to $10,000 will cover the expenses of the accident, and that this fine and favorite boat will resume her regular trips at the expiration of a fortnight. -- Albany Argus, July 16.
lead_paragraph: THE STEAMER NEW WORLD. -- We are glad to learn that the steamer New World, belonging to the People's Line, has been safely towed from Stuyvesant, where she lately grounded, to New-York. On being put into the Section Dock there, her injuries were found to be much less than was apprehended. It was thought at the office of the line, that from $8,000 to $10,000 will cover the expenses of the accident, and that this fine and favorite boat will resume her regular trips at the expiration of a fortnight. -- Albany Argus, July 16.

abstract: The proposition of the Secretary of the Treasury, to levy an impost of five cents pound upon Coffee, will probably be adopted by Congress, and, as a war measure, will doubtless, be cheerfully sustained by the American people. All patriotic citizens feel that it is a
lead_paragraph: The proposition of the Secretary of the Treasury, to levy an impost of five cents pound upon Coffee, will probably be adopted by Congress, and, as a war measure, will doubtless, be cheerfully sustained by the American people. All patriotic citizens feel that it is a sacred duty to support the Government in this trying hour, and to submit to any sacrifices that may be necessary to maintain the integrity of the Union. Among the most available sources of revenue, which are resorted to only in cases of emergency, in our country, duties on tea and coffee hold a prominent rank, on account of the large sum they will probably yield, and the effect they may exercise upon the consumption of the nation and the culinary arrangements of many families.

abstract: Whenever business is dull and employment scarce, sympathy is very properly manifested for "the poor." How to provide work for "the poor," or, at all hazards, to feed and clothe them, is one of the chief topics of discussion in legislative bodies, in the newspapers, and in private circles. In addition to....
lead_paragraph: Whenever business is dull and employment scarce, sympathy is very properly manifested for "the poor." How to provide work for "the poor," or, at all hazards, to feed and clothe them, is one of the chief topics of discussion in legislative bodies, in the newspapers, and in private circles. In addition to the many incorporated charitable institutions which aid "the poor" in various ways, all the year round, in good times and bad times alike, large appropriations are not infrequently made for them from the public treasury when the demand for labor is very slack, and well-to-do philanthropists of both sexes form themselves into private societies for the purpose of collecting and distributing among them food, fuel, money and clothing.

abstract: All experiene shows that sudden changes in the habits of life, whether as it regards the article of food, colthing or exercise, as well as climate, operate directly upon the physical health of those who may be subjected to them.
lead_paragraph: All experiene shows that sudden changes in the habits of life, whether as it regards the article of food, colthing or exercise, as well as climate, operate directly upon the physical health of those who may be subjected to them. Hence the danger to raw recruits entering upon the active duties of a campaign. Most of them are unaccustomed to severe labor, and scarcely any of them are used to long marches, or such work as is required in throwing up intrenchments or constructing fortified camps. Drilling in hot weather is, of itself, severe labor, in fact, camp life is, in its generalities, a total change of physical habits and employment to almost every one of the many thousand volunteers now in the service of the country. The ordinary rations dealt out to the soldiers are altogether different from the food to which they have been accustomed, and are in some respects selected without any reference to those sanitary rules, which every decently read physician would prescribe for the promotion of health. For instance, fat salt-pork and bacon are the leading articles, the great staples of Army rations, and that in a hot climate, and in midsummer, with the mercury ranging daily from 90 to 100 in the shade. Of these, together with bread, there is an abundance, but what number of the volunteers have been accustomed at their homes to have pork and bacon the staple of their daily food? probably not one in ten. Of vegetables, such as potatoes, onions, or cabbages, the soldiers are said to have scarcely any at all, and yet these, outside of the Army, are regarded as absolutely indispensable to the tables of all classes. Fresh meats are not mentioned among the regular rations, and yet probably eight of every ten soldiers have been accustomed to them every day during their whole lives. Without pursuing the subject further, it is perhaps sufficient to say, that a greater change in the food of the soldier could scarcely be made, than that which the recruit experiences on entering upon his military career. This should not be so, if it can be avoided, and we confess to an inability to see a necessity for it. In the matter of economy, we suppose that fresh meats are as cheap as salt pork and bacon, and can be quite as easily secured to an extent at least that will render a healthful variety to the soldier's fare. We suppose, too, that fresh vegetables, such as potatoes, onions and cabbaged, can easily be supplied, and their cheapness ordinarily would render such supply a measure of economy. In fact, the soldiers' food should be of that plain and substantial kind, and assimilating as nearly as possible to that which the men who compose our armies are accustomed to at home. We know that this cannot always be accomplished; but, though difficult in some localities, and under some circumstances impossible, yet much may be done in these respects to soften the hardships of the soldier's life, and render move agreeable the performance of the arduous duties which from a sense of patriotism they have taken upon themselves. A good supply of vegetables, such as potatoes, onions and cabbages, should always be furnished. Fresh meat, if possible, should be supplied five or six times a week. These, with the addition of corn meal and molasses occasionally, would afford a pleasant variety to the monotony of Army rations, and afford a relish for the soldier's food that would at once make them contented, and give them health and strength for the weary marches and hard-fought battles that are before them.

abstract: The Philadelphia Ledger says: Last evening, Lieut McFarland of Company A, Third Pennsylvania Regiment, arrived in this city from Marrtinsburgh, with five rebel prisoners, who give the following names: ROBERT CHAMBERS, JOHN J. HIBBS, JOHN WILD JOHN LEMON and THOMAS M. HOLLIS.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia Ledger says: Last evening, Lieut McFarland of Company A, Third Pennsylvania Regiment, arrived in this city from Marrtinsburgh, with five rebel prisoners, who give the following names: ROBERT CHAMBERS, JOHN J. HIBBS, JOHN WILD JOHN LEMON and THOMAS M. HOLLIS. A guard of live men accompanied the officers. The prisoners were lodged at the Central Station during the night, and early this morning they will be conveyed to Fort Delaware. The prisoners were young men, Virginians. They were captured by the Third Pennsylvania Regiment while on picket duty. Three of them belong to the cavalry and two to the infantry, and all represent that they entered the service on a lark. The issue does not suit them, judging from their rueful countenance last evening while in a cell at the station house. They were taken prisoners on Sunday week, and left Martinsburgh, in charge of the guard, on Saturday. Their uniforms have been taken from their persons and exchanged for citizen's dress. Not a syllable has passed their lips since their capture regarding secession or State rights, and it does not appear that they have a very clear idea of the principles involved in the present struggle.

abstract: SUPPOSED MURDER A woman, named BRIDGET EAGAN, was found dead, Tuesday morning, at her residence, No. 137 Navy-street. Several of her ribs were broken, there was a contusion on her head, and on her body were other indications of violence.
lead_paragraph: SUPPOSED MURDER. -- A woman, named BRIDGET EAGAN, was found dead, Tuesday morning, at her residence, No. 137 Navy-street. Several of her ribs were broken, there was a contusion on her head, and on her body were other indications of violence. A post-mortem examination revealed the fact that she died of congestion of the brain, caused, it is supposed, by blows upon her head. The husband of deceased, JAMES EAGAN, hackman, was arrested on suspicion of having inflicted the injuries. The case will be investigated on Friday by Coroner HORTON.

abstract: In the animadversions and conjectures to which the dispatch of Bitish troops to Canada has given rise, we think that the condition of affiairs in New foundland has not been sufficiently taken into consideration.
lead_paragraph: In the animadversions and conjectures to which the dispatch of Bitish troops to Canada has given rise, we think that the condition of affiairs in New foundland has not been sufficiently taken into consideration. The recent riotous proceedings at St. Johns occurred at a time when we were all so absorbed in our own momentous affairs that they attracted but little of our attention. But the fact is, that the British Government has narrowly escaped having to deal with an insurrection in the great fishing colony as formidable, in its relative proportions, as that with which we are now coping, and very similar to it in its spirit and purpose. Our readers will remember that the Lieutenant-Governor, BANNERMAN, of Newfoundland, was prevented by a mob from opening the Legislature at St. Johns, that houses of obnoxious persons were destroyed, they themselves attacked, and order only restored by the sending of troops from Halifax, who fired upon the rioters, killing innocent people, (as is usual in such cases,) and thereby inflaming passion, although they repressed violence. The agitation is but repressed, not allayed; and it is more than probable that the home Government, considering the disturbed condition of this country, and being possessed of that extraordinary notion prevalent in England, that the United States desires to provoke a war with Great Britain and to foment trouble in the Provinces, has sent these regiments with an eye to a possible need of their services in Newfoundland.

abstract: The brig A. Dunbar, Capt. ROCKWELL, arrived yesterday from Cienfuegos, reports on the morning of the 26th of June left Cienfuegos and was becalmed the fore part of the day, but in the afternoon a breeze springing up, she proceeded on her course; at 4 P.M. made a screw steamer in chase, coming from under the high land in the direction of Trinidad; at 8 P.M. the steamer came up with her and hailed in English, which Capt. ROCKWELL answered in Spanish: as they continued to hail, Capt. R. finally answered in English, when the commander of the steamer, after asking several questions, and hovering about for some time, wore his vessel up, and steamed towards Cienfuegos. From information received from the late papers, Capt. ROCKWELL has no hesitation in asserting that it was the privateer Sumter. He describes her as being a rather low-setting vessel, with three masts, fore-and-aft rigged, and supposes that as it was dark when she came up to him, the broken English replies, &c., had led them to suppose his vessel to be foreign
lead_paragraph: The brig A. Dunbar, Capt. ROCKWELL, arrived yesterday from Cienfuegos, reports on the morning of the 26th of June left Cienfuegos and was becalmed the fore part of the day, but in the afternoon a breeze springing up, she proceeded on her course; at 4 P.M. made a screw steamer in chase, coming from under the high land in the direction of Trinidad; at 8 P.M. the steamer came up with her and hailed in English, which Capt. ROCKWELL answered in Spanish: as they continued to hail, Capt. R. finally answered in English, when the commander of the steamer, after asking several questions, and hovering about for some time, wore his vessel up, and steamed towards Cienfuegos. From information received from the late papers, Capt. ROCKWELL has no hesitation in asserting that it was the privateer Sumter. He describes her as being a rather low-setting vessel, with three masts, fore-and-aft rigged, and supposes that as it was dark when she came up to him, the broken English replies, &c., had led them to suppose his vessel to be foreign

abstract: OUTRAGE IN PERTH AMBOY. New-Jersey is a loyal State, but unfortunately all New-Jerscyites are not respecters of our country's flag.
lead_paragraph: OUTRAGE IN PERTH AMBOY. -- New-Jersey is a loyal State, but unfortunately all New-Jerscyites are not respecters of our country's flag. In Perth Amboy there are a large number of open and blatant sympathizers with the Southern movement, who make their head-quarters at a well-known hotel in that town, and lose no opportunity to vilify and outrage the cause of liberty and its supporters. On Monday an estimable and elderly citizen of that place, Dr. PALMER, was assaulted in the public street by a fellow named ALBERT COMPTON, and after a few words was thrown violently upon the pavement. It seems that a short time since a relative of COMPTON made use of some infelicitous expression of opprobrium concerning the American flag, and Dr. PALMER, fearing she would incur the displeasure and, possibly, ill-treatment from those in the vicinity, justly remonstrated with, and rebuked her. For this, and without notice, COMPTON, taking the law into his own hands, outraged publicly and violently an old and defenceless man. It looks to us as though Mr. COMPTON and all fellows of kindred tastes should receive the early attentions of a Vigilance Committee. They are too lively, entirely.

abstract: William Smith, who was indicted last February for presenting fraudulent papers at the Paymaster's Office, and who pleaded not guilty, and has been in custody ever since in the Tombs, was this morning brought up, and withdrew his plea of not guilty and pleaded guilty. In consideration of his long imprisonment already, and of his being in very ill health from consumption, the Judge sentenced him to be imprisoned for sixty days and to pay six cents fine.
lead_paragraph: William Smith, who was indicted last February for presenting fraudulent papers at the Paymaster's Office, and who pleaded not guilty, and has been in custody ever since in the Tombs, was this morning brought up, and withdrew his plea of not guilty and pleaded guilty. lead_paragraph: Having passed several sleepless nights, distributed by the agencies and cries of a suffering child, and becoming con vinced that Mrs. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply for the child. On reaching home, and acquainting his with with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Hommoeathy. That night the child passed in suffering and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following, the father found the baby still [???] and, while contemplating another sleepless night, the mother stepped from the room to attend to some domestic duties, and left the father with the child. During her absence he administered a portion of the SOOTHING SYRUP to the baby, and said nothing. That night all hands slept well, and the little fellow awoke in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delighted with the sudden and wonderful change, and although [???] first offended at the deception practiced upon her, has continued to use the Syrup, and suffering, crying babies and restless nights have disappeared. A single trial of the Syrup never yet failed to relieve the baby, and overcome the prejudices of the mother.

lead_paragraph: CROTON WATER DEPARTMENT. -- Bids for laying Belgian payment were opened yesterday, and awarded as follows: Regulating and paying Thirty-eighthstreet, between Fourth and Eighth avenues -- awarded to JOHN W. PETTIGREEW, at a cost of $17,799; time seventy days ; sureties, WM. B. REYNOLDS and JOHN PETTIGREW ; eight bids were received. Eight bids were received for doing the same work on Lexington-avenue, between Forty-second and Fifty-seventh streets. The work was given to CHRISTOPHER KEYES, at $25,052 52; time sixty days; sureties not determined. Same on Thirty-sixth-street, between the Park and Lexington-avenue, but of twelve bids received, THOS. A. DUNN's was accepted, at $2,188 40; time, ten days; sureties, JAMES P. and ANDREW J. DUNN. Thirteen bids were received for doing the same work in Twentieth-street, between Broadway and Fifth-avenue, JOHN O'NEIL bid $1,491 48, and will get the job, provided his sureties are accepted, if not, THOMAS A. DUNN takes the work at $1,510 80. Ten bills were received for the same work on Rutherford-place, between Sixteenth and Seventeenth streets. Awarded to JOHN FITZPATRICK, at $950 28; time, sixty days; sureties, JOSEPH CUNNINGHAM and JOHN MCCABE. Eleven bids were received for building a sewer in Forty-fifth-street, from the East River to west of First-avenue, which were laid over at the previous opening. Awarded to THOMAS HAYDEN, at $1,907 60; time, thirty-five days; sureties, OWEN MCGOVEN and DANIEL HAYDEN.

abstract: In the case of William Dunnigan, charged with the murder of John Kievan, by stabbing, on the 23d of March, 1860, the Recorder yesterday charged the jury, who, after a short deliberation, returned with a verdict of manslaughter in the third degree. The prisoner was sentenced to four years in the State Prison, being the extreme penalty of the law for that offence. The Court then adjourned for the term.

abstract: The man to whom, more than to any one rise, the State of Virginia, owes its present terrible misfortunes and humiliation, is HENRY A. WISE, late Governor, and long time leader of the rebellious spirit of the State.
lead_paragraph: The man to whom, more than to any one rise, the State of Virginia, owes its present terrible misfortunes and humiliation, is HENRY A. WISE, late Governor, and long time leader of the rebellious spirit of the State. By his extravagant and inflammatory demonstrations on the occasion of JOHN BROWN's capture, trial, and execution, he made every shallowpated citizen of Virginia crazy with hatred of the North, and burning with a war-fever. And the undimmed victory won by the Commander-in-Chief of all the armies of Virginia over the seven, occupants of Charleston prison, (kindly captured for him by the United States Marines,) made WISE the representative man, and the idol of the class who pined to avenge JOHN BROWN's insult to Virginia in the blood of whole hecatombs of Northern people.

abstract: Henry Rasquin vs. The Knickerbocker Stage Company. -- In this action, which was commenced several months since, the plaintiff sought to recover the sum of $2,000 for the loss of service and expense consequent on an injury to his son, arising, as he alleged, from the carelessness of the defendants' servant. The cause had been at issue for eleven months, during which period it had been twice reached, and the plaintiff had been ready for trial. A settlement was then effected between the President of the Company, and Mr. Rasquin, without the knowledge of the attorney of the latter, who received $350, and executed a release from the claim in suit, and from all costs and charges in the suit. Mr. Rasquin's attorneys disregarded this settlement, claiming that the defendants had combined with the plaintiff, who they alleged was irresponsible to deprive them of their costs. A motion was then made on behalf of the Company to have the action discontinued, which was denied by the Court, whereupon the defendants appealed to the General Term. The following extracts from the opinion of the Court will be found interesting to the profession and the community.

abstract: As the Excise Commissioners approach the  end of their sixty days' sessions, the number of licenses of liquor dealers rapidely increases. Those who thus secure legal protection for their traffic, will escape the trouble brewing from a new quarter. "The Inebriates Asy-....
lead_paragraph: As the Excise Commissioners approach the end of their sixty days' sessions, the number of licenses of liquor dealers rapidely increases. Those who thus secure legal protection for their traffic, will escape the trouble brewing from a new quarter. "The Inebriates Asylum" is entitled by law to ten per cent. of the sum paid into the Treasury for Excise, and are thus interested in the suppression of unlicensed dram-selling. An energetic Board, with able counsel, cooperating with our public authorities, will soon dry up these fountains of misery and crime, and bring under the operation of our laws a class who have defied the Government for years. The sympathy of tax-payers and friends of order will go with this effort; for, humanity aside, the withholding of $300,000 from the treasury at such a time as this, and the attitude of lawlessness of a whole class, when we are putting down the rebellion of another class, cannot be endured. If the gentlemen of the Asylum should refund $10,000 in compelling the liquor dealers to pay over the $30,000 belonging annually to their institution, it would be an investment well employed for themselves and the public.

abstract: We have never witnessed a popular ovasion to a public man that could have proved more gratifying to the recipient than the demonstration at Masonic Temple, on Saturday evening, on the occasion of the reception of Hon: JOSEPH HOLT. The Temple was....
lead_paragraph: We have never witnessed a popular ovasion to a public man that could have proved more gratifying to the recipient than the demonstration at Masonic Temple, on Saturday evening, on the occasion of the reception of Hon: JOSEPH HOLT. The Temple was crowded with citizens of both sexes, who met spontaneously to do honor to the gallant Kentuckian, who, as the citizen, and statesman, had the manliness, the courage and the patriotism to resist the iniquitous influences brought to bear upon him during the late Administration -- bringing all his great ability, and the mighty weight of his influence, to the support of the Government whose existence he had sworn to maintain.

abstract: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRs. WINSLOW we will simply say that she is a lady who  for upwards of 30 years, has untiringly devoted her .... and talents as a famale physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the consti-
lead_paragraph: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRs. WINSLOW we will simply say that she is a lady who for upwards of 30 years, has untiringly devoted her .... and talents as a famale physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, so generally overlooked or carelessly treated by the faculty in too many instances; and, as a result of this effort, and practical knowledge obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article, Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children do certainly RISE UP and bless her especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands at children have been saved from an early grave by the timely use, and that millions yet unborn ill share its benefits and unite in calling her blessed. No MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she was given it the benefit of MRS. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it, mothers -- TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

lead_paragraph: Now that the great rush on the Brooklyn Navyyard is over, the Premises look as quiet and lonesome as they did on New-Year's day. Then the Brandywine Perry. Bainbridge, Savannah, Roanoke, Wabash, Potomac and North Carolina were lying quietly in the stream. When the war required a movement, orders were received to fit out every vessel, and from that day to this officer or man has not seen an idle hour. An idea may be formed of the hurried manner in which business has been carried on, from the following list of ships that have been operated on since the President's Proclamation:

abstract: This regiment was ordered to break camp at 3 o'clock this morning, and proceed at once to Washington. The steamer Kill Von Kull has been chartered to take the regiment direct from Great Neck, where it has been encamped for some time past, to Elizabethport; from thence it will take the cars for the Capital. Quartermaster RICHARDSON has already gone on to make arrangements for the reception of the regiment. Mr. GEORGE W. ROOME, keeper of the City Hall, has presented Col. KENNEDY with a handsome revolver. Other friends of the Colonel have presented him with a sword, sash and belt. The regimental standard is a very handsome affair, made of rich blue silk, with heavy yellow fringe. The device is combination of the National and State arms, with a half globe and spread eagle surmounting. Above is the name of the Tammany Regiment. Underneath is the motto, "Excelsior." The list of officers we have already published.

abstract: The utterance of a single word by Lieut.Gen. SCOTT has sent through the American heart a sense of satisfaction that it has not experienced since the dark day of treason dawned. That word is the monosyllable, "March."
lead_paragraph: The utterance of a single word by Lieut.Gen. SCOTT has sent through the American heart a sense of satisfaction that it has not experienced since the dark day of treason dawned. That word is the monosyllable, "March." As it was borne along the lines from Arlington to Alexandria full fifty-five thousand men leaped to their feet with delight, and prepared for the long-sought encounter with the enemy. All regrets and repinings of the past were shaken off. The memory of toilsome work in ditches, of tedious hours in drill, of days of weary waiting in camp, vanished on the instant. The tents gave up their loiterers, and the hospitals gave up their sick; for the bugle note that sounded "Forward," brought the warm blood coursing through their veins as of old, and nothing could restrain their resolution to go with their stouter comrades to the field.

abstract: Ever since our arrival here, now nearly two weeks, we have been daily expecting to be led after the enemy, who has been constantly retreating first to Bunker Hill, then to Winchester, and now beyond. Why this has not been done it is impossible for us to say, but must be supposed to be for good and sufficient reasons.
lead_paragraph: MARTINSBURGH, Va., Sunday, July 14, 1861.

abstract: This gentleman, of the United States Engineers who was three years in charge of the Government fortifications building at Sandy Hook, is with Gen. MORRIS' Brigade, of MCCLELLAN's Division of the Army in Western Virginia. His numerous friends will be pleased to learn that his fine abilities are held in the highest esteem by Gen. MORRIS, and that he is constantly intrusted with the execution of dangerous and difficult operations. It was Capt. BENHAM that led the skirmishers of Gen. MORRIS' Brigade from Philippa to within rifle shot of the rebel intrenchments on Laurel Hill, and there set down the Union forces in position before them. And Capt. BENHAM led the command in that wonderful forced march of the Union forces over Laurel Hill in pursuit of GARNETT's retreating Army, which ended in the engagement at Carrick's Ford, the death of Gen. GARNETT, and the total rout of the rebel Army.

lead_paragraph: THOMAS H. BAKER, the Captain of the privateer Savannah, with the crew, against whom an indict was found, yesterday, for robbery on the high seas, were brought up, this morning, to be arraigned under the indictment. A large number of spectators were present. The prisoners were brought into Court handcuffed in pairs. Several counsel appeared for them. Mr. LAROCQUE and Mr. LORD appeared for Mr. HARLESTON, the mate; Mr. SULLIVAN appeared for BAKER and some of the crew, and Messrs. MYER, RIDGEWAY and SANDFORD appeared for others of the crew. Mr. BRADY was also retained to assist in the defence.

abstract: OUTRAGE IN PERTH AMBOY. New-Jersy is a loyal State, but unfortuantely all New-Jerseyites are not respecters of our country's flag. In Perth Amboy there are a large number of open and biatant sympathizes with the Southern movement, who
lead_paragraph: OUTRAGE IN PERTH AMBOY. -- New-Jersy is a loyal State, but unfortuantely all New-Jerseyites are not respecters of our country's flag. In Perth Amboy there are a large number of open and biatant sympathizes with the Southern movement, who make their head-quarters at a well-known hotel in that town, and lose no opportunity to vilify and outrage the cause of liberty and its supporters. On Monday an estimable and elderly citizen of that place, Dr. PALMER, was assaulted in the public street by a fellow named ALBERT COMPTON, and after a few words was thrown violently upon the pavement. It seems that a short time since a relative of COMPTON made use of some infelicitous expression of opprobrium concerning the American flag, and Dr. PALMER, fearing she would incur the displeasure and, possibly, ill-treatment from those in the vicinity, justly remonstrated with, and rebuked her. For this, and without notice, COMPTON, taking the law into his own hands, outraged publicly and violently an old and defenceless man. It looks to us as though Mr. COMPTON and all fellows of kindred tastes should receive the early attentions of a Vigilance Committee. They are too lively, entirely.

abstract: At the meeting of the Board, last evening, a tedious discussion took place with reference to the vacancy in the Professorship of German in the Free Academy, Strong preferences were expressed both for the temporary ineumbent, and a German Profesfor applying for the place. The whole subject was
lead_paragraph: At the meeting of the Board, last evening, a tedious discussion took place with reference to the vacancy in the Professorship of German in the Free Academy, Strong preferences were expressed both for the temporary ineumbent, and a German Profesfor applying for the place. The whole subject was settled by reference to a Special Committee of Five. This was considered by Mr. MCKEAN as a reflection on the Committee of the Free Academy, of which he was a member, and he indignantly resigned his position. The Board refused to accept the resignation, but on a motion to reconsider the reference, adhered to their former action.

lead_paragraph: Since the captures made by the Sumter and their arrival at Cienfuegos no American vessel can obtain a charter in Cuban ports, shippers refusing to take the risk of their being fallen in with by the pirates of JEFF. DAVIS. All the sugar and molasses there is to be shipped is given to English and Dutch vessels. This state of things is not only very mortifying, but also very ruinous to American ship-owners and captains. A perfect panic on the subject is said to exist in all the shipping ports of Cuba, which nothing but the early capture and summary punishment of the pirates will remove.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. This handsome and popular establishment was reopened for the Summer season on Monday, having during the short recess been cleaned and otherwise placed on a light and airy footing. Mr. and Mrs. FLORENCE, who come to us as....
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- This handsome and popular establishment was reopened for the Summer season on Monday, having during the short recess been cleaned and otherwise placed on a light and airy footing. Mr. and Mrs. FLORENCE, who come to us as regularly as the dog days, have assumed the management of the establishment, and intend during the coming six weeks to produce several novelties of a patriotic character. Beyond placing the fact of their arrival, with a hint concerning their intentions, on record, it is not necessary to say more. Neither the drama of "Handy Andy" nor the protean farce called "A Lesson for Husbands," invite, by their merits or performance, a particular consideration. They are, moreover, somewhat stale. In the first piece Mr. FLORENCE made his appearance, and was warmly applauded. He is one of the most genial and amusing Irishmen now on the stage. In the farce Mrs. FLORENCE's rentree was, of course, the feature. The lady sang and danced with her usual vivacity. When something of interest is brought out, the Winter Garden will doubtless regain its old popularity.

abstract: This gentleman, of the United States Engineers who was three years in charge of the Government fortifications building at Sandy Hook, is with Gen. MORRIS' Brigade, of MCCLELLAN's Division of the Army in Western Virginia. His numerous friends will be pleased to learn that his fine abilities are held in the highest esteem by Gen. Morris, and that he is constantly intrusted with the execution of dangerous and difficult operations. It was Capt. BENHAM that led the skirmishers of Gen. MORRIS' Brigade from Philippa to within rifle shot of the rebel intrenchments on Laurel Hill, and there set down the Union forces in position before them. And Capt. BENHAM led the command in that wonderful forced march of the Union forces over Laurel Hill in pursuit of GARNETT's retreating Army, which ended in the engagement at Carrick's Ford, the death of Gen. GARNETT, and the total rout of the rebel Army.

abstract: The advance of the Grand Army on Tuesday afternoon took place in four columns the right commanded by Gen. HUNTER, the right centre by Gen. TYLER, the left centre by Col. MILES, the ex- treme left by Col. HEINTZELMAN, and the whole under the command of Gen. McDOWELL.
lead_paragraph: The advance of the Grand Army on Tuesday afternoon took place in four columns the right commanded by Gen. HUNTER, the right centre by Gen. TYLER, the left centre by Col. MILES, the ex- treme left by Col. HEINTZELMAN, and the whole under the command of Gen. MCDOWELL. This immense Army of at least 50,000 men bivouacked on Tuesday night, portions of it in positions recently occupied by rebel troops, and yesterday morning before daybreak again started on its resistless march towards the rebel capital. All Tuesday night Washington was full of rumors that BEAUREGARD had fallen back from Fairfax Courthouse without firing a gun, but although such a course on his part was not unlooked-for, no reliable information to that effect had reached the War Department up to 11 o'clock A.M. yesterday.

abstract: THREATS AGAINST THE UNITED STATES MARSHAL The vigorous and unrelenting course of United States Marshal MURRAY towards the slave-traders, who for the last four years appear to have carried on the business of fitting out their piratical crafts from this port with impunity, is bringing down upon his head the wrath of the whole set of scoundrels, who manifest their spleen in the puerile and cowardly manner of sending threatening letters to the Marshal.
lead_paragraph: THREATS AGAINST THE UNITED STATES MARSHAL The vigorous and unrelenting course of United States Marshal MURRAY towards the slave-traders, who for the last four years appear to have carried on the business of fitting out their piratical crafts from this port with impunity, is bringing down upon his head the wrath of the whole set of scoundrels, who manifest their spleen in the puerile and cowardly manner of sending threatening letters to the Marshal. The following is a copy of one of these anonymous missives received by the Marshal yesterday: "If you do not let up on certain men you have under arrest, on charge of slaving, you will cease your duties as United States Marshal very sudden on some fine night. You are no smarter than other men who have been Marshals before, and you must not think so neither. Dr. BURDELL was done for, so was WALTON, so can a Marshal be done for just as easy. So beware! you put on too big airs with your power, but D-----b can take power away. The men you're persecuting have rich and powerful friends, who will use desperate cure for desperate cases -- so beware."

abstract: To-day we are in receipt of further particulars of the advance of Gen. MCDOWELL'S division to Fairfax Court-house. The advance was made in four columns, one under command of Gen. MCDOWELL, consisting of 6,000 men, one under command of Col. TYLER of 12,000 men, one under command of Col. MILES of 5,700 men, and the other of...
lead_paragraph: To-day we are in receipt of further particulars of the advance of Gen. MCDOWELL'S division to Fairfax Court-house. The advance was made in four columns, one under command of Gen. MCDOWELL, consisting of 6,000 men, one under command of Col. TYLER of 12,000 men, one under command of Col. MILES of 5,700 men, and the other of 10,000 men, under command of Col. HEINTZLEMAN -- the whole amounting to a force of about 35,000. The rebels fled before the advancing army without firing a shot. At Centreville, Gen. MCDOWELL intended stopping for the night, and pushing on for Manassas in the morning; the chances are that the rebels will make a stand there, but it is somewhat doubtful.

abstract: We have previously referred to the novel, as well as vast movement, going on at the South to retrieve the already dilapidated finances of the Confederate Government.
lead_paragraph: We have previously referred to the novel, as well as vast movement, going on at the South to retrieve the already dilapidated finances of the Confederate Government. Money it has none. In credit it is equally out at the elbows. Such repudiators as JEFF DAVIS, with, all their impudence, cannot show their faces in any money market in the world. Borrowing is out of the question. But 100,000 men in the field are not to be fed on chaff. They may enlist in a frenzy, and serve for a month or so from the same impulse. But patriotism is only supported by a well-stocked larder and prompt pay. Without these, a large mass of men, nominally soldiers, are no better than a mob. This the leaders of the rebellion cannot but feel. But every ordinary source of raising money has been tried and has failed. The proceeds of the last crop, unfortunately, was spent before war commenced. The only possible alternative, consequently, was in some way or another to make the coming one available. But this the planter could not do. He had no possible means of sending it to market. All the avenues thither were held by the perfidious Yankees. In this dilemma, Mr. COBB, late Secretary of the Treasury of the United States, hit upon the following happy expedient: That each planter should sell at least one-half of his crop to the Confederate Government, taking for his pay its 8 per cent. bonds, "good as gold." In this way, the planter would get a round price for his crop, while the Confederates would be put in possession of ample means whereby to chastise Northern barbarians. The plan was exactly suited to Southern fancy, and the Vice-President of the Confederates and a large number of his most distinguished confreres are canvassing their constituents in its behalf, with great success.

abstract: Such was the boastful spirit in which the rebel leaders entered upon their revolt, that many timid people were frightened by their terrible threatenings. Northern courage was scouted, and Northern physique derided as no possible match for Southern prowess. One Virginian was counted as equal to two or three New-Englanders, while a South-Carolinian or Georgian was regarded as equal to half-a-dozen of the "cobblers and greasy operatives of the North." We of the loyal States were to be made "to smell Southern powder, and taste Southern steel" -- not in the sunny South, but at our own doors and in our own homes. The "wave of revolution was to roll North" till TOOMBS should "call the roll of his slaves on Bunker Hill," and the Confederate flag wave from the lakes to the Gulf, and from ocean to ocean. Well, we have "smelled Southern powder and tasted Southern steel." Neither has as yet proved at all formidable. The one is very harmless stuff, and the other rather a digestible article. Virginia chivalry is masterly in retreat, and Southern prowess unequaled in running away. The rebel heroes, as it turns out, belong to that class of warriors whom somebody has described as being. "invincible in peace and invisible in war."
lead_paragraph: Such was the boastful spirit in which the rebel leaders entered upon their revolt, that many timid people were frightened by their terrible threatenings. Northern courage was scouted, and Northern physique derided as no possible match for Southern prowess. One Virginian was counted as equal to two or three New-Englanders, while a South-Carolinian or Georgian was regarded as equal to half-a-dozen of the "cobblers and greasy operatives of the North." We of the loyal States were to be made "to smell Southern powder, and taste Southern steel" -- not in the sunny South, but at our own doors and in our own homes. The "wave of revolution was to roll North" till TOOMBS should "call the roll of his slaves on Bunker Hill," and the Confederate flag wave from the lakes to the Gulf, and from ocean to ocean. Well, we have "smelled Southern powder and tasted Southern steel." Neither has as yet proved at all formidable. The one is very harmless stuff, and the other rather a digestible article. Virginia chivalry is masterly in retreat, and Southern prowess unequaled in running away. The rebel heroes, as it turns out, belong to that class of warriors whom somebody has described as being. "invincible in peace and invisible in war."

abstract: The inhabitants of the neighborhood adjoining Forts Tejon and Mojave have commenced getting up a petition to the Government, asking that the garrisons of these forts may be retained. The stockholders assert that they are at the mercy of the Indians since the withdrawal of the troops. It is said that the commander of the Pacific Department is forwarding to the Secretary of War a suggestion for the establishment of a central military station at Vadous, which would necessitate a revision of the general order -- alluded to on Tuesday -- constituting Los Angeles a head-quarters.

abstract: Having passed several sleepless nights, disturbed by the agonies and cries of a suffering child, and becoming convinced that Mrs. WINSLOW'S SOOTHING SYRUP was just the article needed, procured a supply for the child. On reaching home, and acquainting his wife with what he had done, she refused to have it administered to the child, as she was strongly in favor of Homoeopathy. That night the child passed in suffering and the parents without sleep. Returning home the day following, the father found the baby still worse and, while contemplating another sleepless night, the mother stepped from the room to attend to some domestic duties, and left the father with the child. During her absence he administered a portion of the SOOTHING SYRUP to the baby, and said nothing. That night all hands slept well, and the little fellow awoke in the morning bright and happy. The mother was delighted with the sudden and wonderful change, and although at first offended at the deception practiced upon her, has continued to use the Syrup, and suffering, crying babies and restless nights have disappeared. A single trial of the Syrup never yet failed to relieve the baby, and overcomethe prejudices of the mother.

abstract: Dr. J. MARION SIMS, of the Women's Hospital, has taken a brief respite from his arduous labors in that Institution, and sailed in the Persia on Wednesday for Queenstown, when, after a brief visit to Dublin, he will leave, via Edinburg and London, for Paris. In the latter city he will probably add to his already transatlantic reputation by the announcement of a new surgical operation in connection with his specialty. Dr. SIMS will return to New-York some time in the Fall.

abstract: As the question is frequently asked, who is MRS. WINSLOW! we will simply say that she is a lady who for upwards of 30 years, has untiringly devoted her time and talents as a female physician and nurse, principally among children. She has especially studied the constitution and wants of this numerous class, so generally overlooked or carelessly treated by the faculty in too many instances; and, as a result of this effort and practical knowledge obtained in a lifetime spent as nurse and physician, she has compounded a Soothing Syrup for children teething. It operates like magic -- giving rest and health, and is, moreover, sure to regulate the bowels. In consequence of this article, Mrs. Winslow is becoming world-renowned as a benefactor of her race; children do certainly RISE UP and bless her especially is this the case in this City. Vast quantities of the Soothing Syrup are DAILY sold and used here. We think Mrs. Winslow has immortalized her name by this invaluable article, and we sincerely believe thousands of children have been saved from an early grave, by its timely use, and that millions yet unborn will share its benefits and unite in calling her blessed. No MOTHER has discharged her duty to her suffering little one, in our opinion, until she has given it the benefit of MRS. WINSLOW's SOOTHING SYRUP. Try it, mothers TRY IT NOW. -- Ladies' Visitor, New-York City.

abstract: Yesterday, in some thousands of places, and with every variety of observance, was celebrated the Anniversary of American Independence. It was proposed throughout the Union to keep the day with more than usual solemnity, and to take occasion for making a display of patriotic feeling suited to the present crisis. That this has been done not only across the Atlantic, but wherever throughout the Old World a dozen Americans could come together, is a matter of course. Fireworks have blazed, cannon have been discharged, the streets have resounded with the noise of rifles and revolvers, the exuberant feelings of the American youth have vented themselves in shouts and songs; while those who prefer a more intellectual pastime have made or listened to political harangues by the hour. What torrents of eloquence must have been poured out during the last day and night! An ordinary 4th of July is not to be easily surpassed, but we may conclude that this of 1861 will have preeminence over any of the 84 which have gone before it. Denunciations launched against the world in general, defiance of whatever designs may lie hid under the neutrality of foreign Powers, will have been mingled with the old rejoicings at the triumph over the British and with the conventional praises of Republican government. There will be "sentiments"' in abundance -- that is moral or patriotic reflections conveyed in the flowery language for which our cousins are celebrated. For us English there will be the usual satire, the darts, though not very pointed, being plentifully envenomed, and when a fit of good temper comes over the assembly there will, perhaps, be touches of native humor, the best and least artificial efforts of all. Throughout the Northern States the day which commemorates the victory of a popular rebellion over a regular Government will have been thus solemnized with especial seal. The tyranny of the mother country, overthrown at last by the efforts of freemen, the thwarted designs of the bigoted King and his Tory Ministers, will be dwelt upon, as in days past. But in the hearts of both speakers and hearers there will be a heaviness which all this oratory cannot take away.

abstract: This old and flourishing institution, under the charge of Prof. E.A. FAIRCHILD, at Flushing, Long Island, closed its yearly term yesterday, and the occasion was improved in the usual way, by a public exhibition of the school. The citizens of the town, and the friends of the pupils from a distance, gathered in large numbers to witness the exercises, which were of an unusually interesting character. The large hall of the institute was tastefully decorated with evergreens, its only drapery being the American flag, which hung in graceful folds from the top and sides of the windows, A temporary stage, with curtained drawing-rooms, was improvised for the convenience of the orators of the day, and an effective corps of musicians, with the piano as an accompaniment, filled up the interludes with agreeable operatic and patriotic selections. The exercises commenced at 10 o'clock, and, with a brief intermission continued until about 1 P.M. Some sixty of the pupils participated in the exhibition, their pieces, both original and selected, having, to a large extent, direct bearing upon the State of the country. Among those which were well received, were "Fremont on the Rebellion," by GEORGE H. PARSONS; "The Union," by NELSON P. BANTA; "The Volunteers," a dialogue by HOWARD BURTIS and FREDERICK SPRING; "Senator JEFF. DAVIS on Union," by GEO. C. RANDOLPH; and "EVERETT on the War," by GEO. L. SIMONSON. The "Town Meeting," by fourteen amateur comedians, furnished a mirthful conclusion to the performances. Wm. H. LITTLE, of Summit, N.J., pronounced the Valedictory Oration. The self-reliant manner and creditable execution of the students, produced a very favorable impression upon the audience.

abstract: SERIOUS CHARGE AGAINST A RAILROAD CONDUCTOR.-- A young man, named THOMAS DOTY, conductor on the New-Jersey--Railroad, was taken before Recorder MARTINDALE, yesterday, on a warrant charging him with having committed an aggravated assault and battery upon one of his passengers. The...
lead_paragraph: SERIOUS CHARGE AGAINST A RAILROAD CONDUCTOR. -- A young man, named THOMAS DOTY, conductor on the New-Jersey--Railroad, was taken before Recorder MARTINDALE, yesterday, on a warrant charging him with having committed an aggravated assault and battery upon one of his passengers. The complainant, FRANCIS CARLAN, a contractor, residing at Bergen, alleges that on the 8th day of July he purchased a ticket at Newark, for a passage to New-York. While on the way, as the conductor came along for the fare, he felt in his pocket for the ticket but at the moment was unable to find it. Accused demanded the ticket or fare, and finally CARLAN gave him twenty-five cents, at the same time saying that he wanted his money returned if he succeeded in finding the ticket. Before the conductor left the car, CARLAN came across the ticket, and handing it over asked for the return of his money, but alleges that both were retained. This led to an altercation, when he alleges DOTY struck him twice, knocking him nearly insensible, inflicting two very severe wounds over the eyes, and, while down, he was kicked by some person in the small of the back. Upon arriving at the junction on Bergen Hill, the cars were stopped, when complainant and a friend, who had interceded to save him and was also struck, were forcibly ejected from the cars by DOTY, assisted by several of the railroad employes. Since that time until Wednesday last CARLAN has been confined to his house, from the injuries sustained. His face still shows indications of very severe blows, there being a large cut over each eye, which the injured man believes to have been made with brass knuckles.

abstract: It may not have been generally noted by Northern readers that the Constitution of the Confederate States is required to be ratified by the people of each State before it becomes the sovereign rule. The plan of the rebels for letting us ingrates of the old Union out of our unhappy dilemma of a dissolving government was to take the Middle States, one by one, into the Confederate ark and under the Confederate Constitution, and thus finally to reconstruct the Republic with JEFF. DAVIS & Co., at the head, leaving, however, the New-England States carefully out in the cold. Seeing that this was the only hope for us, it is a strange apathy our people have exhibited in not studying the Confederate Constitution with more care, and watching its adoption with more interest.

Seeing that this was the only hope for us, it is a strange apathy our people have exhibited in not studying the Confederate Constitution with more care, and watching its adoption with more interest.

abstract: So increasing is the demand for Havelocks that no one misemploys their time who makes them of any material consistent with coolness. The Ladies' Relief Union sent a lot of colored handkerchiefs to a certain regiment, who immediately appropriated them for Havelocks. One ex-sailor showed himself such an adept in fashioning them, that as a climax to his efforts his superior officer requested one, and was shortly provided with a style exceeding his expectations. The cap consisted of fine handkerchiefs of highly contrasting colors; the crown piece being ornamented with that cheerful design. "Death's head and cross bones."

abstract: -- Some of our people of tender consciences, and secession proclivities, are continually harping upon what they pretend to regard as a terrible fact, that this is a fratricidal war, and that they cannot sustain the Government in a controversy in which brother is fighting against brother. Of this class is Mr. VALLANDIGHAM, of Ohio, the leader of secession in the present House of Representatives. He talks so tenderly of our "Southern brethren" that one would almost suppose that the milk of human kindness flowed only in the veins of Southern men. But did it never occur to these men of peace, that those same "Southern brethren" have no such compunctions visitings? When or where has kindness, conciliation, forbearance, or even mercy been inculcated in the rebel councils? What Southern Press or Southern orator has spoken one word of tenderness towards the people of the loyal States, recognizing them as brothers or speaking of them as such? It is a great mistake to suppose that the loyal forces are marching for the conquest or subjugation of their "brethren" of the South. They are moving, and they will fight for the preservation of their country; for the salvation of the Government under which they have lived, and to which they owe allegiance; -- for the perpetuation of that national unity in which alone is security, strength, civil and religious liberty, and it is against the enemies of these only that their warfare is waged. When those enemies shall forego their rebellion, when they shall renounce their treason against the Constitution, and cease their conspiracies against the Union, the brotherhood of States will be restored. But until then, to cease our efforts to overcome treason, is to sanction its wickedness, and participate in its guilt. The patriot's first and highest duty is to uphold the integrity and honor of the Union, and those who would consent to its dissolution under pretence of tenderness towards our "Southern brethren," are simply sympathizers with the traitors and their cause. It is not conscience but a lack of patriotism that actuates them.

abstract: This Fourth of July is like no other that the Americans have ever seen. It may have been foreseen by some of their wisest men; indeed, we know that it has been from the days of the Revolution till now; but its actual appearance must be the most solemn spectacle ever gazed upon by the citizens of the Republic. How many of them will to-day be thinking of that now memorable walk of WASHINGTON's on the bank of the Schuylkill, where he was found thoughtfully pacing the grass, meditating, as he explained at the moment, whether it would not be better to give up the idea of the Union, than to run the risks of such compromises as were found necessary. How many will now openly admit -- what they would never acknowledge to themselves before -- that the Union has never been a sound, honest fact, single in its meaning, and. sincere in its professions! To-day, when Virginia is the seat of civil war, how many Northern men will recall the traditional discontent at the supremacy of that proud State, and the melancholy conviction which always went with it, that the Union depended on that supremacy! JOHN ADAMS was accustomed to say that "the Frankford advice" was what had placed the Union in a false position. When some of the chief founders of the Republic were in consultation at Frankford, near Philadelphia, on the meeting of the first Congress, the Pennsylvania delegates conjured the Massachusetts members not to let the word "Independence" pass their lips under any temptation, and not to propose any scheme or part of a scheme; but to give the lead altogether to Virginia. The leading took the form of compromises, so called, which were in fact bribes. The property suffrage of the slave owners was conceded by the Northern States, as a professed equivalent for the larger share of direct taxes borne by the Southern States; and that condition of affairs was established which, in fact, rendered the maintenance of the Union dependent on the supremacy, of the Virginian interest, since extended over half the country, with aggravations which have been found at length intolerable. The issue has been foreseen by other Virginians than WASHINGTON himself. The last of the band of noble Virginians of the revolutionary time, the venerable Chief-Justice MARSHALL, sank into sadness, in his latter years for reasons which he avowed to his friend STORY and others who had his confidence. He said that he saw his own State going to ruin under the desolating influences of Slavery, and that the ruin of Virginia would destroy the Republic. Many of the citizens of every State are pondering these things to-day, and talking about them to their children; and it may be well that they should be remembered elsewhere.

abstract: The remarkable animation that has been infused into the Stock Market by the news of the Army's advance into Virginia, has much significance to every good citizen. For, how
lead_paragraph: The remarkable animation that has been infused into the Stock Market by the news of the Army's advance into Virginia, has much significance to every good citizen. For, however true it is that speculations of the brokers' Board have directly little to do with the real, life-giving business of the country, and however difficult it is for the uninitiated to distinguish between the actual and the artificial transactions that are daily made, it is indisputable that no other thermometer of public confidence is so sensitive and reliable as the Exchange. When confidence rises among the people, the speculators respond by a rush for stocks, which, of course, advance in price. When confidence, declines, the rush is quite as rapid to "unload," and stocks fall as fast as they arose.

abstract: At the late Presidential campaign, Senator BRECKINRIDGE was the peculiar candidate of the Secessionists. He was the embodiment of the pestilent theory that underlies the treason that has since culminated in rebellion in the Southern States. At the North he was
lead_paragraph: At the late Presidential campaign, Senator BRECKINRIDGE was the peculiar candidate of the Secessionists. He was the embodiment of the pestilent theory that underlies the treason that has since culminated in rebellion in the Southern States. At the North he was the favorite of a small fragment of the shattered Democracy, whose fealty to party and zeal for its usages were stronger than their allegiance to the Constitution. He represented the extreme of Southern ultraism, and his election was, by coercing the North and West into all the concessions demanded, to avert the threatened ills that were looming in the perspective, or failing in this, he could, if need be, not only hand over his own State to the Southern Confederacy, but even Maryland and the Capitol at Washington, thus severing the Union and throwing all the Border States into the domain of the cotton oligarchy. Mr. DOUGLAS was rejected, because, while he was what the South termed conservative to some extent, yet they regarded him as too deeply imbued with a love for the Union, and too faithful in his allegiance to the Constitution, to serve their purposes.

abstract: In the Senate, the other day, a bill was introduced by Mr. POMEROY, and read twice by its title, viz.: "A bill for the Suppression of the Slaveholder's Rebellion." The title of this
lead_paragraph: In the Senate, the other day, a bill was introduced by Mr. POMEROY, and read twice by its title, viz.: "A bill for the Suppression of the Slaveholder's Rebellion." The title of this bill was subsequently commented on with some feeling by Mr. BRECKINRIDGE, who maintained that the revolt which the Government is about to exert its entire power to suppress, is not a slaveholder's rebellion, but a movement in which all classes in the Southern States -- non-slaveholders as well as slaveholders -- equally participated. The fact adduced by Mr. BRECKINRIDGE is, in the main, undoubtedly correct. The great rebellion of the South is not confined to the slaveholders, or to any other class, but pervades in some degree, all shades of society, without reference to possessions or occupations. Yet, notwithstanding this indisputable fact, it would be impossible to characterize the wicked insurrection which now prevails in the slaveholding States, more aptly and truly in the brief title of a bill, than by the words which have been employed by the Senator from Kansas, -- THE SLAVEHOLDER's REBELLION. It is, in fact, an insurrection against the peace of society, which had its origin in the especial interest of the slaveholder, and which has been promoted, encouraged and fired, at every step of its progress, under an open demand for the extension of the area of Slavery, and the increase of the political power of the slaveholding class.

abstract: The Fourth was very soberly and quietly kept, here in London. It was rather a feeling of duty, as if patriotism demanded it, than any hope of enjoyment, that included some of the residents here, of whom Dr. PATTEN took the lead, to meet and have a breakfast, and make some speeches.
lead_paragraph: The Fourth was very soberly and quietly kept, here in London. It was rather a feeling of duty, as if patriotism demanded it, than any hope of enjoyment, that included some of the residents here, of whom Dr. PATTEN took the lead, to meet and have a breakfast, and make some speeches. Certainly it was a much better conducted affair than the unfortunate meeting at the Louvre in Paris, some time ago, which came near making a war out of hand, and the bad effects of which are likely to hurt us in England more than the cotton-interest itself. The breakfast, over which Dr. PATTEN presided, was lucky in not being lorded over by diplomats, who seem to be unlucky birds, to judge from our experiences of Messrs. CLAY, BURLINGAME, and HARVEY. This time it was the clergy who carried off the honors of the day, and if all our celebrations could be conducted so creditably as this one, it's a pity that they should not all be placed under the supervision of the cloth. There is little to be said of it further than that it was quiet and in good taste. Among the persons present, I noticed quite a number of theatrical celebrities. The pulpit and the stage are both strong engines, and we are lucky if we can keep them in alliance, and on our side, but this time they really seemed to fraternize and divide the dignities between themselves.

abstract: If lying would win battles, or falsehoods accomplish revolutions, we of the loyal States might lay down our arms in utter hopelessness of achieving the salvation of the Union. The inventive genius of the rebel leaders, unrestrained by any considerations of conscience, would so far overmatch us, that it would be utter folly to attempt resistance to the power of their mendicity. A little while ago we were replenishing cur bankrupt treasury by the sale of slaves to Cuba, that we had captured in Virginia, of lured from their masters in Missouri and Kentucky. Then Gen. LYON was utterly defeated and made prisoner in the West. A little later and MCCLELLAN, with twelve thousand Union troops, was captured in Western Virginia. And now it is going the rounds of the Southern Press that Gen. PATTERSON, With fifty thousand men, has been utterly overthrown, cut up and annihilated. These monstrous stories are circulated throughout the seceded States, and the Southern people are made to believe them all as Gospel truths. Secession throws up its cap at every defeat as if it were a victory, and when its troops are routed or run away, it shouts to its deluded followers in the background that the loyal forces are annihilated. All this is done to keep up the spirits of the Southern masses, and fan the flames of revolt. The time will soon come when the deluded people of the South will discover how they have been deceived and betrayed, and when it does come they will hold their betrayers to a fearful accountability. The bold, bad men, who hurried them from their allegiance, and occasioned to them so much of misfortune, will be reckoned with by their own people, if they escape a traitor's doom at the hands of the Governments.

abstract: A good part of the time was wasted in the United States Senate, on Wednesday, in the discussion of that rare theme, the "negro question." Mr. POWELL, of Kentucky, whose devotion to the Constitution is so questionable, and whose sympathy with treason is so manifest, desired to amend the pending bill by a provision requiring that no part of the Army or Navy of the United States should be used to "interfere in any way with African slavery." In reply to the protest of Senator SHERMAN against the imputation implied in the proposed amendment, Mr. POWELL insisted on its propriety, venturing the declaration that the people of the South "might well be alarmed that the war was intended to subjugate and abolish slavery."
lead_paragraph: A good part of the time was wasted in the United States Senate, on Wednesday, in the discussion of that rare theme, the "negro question." In reply to the protest of Senator SHERMAN against the imputation implied in the proposed amendment, Mr. POWELL insisted on its propriety, venturing the declaration that the people of the South "might well be alarmed that the war was intended to subjugate and abolish slavery."
