abstract: ATTEMPTED MURDER. -- Detective VAN WAGNER, yesterday, arrested a man named GILES VAN VOST, on a charge of attempting to kill his wife. It appears that the parties have not lived together for some time past, and on Wednesday last the accused met his wife at No. 113 Myrtle-avenue, when he attempted to kill her by shooting her with a pistol. The ball entered her face, passing off to one side, inflicting a serious if not fatal injury. The prisoner was committed to await the result of the injuries to his wife.

abstract: The People vs. Edward Riley. -- The prisoner, who was convicted on the 22d of June last, at a Court of Special Sessions, on a charge of petit larceny, was brought up on a writ of habeas corpus, and asked for his discharge, on the ground that under the law of 1860 the taking of even the sum of one cent was a felony, and that the Court of Special Sessions had no jurisdiction. The District Attorney acceded to the fact that the Recorder had so held in a previous case. The Justice accordingly discharged the prisoner, taking the same view of the case.

The District Attorney acceded to the fact that the Recorder had so held in a previous case. The Justice accordingly discharged the prisoner, taking the same view of the case.

abstract: The recent encounters with the enemy prove what few doubted but which [???]are proud to see demonstrated -- the courage and pluck of the loyal forces. On [???] occasion as yet have they faltered, and in no instance have they failed of victory, when they have met the rebels on anything like equal terms. They not only fight well, but they march well in their hunt after the enemy. We doubt whether an Army has ever been gathered in so short a time that has proved itself more efficient in all that constitutes good soldiering, than that which is now marching towards Richmond and the Gulf. It has secured for itself a prestige that will carry victory with it wherever it goes. We hope that the forward movement will not be arrested. The spirit of the men is the very best, and their desire to meet the enemy should not be baulked without the interposition of some necessity too potent to be resisted.

abstract: The People ex rel., Sarah B. Griffin vs. Daniel E. Sickles. -- This is an application made on the part of Sarah B. Griffin for the discharge of Henry B. Griffin, her husband, who, in an unguarded moment, devoted himself to the cause of his country and Daniel E. Sickles, by enlisting in the Excelsior Brigade. His wife says that he was under the influence of his cups when he did it. Mr. Griffin was not produced in Court, in obedience to the writ, but the counsel for the defendant raised a jurisdictional question, which put a quietus upon the writ for the present. The ground taken was, that the Court had no jurisdiction. The application should have been made in Richmond County. With this view the Judge assented, and discharged the writ.

abstract: The necessity of having the popular mind prepared for both fortunes will in all probability be taught with a certain degree of thoroughness before this war draws to a close. It it not to be expected that victory shall perch nowhere but on our banners, and that the march of the great North will sweep without interruption to the Gulf of Mexico. It is something more than a holiday parade the nation is contemplating. We have accepted the idea of war reluctantly, because we know its horrors, and the contingency of disaster; and we shall be in no adequate mood to prosecute it to a successful result, if we are unprepared to accept a due proportion of reverses along with our triumphs.
lead_paragraph: The necessity of having the popular mind prepared for both fortunes will in all probability be taught with a certain degree of thoroughness before this war draws to a close. abstract: In the matter of the application of Jeremiah Brenan -- About two or three weeks ago Jeremiah Brenan went on a bender, and, as sworn to by several good-looking and credible witnesses, got as drunk as he could be. While in this state Mr. Brenan became discouraged with his prospects, and, disgusted with the artificial structure of society in general, he thought that the only place in creation where the prospects of rapid advancement were most likely to be attained, were on board a man-of-war. Mr. Brenan accordingly went to the United States recruiting office, placed his name upon the roll, and became a jolly tar. Mrs. Brenan, however, is of a different turn of mind, and like Mrs. Micawber, will not desert Mr. Brenan. While Mr. Brenan was enjoying himself on board the North Carolina. "waiting for something to turn up," he was informed by one of the officers that he was wanted upon a writ of habeas corpus, and forthwith was brought over to see Justice MONCRIEF, who, after hearing all the proofs in the case, concluded Mr. Brenan was sober enough to know what he was about, when he enlisted, and remanded him to the custody of the United States. Mr. Brenan is good for three years.

abstract: At the late election for members of Congress in Maryland, HENRY WINTER DAVIS, J.P. KENNEDAY, ROBERT MCLANE and HENRY MAY were the prominent candidates for the district now represented by the latter gentleman. There was no doubt of the loyalty of the people of that district. None but a Union man, or one who was understood to be such, could by any possibility have been elected. Of the so-called Union candidates, the allegiance of Mr. MAY alone was at any time doubted, but so loud were his denunciations of secession, and so earnest his professions of patriotism towards the Union, that those doubts were removed, and Mr. KENNEDAY retired from the canvass, assured that, in the election of Mr. MAY, the Union cause would find an able and efficient supporter. The election resulted in the defeat of DAVIS and the success of MAY, who now holds his seat by the votes of a loyal constituency. How justly he represents them, will be shown by his subsequent career.
lead_paragraph: At the late election for members of Congress in Maryland, HENRY WINTER DAVIS, J.P. KENNEDAY, ROBERT MCLANE and HENRY MAY were the prominent candidates for the district now represented by the latter gentleman. There was no doubt of the loyalty of the people of that district. None but a Union man, or one who was understood to be such, could by any possibility have been elected. Of the so-called Union candidates, the allegiance of Mr. MAY alone was at any time doubted, but so loud were his denunciations of secession, and so earnest his professions of patriotism towards the Union, that those doubts were removed, and Mr. KENNEDAY retired from the canvass, assured that, in the election of Mr. MAY, the Union cause would find an able and efficient supporter. The election resulted in the defeat of DAVIS and the success of MAY, who now holds his seat by the votes of a loyal constituency. How justly he represents them, will be shown by his subsequent career.

abstract: The engagement at Bull Run proves to have been far less important than appeared from the first dispatches. Gen. TYLER was making a reconnoisance in force, when a portion of his brigade was fired into from masked batteries of rifled cannon, stationed in the wood across the creek. The advance was gallantly sustained by Col. RICHARDSON, in command of three companies of the Massachusetts First and SHERMAN's battery. After being relieved by the Michigan Second and the New-York Twelfth, Volunteers, (not Col. BUTTERFIELD's,) the National forces took up a position on a neighboring hill, and planted rifle cannon, supported by Capt. BRACKETT's cavalry, and the troops already named. From this position a steady fire was kept up on both sides until yesterday morning, doing some execution -- accounts differ much as to the loss of either side. Gen. MCDOWELL estimates the loss of killed and wounded at about forty on the National side. Other accounts, however, magnify the numbers considerably. After several hours' firing, the attacking forces retired beyond the range of the rebel batteries, while vigorous preparations were made for flank movements, attacking the secession batteries on all sides. A number of Members of Congress witnessed the engagement, in which about four thousand troops on either side participated. The latest details of the fight yet received by mail, are given in our editorial correspondence this morning. It will be perceived by all accounts that the rebels, as usual, dared not show themselves in force, but kept their usual shelter of ravines and batteries. The latest news from the advance camp, which reaches us in our editorial correspondence via Washington, confirms our impression that the affair at Bull's Run was of minor importance. Gen. MCDOWELL had made thorough arrangements for reconnoitering the enemy's position. One of the rebel batteries was abandoned, and if the others could not be flanked they were to be attacked in front with heavy artillery, of which there was plenty at Gen. MCDOWELL's command. The depredations of our troops excited the greatest indignation among the officers, and steps were taken to punish the offenders. There is every indication of a further advance and severe engagement to-day.

abstract: The Annual Commencement of the Normal Schools of the City took place at the Academy of Music last evening. To one who has ever attended a Normal School Commencement, it would be superfluous to say that the building was crammed. There may have been room for a dozen more persons than were in the Academy of Music last evening, but it would be difficult to tell where they could be packed, -- certainly not in any position that commanded a view of the stage. The exercises were of the usual character, comprising written compositions by the graduates, distribution of diplomas and State certificates, addresses, &c., the whole interspersed with choice selections of music and singing. Among the songs was the "Star Spangled Banner," unheard at former Commencements, but whose omission would have been unpardonable at this.

abstract: We are informed, by a special dispatch from Washington, that the British Government are about to demand from our own the exemption of at least one Southern port from the operations of our blockade. That nation begins clearly to see the precipice upon which it stands. It is already numbering the days it has employment and food for millions of its people, material for its manufacturing establishments in which hundreds of millions are invested, and upon which no small portion of the vast commercial and monetary operations of the Empire are based. Raw cotton begins to be regarded in the same light as scraps of food by a beleaguered and famishing garrison. On the 5th of July there were only 1,100,000 bales in Liverpool, of which 159,000, or about one-sixth of the whole, changed hands in a single week. In the great strait, every corner of the globe is ransacked for a supply to make up for the loss of the American crop. Fifty-eight specimens from different localities lay on the desk of the Editor of the London Post at one time. In all this there is great encouragement for the future; but it does not meet the emergency. With all the stimulus added to its culture, the deficit arising from the loss of the supply from America cannot be made up elsewhere in five years. This the British Government well know. Hence its proposed notification to that of the United States that an inevitable necessity will compel it to demand of us the opening of one of our ports. Any amount of surveillance over the export will be allowed, provided only that a supply of cotton be obtained.

abstract: -- A day or two after Gen. PATTERSON established himself in Martinsburgh with his advancing column, he was reported to have received a gasconading message from Gen. JOHNSTON, heading the secession rebels near by, suggesting the immediate removal by Gen. PATTERSON of all the women and children from the town, as he (JOHNSTON) wished to assault the place. Gen. PATTERSON, having no time nor disposition to attend to the banter and bravado of the secession General, paid no heed to the message, and JOHNSTON withdrew his Army sulknig to Winchester, and took position behind his intrenchments.

abstract: A lady, who has been for some time a teacher in Northern Alabama, and who left there on the 20th of June, informs the Newburyport Herald that much apprehension existed in regard to slave insurrections. About the middle of May one had been planned. A black preacher had told them LINCOLN was their Moses to rescue them from bondage. All the details had been arranged, and all the beautiful white girls apportioned to the lot of different negroes. It seemed, however, that two negroes disputed about one very beautiful and wealthy young lady, and in anger one informed of the plot, and means were taken to arrest it. The lady said one great reason she had for leaving was her tear of a slave insurrection.

abstract: A most extraordinary statement reaches us through Western Virginia papers, to the effect that a serious fight occurred between the Virginians and Georgians, lately, of Gen. GARNETT's command, in which at least fifty lives were lost. The reason is alleged to be a quarrel in regard to camp work. The Georgians were compelling the rustic Virginians to do all the work in the intrenchments, saying that they were "gentlemen," and did not come to Virginia to dig holes in the ground, but to "help Virginia out of a land [???]." The blood of Old Virginia could not brook this arrogance and imposition, and the fight ensued. Many facts incline us to credit this story. It is well known that a deep and general alienation has occurred between Eastern Virginia and their Southern allies, and that reproaches are beginning to fill the papers on both sides. This estrangement would quickly reach the Western camps, and conduct such as is ascribed to the Georgians would ripen it to a collision. The utter demoralization of GARNETT's command betrays some hidden cause of weakness, and GARNETT's own heedlessness of death, and apparent courting of it, in all probability was owing to the unhappiness of his position in having to lead a mob of mutual enemies instead of a united band of faithful soldiers.

abstract: Henry Tomes vs. John A. Farrington et al. -- This suit was brought in a District Court by Mr. Tomes, President of the New-York Sportsman's Club, to recover the penalty of $25 for an alleged violation of the somewhat noted statute of 1860, in that the defendants had in their possession at their place of business, in this City, and exposed for sale, the fresh venison of one deer. The defendants' answer alleged that the deer referred to had been killed out of this State prior to the day when the statute went into operation, and also denied any knowledge whether the plaintiff was President of the Sportsman's Club. The plaintiff asked judgment on the pleadings, which the Justice refused to give, and dismissed the complaint. The plaintiff appealed.

abstract: Col. W.G. COFFIN arrived here from the Indian Territory on Monday. Col. A few weeks ago he left here fort Smith, which is the head-quarters of Mr. ELIAS RECTOR, his predecessor.

abstract: MELANCHOLY DEATH OF A LIEUTENANT OF ARTILLERY. -- Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest, yesterday, at No. 21 1/2 Eldridge-street, upon the remains of FRANCIS E. MILLS, a Lieutenant in the E.D. Morgan Light Artillery corps, who was fatally injured on the 4th inst., while firing a salute at Jamaica, L.I. The deceased had accompanied his command to the place named, with the object of celebrating Independence Day, and at sunrise the National salute was fired under his direction. At sunset the salute was repeated, but at the thirty-third round the cannon was prematurely discharged, and the deceased, who, at the moment, was ramming home the cartridge, lost his thumb by the explosion. He received attention from a surgeon, and two days afterwards was brought to his residence in Eldridge-street, where he seemed to be gradually recovering until Wednesday last. At that time alarming symptoms appeared, and on Thursday night he died of tetanus or lock-jaw. The jury declared the unfortunate occurrence to have been no person's fault. Mr. MILLS was a native of New-Jersey, nearly 27 years of age, and has left a family.
lead_paragraph: MELANCHOLY DEATH OF A LIEUTENANT OF ARTILLERY. -- Coroner GAMBLE held an inquest, yesterday, at No. 21 1/2 Eldridge-street, upon the remains of FRANCIS E. At that time alarming symptoms appeared, and on Thursday night he died of tetanus or lock-jaw. The jury declared the unfortunate occurrence to have been no person's fault. Mr. MILLS was a native of New-Jersey, nearly 27 years of age, and has left a family.

abstract: The clerks at the office of the Union Defence Committee, Fourth-avenue, were busily engaged yesterday, in paying out a portion of a sum of money, amounting to $20,000, which the Committee received from the Comptroller last Thursday. Payments were made only on the back tickets held by the families of volunteers, a large number of which were partially canceled two and three weeks ago. In addition to the apartment already occupied by the Committee, an adjoining one of equal size, and communicating with the former at the street end, has been fitted up with benches for fire accommodation of applicants. The benches are so constructed and arranged in each department that there can be no confusion among the ticket holders in point of precedence. As soon as one enters she proceeds to the rear of the building, and gradually moves forward, as her successors, one by one, arrive at the teller's desk and depart with their money. From early in the morning till late in the afternoon both rooms were densely crowded with women and children, and, although the paying-out process was conducted with surprising facility, no apparent diminution was observed in the large number of applicants, until about 4 o'clock P.M. The clerks are furnished with a roll containing the names -- nearly 1,200 -- of all the persons entitled to receive money from the Committee, and also a black list, embracing the names of deserters, expelled soldiers, and others, who have forfeited their claims for aid. This list, having 1,000 names, is carefully scrutinized before the money is paid over, and if an applicant presents a ticket on the strength of the services of a soldier whose name appears thereon, it is immediately destroyed, and she leaves the premises empty-handed. The Committee are at work preparing a detailed report of their proceedings, which will soon be placed before the public.

abstract: Those who know JOSEPH HOLT, of Kentucky will not be at all surprised by the fiery, the energetic, the sublime vindication of the Union cause which he has just made before a Kentucky audience, and which we have had the pleasure of laying before the readers of the TIMES. We exaggerate not at all where we say that for impassioned eloquence, fervent patriotism....
lead_paragraph: Those who know JOSEPH HOLT, of Kentucky will not be at all surprised by the fiery, the energetic, the sublime vindication of the Union cause which he has just made before a Kentucky audience, and which we have had the pleasure of laying before the readers of the TIMES. We exaggerate not at all where we say that for impassioned eloquence, fervent patriotism, vivid portraiture of the causes, the circumstances and consequences of the gigantic treason that menaces the land, -- for burning invective against his country's foes and stirring appeals to all the noble sentiments and memories of his hearers, to come up to their duty in this dark hour of the nation's danger, there has been no effort, North or South, to match it in all the history of the rebellion. It is worthy of the days of Revolutionaryfaith, fortitude and earnestness. It is a triumph that adds lustre to the record that such men as PATRICK HENRY, JOHN ADAMS, HENRY CLAY and DANIEL WEBSTER have made of American eloquence.

abstract: A recent issue of the Mexican Extraordinary contains a list of the various Govern- ments and Executive officers in Mexico since 1821, when that country achieved its Independence, up to the beginning of the present year, when JUAREZ was chosen Constitutional President. During these forty years, the form of the Mexican Government...
lead_paragraph: A recent issue of the Mexican Extraordinary contains a list of the various Govern- ments and Executive officers in Mexico since 1821, when that country achieved its Independence, up to the beginning of the present year, when JUAREZ was chosen Constitutional President. During these forty years, the form of the Mexican Government has been changed from one thing to another, and backwards and forwards, no less than fourteen times; while the Emperors, Presidents, Constitutional Presidents, Military Chiefs, Dictators, Supreme Dictators, and-so-forth, who have administered the various forms of civil polity, have averaged considerably over one per year, and at certain periods have counted up about one a month. After the first and second regencies and the emperorship of ITURBIDE, come in rapid procession the Provisional Government, the Federal Republic, a Central Republic, and a Dictatorship; then again in quick order a Central Republic, Federal Republic, and Dictatorship; followed again by Central and Federal, Dictatorial, Federal and Anarchical rule, in interminable confusion. Revolutions, conspiracies, reactions, decrees, plans, pronunciamientos, ceaselessly succeed each other -- each of them interspersed with bloody wars, and each of them working out always anarchy and tyranny, social distraction and national ruin, until, at last, the unfortunate and struggling Republic seems ready to finally dissolve at the touch of any foreign foe. The administrators of the various Governments have been changed over fifty times in the last thirty years -- most of them having been successively driven out by some such conspiracy as that which is now attempting to overthrow this Republic and its constitutionally elected President. In one year alone there were no fewer than five acting Presidents in succession; and during the last three years the Government has been changed four limes, and has had no less than seven supreme executive officers. SANTA ANNA comes to the surface as chief no less than ten times -- five times as President under the Federal Republic, twice as Provisional Dictator, twice as President under the Central Republic, and once and finally as Supreme Dictator in permanence -- his terms of office varying from a fortnight to a half-year or year apiece, though at his last dictatorship he managed to hold the reins of power for two years, three months and twenty-two days. In 1839, BRAVO enjoyed the glory of the Presidency for a week, and again, seven years later, for six days. The associate Triumvirs ruled the Confederate Republic for a week and a day. COMONFORT was substitutionary President of the third Federal Republic for one year, eleven months and nineteen days; he then succeeded to the Constitutional Presidency of the same, which he held for seventeen days; and finally became provisional President of the Central Republic, which he held for twenty-eight days. Few of the Presidents have maintained their seats more than a few brief months before they were overtaken by a successful rival, when they in turn then speedily joined the great army of plotters against whoever happened to hold the reins of power. And thus have they gone on, forever overthrowing and being overthrown, through the long and dreary roll of Mexican chiefs. Besides these general revolutions, the local conspiracies, secessions, and revolts have never ceased for a month since the Republic had an existence.

lead_paragraph: The United States Government will soon be confronted by a question, the decision of which may add extreme acrimony to the war now waging between the loyal States and the South. The trial of Capt. BAKER and his asso- ciates, of the privateer Savannah, must very shortly result in their conviction, and their condemnation to suffer the extreme penalty of the law for piracy. Nothing but a pardon or a respite from the President of the United States can stay their doom, after the decree of Court and jury is entered up.

abstract: CLOSING OF THE BROOKLYN PUBLIC SCHOOLS. -- The closing exercises of the Public Schools on Friday were of a very excellent character, and fully maintained the high standard that has been placed upon them by the public At No. 15, the Primary Department, under the superintendence of Miss SARAH J. MARTIN, (formerly of New-York,) was excellent, and especially the allegory of Union and Disunion. Speaking, recitations and music composed the remainder, until near the close, when addresses were made by Messrs. Sprague, Median, Graham, Green-leaf, Rockwell and Douglass. The schools will reopen on the first Monday in September.

abstract: The Fourth Wisconsin Regiment, which left Buffalo on Wednesday morning, arrived in Corning in the afternoon, but there found their further progress stopped by a dispatch from Mr. MINOTT, of the Erie Company, directing that they should not be taken to Elmira over their branch. Up to 10 o'clock last night this refusal was persisted in by the Erie Road authorities at Corning, to the great annoyance and vexation of the regiment, who were naturally at a loss to conceive any adequate reason for such a course.
lead_paragraph: The Fourth Wisconsin Regiment, which left Buffalo on Wednesday morning, arrived in Corning in the afternoon, but there found their further progress stopped by a dispatch from Mr. MINOTT, of the Erie Company, directing that they should not be taken to Elmira over their branch. abstract: The Philadelphia North American says: "The configuration of the Valley of the Kanawha, into which Gov. WISE has ventured with a force of madcaps, is singularly favorable to shuting him in, and to the capture of his whole force. It is a natural trap, the entrance to which from Eastern Virginia is far easier than the exit by the same path, while on all other sides, except towards the Ohio, it is practically closed to the passage of troops in or out. The Kanawha River lies in a very deep, narrow valley, parallel to the great Alleghany Mountain masses, from which a very slight descent takes the current to the Ohio River, north and northwest. East of this valley the mountain mass rises very abruptly and very high, with only here and there a bridle path leading up to the upper valleys along the deep bed of some tributary stream. Southward the valley grows narrow rapidly, coming to an abrupt close near the junction of the Ganley and New rivers, the two great branches of the Kanawha, both of which break down to the level of the Kanawha through very deep gorges many miles in length.
lead_paragraph: The Philadelphia North American says: "The configuration of the Valley of the Kanawha, into which Gov. abstract: The FLORENCES, at the Winter Garden, are doing as well as can be expected, the times, and lack of novelty being considered. Their entertainment is of the right kind, and if it were a little newer, would, in spite of adverse circumstances, attract the full attention of the public. Mrs. FLORENCE's versatility is as as agreeable as ever, and Mr. FLORENCE's Irishman is, as we have frequently observed, a most genial and pleasant impersonation. Several novelties are said to be in preparation, some of them of a patriotic character.

lead_paragraph: The English magazines, issued on the day of departure of the last mail, show us what are the feelings and opinions of our transatlantic cousins, of that portion at least which is represented by the quarterly and monthly publications, with regard to the conflict between the North and the South. The Editor of the United Service Magazine, the monthly organ of the Army and Navy, commenting on the dispatch of troops to Canada, a step to which he objects on the ground that they are more to be required in the Mediterranean, yet expresses his belief that the chances of England becoming entangled in the war are increasing.

abstract: It is not known whether Gen. SCOTT intends to take the field in person. Some think he will; but it is probable that his age and feeble health may interpose barriers to an active participation in the fight. At any rate he will receive the glory of having planned the campaign, when success... crowns it, and his laurels will not be sullied by his remaining quietly at Washington.

abstract: The Newborn (N.C.) Progress has the following: "Information reached here last night, by a Lieutenant of the Roanoke Guards, that on Wednesday, the 10th inst., between 12 and 1 o'clock, a man-of-war, 44 guns, came under the guns at Fort Hatteras, when an engagement took place, which lasted three-fourths of an hour, each party firing about seven or eight guns. No damage was done on our side. The vessel was struck twice and thought to have been disabled, as she struck colors and sloped."

abstract: The entire change which has taken place in the tone and the attitude of the Secessionists since the uprising in the loyal States reminds us of an anecdote told of Mr. BERDAN, now Col. BERDAN, of the Regiment of Sharp-shooters. Several years ago Mr. BERDAN, then a very young man, and not so widely known as he is now, either as...
lead_paragraph: The entire change which has taken place in the tone and the attitude of the Secessionists since the uprising in the loyal States reminds us of an anecdote told of Mr. BERDAN, now Col. BERDAN, of the Regiment of Sharp-shooters. Several years ago Mr. BERDAN, then a very young man, and not so widely known as he is now, either as an inventor, for his personal qualities, or as a rifle shot, was talking with a friend in the barroom of an inn at a town on the Kentucky side of the Ohio. In the room was also one of those Bowie-knife bullies who infest the South and West; a man who had made himself dreaded wherever he was known by his readiness to pick a quarrel, and his skill with the knife, the rifle and the pistol. This man, stepping up to Mr. BERDAN's friend, said that he wanted to speak to him. "Wait a moment," was the reply; and the interrupted conversation went on. Soon the bully stepped up again, and, laying his hand on the shoulder of his acquaintance, said, in a tone half-banter, half-earnest, "J------, when I tell you I want you, I expect you to come." "Certainly, certainly; but Mr. BERDAN was talking about his invention; and it was so interesting that"------. "Oh, d------ those Yankee inventions, and d------ the fellows that come to sell them." The words were hardly well spoken when the speaker was flying backward over a huge open stove behind him, being constrained thereto by a well-delivered blow between the eyes from Mr. BERDAN's right arm. There was a tumult at once; and men threw themselves between the inventor and immediate death. They informed him, however, that his fate was but postponed. His opponent would of course challenge him, and certainly kill him if he accepted; and if he did not accept, shoot him "on sight" for not accepting. Mr. BERDAN replied that he was not a fighting man, but that "on this occasion he fought." He was challenged in due form and accepted -- naming, as his weapons, rifles at two hundred yards. The terms suited his opponent "exactly," but he begged Mr. B.'s indulgence for a few days, till he recovered the use of his eyes. Mr. B. was accommodating. But the blow was so well planted that recovery was rather slower than was expected; and meantime a long-expected rifle match came off in the neighborhood which was to decide the merits of two rival manufacturers, one of whom was the famous WESSON. WESSON had undertaken, to produce a man who, with his rifle, could beat DIMMICK, a great shot, whose remarkable feats had brought the rival gun into general favor. To make the story short, WESSON's champion proved to be Mr. BEEDAN, who, on three-trials of ten or twelve shots each, at two hundred yards, not only beat DIMMICK on every trial, but made the greatest rifle-shooting on record in this country. His name, of course, was, in that place, at once in every body's mouth; but the nub of the whole affair was, that he soon received a message from his challenger that it was hardly worth while for him to await the recovery of the damaged eye, and that he might consider the challenge as withdrawn! And so ended the only duel and the only rifle-match in which Col. BERDAN was engaged.

Additional Deputy-Sheriffs have been appointed for the express purpose of arresting unlicensed liquor dealers, and yesterday they arrested EDWARD STAPLETON, of No. 27 Washington-street; DANIEL FOGARTY, of No. 22...
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF UNLICENSED LIQUOR DEALERS. The licenses granted last year expired on the 18th inst., and the Commissioners yesterday gave orders to arrest all persons who sold liquor without license. Additional Deputy-Sheriffs have been appointed for the express purpose of arresting unlicensed liquor dealers, and yesterday they arrested EDWARD STAPLETON, of No. 27 Washington-street; DANIEL FOGARTY, of No. 22 Vandewater-street; P. HUGHES, of No. 445 Tenth-street, and others, all of whom are now in prison. The Commissioners are now determined to do their duty, and to teach law-breakers that they can have their own way no longer, but must either obey the excise law or suffer the penalty prescribed for its willful violation.

abstract: Company I, a new corps, to be attached to the Ninth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., passed down Broadway yesterday afternoon, on their way to the seat of war, with very full ranks, (there being 110 men represented.) The company marched like veterans, and made a splendid appreance. The officers of this fine corps are as follows: PETER J. CLAASSEN Captain:
lead_paragraph: Company I, a new corps, to be attached to the Ninth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., passed down Broadway yesterday afternoon, on their way to the seat of war, with very full ranks, (there being 110 men represented.) The company marched like veterans, and made a splendid appreance. The officers of this fine corps are as follows: PETER J. CLAASSEN Captain: FRANCIS E. SMITH, First Leutenant; CHAS. H. WHEATON, Second Lieutenant. This company was recruited through the personal exertions of Lieut, FRANCIS E. SMITH, by special orders from Col. STILES, of the Ninth Regiment. The company were uniformed and equipped entirely through the efforts of their own officers, and have not received any assistance whatever from the State authorities. The members of this company were sworn into the service of the United States oil Thursday last, by an officer of the Army, and are now ready for active service. Lieut. SMITH desires to acknowledge the receipt of under-clothing so liberally bestowed on his company by the ladies of the Church of All Souls, the St. Ann's Relief Association, and the Ladies' Relief Society of the Dutch Reformed Church. Fifth-avenue, all of which were thankfully received and duly appreciated by the men; also the receipt of a liberal donation from S.J. STRONG. Esq., Assistant-Postmaster, who will pleasure accept the thanks of the company.

abstract: DECISION IN THE CASE OF THE VERMONT AND CANADA RAILROAD. -- We are informed officially, that the decree of the Chancellor's Court of Vermont, has been made, confirming the lease to the Vermont Central Railroad in all its parts, and fixing the cost of construction at $1,348,500, ordering the roads to remain in the hands of the present receivers, and the income to be paid in liquidation of rents. The Directors can order a four per cent. dividend, payable Aug. 1, if they think proper.
lead_paragraph: DECISION IN THE CASE OF THE VERMONT AND CANADA RAILROAD. -- We are informed officially, that the decree of the Chancellor's Court of Vermont, has been made, confirming the lease to the Vermont Central Railroad in all its parts, and fixing the cost of construction at $1,348,500, ordering the roads to remain in the hands of the present receivers, and the income to be paid in liquidation of rents. The Directors can order a four per cent. dividend, payable Aug. 1, if they think proper.

abstract: The Senate has concurred with the House in committing the task of putting down the rebellion, and by implication of preserving the future peace of the country, to volunteers. This action is not only in harmony with the genius of our institutions, but with the most obvious dictates of economy and safety.
lead_paragraph: The Senate has concurred with the House in committing the task of putting down the rebellion, and by implication of preserving the future peace of the country, to volunteers. This action is not only in harmony with the genius of our institutions, but with the most obvious dictates of economy and safety. A people who appoint the Government, and provide the means for its support, should never lose sight of the fact that they must defend it from harm. Whenever this duty and office is delegated they become indifferent to the character of their rulers, who seize upon this indifference as the means of their own aggrandizement. The idea that the people are to protect, as well as support their Government, keeps constantly alive a sense of patriotism, as well as manliness and power. It is the only thing that gives real dignity to a democracy. It trains the people as to the duties both of Government and subject, and renders them adepts in the science of practical politics. Power must rest somewhere, and nothing tends so much to transfer it from the people to the Government as a standing Army. DE. TOCQUEVILLE saw clearly that our advantage over all other nations lay in dividing up the functions of government into infinitesimal quantities, rendering concentration and consequently oppression impossible. A well administered Government has never anything to fear from the people, while a well-disposed people may have everything to fear from Government.

abstract: From the data which have already been given in the TIMES in regard to the capabilities of Africa as a cotton field, it is evident that all that is now wanted there is the application of capital, in order to an extensive export of the staple to the American and European markets.
lead_paragraph: From the data which have already been given in the TIMES in regard to the capabilities of Africa as a cotton field, it is evident that all that is now wanted there is the application of capital, in order to an extensive export of the staple to the American and European markets. Although much cotton is now grown there, and considerable quantities are manufactured by the natives for their own use, yet it will require the stimulus of intellect and capital from abroad before the native labor can be brought into such exercise as to induce confidence in a continuous supply from those regions. The Portuguese have, for some time past, yearly purchased large quantities of cotton cloths for use among the slaves of Brazil. From Lagos and the Bight of Benin it is stated that 200,000 cotton cloths of native manufacture had been exported in 1857, the amount of weight being nearly 1,000,000 pounds. These, of course, are more cumbrous than articles of American manufacture. Merrimac, or Lowell manufactured cottons, would soon supplant the native fabrics for most purposes, if the natives could exchange their raw materials for the various manufactured articles of America or England. The certainty of a lucrative commerce following in the wake of civilization; should call for the inquiry as to the feasibility of opening a commercial intercourse with the West Coast of Africa, and the regions bordering on the Niger.

abstract: Our dispatches indicate the probability that an attack will be made this morning upon the rebel position at Bull's Run and Manassas. No movement of our troops, except in the way of reconnoitering, took place yesterday, but an advance was to be made last night, to be ready to commence operations at daylight. Whether Gen. MCDOWELL intends to make a direct attack upon the batteries, the exact position of which was ascertained on Thursday, or whether he intends to turn the rebel position -- an undertaking which is believed to be perfectly feasible -- is unknown; but it is intimated that the latter course will probably be pursued. The lines of the hostile forces were yesterday very near to each other -- sonear, in fact, that noises made in the rebel camp could be distinctly heard in ours. BEAUREGARD himself is stated to be now at Manassas, though a few days since he was at Bull's Run. Gen. CAMERON, the Secretary of War, yesterday visited the National camp at Bull's Run, and reviewed the troops.

abstract: Judge CADWALADER, on Friday, delivered a decision in the case of the prize-ship Parkhill, which was taken into Philadelphia several weeks ago. The decision, which is very long, commences with a review...
lead_paragraph: Judge CADWALADER, on Friday, delivered a decision in the case of the prize-ship Parkhill, which was taken into Philadelphia several weeks ago. The decision, which is very long, commences with a review of the recent events in the history of our country, beginning with the Declaration of Independence by the State of South Carolina, in December last, the succeeding events of a similar character in other States, and the organization of a hostile Government, and the commencement of hostilities, that had now assumed the proportions of a general war. The capture of the libeled vessel by the United States frigate on the 20th of May last, off the port of Charleston, while on her voyage from Liverpool to Charleston, was next alluded to, as well as the averments of the libel -- viz.: that she was engaged in an attempt to violate the laws of blockade established at that port, and that she is the property of insurgents and rebels. If the latter position is sustained, it was unnecessary to enter into a consideration of the former. In the present hostile relation of South Carolina to the Genera Government, can a citizen of that place maintain a claim to the captured property in the Courts of the United States?

abstract: JUMPED FROM A WINDOW. -- An estimable citizen, named JOHN SHOTWELL, residing in Hoboken, was seriously injured on Friday by jumping from the second story window of his residence. Mr. SHOTWELL has been suffering from illness for some time past, resulting in aberation of mind, and his family, being solicitous for his safety, kept a strict watch over him. On Friday, however, during the temporary absence of the nurse, he jumped out of the window to the area below, and sustained a compound fracture of the right leg and confusions of the head. He received medical attendance, and may recover.

abstract: The Twenty first Regiment New-York Volunteers, last Sabbath evening, struck their tents at Camp Kalorama, Washington, where they have been in camp nearly five weeks, and marched across the Long Bridge, and are now stationed in Fort Runyon. abstract: In different communications, and more particularly in one over the signature of S.M. FULTON, President of the Philadelphia, Wilmington and Baltimore Railroad, great complaints are made of the transportation of troops over the Central Railroad of New-Jersey to Harrisburgh, and thence to Baltimore and Washington. As the route via Harrisburgh is longer than that by Philadelphia, there must be some reason for sending troops by the former road. This Mr. FELTON finds in the corrupt motives of political schemers. As the traveling public have long been familiar with the annoying delays and changes of cars at Philadelphia, Havre de Grace and Baltimore, they may find a better reason in these defects. At first, all the regiments sent by land passed through Philadelphia; but so great were the difficulties in transshipment of men and munitions, and so many men wandered from the ranks, were enticed away to dram-shops, or exhausted in marching through the cities, that the military authorities resolved to try the Harrisburgh route, despite the additional distance, as by that route, regiments, with their horses, artillery and stores complete, could be taken through to Washington without any necessary change, and without exposure to temptation. The gulge is the same throughout, which is not the case on the other route, and this not only avoids changes, but enables all the cars of the companies, including the Pennsylvania Central Railroad, to be united in case of emergency. Four regiments a day can be taken if necessary. This route now has decidedly the preference. Officers who have taken regiments both ways, can testify which is the better military route.

The gulge is the same throughout, which is not the case on the other route, and this not only avoids changes, but enables all the cars of the companies, including the Pennsylvania Central Railroad, to be united in case of emergency. abstract: The uppermost thought in every man's mind to-day will be upon the expected battle between the Union Army and the rebels, at or near. Manassas Junction. To use a strong figure, the nation may be said to be holding its breath in earnest attention to hear the first tidings of the conflict. It does not seem possible that the advance of the Army under Gen. MCDOWELL can be delayed a day longer. Gen. JOHNSTON, with about the best disciplined and most efficient corps of the rebel force, is believed to have retreated from Winchester and effected a junction with BEAUREGARD's Army. We know that Norfolk, Richmond, Lynchburgh and other rebel camps, are in easy reach of Manassas by railroad; and under the menace of an attack by the Union Army, the great body of the Confederate forces in Virginia could quickly be called to the Junction. That is a strong position by nature, and well fortified. If occupied by the entire Army of the South, it would present a defence from which our own grand column would recoil. And thus would the advance upon Richmond be suspended, to the nation's sorrow and shame.

abstract: Yale College, says the New-Haven Journal, has furnished a considerable number of officers and soldiers to the National Army recently. Besides those heretofore mentioned, the Class of 1862 has given THOS. SKELDING, of Stamford, to DURYEE's Zouaves; H.H. BLOOM, of New-York, to SICKLES' Brigade; and FRANK STANWOOD, of Boston, to the Regular Army. Mr. STANWOOD is the last to leave his class. He has received an appointment of Second Lieutenant of Cavalry, with orders to report next month, and last evening his classmates had an impromptu meeting on the College Green, and presented him a handsome and costly cavalry sabre. E.C. RIPLEY made a short presentation speech, which Lieut. STANWOOD briefly responded to. The sabre scabbard bears this inscription: "FRANK STANWOOD, FROM HIS CLASSMATES IN YALE."

abstract: The news from the seat of war must thrill every loyal American heart with deep emo- tion. The trust reposed by the country in its heroic Army has not been misplaced.
lead_paragraph: The news from the seat of war must thrill every loyal American heart with deep emo- tion. The trust reposed by the country in its heroic Army has not been misplaced. After a battle of unparalleled severity, in which our soldiers fought against great odds in regard to position, and against forces not much inferior, if at all, in point of numbers to their own, they have come off more than conquerors -- not only driving the enemy from their formidable positions, but seizing all their guns and equipments, and pausing only when the sheltered ranks of the rebels found safety, after retreat, in other and equally strong defences.

abstract: The bill authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to borrow $250,000,000 to prosecute the war, passed both Houses of Congress and became a law several days ago, but we cannot learn that any of our public functionaries or Representatives at Washington have yet deemed it of sufficient importance, to send a perfect copy of the bill as passed, even to the Sub-Treasurer or Collector in this City, still less to any of the public journals. None of the business men in this financial centre of the American world, appear to have any certain or reliable information of the terms or conditions on which this enormous loan is to be made, nor of the time, means or security proposed for its repayment. We have heard, however, in general, from Washington, that the bill, submitted to Congress by Secretary CHASE, and passed by the House, was materially modified by amendments in the Senate, and especially that the very important clause pledging the revenues from certain specified sources to the punctual payment of the interest on the debt, was stricken out.
lead_paragraph: The bill authorizing the Secretary of the Treasury to borrow $250,000,000 to prosecute the war, passed both Houses of Congress and became a law several days ago, but we cannot learn that any of our public functionaries or Representatives at Washington have yet deemed it of sufficient importance, to send a perfect copy of the bill as passed, even to the Sub-Treasurer or Collector in this City, still less to any of the public journals. None of the business men in this financial centre of the American world, appear to have any certain or reliable information of the terms or conditions on which this enormous loan is to be made, nor of the time, means or security proposed for its repayment. We have heard, however, in general, from Washington, that the bill, submitted to Congress by Secretary CHASE, and passed by the House, was materially modified by amendments in the Senate, and especially that the very important clause pledging the revenues from certain specified sources to the punctual payment of the interest on the debt, was stricken out.

abstract: It is quite unnecessary to recommend a book thus entitled to military men. The best practitioners in all professions are the first to secure the new technical books; and if the professors find them invaluable, how indispensable must they be to under-graduates; and who among us in the present war-time is not a student, of some grade, in military science?
lead_paragraph: It is quite unnecessary to recommend a book thus entitled to military men. The best practitioners in all professions are the first to secure the new technical books; and if the professors find them invaluable, how indispensable must they be to under-graduates; and who among us in the present war-time is not a student, of some grade, in military science? Although confined under the modest title, to the convenient form of a dictionary, this book is really an encyclopedia, both elementary and technical, and as such occupies a gap in military literature which has long been most inconveniently vacant. There are, indeed, for special purposes, excellent books of tactics for infantry and cavalry, of artillery practice, active service, commissariat, materiel, discipline and law, both rudimentary and profoundly technical; but never before have the subjects embraced in this title been condensed into a single volume of definitions and essays, not so brief as to be superficial and incomplete, nor so extended as to be diffuse and unnecessarily detailed, and hence equally valuable to the novice as a comprehensive text-book of miscellaneous instruction, and to the practitioner as a hand-book of general reference and information.

lead_paragraph: Harper's, for August, is out promptly. Why do not the proprietors avail themselves of the popular passion, and call it a "war number?" It might lay claim to such honor, insomuch as it has an article called the "Sword and the Pen," "The fight at Oriskany," "The Bakertown Militia," and "The Countersign." These articles all are of kin to the battle-field; that they bear no special relation to the present contest, is a matter not to be taken into consideration.

abstract: Until the author of Tom Brown at Oxford put pen to paper, the inner depths of life at the English Universities were never very thoroughly unveiled. abstract: Among the South Caro- linians who made such excellent time in the great helter-skelter race from Fairfax CourtHouse on Wednesday last, we find the name of Capt. RHETT, of the Charleston "Brooks Guard."
lead_paragraph: Among the South Caro- linians who made such excellent time in the great helter-skelter race from Fairfax CourtHouse on Wednesday last, we find the name of Capt. RHETT, of the Charleston "Brooks Guard." We suppose this can be none other than our fire-eating confrere, R.B. RHETT, Jr., of the Charleston Mercury, and son of R.B. RHETT, Sr., member from South Carolina of the Richmond Congress, who, with YANCEY, was the original prophet and propagator of Disunionism. RHETT, Jr., figured very fiercely around Charleston about the time of the bombardment of Fort Sumter as a Lieutenant in the South Carolina Army, "Brooks Guard," and it seems that for his exploits in that bloodless encounter, or for something else, he has been promoted to a captaincy. But it is painful to note that on the very first opportunity which this howling son of chivalry had to really distinguish himself, he should have achieved distinction only by being in the van at the Fairfax races. He has bragged so long and so loudly in his Mercury, about whipping the Yankees ten to one, that it might have been expected that he and his fellow-chivs, would surely have stood ground when MCDOWELL advanced with a force not more than four or five times stronger than theirs, to say nothing of the fortifications behind which they were sheltered. But RHETT, after all his bluster, took to his heels with the rest of his chivalric crew, leaving guns, pistols, swords, knapsacks, and even their breeches and boots -- (only think of it, a chivalry cutting stick, without his pistol or pantaloons) -- to say nothing of their half-cooked dinner and several copies of the Mercury -- as trophies to the Yankees! Who could have thought it? And who could have thought anything else?

abstract: The telegraph, always obsequious to commanding officers who have the power to suspend communication, apprises us that the responsibility of Gen. PATTERSON'S inactivity is attributable not to the General but to his men.
lead_paragraph: The telegraph, always obsequious to commanding officers who have the power to suspend communication, apprises us that the responsibility of Gen. PATTERSON'S inactivity is attributable not to the General but to his men. The term for which a majority of his force volunteered is nearly complete; and we are informed that the most ardent endeavors of the chief to induce his men to follow him into action were defeated for this reason. The reader will believe what he pleases of this. For ourselves we receive it as a disgraceful slander upon the Army. Of the troops in the valley of Virginia, a large proportion were t from sent Washington and Baltimore, all eagerness for the chance, which seemed to be so much more promising in PATTERSON's command, of encountering the enemy. The spirit with which these brave fellows crossed the Potomac and routed the enemy at Hainesville, is sufficient demonstration of the sincerity of their operations and the sturdiness of their courage. Some subsequent causes must be found to account for their present alleged indisposition to advance; and it will, in all likelihood, be found in the vacillation, hesitation and pusillanimity which, have characterized their leader. Under such a chief they may well refuse to go into action; and we venture to say that the substitution of Gen. BANKS will show that distrust of his predecessor, and not fear of the enemy, is the foundation of their reluctance.

abstract: The valley of Virginia has long been tabooed and hated by the lowland conspirators of Virginia for its recognized loyalty, and, in portions of its length, for its almost unanimous opposition to the purposes of the rebellion.
lead_paragraph: The valley of Virginia has long been tabooed and hated by the lowland conspirators of Virginia for its recognized loyalty, and, in portions of its length, for its almost unanimous opposition to the purposes of the rebellion. The sudden apparent transfer of this prosperous and peaceful region from the support of the Union to the cause of treason was a result of the unhappy example of two or three popular and very able leaders, who were everawed by the demonstrations of the conspirators within and around the Richmond Convention. It was a change of sentiment in its very nature and origin wholly factitious, and produced, in a great degree, by a gross misapprehension of the facts which led to the President's Proclamation, and finally effected by the use of a well-arranged political machinery, in a moment of extreme popular excitement. Thus far the people of the valley have felt but lightly the pressure of the war. They have seen nothing but the march of gay and hopeful ranks, in high spirits and good humor, on the way to the appointed field, where the reputation of Southern prowess was to be practically vindicated by easy victories over an unchivalrous Northern rabble. But things have changed, and events are taking an unexpected turn. The ranks of these youthful and most inexperienced heroes are retreating hastily and in some alarm, without even risking a battle, before the steady tread and stern advance of an undervalued [???]. This retiring army -- fatigued by a cruel march under a scorching sun -- sullen, morose and discouraged -- will be under little discipline and is only too likely to give vent and practical expression to its mortification and discontent by outrages upon the unoffending population -- whose allegiance to treason is well doubted -- along the line of its retreat.

abstract: A THRILLING INCIDENT.--On Saturday afternoon, as the Staten Island ferry-boat Southfield was on her down trip at 5 o'clock, and when about one mile below Government's Island, a little boy, aged about three years, son of Mr. J.H. WATSON, who resides at No. 87 First-place, Brooklyn, fell overboard from the upper deck.
lead_paragraph: A THRILLING INCIDENT. -- On Saturday afternoon, as the Staten Island ferry-boat Southfield was on her down trip at 5 o'clock, and when about one mile below Government's Island, a little boy, aged about three years, son of Mr. J.H. WATSON, who resides at No. 87 First-place, Brooklyn, fell overboard from the upper deck. He was in charge of his sister, aged twelve or fourteen, and was accompanied by a brother, aged about eight. They were going to Clifton to visit some friends. The little fellow was sitting on the lower rope of the guard, near the pilot house aft. A woman who had cakes for sale wished to pass with her basket, and as he was making room for her, he lost his balance and went over. A scream of horror came from all who saw it, and the sister and brother were well nigh paralyzed with fright. A gentleman who sat near hurried to the pilot house, and notified the man at the helm, "a child overboard!" In an instant the bell clanged in the engineer's room, wheels and rudders were reversed, the pilot hastened to the other pilot-house, and the boat went back with all speed, following the wake she had just left. A steamboat was seen coming down the bay and crossing our tack about half a mile off, at about the point where the child went over. Every effort was made to signal them to stop, shout upon shout went over the water from a hundred voices, and hats and handkerchiefs were used with a downward movement; but, strange to say, it was interpreted to be what it did not resemble, and these signs of warning and distress were answered by cheers and the waving of handkerchiefs. This was followed by a loud moan of disappointment, and cries of, "These, they have run over him!" All hope of saving the boy seemed to be stifled, but the returning boat kept on, feeling her way cautiously, when presently a little hat was descried, and then a little body, still, buoyant, and face upward. A thrill of hopeful expectation of a rescue was felt by the hundred anxious passengers. "There he is!" "There he is!" "Slack up!" "Stop her!" The pilot sounded his bell to slow the engines, when a tail, spare man was seen divesting himself of hat, coat, vest and boots. He dropped himself from the upper to the lower forward deck; went over the guards, hung down by his hands, and dropped into the water just as the boat was about coming in contact with the body. She had a little too much headway, and cries were heard on all sides, "They will be struck by the wheel!" "Stop her!" Sure enough, they would have been struck, but, with wonderful presence of mind, the gentleman dove under the wheel and came up near the stern with the boy in his arms. Life-preservers were thrown over and a small boat was lowered. The gentleman seized the latter with one hand, laid the boy in with the other, got in himself, and commenced at once to roll and rub him. Presently they were taken on board; the child was heard to cry, and the glad news, "He is alive!" "He will be saved!" went from mouth to mouth until every face beamed with a smile of intense satisfaction. The sister and brother came forward excited and in tears. They assisted to divest him of his drenched clothing; a blanket was brought, in which he was wrapped, and the efforts to resuscitate were diligently pushed. One gentleman look from his wallet a newspaper slip containing printed directions, by E. MERIAM, for rescusitating a drowned person. When the boat arrived at Quarantine landing, the body was taken to the residence of the Health Officer, where Dr. GUNS and the other health officer, with the ladies in the house, gave proper attention to the little sufferer. Word was immediately sent to friends at Clifton, and the parents were telegraphed to Brooklyn. They arrived between 8 and 9 o'clock, and found that all was well. The child was restored to consciousness, and his chief complaint was thus expressed: "Papa, I fell in water and lost my hat." It was with much difficulty that the brave man who thus periled his own life to save this little fellow could be induced to give his name; but the impropriety of his keeping it, from the knowledge of the parents was so urged upon him that he finally wrote his address on a card for the sister, with a request not to show it except to her parents. It transpired, however, at the landing, that this noble deed was performed by "Capt. J.W. KITTREDGE, care of E.F. TEFT & Co., Nos. 126 and 128 [???]-street, New-York." His wife, with a nurse and child, were believed to be on board at the time.

abstract: The weekly recruiting reports of last weak for the old Army Regiments show no improvement. Only twenty-two men were enlisted in this City; one detachment of about a dozen arrived from Buffalo, and one from Rochester.
lead_paragraph: The weekly recruiting reports of last weak for the old Army Regiments show no improvement. Only twenty-two men were enlisted in this City; one detachment of about a dozen arrived from Buffalo, and one from Rochester. Although several other rendezvous -- those in the Department of the West -- have been ordered to send on the persons accepted to this place, none have come, as yet. In short, all the recruits obtained now for the regulars would be not more than enough to supply the current wants of the line in times of peace. The new eleven regiments have not a full company apiece as yet. If some volunteer regiments are not turned over wholesale to the War Department, it is difficult to see where privates and non-commissioned officers for the late Army appointments will be found. In New-York City, Yorkville, Fort Hamilton, Pittsburgh, Penn., Wheeling, Va., Troy, N.Y., Boston, Cincinnati and Louisville, offices are open, "utterly regardless of expense," -- but candidates for military glory appear like angel visitants, few and far between.

abstract: Had Mr. ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS remained a member of the National Congress, it is not at all likely that any ordinary contingency would have made him Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means. Should he, escaping the fate of a traitor, return to that body, the chances of that distinction may be regarded as entirely extinguished.
lead_paragraph: Had Mr. ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS remained a member of the National Congress, it is not at all likely that any ordinary contingency would have made him Chairman of the Committee of Ways and Means. Should he, escaping the fate of a traitor, return to that body, the chances of that distinction may be regarded as entirely extinguished. His cotton loan speech at Augusta, which we reproduce elsewhere, must do the business for him. Abounding in crude and confused ideas of the elementary principles of economy and finance -- with frequent admissions of ignorance as to points which formed the foundation of his argument; and exhibiting ignorance quite as profound of matters in regard to which he assumed himself to be well informed, his remarkable forensic effort deserves transmission to posterity, as a model of all that a speech upon a national budget ought not to be. The only merit to be claimed for the effort, is its apparent earnestness and sincerity; but even these must be called in doubt, when we find the orator boldly representing the taxable values of the State of New-York at a figure considerably less than those of the City alone; and when we find him demonstrating, doubtless to the satisfaction of the throng of entranced planters, their wives, heirs and assigns, that the Confederate Bonds, secured by conditions never in the least likely to be fulfilled, are far more valuable than coin, the worth of which is unconditional.

abstract: The New-York Evangelical Alliance, which has assumed the onerous duty of caring for the religious wants of the soldiers of the Union engaged in the suppression of the great rebellion, held a meeting last night at Dr. MCCAULEY's Church in Fifth-avenue. The crowd was so great, that Dr. TYNG, in stating the purpose of the meeting, regretting the absence of Dr. SPRING remarked that if perchance the venerable and venerated pastor of the Brick Church had become lost in the mass, they would be obliged to somebody to have him forwarded to the pulpit.
lead_paragraph: The New-York Evangelical Alliance, which has assumed the onerous duty of caring for the religious wants of the soldiers of the Union engaged in the suppression of the great rebellion, held a meeting last night at Dr. MCCAULEY's Church in Fifth-avenue. abstract: The close contact of our Army with the ranks of the Secessionists and the events of the war, are revealing a fact in regard to the character of rebel recruits that should fix an indelible disgrace upon the insurgent leaders before the civilized nations of the earth.
lead_paragraph: The close contact of our Army with the ranks of the Secessionists and the events of the war, are revealing a fact in regard to the character of rebel recruits that should fix an indelible disgrace upon the insurgent leaders before the civilized nations of the earth. We allude to the numbers of extremely youthful persons -- in some cases boys, or more children -- that are found in the rebel service. Two circumstances, just brought to light, explain our meaning and enforce the preposition we make. At the camp at Laurel Hill, of Western Virginia, which Gen. GARNETT abandoned when he commenced his late disastrous retreat, were found a number of newly made graves. Several had inscriptions on their head-boards.

abstract: The Buffalo Commercial says: "A wealthy Mississippi planter, whose home is in Natchez, left Buffalo, Wednesday night, on the Western Metropolis, en route for home. He was accompanied by his wife, recently returned from an European tour. While on board the boat he openly announced to the passengers that he was a Secessionist, and that he intended to contribute his means to the cause of the Southern Confederacy on his arrival home. He said his brother-in-law, who also resides in Natchez, raised 550,000 bales of cotton last year, of which he contributed 100,000 bales to the Confederacy. This year he will raise 600,000 bales, and he intends to give it all to the cause, besides $50,000 in money. He was not molested."

abstract: It is a sad pleasure to communicate to you a state of affairs in Northwestern Virginia that at first sight may appear disastrous, but which, upon closer examination, sheds many a ray of satisfaction and encouragement to our future career--satisfaction that our late ill-success has lost to our State that portion which should never have been defended, and encouragement from the fact that our gallant boys fight with so much success against a thousand odds.

abstract: The proprietors of the TIMES announce with pleasure the completion of arrangements for furnishing the morning edition some hours earlier than, heretofore, and that complaint upon this subject, which has been so general, can no longer justly exist. abstract: STATEN ISLAND. -- A most agreeable Concert -- and one of high artistic merit -- took place on Saturday evening, at the new and elegant Hall of the St. Julien Hotel. It is seldom, even in this City, that we have a more recherche programme, or better artists to interpret it. The first morceau was HAYDEN's charming Quartette in G major, (opus 77, No. 1,) played faultlessly by Messrs. NOLL, HELWIG, BESIG and BERGMANN; then came a Solo on the piano-forte by Mr. J.B. MILLS, who still maintains his preeminence as our most finished performer. The piece was a new fantasia on themes from MEYERBEER's opera "Le Pardon de Ploermel," introducing some of the gems of that work, and replete with effective passages for the piano. It is Mr. MILLS' latest addition to the repertoire of his instrument, and in his hands is certainly as effective as it well can be. Mme. von BERKEL, an artiste who is heard to great advantage in the concert-room, gave a romance by MEYERBEER from the "Huguenots," with excellent taste, and later in the evening sang a couple of songs -- one of them Scotch, the other German -- to the entire delight of the audience. The remaining features of the programme were a new and very vigorous Trio by RUBINSTEIN, in B flat, (the third, op. 52) -- a work richly filled with motives, and carefully elaborated for the various instruments, and a Grand Fantasia on themes from "L'Elisir d'Amore," by HENSELT, played by Mr. MILLS. Both these productions were rendered so efficiently that their performance left nothing to be desired. We cannot recall a Chamber Concert where care and ability worked together more agreeably. It is a healthy sign of musical progress that such an entertainment is called for in our places of fashionable resort. The saloon of the St. Julien is admirably adapted for classical music. Ebery tone of the piano, (a superb instrument from Messrs. STEINWAY's establishment) could be heard in its full vibratory richness.

abstract: The children connected with Mr. BEECHER's congregation, in Brooklyn, with their parents, friends, and pastor, assembled in the church, yesterday afternoon, to take part in exercises appropriate to the close of the Sunday School for a month's vacation. Mr. BEECHER dispensed with his evening sermon, in order that this interesting festival might be held at a late and cool hour of the afternoon. After the singing of various hymns, addresses were made by THEODORE TILTON, Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, and GEORGE A. BELL, Superintendent of the school. A distribution of flowers to the children took place at the close of the exercise.

abstract: Yesterday was a glorious day for the National arms, and one in which Rebellion was taught a lesson which it will not soon forget, though at the expense of a sad loss of life.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was a glorious day for the National arms, and one in which Rebellion was taught a lesson which it will not soon forget, though at the expense of a sad loss of life. In accordance with preparations made on Saturday night, based upon the knowledge gained by numerous reconnoissances of the enemy's position after the battle of Bull's Run, the National Army was put in motion before daylight, yesterday morning, and advanced in three columns -- the main body passing Centreville in the direction of Perrysville, by which movement the position of the rebels was outflanked. The head of the centre column was preceded by a thirty-pounder rifled cannon to clear the way of any masked batteries which the enemy might open, and at 6 o'clock the first shot was fired from it, which, however, was not replied to. Col. RICHARDSON commanded the column which took the road to Bull's Run, where the fight of Thursday took place; Gen. TYLER commanded the centre column, which took the Warrenton road; and Col. HUNTER commanded the flank movement, by which the main attack was made -- the two other movements being intended as feints. Our artillery made various attempts to draw the fire of the enemy, but they kept silent until nearly nine o'clock, when rapid shots were exchanged between the skirmishers. Soon afterwards heavy clouds of dust were seen in the rear of the rebel position, indicating large reinforcements from Manassas, for which they had probably been waiting before replying to the fire of our artillery. At half-past eleven, the head of HUNTER's column was discovered across the Run, advancing upon the rebel flank, and the engagement then soon became very active. A constant roll of musketry marked his advance, while the artillery of the centre column played incessantly upon the enemy, forcing them to fall back. They made three attempts to charge with the bayonet upon our troops, but were each time repulsed with terrible loss. Their cavalry also made an attempt upon our flank, but that met with no better success. According to the latest bulletins received at Head-quarters in Washington, the rebels were finally compelled to retire with precipitation from their position, and fall back behind their Manassas lines -- some accounts say with the loss of all their ordnance and equipments. Our latest advices direct from the battle-field have the fight still in progress, but there seems to be no doubt, from the nature of the latest official bulletins, that the success of the National arms has been complete. The losses in killed and wounded on our side are very heavy -- those of the rebels must have been fearful, from the superior nature of our arms, and the rapidity and precision with which they were served.

abstract: DEAR SIR: Mr. MURRAY having responded for me, much more handsomely than I could have done, to your address on the presentation of the medal on behalf of the citizens of New-York, it is as unnecessary, as it would be out of order for me to write you as their organ on that occasion.
lead_paragraph: DEAR SIR: Mr. MURRAY having responded for me, much more handsomely than I could have done, to your address on the presentation of the medal on behalf of the citizens of New-York, it is as unnecessary, as it would be out of order for me to write you as their organ on that occasion. But as at the close of that address you say that your language is that of heartfelt sincerity, truthfully reflecting your own feelings, I feel that it will not be improper for me to express to you individually, as I now do, my acknowledgments of, and my thanks for, the beautifuland too highly complimentary manner in which you were then pleased to speak of my services.

abstract: It is stated that many soldiers fell by the way from sun-stroke, in the march to Fairfax Court-house. The day was excessively hot, and this consequence was to be expected, as a natural fruit of the absurd and unaccountable manner in which the troops had been clad.
lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON, Friday, July 19, 1861.

abstract: The news of our national disaster fell upon the public with overwhelming force. It came at a time when the full torrent of exultation at a supposed victory was spreading itself through the City, and cheering hearts that might be rendered desolate by the first
lead_paragraph: The news of our national disaster fell upon the public with overwhelming force. It came at a time when the full torrent of exultation at a supposed victory was spreading itself through the City, and cheering hearts that might be rendered desolate by the first details of the fight. No one was prepared for a check so abrupt. When the first dirty newsboy whirled through the streets, shrieking at the top of his ominous voice, "Defeat of the Union Army," no one felt the slightest disposition to buy an extra. It was regarded as a smart commercial fraud, which ought to be put a stop to by the police. But bad tidings travel apace, and in a short time it was known that a reverse had really been encountered. The newsboys -- who, if they wrong as a rule, are sometimes wronged as an exception -- were then in demand. Their stock of papers was rapidly exhausted, and the supply not being able to keep pace with the demand, the fortunate possessor of an extra became a sort of animated bulletin. Circles that constantly increased gathered around him, and heard with consternation the unhappy tidings. From 11 A.M. until midnight business, as an absorbing and distinct pursuit, was virtually suspended. Those who made a show of attending to it were so disheartened and preoccupied, that they will probably regret having done so. In Wall-street, where the death of one's grandmother has a commercial value, the reverse was considered disadvantageous to our cause to the extent of 4 per cent. Securities declined to that extent.

abstract: The call of Gen. MCCLELLAN to assume command of the forces upon the Potomac, is perhaps the most judicious change the Government could make in the leadership. Not that Gen. MCDOWELL has exhibited any deficiency of soldierly qualities, or courage, or talents as a commander. But the prejudice of a defeat cannot fail to impair the confidence of his men; for the soldier is apt to regard with almost superstitions distrust the ill-fortune that has attached itself even momentarily to their General. To be led by one who has never been beaten, is a victory half earned; and we have reason to believe the experience and skill of Gen. MCCLELLAN will earn the rest.

abstract: CITY MORTALITY. The deaths in this City for week ending July 21, numbered 532, being a decrease of 33 from the previous week, and an increase of 36 over the corresponding week of 1860. Of this num
lead_paragraph: CITY MORTALITY. -- The deaths in this City for week ending July 21, numbered 532, being a decrease of 33 from the previous week, and an increase of 36 over the corresponding week of 1860. Of this number, 175 were adults, and 357 children; 291 were males, and 241 females. The leading causes of death were: Consumption, 59; cholera infantum, 58; infantile convulsions, 64; marasmus, 33; diarrhoea, 28; inflammation of lungs, 21; dropsy in the head, 18; dysentery, 14; scarlet fever, 18, small-pox, 14; congestion of brain, 10; inflammation of bowels, 11; apoplexy, 7; inflammation of brain, 12; measles, 7; cholera morbus, 8; disease of the heart, 6; teething, 9; casualties, 8; drowned, 12; lock-jaw, 2; old age, 3. 228 of the children were of foreign parents, and 24 of native parents. 80 deaths occurred in the various public institutions. There were deaths in every Ward of the City, the largest number (68) being in the Nineteenth Ward, and the smallest number (1 each) in the Second and Third Wards.
