abstract: We have never seen a more wide-spread manifestation of surprise, mingled with sorrow, than that exhibited by all classes, yesterday afternoon, on receiving the startling
lead_paragraph: We have never seen a more wide-spread manifestation of surprise, mingled with sorrow, than that exhibited by all classes, yesterday afternoon, on receiving the startling intelligence of the sudden retreat of the National forces from their late scene of glorious conflict. The event stood in such singular contrast with the indomitable courage exhibited on the preceding day by all our regiments, and especially those this City had sent to the field, that the desire was universal to find some explanation for a reverse so unexpected. Even yet the cause is not fully apparent, and we can but await further findings.

abstract: The United States Marshal's Office was the centre of quite an attraction during the forenoon of yesterday, on account of the presence there of the captured privateersmen of the Sumter and Jeff. Davis,
lead_paragraph: The United States Marshal's Office was the centre of quite an attraction during the forenoon of yesterday, on account of the presence there of the captured privateersmen of the Sumter and Jeff. Davis, and particularly of the colored man TILLMAN, and his associate STEDING, second mate of the schooner S.J. Waring, who succeeded in retaking their vessel from the pirates by killing the ringleaders and throwing them overboard when they were within less than one day's sail of Charleston. TILLMAN was the chief object of curiosity, and he related the particulars of their adventures with the pirates with great clearness, and without any apparent compunctions for the part he acted.

abstract: The partial success of the National arms, which we chronicled yesterday, was followed by a disaster which more than counterbalanced it, and Gen. McDOWELL'S command, instead of pushing, victo
lead_paragraph: The partial success of the National arms, which we chronicled yesterday, was followed by a disaster which more than counterbalanced it, and Gen. McDOWELL'S command, instead of pushing, victorious, through the Rebel lines at Manassas Junction, has fallen back, and now re-occupies the intrenched position at Arlington Heights and Alexandria, having been terribly cut up, and having lost a great number of cannon and other appliances of war. From among the numerous and evidently exaggerated statements which have reached us, it is impossible to extract the exact truth relative to the cause and progress of this retrograde movement, and we must leave it for our correspondents, and the official dispatches shortly to be published, to place the mutter clearly before the public. It is encouraging to know, however, that the latest telegrams which reach us are of a decidedly more cheerful character than the first once. It appears that up to the date of our intest dispatches from the battle-field on Sunday evening, the greatest success was attending the movements of our Army. The Engineer Corps were about erecting a pontoon bridge across Bull's Run, the batteries were being unmasked one after the other, and the enemy were seemingly in retreat, when a terrine panic broke out among the teamsters, who had incansiously advanced too far, which was communicated to the numerous body of civilians present, and subsequently to some of the volunteers, -- the result of which was finally a general retreat. Our losses, in killed and wounded only a partial list of which we are able to give this morning, are frightful, though not so bad as at first represented. It is useless to give estimates, as they are wholly unreliable. The forces engaged on our side were greatly inferior to those of the enemy, which are believed to have numbered, after the addition of JOHNSTON's command, some ninety thousand, while those of the National actually in the battle did not exceed twenty thousand.

abstract: The Message of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS is by no means a cheerful paper. On the conirary, as far as we have received extracts or ver sions of it, it seems to be burthened with com
lead_paragraph: The Message of Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS is by no means a cheerful paper. On the conirary, as far as we have received extracts or ver sions of it, it seems to be burthened with complaints of the United States and Mr. LYNCOLN, the President. Indeed, a person who should read only Mr. DAVIS' side of the story, and should be so verdant as to put any faith in his truth and sincerity, would come to the conclusion that Mr. DAVIS is a badly-treated President, and the United States a. Governmental entitled to little consideration on the score of honor and humanity.

abstract: The last number of PETERMANN'S Communications, the best geographical periodical now published, contains an article on Labrador, by OSCAR M. LIEBER, with a chart of the eastern coast of
lead_paragraph: The last number of PETERMANN'S Communications, the best geographical periodical now published, contains an article on Labrador, by OSCAR M. LIEBER, with a chart of the eastern coast of that country, from the Strait of Belleisle to Cape Chudleigh. Mr. LIEBER (one of our townsmen, Dr. FRANCIS LEIBER, and well known by his geological reports on the State of South Carolina) was the geologist of the United States expedition sent by our Government in the month of July, 1860, to observe the eclipse at Cape Chudleigh. The article is of great geological, geographical and ethnographic, interest; and the chart, which has been drawn from Mr. LIEBER's drawing, with additions which were not at his disposal, but which Dr. PETERMANN possessed, is the most complete and accurate now existing of a country concerning which the English Admiralty charts, as well as any others published until now, are incomplete and often incorrect. Our chartographers will make prompt and good use of this valuable contribution to American geography. It will be found appended to No. 6 of the year 1861 of Dr. A. PETERMANN's Miltheilangen, published at Gotha.

abstract: There is no occasion to belittle the calamity which has fallen upon the country. The gallant Army of the Union has been routed and put to flight by the Army of the rebels:
lead_paragraph: There is no occasion to belittle the calamity which has fallen upon the country. The gallant Army of the Union has been routed and put to flight by the Army of the rebels: and if, from the fragments enough material can be gathered to insure the immediate safety of the Capital, the nation will have a melancholy and imperfect reason for congratulation. The plot of this tragedy it is hardly worth while to analyze. We only know that recoiling from their exposed encounter with hostile batteries, on Thursday last, our troops had prepared themselves for an exhibition of greater strength and more desperate valor; and that up to a certain hour on Sunday afternoon, these preparations had borne fruit in a series of brilliant successes, in which three powerful batteries of the enemy had been captured. At this moment, the foe seemed to have redoubled his forces, and to have brought to the struggle with our exhausted, but courageous fellows, a renewed and irresistible power, against which they found themselves unable to make head. Upon our lines of exhausted and inexperienced soldiers, hostile cavalry in great numbers charged impetuously: a species of assault for which they had no preparation, and which only veterans know how successfully to repel. A panic retreat followed; artillery, baggage, arms are abandoned to an enemy which, strange to say, made no pursuit; and the defeated only paused within the lines of their distant intrenchments. To attempt any diminution of this victory of the rebels would be absurd self-delusion. The world will tell over the count of dead and wounded; the guns, nearly a hundred in number, captured by the victors, and the standard seized -- alas, that the starry flag of our fathers should be that standard -- and from these elements will determine the real magnitude of the National loss.

abstract: It is admitted on all hands, that the money to be raised on loan, by the Government during the present fiscal year, will fall short of its actual accessities, by at least eighty
lead_paragraph: It is admitted on all hands, that the money to be raised on loan, by the Government during the present fiscal year, will fall short of its actual accessities, by at least eighty millions -- and that taxation, either direct or indirect, or both, must be resorted to, without delay, to provide for the deficiency. The very interesting question then arises, and one which Congress must decide before adjourning -- on whose shoulders, or, in other words, on what species of property, shall this heavy burden be imposed? We see by the amended Tariff Act, just received from Washington, that Congress has acted in part on that branch of the subject embracing "indirect" taxation, by taxing tea fifteen cents, coffee five cents, and sugars of different kinds from two and a half to six cents a pound, with some increase of preexisting rates on some other articles of less importance. It is estimated that the additional revenues provided by this bill, necessarily fluctuating with the consumption of the articles taxed, will yield about thirty-five millions. That amount, we fear, will do little more than supply the deficiency of our preexisting revenues in paying the ordinary expenses of the Government. True it is, that not only those expenses, but all the expenses of the War, might be largely reduced, if anything like a rigid or prudent economy could find its way into Congress, -- but we despair of that. We believe our faithful representative, Mr. CONKLING, and his associates on the Retrenchment Committee, to be gentlemen of pure character and patriotic aims, but we are admonished by all past experience not to indulge the romantic hope, that any Committee will be permitted to abridge, to any material extent, the salaries or perquisites or means of depredation of favored officeholders.

abstract: The first report of the brilliant achievements of ourtroops at Bull's Run had scarcely been heralded in the city, and the news had hardly been discussed and digested, are things of sudden disaster to the Na-
lead_paragraph: The first report of the brilliant achievements of ourtroops at Bull's Run had scarcely been heralded in the city, and the news had hardly been discussed and digested, are things of sudden disaster to the National arms has filled the patriotic Northern heart with profoundest melancholy and most poignant grief. In the first flush of excitement attending the information of the grand advance upon the intrenched hosts of the enemy, the capture of their batteries, and resistance to their cavalry charges, men's blood received fresh warmth from the flames of patriotic fire and coursed move swiftly through their veins. In their stations, shared even by the many who wait in eager suspense tidings of them they hold most dear, the thought of a repulse was never harbored. Had not the course of the authorities been marked by a full consciousness of overwhelming power? The populace, self-sacrificing and earnest in waging that war on behalf of [???] had flocked in legions to the national defence. Thousands more, many of whom had already organized into regiments, [???] but a word to take the [???], but that word from the Government never came. On the contrary, they were rejected. A feeling of security, amounting almost to a sense of invincibility, had taken aggression of the popular mind last [???], it was [???] broken. Men were stricken with dismay when the first brief dispatch announcing the retreat of the Union forces was [???] by the City Press. The statement came with crushing force, and none were prepared to credit it. All doubled its truth, and awaited, with anxiety, further advices. Some considered the announcement a cruel ruse of the stock brokers, and bets were freely offered against its being true. Others believed that it might be fact, but if so, it was a [???] of MCDOWELL's to draw the [???] from behind his batteries and attack him in the field.

abstract: Col. RUSSELL, of Kentucky, lately appointed United States Consul for Trinidad, sailed on Thursday in the steamship Santiago de Cuba. Col. RUSSELL was accompanied by Mr. E. MARSU, late bookkeeper of the Metropolitan Hotel, and Mr. ANDREW SHEEHAN. About sixty ladies and gentlemen, friends of the Colonel, accompanied them down the bay. When outside the Hook the steam tug Putnam, which had been chartered for the occasion, took the party off. After three hearty cheers were given for the Colonel and his companions, they steamed quietly back to this City.

abstract: A highly interesting letter to the Cincinnati Commercial, dated Beverly, July 14, gives not only the latest information of Gen. McCLELLAN'S whereabouts, but also a very minute and detailed review of the late battle, We have only room for the follow
lead_paragraph: A highly interesting letter to the Cincinnati Commercial, dated Beverly, July 14, gives not only the latest information of Gen. McCLELLAN'S whereabouts, but also a very minute and detailed review of the late battle, We have only room for the following extracts: According to the testimony of captive rebel officers, Gen. GARNETT recently visited Rich Mountain, when his advise respecting rear defences was asked. The engineer was consulted, and a council of war was held, when it was unanimously decided that the configuration of the mountain made it physically impossible for the National troops to turn the rebel flank and get into their rear. So it seems. That Gen. MCCLELLAN did not concur in this view was afterwards established. But I mention as a remarkable fact that on Sunday night preceding the battle, and while Gen. MCCLELLAN was encamped at Buckhannon, he wrote a letter to Gen. SCOTT, in which he said: "We shall probably, have a fight at Roaring Run or Rich Mountain, one or the other. I shall there repeat your Cerro Gordo operation, turn the enemy's flank and assail his rear." This whole campaign has developed, in its main features, precisely according to the plan formed by Gen. MCCLELLAN before he left Cincinnati.

abstract: The manner of the retaking of this prize of the rebel privateer is one which, however humanity may shudder at its contemplation, yet is in
lead_paragraph: -- The manner of the retaking of this prize of the rebel privateer is one which, however humanity may shudder at its contemplation, yet is in accordance with the rules and among the hard necessities of war. The man who achieved it is entitled to the respect and commendation of his countrymen. That his skin is not white should make no difference in this respect. It was an act of heroism which nothing but patriotism could inspire, and The courage with which he executed it shows that he is possessed of the heart of a true man.

abstract: The first report of the brilliant achievements of our troops at Bull's Run had scarcely been heralded in the city, and the news had hardly been discussed and digested; ere tidings of sudden disaster to the Na-
lead_paragraph: The first report of the brilliant achievements of our troops at Bull's Run had scarcely been heralded in the city, and the news had hardly been discussed and digested; ere tidings of sudden disaster to the National arms has filled the patriotic Northern heart with profoundest melancholy and most poignant grief. In the first flush of excitement attending the information of the grand advance upon the intrenched hosts of the enemy, the capture of their batteries, and resistance to their cavalry charges, men's blood received fresh warmth from the flames of patriotic fire and coursed more swiftly through their veins. In their station, shared even by the many who wait in eager suspense tidings of them they hold most dear, the thought of a repulse was never harbored. Had not the course of the authorities been marked by a full consciousness of overwhelming power? The populace, self-sacrificing and earnest in waging the war on behalf of liberty had flocked in legions to the national defence. Thousands more, many of whom had already organized into regiments, awaiting but a word to take the field, but that word from the Government never came. On the contrary, they were rejected. A feeling of security, amounting almost to a sense of invincibility, had taken possession of the popular mind, but yesterday it was rudely broken. Men were stricken with dismay when the first brief dispatch announcing the retreat of the Union forces was bulletined by the City Press. The statement came with crushing force, and none were prepared to credit it. All doubted its truth, and awaited, with anxiety, further advices. Some considered the announcement a cruel ruse of the stuck brokers, and bets were freely offered against its being true. Others believed that it might be fact, but if so, it was a feint of MCDOWELL's to draw the enemy from behind his batteries and attack him in the field.

abstract: HENS' NESTS SURE REMEDY FOR EATING EGGS. Fowls of all kinds, when laying, like a secret place, where their fellows cannot see them. Therefore, they do not like to squat down in the
lead_paragraph: HENS' -- NESTS SURE REMEDY FOR EATING EGGS. -- Fowls of all kinds, when laying, like a secret place, where their fellows cannot see them. Therefore, they do not like to squat down in the hennery, surrounded by a greedy flock, that are ready to pounce into the nest, as soon as an egg is layed, and devour it. Therefore, to gratify the hen's secretiveness, and at the same time save the eggs from being devoured by one of the flock, my practice has been, for a number of years, to make their nests in nail kegs -- not those that are very small, not the largest ones -- but of those that will hold about one hundred pounds of nails. In years past, I have been accustomed to fill a keg about half full of straw for a nest; but, the past Winter, I have sawed all the kegs in two equal parts -- knocking out the heads, and then nail a piece of cloth over the large end of each half keg, for a bottom. Any kind of old or new cloth may be tacked on with small trimming tacks. During the Winter, these half kegs are miled up against the side of the hennery, about four feet from the floor. Hens that lay will soon learn that when they get into these nests, their fellows cannot see them, as they are completely secluded in their cosy little nests; and if they themselves are disposed to eat eggs, they find that, if they attempt it while standing on the edge of the keg, they cannot reach them conveniently; and if they hop down into the nest, and attempt to pick the eggs, they will roll down against their feet, and they soon learn that they are not able to pick hard enough in such a position to break the shell. I find that a cloth bottom is superior to a wooden bottom, covered with a nest of straw. As the weather becomes warmer, so that the hens seek nests in the yard, we make nests in secluded nooks, or the kegs might be removed from the hennery and nailed against the side of the fence, and a little roof made over them.

abstract: A large lot of quinine -- now a scarce article in the South -- reached Tennessee recently concealed in a show wagon, the driver of which started for some point in Indiana, crossed the river under the character of being the avant courier of a show, and so contrived to travel through Kentucky until he reached a congenial climate, making, it is said, ten thousand dollars by the trip. It is said that needles sell in the South for five cents each, and that two or three weeks since an individual smuggled into Nashville, in his trunk and about his person, a sufficient number to clear upwards of two thousand dollars. He has since made a similar speculation upon spool-cotton, also a scarce article, and like needles very likely to escape detection.

abstract: "The Confederate States," says the Charleston Mercury, "have had four instrumentalities to win them peace, and the acknowledgment of their independence: 1. Negotiation. 2. Fighting on the sea or privateering. S. Fighting on land. 4. Cotton. Two of these instrumentalities have failed." Such is the "Quadrilateral" on which the rebel States relied for success in their treason, and such the confession of the failure of two of them The refusal of European nations to acknowledge them as a power, has deprived them of the prestige of nationality, and the closing of European ports against their piratical cruisers, has brought "privateering," (to use the language of the Mercury again,) "as a means of coercing a peace by sweeping the the shipping of the United States from the seas, to an end." Thus fighting by land, and cotton are what remain to secession. We can understand the power of the former, and can trace it to its remote sequence in the final overthrow of rebellion, whatever temporary success treason may, in the last two or three days, have achieved. How cotton is to prove a defence when the other three "instrumentalities" shall have, failed, passes our comprehension. It cannot be eaten, and with the ports of the Cotton States sealed by blockade, and all egress by land cut off, the millions of bales will be as harmless as so many sandbags, and almost as valueless. But it is insisted by the Mercury that the necessity for this staple will force England and France to side with rebellion, and that through their aid the independence of the revolted States will be compelled. This, we think, may be safely regarded as among the senseless vagaries of the Southern brain. The necessities of these two great nations for cotton will not make them regardless of the law of nations, nor disloyal to the great principles of freedom and humanity. They will bear the evils of a short supply for a season, rather than violate their treaty obligations with a friendly power, struggling to put down a rebellion the wickedest that the sun ever shone upon, the avowed object of which is to initiate a new civilization, based upon the propagandism and perpetuation, through all time, of human slavery.

abstract: It may be invidious to distinguish between the merits of the several bodies of troops en- gaged in the battle of July 21; but it is due to the regiments of foreign origin to remark the eminent courage and efficiency of their service. To the Sixty-ninth Regiment too much praise for unflinching and persistent gallantry can hardly be awarded.
lead_paragraph: It may be invidious to distinguish between the merits of the several bodies of troops en- gaged in the battle of July 21; but it is due to the regiments of foreign origin to remark the eminent courage and efficiency of their service. To the Sixty-ninth Regiment too much praise for unflinching and persistent gallantry can hardly be awarded. It is with sinceresorrow we have to record the loss of their bravo commander, who, in a military career so brief, had extended to the whole country the sentiments of respect for his patriotism, energy and self-devotion, which he had long since secured in this City. The safety of Capt. MEAGHER, who was throughout in the heat of the fight, and had a horse shot under him, will be matter of sincere congratulation among his legion of friends. The Seventy-ninth seems to have emulated the Irish Regiment in its sturdy and manly fighting qualities. And when the retreat had been ordered, it was the masterly skill of the German Brigade, under Col. BLENKER, which covered the movement, and prevented any accumulated disasters. This tribute, so well earned, cannot detract from the credit of the native troops. The immense sacrifice of life sustained by the Fire Zouaves and the Seventy-first Regiments proves how dauntlessly both of them must have held the most dangerous positions, and urged their conflict with the enemy. But the fact must not prevent us from according that prominence in the dividend of honor, which clearly belongs to the Cell, the Gael, and the Teuton.

abstract: In the commencement of this campaign we urged upon the authorities the necessity of organizing an efficient corps of cavalry for the Army. We were met by the assertion that cavalry had ceased to be regarded as essential to military operations, and that the same number of men would be more serviceable on foot than mounted. In fact, we were told that cavalry was obsolete in modern military science. The events of the last few days have demonstrated that we were right in our views, or that the authorities at Washington have changed theirs, for they are now full of energy in the organization of regiments of cavalry, which should, in common prudence, have been in the field long ago. A force of five or ten thousand men, good riders, accustomed to the use of horses from their youth, might easily have been raised in the State of New-York alone, and who, by this time, might have been so drilled and taught as to have been one of the most efficient branches of the military power of the country. It would almost seem that we are doomed to learn wisdom only from the lessons of disaster, and that we begin to study these only on the day after defeat. Still it is encouraging to know that we do progress; that routine does not prevent us from profiting by a painful experience, even though a common forecast would have avoided the misfortunes that make us wise.

abstract: Mr. BAYARD, of Delaware, is among the few Senators in Congress of the United States, who demand peace at the expense of the Union; who see in this war nothing but slaughter -- no object to be attained -- nothing worth fighting for. With him, and such as him, the Union is nothing, the Constitution nothing, the great American Republic nothing, when put into the scale against a war for their preservation. One rebel life -- one ounce even of rebel blood -- is of more value than them all. Hence he demands peace at any sacrifice, and if to attain it the Republic is to to be sponged out from the map of the world, and obliterated from the catalogue of nations, it should be done. His State, we believe, has never seriously wavered in its loyally to the Union. It has called no Conventions, sent no emissaries to the seceded States, though some may have volunteered their services. It has gone along quietly and patriotically under the old flag, bearing its share of the burthens of sustaining the Government, entering into no conspiracies, sympathizing with no treasonable movements for its overthrow. We suppose that the people of Delaware are as faithful to their allegiance to the Constitution as are those of New-York, Pennsylvania, or Ohio, and are as fixed in their resolve that it shall be maintained. Senator BAYARD therefore represents simply his own opinion and views, and not the sentiments of his constituency.

abstract: Exaggeration played its usual trick with the news of Sunday's battle. In the light of more detailed and authentic advices, it may fairly be considered doubtful whether either party has gained a victory; for while, panic-stricken, our exposed forces left the field, it is clear that the enemy never quitted their entrenchments to occupy it; in fact, they appear to have been so much intimidated by the encounter, as to pretermit the opportunity they undoubtedly possessed to cut to pieces our retiring troops. This omission may be explained in two ways. In the fighting throughout the day the National troops had exhibited every superiority of strength, tact, and courage, uniformly driving before them the enemy when he ventured beyond his defences, and even capturing three of his batteries in succession. Such exploits could not fail to fill the insurgent ranks with dread of the equal terms upon which they must stand were they to quit their lines; and, indeed, after the prodigies of valor our fellows had displayed, they had every reason to believe the backward movement was a feint to decoy them from their almost impregnable works, to ground where the conditions of the contest should be equalized.

abstract: ARREST OF AN EX-CUSTOM-HOUSE CLERK. -- Deputy Marshal LEE yesterday arrested JAS. B. KINSLOW, for several years past, until quite recently, a bonded clerk in the Custom-house, on a charge of stealing thirty "owner's oath bonds," of the denomination of $100 each. The robbery took place about the 10th inst., and was effected by cutting out several leaves from the bond book. KINSLOW was recently discharged from the Custom-house, but has been in the habit of visiting his former quatrers frequently, and when the theft was discovered, suspicion rested upon him. He was committed to the Tombs by United States Commissioner OSBORNE.
lead_paragraph: ARREST OF AN EX-CUSTOM-HOUSE CLERK. -- Deputy Marshal LEE yesterday arrested JAS. B. abstract: - It has been asserted, upon sufficient authority, that the commanders of the insurgents have availed themselves of the skill, so general in the South, in the use of the rifle, for the organization of Sharp-shooting companies attached to each regiment; and that these men are directed to select as their targets the officers of the National Army. Some evidence of the truth of the story may be found in the affair of Sunday. The number of officers killed and injured is out of all proportion to the number of the rank and file, showing that the enemy had not used their weapons indiscriminately. To the efficiency of these practiced marksmen may also be ascribed another circumstance, which has excited surprise, namely, the fact that nearly every horse of the artillery trains was shot; and that, for this reason, the guns had to be left behind. Clearly, there cannot be too much activity in bringing the same description of skill to the aid of our Army. Where is the regiment of Col. BREDAN?

abstract: From the latest news in the City we hear of casualties among the following officers of the regulars: Capt. B.H. TILLINGHAST, of the famous First Artillery -- SLEMMER's and ANDERSON's regiment -- is severely wounded. This was one of the best commandants we had. He is a New-Yorker, a graduate of West Point, and entered the service as a Second Lieutenant in the Third Artillery, in 1851. Lieut. HITCHCOCK, a new  appointment in the Marine Corps and a Lieut. HARRINGTON are put down as killed.

abstract: Patting together the accounts which reach us from all quarters, we are brought still more forcibly to the conclusion that the retirement of the National Army from before Manassas on Sunday, was in the face of victory, and not defeat. As our dispatches continue to come in, they cut down the exaggerations of the first reports, and we now begin to have a more definite idea of what we have suffered.
lead_paragraph: Putting together the accounts which reach us from all quarters, we are brought still more forcibly to the conclusion that the retirement of the National Army from before Manassas on Sunday, was in the face of victory, and not defeat. As our dispatches continue to come in, they cut down the exaggerations of the first reports, and we now begin to have a more definite idea of what we have suffered. It is probable that our loss in killed and wounded will not exceed six hundred. Several of the cannon reported to have fallen into the hands of the enemy, are found to be saved. The number of baggage wagons lost is much less than at first reported -- and so of other items. On the other hand, the losses of the rebels, in killed and wounded, must have been fearful. It is estimated at Memphis, Tenn., to reach three thousand, and the nature of the dispatches from the rebel camp to the Southern journals are of a tone indicating anything but the exhilaration of victory. Perhaps the most significant indication is the fact that they made no attempt to follow our retiring forces, but remained behind their intrenchments. Col. EINSTEIN, of the Twenty-sixth Pennsylvania Regiment, returned to the battle-field with a party of men about 11 o'clock on Sunday night, and brought away six pieces of our artillery which had been left behind, without any attempt at molestation on the part of the enemy, who were at that time nowhere in sight. It appears, also, that a portion of our army still remains at Centreville, where no attempt has been made to molest them. Meanwhile the most vigorous measures have been inaugurated by the Government to correct the mistake which has been made. And at the end of a few days we may expect to see an army of a hundred thousand men at Washington, ready to make another essay in behalf of the Union.

abstract: Hon. J.S.T. STRANAHAN and A.J. BENSON, Esq., returned from Washington last evening, bringing with them the following list of killed and wounded of tire Fourteenth (Brooklyn) Regiment, Col. A.M. WOOD. These gentlemen also bring the gratifying intelligence that Lieut.-Col. FOWLER, of the Fourteenth, before reported deed,  was at Arlington Heights, alive and well.
lead_paragraph: Hon. J.S.T. STRANAHAN and A.J. BENSON, Esq., returned from Washington last evening, bringing with them the following list of killed and wounded of tire Fourteenth (Brooklyn) Regiment, Col. A.M. WOOD. These gentlemen also bring the gratifying intelligence that Lieut.-Col. FOWLER, of the Fourteenth, before reported deed, was at Arlington Heights, alive and well. The rumor of his being killed is supposed to have been founded upon the fact that when Col. WOOD was wounded, he took him from the field, and his disappearance led to the supposition that he had fallen. The safety of Col. FOWLER was at once communicated to his wife, who, for the twenty-four hours previous, had mourned him as dead.

abstract: There is a divinity shaping the course of  this war, and we must accept its fortunes and its misfortunes with equal trust and hopefulness. These is one thing, and only one, at the bottom of the fight, and that is the negro. And yet, both North and South are studiously ignoring the fact, and deceiving themselves and trying to deceive the world as to the cause of quarrel.
lead_paragraph: There is a divinity shaping the course of this war, and we must accept its fortunes and its misfortunes with equal trust and hopefulness. These is one thing, and only one, at the bottom of the fight, and that is the negro. And yet, both North and South are studiously ignoring the fact, -- and deceiving themselves and trying to deceive the world as to the cause of quarrel. The South pretends to be fighting for independence -- but it is fighting for the establishment of human bondage as the basis of republican government. The North, or loyal States, claim to be fighting for the reestablishment of the Constitution and laws, and to have no thought of property or social institutions in their minds. But they know that until, Slavery changes its relation to Government, and becomes its complete subject, instead of its arrogant master, the peace and safety of the Republic are impossible.

abstract: The error withwhich this officer began his military careerseems to have been amply atoned for by zeal and gallantry in the late battle. For twenty hours the various accounts agree in telling us the General was in his saddle, busy in passing from point to point, and during the engagement, exposing himself recklessly to the hottest fire of the enemy. For the sake of this really meritorious display of activity and bravery, let the record of Vienna be expunged from the chronicle of the war.

abstract: Thomas H. Baker, the Captain, and the crew of the Savannah were this morning arraigned to plead to the indictment. It was proposed not to have the indictment read to them, but the District Attorney seemed to think it had better be read, and the Deputy Clerk, Mr. Stilwell, accordingly read it to them, while they stood wearily before him. This being over, the prisoners were severally asked if they pleaded guilty or not guilty, and all answered not guilty.
lead_paragraph: Thomas H. Baker, the Captain, and the crew of the Savannah were this morning arraigned to plead to the indictment. It was proposed not to have the indictment read to them, but the District Attorney seemed to think it had better be read, and the Deputy Clerk, Mr. Stilwell, accordingly read it to them, while they stood wearily before him. This being over, the prisoners were severally asked if they pleaded guilty or not guilty, and all answered not guilty.

abstract: The TIMES, on Monday, in common with every other City journal, failed to publish the fact that the Union troops had been defeated in the battle in advance of Manassas Junction The whole community was thus misled in regard to one of the most important incidents of recent history. We desire it to be distinctly understood that we are not in the slightest degree responsible for what, if done deliberately by us, would be branded as a wanton and reckless trifling with the feelings of the public.

abstract: The First Regiment of the Excelsior Brigade took their departure from Staten Island yesterday of ternoon. They received orders to march on Monday, and gave vent to their joy by exultant cheers. Everything was packed up on Monday evening, the tents being left behind for the use of the camp until the last regiments move. During the day the wives and daughters of the members came to bid adieu to their friends.
lead_paragraph: The First Regiment of the Excelsior Brigade took their departure from Staten Island yesterday of ternoon. They received orders to march on Monday, and gave vent to their joy by exultant cheers. Everything was packed up on Monday evening, the tents being left behind for the use of the camp until the last regiments move. During the day the wives and daughters of the members came to bid adieu to their friends. The scene between many of these was deeply affecting. The partings were in nearly every case taken as if for the last time. The sorrowful news from the Army in Virginia evidently added much to the concern which possessed the mind at these last interviews. There was a meeting at the Head-quarters in the evening, when the men were fully informed of the reports from the Army. The effect upon the soldiers was most extraordinary. Vociferous cheers were given for the Sixty-ninth and its gallant Colonel, and clamorous expressions of impatience to be led into the field. There was no sign of hesitation or despondency. Two companies arrived on the ground about midnight with a band of music, when the entire camp was roused and came out, hoping to hear some encouraging news. They gave cheers for their newly-arrived recruits, and then retired again.

abstract: We learn by telegraph,that the bill to levy a Direct Tax, was introduced into the House of Representatives to-day, and referred to the Committee of the Whole. The amount is not stated, but we presume of course that it is sufficient, at least, to pay the interest on the debt now existing, and that to be incurred during the present fiscal year, -- and further, that its proceeds will be specially pledged to that object. This was the case with the Direct Tax levied by the act of 1815, and is indeed indispensable to the due support of the public credit. We are engaged in an honest war, and mean honestly to pay for it, by an honest scheme of finance. The rebels may pay, if they can, by forced loans of cotton. We intend to pay in honest cash, and punctually at the day.

abstract: If the Congressional Committee on Naval Affairs, to whom the subjects of the Stevens Battery and the construction of shot-proof vessels in general, have been referred, will only take time and pains to investigate the matter thoroughly, they will confer a favor upon the public, which few Committees have the opportunity to grant.
lead_paragraph: If the Congressional Committee on Naval Affairs, to whom the subjects of the Stevens Battery and the construction of shot-proof vessels in general, have been referred, will only take time and pains to investigate the matter thoroughly, they will confer a favor upon the public, which few Committees have the opportunity to grant. After the developments of the last three months, not even a Peace Society can be found to oppose the better and immediate protection of our great hasbors against rifle-armed and steel-clad invasion. The eighteen-inch globes of the new Rodman guns, and the yard-long bolts -- we may as well, say thunderbolts -- of the steel cannon which we shall mount on our forts one of these days -- "built-up" jobs to the contrary -- may, indeed, scatter the ponderous scales of such sea-monsters. as the Warrior and the Black Prince, but thinking people will hardly allow these fast-sailing leviathans the advantage of an undisputed channel and a flood tide, with only the gauntlet, of a few broadsides from shore, to run, which passed, the city itself is at the mercy of the enemy's shells and red-hot shot. They want steel-hide to meet steel-hide in fair fight, disputing every inch of brine by hard blows in close quarters, so that the shore, batteries may have time to drive the intruder back or to the bottom; for a coat of steel mail is not going to be knocked into a wreck during the few moments it will occupy in sailing under our forts at fifteen or sixteen miles an hour; and if the Warrior should get as far as Hoboken with so much left of her as half-a-dozen guns, men enough to serve them, and whole compartments enough to keep them out of water, she could make short work with the City of New-York. It is not probable that a wooden enemy could ever get further than Fort Hamilton; but it is extremely probable that out of a small fleet of mailed ships, with no opposition but stationary guns on shore, at least one could sail beyond shot-range, and so bombard the City at its leisure. Such ships must be met by others of a similar or better class, competent to engage and, in fact, monopolize their attentions -the forts will do the rest. To send wooden walls against a volcano of red-hot metal would be perfectly idle; a few hundred rifle-armed gun-boats, surrounding the Warrior, might sink her; but evidently the shortest, surest, and cheapest way to fight her, and to delay her -- that is the great point -- is to send another Warrior out to meet her. Hence the subject of iron-clad ships is most timely.

abstract: Every mother should be prepared to act in the capacity of both nurse and physician to her children; she can, it she will, discharge these duties much better than any one the can employ. abstract: THE PIRATE SLAYERS AT BARNUM'S MUSEUM.  WM.TILLMAN, the colored steward of the schooner S.J.Waring, and WM.STEDDING, who assisted him in throwing overboard the pirates, and resuming command of the vessel after she had been captured by the privateer Jeff.Daavis, visited Barnum's Museum yesterday. As soon as it became known that they
lead_paragraph: THE PIRATE SLAYERS AT BARNUM's MUSEUM. -- WM.TILLMAN, the colored steward of the schooner S.J.Waring, and WM.STEDDING, who assisted him in throwing overboard the pirates, and resuming command of the vessel after she had been captured by the privateer Jeff.Daavis, visited Barnum's Museum yesterday. As soon as it became known that they were in the Museum, they were surrounded by a large crowd of the visitors present, and at once found themselves the lions of the occasion, and apparently the chief attraction of the place. So great was the anxiety of the crowd to hear the particulars of their encounter with the pirates, and so many times were they obliged to repeat the story, that they had no time to inspect the curiosities which they came to see, and requested of Mr. BARNUM to be allowed to come again to-day free of charge. They were told that they might come as often as they pleased, and subsequently Mr. BARNUM obtained permission from the District-Attorney for them to visit the Museum daily until otherwise ordered. The large numbers of people who have applied for permission to see them at the house for the detention of witnesses will, therefore, have an opportunity of gratifying their curiosity by visiting the Museum on any day during the coming week. The coat worn by the Captain of the pirate gang, the hatchet with which they were dispatched, and the secession flag which they manufactured out of the Union flag found on board of the schooner, will also be exhibited, and the particulars of the recapture of the schooner will be rehearsed to all who desire to hear them.

abstract: Nothing could have spoken better for the honor and the welfare of the country than the feeling that was universally elicited by the monstrously exaggerated reports of the retreat from Bull's Run.
lead_paragraph: Nothing could have spoken better for the honor and the welfare of the country than the feeling that was universally elicited by the monstrously exaggerated reports of the retreat from Bull's Run. When we all believedthat we had lost nearly three thousand men in the battle, that our soldiers had fled because they dared not face the rebels, leaving all their artillery upon the field, flinging away their muskets and knapsacks to facilitate their escape from an exultant and pursuing foe; that the panic was so utter and so universal that no regiment left the field in order; that our rear was not protected, and that the disorderly fugitives could not be rallied at any point upon our line of communication, -- in short, that the whole main body of the National Army had been put to utter and ignominious rout, that we had suffered disgrace and demoralization, as well as defeat, and That for the present all was lost, including honor, the temporary feeling was one of surprise, of sadness, almost of woe. Women who had no personal friends in the field wept and lamented as if they had been bereaved; and silent men wished for the moment that they were women, that they might thus relieve their overcharged bosoms. But amid all this there was not even a momentary flinching from the determination to put down the insurrection by the strong hand. The flood rose the higher because of the obstacle that it encountered, and in a moment broke it down, and bore it off, on a resistless current. Men were sorrowful, but not despondent; and went about with a compression of the lip and a sad determination in the eye that boded ill to those who had brought them to this sorrow. And now that we find that our volunteers more than made good our expectations of them, that even when fighting under every disadvantage, they proved, one to two, more than a match for their opponents, and that the flight began not among those who were in action, but with the teamsters and the reserve, and that our twenty thousand left their sixty thousand foes not in a condition to pursue, the spirit of the country has risen to a higher point than that at which it stood before this ill-starred movement on Manassas; and the only audible voice is that which calls for instant and vigorous preparation.

abstract: The Committee appointed by the Common Council, met in the chamber of the Board of Aldermen last evening, for the purpose of making suitable arrangements for the funeral obsequies of Col. KENNEDY. On motion, of Mr. ORTON, a Sub Committee of three was appointed by the Chairman, Mr. FROMENT, to take charge of the matter, and make such preliminary arrangements as were deemed advisable. Messrs. [???] BRANDON, and ORTON were delegated to serve on that Committee, and on motion Messr. FROMENT and BARNEY were added to the list. The Tammany Society notified the Committee, that they were willing to, occupy any position in the procession that may be assigned them by the latter. The Committee then adjourned to meet at 12 o'clock to-day in room No. 8 City Hall, to receive the report of the sub-committee.

abstract: The most vigorous measures have been inaugurated by the Government to correct the mistake of Sunday last, and to put the Army in a condition to make it impossible that such another event can occur.
lead_paragraph: The most vigorous measures have been inaugurated by the Government to correct the mistake of Sunday last, and to put the Army in a condition to make it impossible that such another event can occur. A complete reorganization of the Army is to take place immediately, and such steps will be adopted as will insure us, as far as it is possible to do so, against incompetency among the officers. To this end general orders were issued yesterday from the War Department, that all officers of regiments will hereafter be subject to examination by a Board of officers, to be appointed by the Secretary of War, with the concurrence of the Lieutenant-General, in order that their fitness for the positions assigned them may be assured -- their places, should they be be found incompetent, to be filled by officers who shall have passed an examination successfully. Business at the War Department yesterday was remarkably heavy. Tenders of troops are made in surprising numbers. Up to 12 o'clock, at noon our dispatches state, nearly eighty thousand new men had been accepted, and are now being mustered into the service. It is understood that Illinois alone has offered seventeen, and Indiana ten new regiments, some of which are already on the way. The response to the new call of the Government is wonderfully prompt, and indicative of a spirit and determination which will certainly carry us in the end over all intervening obstacles to success. Confidence is again fully restored in Washington, and the fears of a rebel attack upon the city, which were entertained on Monday, no longer prevail in any quarter.

abstract: In the war excitement our people have quite overlooked one of the most substantial triumphs of peace which has marked our recent history.
lead_paragraph: In the war excitement our people have quite overlooked one of the most substantial triumphs of peace which has marked our recent history. We refer to the entire success of the Daily Overland Mail, which went intooperation on the 1st inst. The first coach of the new line, which left Placerville on the morning of the 1st of July, arrived at St. Joseph on the 18th inst., in only seventeen days and one hour from one terminus to the other. The schedule time during the summer season is twenty days. The agents write that their drivers had not the slightest difficulty in making their time; on the contrary, they came in ahead of time, without any effort to that end. Four passengers came with the first coach, and some two hundred additional passengers from California were booked for the coaches to come, as soon as they could be brought.

abstract: Nowry vs. Samuel Lord. -- In 1859 the plaintiff obtained a judgment against the defendant, who is one of the firm of Lord & Taylor, from which judgment the defendant appealed to the General Term of this Court, where the judgment was affirmed. He now takes an appeal to the Court of Appeals, and offers his copartners as sureties, who execute the undertaking on appeal. The sureties only presented themselves for justification, which the plaintiff's counsel proposed to examine them as to the liabilities of the firm of Lord & Taylor, both as to its actual and contingent indebtedness. To this the counsel for the defendant objected. The Court, after a long discussion of the subject by counsel, decided that a party could not inquire into the liabilities of a firm doing business, nor could a member of thefirm be compelled to disclose the amount of their firm indebtedness, either actual or contingent; that a justification to the effect that the sureties were worth individually double the amount of the judgment, over and above liabilities, was sufficient. The counsel for the plaintiff, however, suggested to the Court, that in the event of the insolvency of the firm, not only would the copartnership property be liable, but the individual estate of each member of the firm might be swept away, and prevent the payment of the judgment.

abstract: The People ex rel J. A. H. Hasbrouck vs. The Supervisors of New-York. This was an application for a mandamus to the Board of Supervisors, directing them to audit and allow certain claims and accounts against the County of New-York, which he has presented to them and which they have rejected.
lead_paragraph: The People ex rel J. A. H. Hasbrouck vs. The Supervisors of New-York. -- This was an application for a mandamus to the Board of Supervisors, directing them to audit and allow certain claims and accounts against the County of New-York, which he has presented to them and which they have rejected. These bills amount together to about $1,400, for various articles of stationery, for printing and binding done for different Departments of the Government, mainly connected with the Courts. Among there are bills for printing calendars for the Supreme Court, and for printing and stationery furnished the County Clerk; for printing indictments, subpoenas, and other necessary blanks, for the District Attorney's office; for binding docket of judgments and calendars, and printing declarations of intentions, and other papers, for the Court of Common Pleas; for stationery, &c., furnished to the Clerk of the Superior Court, and for printing blank convictions, and copies of sentences, and other matters, for the Court of Sessions. These accounts also contained a few charges for stationery, such as wafers, rubber bands and pens, amounting in all to a very small sum, and were furnished during the year 1859. In all cases the accounts are certified by the clerks of the courts for which the work was done -- for the District Attorney's office is certified to by the Assistant District Attorney.

abstract: It would be wrong to say that the war is not being actively prosecuted. Although we have not to report any important event, yet the National troops are evidently led by energetic commanders.
lead_paragraph: It would be wrong to say that the war is not being actively prosecuted. Although we have not to report any important event, yet the National troops are evidently led by energetic commanders. Gen. SCOTT is censured by the more restlessspirits for his slow and cautious system of tactics; but a brilliant Napoleonic march and occupation of a hostile capital are feats which can only be accomplished by a disciplined army or against a most contemptible foe. Now, Gen. SCOTT has neither trained soldiers under him, nor is he marching against Mexicans. His army is formed, doubtless, of good material, and in a few months his recruits may be turned into excellent soldiers:but at present they are neither soldiers, nor, what is worse, have they soldiers to command them. Ludicrous stories are told of the incapacity of the National officers, numbers of whom are mere party politicians, who have received Colonelcies, and even Generalships, instead of being appointed Postmasters and Collectors. Even the men highest in command, like Gen. BANKS, have no special training; and though they may, like Roman patricians, be able to turn from their farms to give advice to their clients one day, and to command the legions the next, they have as yet given no proofs of such versatility, and their genius is distrusted exceedingly by their Commander-in-Chief, Gen. SCOTT himself. This veteran officer, whose abilities are justly appreciated by his countrymen, is described as much annoyed and hampered by the subordinates who are forced upon him; and this, coupled with the rawness of his army, has induced him to insist on slow and well-considered movements. It is said that he has had more than one dispute with members of the President's Cabinet, who are desirous that he should practise a more dashing style of warfare. On one occasion the General met the Cabinet, and, being urged to march at once on Richmond, declared that he would rather resign his command than forfeit his reputation, and thus only did he succeed in silencing his critics.

abstract: Some misstatements having been made in reference to the person who so gallantly recaptured the colors of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, we are requested to state that it was done by Capt. JOHN WILDEY, of Company I, Fire Zouaves. The colors had been seized by a Captain of the Black Horse Cavalry, who was making off with them, when he was shot by Capt. WILDEY. In addition to the colors, Capt. WILDEY also secured the rebel Captain's sabre, which has been sent to Mr. GERSHON COHEN, of this City.

abstract: At 3 1/2 o'clock, A.M., yesterday, the remains of Col. KENNEDY arrived in this City, via New-Jersey Railroad, under the charge of Quartermaster JOHN RICHARDSON, of the Tammany Regiment. Three soldiers of the regiment were also detailed to escort the body hither. Superintendent JOHN A. KENNEDY, brother of the deceased, the wife of deceased and her brother came to the City in the same train. Mr. WILSON SMALL and several members of the Tammany Society were in waiting at the ferry to receive the body, which was placed in a hearse and conveyed to No. 33 Hammond-street, the  former residence of the deceased. The body was embalmed at Washington, and encased in a costly coffin, and was habited in uniform. The coffin was taken into the back parlor, where numerous relatives and friends of the deceased had assembled to view the body. Upon the lid lay his cap, sword and belt, surrounded with wreaths and flowers. At a meeting of the Council of Sachems at Tammany Hall, in the afternoon, it was decided to concur with the Joint Committee on National Affairs of the Common Council in whatever arrangement they may make to-day in regard to the funeral obsequies. At a meeting of the General Tammany Committee held in the evening, District-Attorney WATERBURY offered a series of resolutions respecting the life and noble conduct of Col. KENNEDY, and deploring his sudden death. In offering the resolutions, Mr. WATERBURY said that Col. KENNEDY was not only a member of Tammany Society, but was a Representative in the Democratic State Committee, and the Grand Sachem of the Society, also commander of the regiment which owed its existence to his labors. The speaker then alluded to other members of the Society who have passed away within a few years, and concluded by saying that he believed that this nation was determined to have one Union, one Constitution and one flag, unbroken and triumphant from the lakes to the Gulf.

abstract: The United States revenue cutter Jackson, Capt. HYDE, arrived this morning from a cruise in the Gulf in search of Privateers. She has not seen any.
lead_paragraph: The United States revenue cutter Jackson, Capt. HYDE, arrived this morning from a cruise in the Gulf in search of Privateers. She has not seen any. On the 16th inst., when 40 miles south of Cape Henry, discovered a wreck on shore; saw from 100 to 150 men around it. Sent in a flag of truce, but they would not communicate. They were armed with muskets and guns, and the only reply they made was, "come ashore." After returning on board several shot and shell was thrown among them. Could not land any force on account of the high surf.

abstract: It would seem that this body, now in session at Jefferson City, is about placing the State in its true position of allegiance to the Union. Gen. ROBERT WILSON, a staunch Union man, has been elected President, in the place of STIRLING PRICE, who presided at the last session, but who joined the fortunes of Gov. JACKSON in his crusade against the Government. A resolution, which, it is said, will pass by a large majority, is pending, which declares that the Executive has violated the trusts reposed in it by its revolt, and has expatriated itself. From present indications, Missouri will follow the example of Western Virginia, by placing in the various positions connected with the Executive Department men who are loyal to the Constitution and who are opposed to secession in all its forms. Gov. JACKSON will thus be deposed by the people of Missouri themselves, and a true man substituted in his place. The folly as well as guilt of his treason will be punished by exclusion from his office and banishment from his State and home should he escape the severer punishment due to his crimes. His mad efforts to compel his State into rebellion have already made him an exile, and the temper of the people, as developed by the Convention, will probably make that exile perpetual.

abstract: That portion of the Press, which, by its intemperate urgency, brought about the casualty of Sunday, has turned its energies in a direction where it is likely to do even greater mischief.
lead_paragraph: That portion of the Press, which, by its intemperate urgency, brought about the casualty of Sunday, has turned its energies in a direction where it is likely to do even greater mischief. For the cry "Onward to Richmond," which has covered the fields of Virginia with our brave fellows, slaughtered while gallantly endeavoring to achieve the impossible, they have substituted a cry for a dismissal of the Cabinet; as if this moment of national agony and effort were timely for a revolution of the Government; and the displacement of the President's actual advisers by untried and entirely inexperienced men. It is possible, though it strikes us as being extremely improbable, that hostility to the cause of the Union would take a more malignant and dangerous form. The Cabinet has been guilty of no act that should lose it the confidence of the country, unless it consist in yielding too readily to the counsels of the very journals which now demand its overthrow. This is an error that is not likely to be repeated. Neither Government or people is in the temper to listen again to the advisers whose counsels have brought us to shame, and added a year to the war; and we may hereafter confide not only in the wisdom, but in the independence of the Administration, in conducting this great contest.

abstract: There is little doubt now that Col. A. M. WOOD of the Fourteenth (Brooklyn) Regiment New-York State Militia, who was wounded at the Bull's Run battle, is a prisoner in the hands of the enemy if alive. Congressman ODELL, of the Second District, last night telegraphed from Washington that Col. WOOD had not been heard from. Postmaster LIN
lead_paragraph: There is little doubt now that Col. A. M. WOOD of the Fourteenth (Brooklyn) Regiment New-York State Militia, who was wounded at the Bull's Run battle, is a prisoner in the hands of the enemy if alive. Congressman ODELL, of the Second District, last night telegraphed from Washington that Col. WOOD had not been heard from. Postmaster LINCOLN, who left Washington Tuesday noon, and arrived in this City yesterday, says, that Chaplain INSKIP, of the Fourteenth, told him that Col. WOOD's horse was killed by a cannon ball while he was gallantly leading his regiment, and that the same shot wounded Col. WOOD's leg, just above the knee. He was placed in an ambulance, and they had reached Bull's Run Creek with him, where they crowd was tremendous and the panic at its height At this point the Chaplain was swept away from the ambulance by the retreating soldiers, and he did not see him again. At this crossing the balls from the rebel batteries fell thick and fast, and it is possible that Col. WOOD here received further injuries.

abstract: Our Special Correspondent has made good use of his time in the Confederate States. Without effort, and merely by giving the results of his quick observation, he has drawn for us a picture of the Sscessionists, in their military capacity, which is as interesting as anything that OEMSTED has depicted of their ordinary life.
lead_paragraph: Our Special Correspondent has made good use of his time in the Confederate States. Without effort, and merely by giving the results of his quick observation, he has drawn for us a picture of the Sscessionists, in their military capacity, which is as interesting as anything that OEMSTED has depicted of their ordinary life. It is the tendency of the world to give a man credit for only one order of talents. If he is a man of taste, he cannot be a man of business; if he be persevering and methodical, he must be humdrum, without a spark of genius. But the most dangerous quality he can have is to be brilliant and entertaining, for then everybody will agree that he cannot be profound and far-sighted, a calm thinker, and so forth. The value of Lord MACUALAY's History is secretly doubled by a great many worthy people, on no other grounds than that they actually found a pleasure in reading it. Let a traveler fill his pages with second-hand statistics, or discuss the future of textile manufactures at intolerable length, and he will at once obtain a sort of reputation. We all feel convinced that he has thought deeply, and that though we have skipped the last twenty pages, they must be of the utmost importance to humanity. This heavy respectability will never be attained by our letters from America. Every one reads them through, finds them interesting, and is glad when a fresh one appears. But they give, it seems to us, the strongest proof that real instruction need not be conveyed in the form of a blue-book. Our correspondent does not append returns of the acres sown with corn or cotton; he does not express decimally the proportion of men armed with the rifle or the smooth-bore musket; but the result of reading his letters is that we all now have a considerable knowledge of the Southern politicians and people as they show themselves under the excitement of revolution; that we perceive what the Southern levies, are like -- at least, in the remoter districts; that we can estimate the chances of a collision, or the chances of success in it; that, in fact, there is a flood of light thrown on the situation of affairs at every spot from which one of these letters is dated. It has been our task to read whole quires of correspondence, public and private, in writing or in print, from America, and we must say that almost the only letters which give us any real knowledge how things are going on are these.

abstract: Must shocking stories begin to be reported of the barbarities practised by the rebels upon the wounded men and prisoners of the Union forces that fall into their hands.
lead_paragraph: Must shocking stories begin to be reported of the barbarities practised by the rebels upon the wounded men and prisoners of the Union forces that fall into their hands. We are told of their slashing the throats of some from ear to ear; of their cutting off the heads of others, and kicking them about as footballs; and of their setting up the wounded against trees, and firing at them as targets, or torturing them with the plunges of bayonets at their bodies. To cap the climax of atrocities, it is stated that a hospital in which many wounded soldiers were suffering extreme agony, or quietly yielding up the battle of life, was fired upon and burned. An isolated story of inhuman treatment in the midst of a battle, or in the heat of pursuit, after one is fought, would not be entitled to grave consideration, as illustrating the general animus of an Army; for exceptional cases of cruelty will always, and among all people occur. But the iteration of these stories of rebel barbarity from so many sources, and in such various forms, compel us to the belief that there is a deeper foundation for them than the casual passion of individual natures, and that there is some general prevailing temper in the rebel Army that finds its natural outburst in these barbarities. We have only to look to the public teachings of the leaders of the rebellion to find, we think, the ready explanation of the sanguinary and demoniac deeds we hear related of their men. By their proclamations and messages, both BEAUREGARD and JEFFERSON DAVIS have branded the Union troops that they are now fighting as outlaws of civilized warfare. The former, when he assumed command at Manassas, and commenced to gather an Army around him, issued a manifesto to the people of the Southern States full of malice and of lies, as wicked as the devil himself could have coined them. He declared that the soldiers of the loyal States, then about to invade Virginia, were brutal robbers who had no honest sentiment to inspire them, but were animated by the promise of the "beauty and booty" of the South, with which to gratify their lust and their love of plunder. This base libel, spread broadcast among an ignorant and untraveled people such as compose so large a part of the population of the Southern States, was calculated to excite the deepest fears and the most fiendish resentment towards the soldiers of the Union. What mercy was due and what could be given to a horde of vandals so rapacious and so vile as the Union troops were represented to be.

abstract: A grand ovation was accorded by our citizens, yesterday, to the Twelfth Massachusetts Volunteer Regiment, enlisted for the war, under command of Col. FLETCHER WEBSTER, the son of the sage of Marshfield. The Twelfth is the pet of the Bostonians. It was mustered into the service about five weeks since, and has in the interim been thoroughly equipped and drilled. The physical appearance of the men is not the least credit to the old Bay State. While they are brawny and muscular, and healthy, they are at the same time orderly, and adapted to discipline. The personal popularity of Col. WEBSTER has helped, in a great degree, to elevate the character of his corps. Not only through the reputation of his father, but as Secretary of Legation to China under Mr. CUSHING, as the incumbent of important positions at Washington, and as Surveyor of the Port of Boston, Col. WEBSTER has attached to himself hosts of friends, who have cope all in their power to make his command as effective as any that has yet taken uparms in defence of the Union. The recent news from the seat of war has infused a new spirit into the men, and they are now as [???] a body as has passed through this City.

abstract: The great blunder of Sunday lay in fighting the battle which ended so disastrously. Under no circumstances is it ever justifiable, in a military sense, for an inferior force to attack a superior when the latter has his own choice of position, and is strongly intrenched.
lead_paragraph: The great blunder of Sunday lay in fighting the battle which ended so disastrously. Under no circumstances is it ever justifiable, in a military sense, for an inferior force to attack a superior when the latter has his own choice of position, and is strongly intrenched. The chances are fifty to one against success. In this instance Gen. MCDOWELL was perfectly aware that the rebel forces either outnumbered his own, or could easily be made to do so by reinforcements which they had every facility for bringing forward. To use his own expression, the night before the battle, it was with them simply a question of rolling stock and provisions. He knew, too, that they had labored zealously for three months, under skillful engineers, in a country admirably adapted to defence, to fortify their position.

abstract: Camp Scott now begins to wear a deserted aspect. Two more regiments have struck their tents, and nothing now marks the place where they have been encamped but the charred grass upon which the camp-fires have been lighted. The Second Regiment,
lead_paragraph: Camp Scott now begins to wear a deserted aspect. Two more regiments have struck their tents, and nothing now marks the place where they have been encamped but the charred grass upon which the camp-fires have been lighted. The Second Regiment, upon receiving orders to march, immediately commenced packing, and intended leaving on Tuesday, but owing to some unexplained cause did not leave Staten Island till nearly 3 o'clock yesterday. The steamboat Atlas was chartered to convey it to South Amboy, where the cars were taken for Washington. A number of friends of the men were upon the dock waiting to bid them good bye, and utter "God be with you." On the appearance of the men the women began to cry, and wring their hands in anguish; some beat their bosoms, and gave way to the greatest grief. Altogether it was a scene not easily to be forgotten. The men were soon embarked, and as the vessel steamed away the men were saluted with hearty cheers, which they returned with a right good will. The following is a list of the officers:

abstract: It is unfortunate for the rebels that the time of the regiments which enlisted for three months expired so soon after the ill-starred movement upon Manassas. Just upon its rebound from the terrible blow inflicted by the news of Sunday's battle, the public mind receives new stimulus by the return of thousands of men who passed through that sharp and bitter ordeal, and who came out with their honor untarnished, their bravery and spirit beyond suspicion. Our admiration of them and our sympathy with them, are but increased by our knowledge that, by the blunder of those who are responsible for that battle, they were sent upon an expedition from which they could have returned victors only by a combination of circumstances little less than miraculous. Our determination to stamp out this wicked and most unnatural rebellion, is but deepened and strengthened at the sight of our camp-worn, battle-stained friends and kinsmen, who have vainly suffered privation and encountered peril in what is but the opening of this just, this holy war. We feel at the sight of those thinned ranks and tattered ensigns as PAUL JONES did when, with his ship apparently dismantled in action, he replied to the question whether he would surrender, that he had not yet begun to fight.

abstract: Governor MORGAN, it will be seen by his Proclamation, published in another column, has conclucled, under the requisition of the President for more troops, to call for twenty-five thousand additional Volunteers, to serve for three years, or during the war. A general order, prescribing the mode of organization will be issued immediately.
lead_paragraph: Governor MORGAN, it will be seen by his Proclamation, published in another column, has conclucled, under the requisition of the President for more troops, to call for twenty-five thousand additional Volunteers, to serve for three years, or during the war. A general order, prescribing the mode of organization will be issued immediately. The rendezvous will be at New-York, Albany and Elmira, with the head-quarters at Albany.

abstract: The best sign of the times is that nobody seems discouraged by the defeat of Sunday. Considering the unbounded confidence of success which seemed to be cherished, and the importance of this first general action between the main bodies of the opposing forces, it would not have been at all surprising if many persons had been inclined to surrender all faith in our ability to suppress this great rebellion.

abstract: Mr. TRACY, of the Rochester Express, was one of the spectators of the disaster at Bull's Run. The Albany Evening Sournal says that, before Mr. TRACY left Washington, he, with others, called on Gen. SCOTT to see whether something could not be done to reach and rescue the missing men. The General replied angrily, that they had no business on the field, and they must take their chances with others.

abstract: It is stated in certain quarters that one result of the defeat at Bull's Run has been to intensify the dislike of regular officers to volunteer troops. We believe this to be grossly unjust.
lead_paragraph: It is stated in certain quarters that one result of the defeat at Bull's Run has been to intensify the dislike of regular officers to volunteer troops. We believe this to be grossly unjust. There were comparatively few regulars in the action of Sunday; -- but so far as we can learn, from personal observation or the information of others, they were not at all superior to the volunteers in their readiness to go into action, nor behind them in their eagerness to go out. In the affair of Thursday the cavalry, composed of regulars, quit their positions twice with anything but military order and steadiness, -- once when a cannon ball struck one of their number, and again when the Twelfth New-York Regiment broke and ran from the woods. After the retreat of Sunday night, moreover, about a dozen of these regulars were the first to reach the picket-guard nearest Arlington, -- and if they had not been very properly stopped by the guard as deserters, they would have been among the first arrivals in Washington.

abstract: The President of the United States having requested me to furnish additional troops for the prompt suppression of resistance to the Constitution and laws, I do hereby call for a volunteer force of 25,000 men to serve for three years, or during the war. Such force will be raised pursuant to a general order which will be issued immediately, and which will prescribe the mode of organization. To the end that every portion of the State may have an opportunity to contribute thereto, the rendezvous will be at New-York, Albany and Elmira -- the head-quarters at Albany.

abstract: DE CORDOVA's LYCEUM. -- Mr. R.J. DE CORDOVA, a gentleman who is well known as one of our best lecturers, and in a branch almost exclusively his own, has arrived, it will be perceived, at the dignity of an establishment of his own. The Lyceum has flashed upon our firmament like the war comet, but is better known. In its lugubrious moments it is called Hope Chapel, and as such has long been the prey of lecturers. Mr. DE CORDOVA in re-christening the place has in a way protested against its antecedents. Dullness, we may be sure, will be banished from its precincts whilst he is there, and excitement, if not fun, reign in its place. For although Mr. DE CORDOVA is famous for humor, he possesses the twin brother of that faculty, pathos, and can turn from the ludicrous side of the Prince's visit to the earnest one of the Great Rebellion, without laying aside a particle of his natural ability.

abstract: The announcement that the Sixty-ninth, Seventy-first, Twenty-eighth and Eighth Regiments would arrive from Washington yesterday forenoon, drew thousands of the citizens out to witness and to take part in their reception. As early as 9 o'clock, Broadway, near Cortlandt-street, was thronged, and from thence to the Jersey City Ferry the entire street and sidewalks were blocked with people.
lead_paragraph: The announcement that the Sixty-ninth, Seventy-first, Twenty-eighth and Eighth Regiments would arrive from Washington yesterday forenoon, drew thousands of the citizens out to witness and to take part in their reception. As early as 9 o'clock, Broadway, near Cortlandt-street, was thronged, and from thence to the Jersey City Ferry the entire street and sidewalks were blocked with people. From all the windows and housetops, flags were flying, and stretched across the streets were banners containing inscriptions of welcome. On one of these were the words : "Welcome, New-York's gallant sons," and upon another, "Defenders of our Flag, welcome. God bless you!"
