abstract: This regiment, which has been encamped at St. Johnsbury, Vt., during the last six weeks, arrived in Jersey City, en route for the seat of war, yesterday morning. The members are from different parts of the State, but more particularly the northern part, ...
lead_paragraph: This regiment, which has been encamped at St. Johnsbury, Vt., during the last six weeks, arrived in Jersey City, en route for the seat of war, yesterday morning. The members are from different parts of the State, but more particularly the northern part, east of the Green Mountains. The regiment numbers some nine hundred men, including a brass band of twenty-four pieces, which is under the direction of D.H. ADAMS, of Burlington. All the members of the regiment are young men, averaging not over 24 years of ago; they are an athletic, brawny looking set of fellows, consisting of farmers, lumbermen, machinists, mechanics, professional men, and about 200 school-teachers. The baggage train consists of 17 wagons, a band-wagon and ambulances; each of which is drawn by four horses. The horses and wagons did not come on with the regiment. Yesterday the horses left St. Johnsbury by railroad; at Concord, N.H., it was the intention to stop and take on board the wagons and further them to Baltimore, where they will be delivered to the regiment. The regiment left St. Johnsbury on the 24th, and came via Springfield and Hartford, to New-Haven, where the steamer Elm City was chartered to convey them to Jersey City, where they took a special train for Baltimore. Along the whole route the residents of the various towns where the train stopped at, came to the stations and cheered them, in fact the whole journey was a complete ovation; the citizens sent into the cars all sorts of refreshments to regale the men. Just before the train started the band would strike up some national air as a parting salute. The whole of the men are armed with the Enfield rifle, and the regiment is well furnished with all necessary equipments for the camp. Annexed is a list of the officers:

abstract: Yesterday a trotting match took place on Fashion Course, Long Island, between b. m. Flora Temple, in harness, and b. s. Ethan Allen and mate, to wagon, for $1,000, mile heats, best 3 in 5. Ethan Allen won the first heat; Flora Temple the second and race, owing to Ethan and mate running away with their driver, S. MCLAUGHLIN. They ran, two miles, before he could pull them up. Flora trotted this heat in 2:20 1/2, being the quickest time ever made on Long Island. Over ten thousand spectators were present, the largest number known on a Long Island race-course for some years.

abstract: Extras are fashionable in the newspaper world now-a-days, and why should not scientific journals indulge themselves in the luxury, especially when the movements of such a distinguished stranger as the great comet are to be noted. The American Journal of Science and Arts has just issued an extra giving some particulars of the wonderful body which has just paid us a passing visit. Observations made by Lieut. GILLIS and Professor ROBINSON, U.S.N., at Washington, as well as by Professor HUBBARD and Mr. FERGUSON, demonstrate conclusively, according to the Journal, that this comet is not only not the comet of 1556, called Charles Vth's., but that this is its first appearance -- its debut. In this conclusion the distinguished astronomer, Mr. E.P. BOND, of Harvard, concurs. He estimates the breadth of the head of the comet at the nucleus, at 156,000 miles, the height of the inner envelope at 11,500 miles, and the length of the tail at 15,000,000 miles. The credit of the discovery of the comet Dr. BOND awards to Dr. BRUNNON, of the Ann Arbor, Michigan, Observatory. He detected its presence in the heavens, between 1 and 2 o'clock, on the morning of Sunday, June 30. Some claim to have seen it on the Friday preceding, but this, Mr. BOND asserts, was impossible, as it could not have been visible at that time.
lead_paragraph: Extras are fashionable in the newspaper world now-a-days, and why should not scientific journals indulge themselves in the luxury, especially when the movements of such a distinguished stranger as the great comet are to be noted. The American Journal of Science and Arts has just issued an extra giving some particulars of the wonderful body which has just paid us a passing visit. Observations made by Lieut. GILLIS and Professor ROBINSON, U.S.N., at Washington, as well as by Professor HUBBARD and Mr. FERGUSON, demonstrate conclusively, according to the Journal, that this comet is not only not the comet of 1556, called Charles Vth's., but that this is its first appearance -- its debut. In this conclusion the distinguished astronomer, Mr. E.P. BOND, of Harvard, concurs. He estimates the breadth of the head of the comet at the nucleus, at 156,000 miles, the height of the inner envelope at 11,500 miles, and the length of the tail at 15,000,000 miles. The credit of the discovery of the comet Dr. BOND awards to Dr. BRUNNON, of the Ann Arbor, Michigan, Observatory. He detected its presence in the heavens, between 1 and 2 o'clock, on the morning of Sunday, June 30. Some claim to have seen it on the Friday preceding, but this, Mr. BOND asserts, was impossible, as it could not have been visible at that time.

abstract: JOHN STACOM, residing at No. 72 Elm-street says he was in the late engagement. He returned Tuesday morning, leaving Washington at 4 o'clock. He left the scene of action at 6 o'clock P.M., Sunday. The Sixty-ninth left Fort Corcoran on Tuesday, at 3 o'clock P.M., and encamped that night at Fairfax Court-house.
lead_paragraph: JOHN STACOM, residing at No. 72 Elm-street says he was in the late engagement. He returned Tuesday morning, leaving Washington at 4 o'clock. He left the scene of action at 6 o'clock P.M., Sunday. The Sixty-ninth left Fort Corcoran on Tuesday, at 3 o'clock P.M., and encamped that night at Fairfax Court-house. Wednesday night reached Germantown. On Thursday morning, the Division under Col. SHERMAN took up the line of march, led by the Twelfth New-York Volunteers. After marching a short distance, a masked battery opened on them. Our regiment were ordered by Gen. TYLER to advance. After a short time we received orders through Gen. MCDOWELL to fall back, when we halted for the night. About 2 o'clock in the morning we passed to the right of the battery without any danger. Marched about three miles and formed into line of battle, with our battery firing a gun at intervals to get the enemy out, which at length we did, they having returned a few shots. Shortly after the action became general. We succeeded in forcing our way down into the Run, (like a ravine,) between two mountains, in doing which we had to march through mud and water knee-deep. We marched double-quick about a mile to a hill, where there was a small house, uninhabited, where we afterwards left our wounded. Here we engaged a large number of the enemy's infantry, which we succeeded in driving back, the masked batteries playing on us. The other divisions of our Army engaged the enemy. The fight continued without intermission till 4 o'clock P.M., when we succeeded in silencing three or four batteries. The firing then ceased. We felt quite elated, seeing Gen. MCDOWELL complimenting Col. CORCORAN on the success of our victory. Suddenly a large reinforcement came up, and opened on us with terrific effect. We suffered terribly, but firmly kept our ground. Once, our regimental flag was captured; but Capt. THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER, clutching the green flag, and shouting to the men, rushed after to capture it, which we eventually did. Capt. WILDEY, of the Fire Zouaves, shot the rebel who held the flag. We ran up to the edge of the woods and fired at them. They were behind natural rocks with earthen works, with four guns or more in each battery. We captured four. We found them nearly all spiked. Each battery was at distances averaging about two hundred yards they looked like bee hives. The country round was full of brushwood and trees, which gave them an advantage. The width of the road was only about 12 feet, a slight descent to the fields at each side. The ravine on an average was about one-half mile wide, with masked batteries at each side. It was utterly impossible we could hold out. We lost several of our officers, including Capt. HAGGERTY, Company A, Acting-Lieut.-Col. DALTON, Capt. CATANAR, and a few others. It was melancholy to see the poor fellows lying all around dead. I contrasted it with the joy they felt only a few minutes before, and felt sad. However, one has no thought in battle; the noise and confusion is really awful; it completely crushes out all feeling. Among those who distinguished themselves, (that I saw,) was the Colonel, who was very cool and collected. Capt. THOS. FRANCIS MEAGHER, who acted as aid to Col. CORCORAN. He rode a splendid while horse. He lost his cap, and was remarkable in his bare head, urging the men forward. Lieut. COONAN, of Company J, and private MAXWELL SULLIVAN Company C, were remarkable in their attempt to rescue the regimental colors. We got orders to retreat, which we did in good order, forming a hollow square. We marched off the field on the road.

abstract: Gen. PATTERSON is said to have written a private letter exculpating, or trying to excelpate, himself from blame in permitting Gen. JOHNSTON to retire from his front and reach Manassas, whereby the fortunes of the day in the recent battle were turned against the United States.
lead_paragraph: Gen. PATTERSON is said to have written a private letter exculpating, or trying to excelpate, himself from blame in permitting Gen. JOHNSTON to retire from his front and reach Manassas, whereby the fortunes of the day in the recent battle were turned against the United States. The points of defence of this Pennsylvania General are as follows: Gen. JOHNSTON was strongly intrenched at Winchester; he had recently been reinforced by troops from Georgia, Alabama and elsewhere, running up the numbers of his Army to 35,000 men, besides 6,000 Virginia militia, making a total of 40,000 men. On the other hand, Gen. PATTERSON says he had less than 20,000 men, and of these, nineteen regiments were within a few days of the expiration of their enlistment, and all but four of these had positively declined to stay one hour beyond their time. Under these circumstances, Gen. PATTERSON folt unable to assume an offensive attitude, and took up a position where he could easily take care of the remnant of his dissolving Army.

abstract: JUST ONCE. An individual's griefs or wrongs may be of little account to others, but when the gravest public interests are imperiled, through personal attacks and the coarsest imputations of base motives, the assailed, however humble, owes duties to others which cannot be disregarded. I propose here to refute months of persistent and envenomed defamation by the statement of a few facts.

abstract: Intelligence that the danger of an immediate movement of the rebels upon Washington is imminent, reaches us from trustworthy sources. Their plans are represented as welldigested and apparently entirely feasible. Leaving Gen. JOHNSTON to look after PATTERSON'S division, Gen. LEE, whose column, according to reliable information, had already left the lines at Manassas, is to proceed along the eastern slope of the Blue Ridge, until he reaches and crosses the Potomac.
lead_paragraph: Intelligence that the danger of an immediate movement of the rebels upon Washington is imminent, reaches us from trustworthy sources. Their plans are represented as welldigested and apparently entirely feasible. Leaving Gen. JOHNSTON to look after PATTERSON'S division, Gen. LEE, whose column, according to reliable information, had already left the lines at Manassas, is to proceed along the eastern slope of the Blue Ridge, until he reaches and crosses the Potomac. Thenwith the aid of a general, preconcerted insurrection of the Maryland Secessionists, his force will be greatly strengthened, enabling him to cut off all communications, and by a rapid advance to approach the undefended side of the Capital. Simultaneous with his arrival at this point, the main body under BEAUREGARD will march with corresponding expedition upon Arlington Heights, attacking our Army there so fiercely as to prevent it from assisting in the repulse of Gen. LEE. The result of this strategy is regarded as certain. Washington and its archives must fall into the hands of the insurgents. The President, Congress, and the officers of the Government, only saving themselves, if they escape at all, by embarcation on a man-of-war and a flight down the Potomac.

abstract: We are inexpressibly pained to learn from Washington, that very inadequate provision has been made by the regular authorities, for the proper care of the wounded in the late battle. It seems incredible in a Christian, civilized community, but we are credibly informed, that some of our gallant soldiers, for sheer  want of hospital garments, even yet lie sweltering in ther bloody uniforms, fostering with fever and maddened with thirst.

abstract: By a courier who left yesterday for Gallipolis, I sent you a telegram, announcing the result of an engagement with the enemy, the day previous. We have no means of communicating with our friends except by river or courier; and as a steamer will leave for the Ohio in the morning, I embrace the opportunity to send you the particulars of this ill-starred, not to say disastrous affair.

abstract: A destructive fire, involving an aggregate loss of nearly $10,000, occurred yesterday afternoon at 2 1/4 o'clock, in the range of frame buildings known as the "Hoffman Block," located immediately north of Reservoir-square, the former site of the Crystal Palace. The flames first appeared on the 'second floor of No. 722 Sixth-avenue, a three-story structure occupied by GEO. T. EGNER as a dwelling and eating-house, and, spreading with rapidity, destroyed the two upper stories of the buildings fronting on Forty-second-street, for a space of 250 feet in length from No. 63 to No. 45 (inclusive, as well as the house next to EGUER's, on the corner of Sixth-avenue and Forty-second-street. This last-mentioned building was occupied by SMITH HETHERING as a bar-room, and his loss on stock and fixtures is covered by an insurance of $600. The lower floors of the various buildings were tenanted by small shopkeepers, and the upper portions of the premises were occupied by families. As nearly as the losses could be estimated it is probable that the storekeepers will be reimbursed by the Insurance Companies, but the families its a general thing were not so fortunate. Mr. GEORGE F. EGURR, who occupied the building in which the fire broke out, places his loss at $700, and is insured to that amount. The upper floors of Nos. 61 and 63 Forty-second-street, were used by Mr. T. O'BRIEN as a laundry. His appurtenances are insured for $750 in the Pacific, and that sum more than covers the loss. The stores beneath were occupied by PETER DIVINE, as a grocery and liquor establishment; insured on stock for $500 in the Manhattan. WM. J. BAXTER, tinsmith, had a shop on part of the first floor of No. 59; his loss is covered by $500 insurance in the Hamilton. The lower floor of the same building was occupied by WILLIAM BORM, shoemaker, who lost everything; insured. JAMES MURRAY dwelt in the upper part; his furniture was insured in the Citizens Company. The whole of No. 57 was occupied by GEO. HAND as a laundry; loss covered by insurance of $560 in the Manhattan. Three families, named MCGLYNN, JACQUES and LEIPNER, resided in the upper stories. Neither was insured. The ground floor of No. 53 was a liquor-store, kept by FERGUSON BRENNAN; loss $300; uninsured. The families of JAMES and LAWRENCE MCCOY, occupying the upper floors, were burned out, losing almost everything; uninsured. WM. KROHNE, manufacturer of cidar and vinegar, occupied the first of No. 51 his loss is fully covered by insurance of $1,000 in the Manhattan Company. The second floor [???] as a dwelling for EPHRAIM REESE and [???] furniture insured in the Manhattan for $400. The third floor was occupied by FREDERICK EUDRES, whose loss is covered by a policy for [???], in the same company. HERMAN ENGERSOLL, also a tenant in the building, suffered to some extent, and was not insured. The confectionary store of THOS. S. MANNING, first floor of No. 49, was burned out; stock uninsured. JAEES B. PAGE and family lived upstairs, his furniture was insured for $500 in the North River lnsurance Company. A liquor store, kept by EDWIN SKIDMORE, occupied the lower floor of No. 47, and was insured for $300 on the stock in the Hamilton. Mrs. SARAH MITCHELL tenanted the secondfloor. Her furniture was insured in the Hamilton for $300. The tenants of the third floor, Messrs. WHITE & MADDEN were not insured.

abstract: All volunteers in the service of the United States can claim as their right under the Army Regulations, suitable clothing and equipment. The Quartermaster's Department is now able to supply nearly all proper demands upon it, and will soon be prepared to do so still more fully and certainly. Before the end of the month, the Department will have engaged, for instance, 3,000,000 yards of flannel, 800,000 pairs of bootees, 800,000 pairs of woolen stockings, 200,000 felt hats, 200,000 haversacks, with blankets, &c., in proportion -- these quantities being, in addition to what had been previously secured. These supplies are of much superior quality to those furnished by the State Governments, or those generally furnished by Patriotic Societies and individuals for the Volunteers. A large proportion of the articles furnished soldiers gratuitously of which they purchase for their own use, are soon found incumbrances, and are thrown away or left behind, where they, will be useless at the first important march of a campaign.
lead_paragraph: All volunteers in the service of the United States can claim as their right under the Army Regulations, suitable clothing and equipment. The Quartermaster's Department is now able to supply nearly all proper demands upon it, and will soon be prepared to do so still more fully and certainly. Before the end of the month, the Department will have engaged, for instance, 3,000,000 yards of flannel, 800,000 pairs of bootees, 800,000 pairs of woolen stockings, 200,000 felt hats, 200,000 haversacks, with blankets, &c., in proportion -- these quantities being, in addition to what had been previously secured. These supplies are of much superior quality to those furnished by the State Governments, or those generally furnished by Patriotic Societies and individuals for the Volunteers. A large proportion of the articles furnished soldiers gratuitously of which they purchase for their own use, are soon found incumbrances, and are thrown away or left behind, where they, will be useless at the first important march of a campaign.

abstract: One of the best if not the best military man in New-York, Lieut.-Col. SHAFER, is actively engaged in perfecting this thoroughly and effectively officered regiment, in company and battalion drill. Over 600 hardy men are upon its muster rolls under pay, uniformed and fully equipped. Their quarters, (Palace Gardens,) have been a favorite Summer resort of our citizens, and here, the soldiers are carefully provided with rations and clothing, and in all respects made comfortable. Those who, of the returning three months regiments, are desirous of reenlisting, can have no better opportunity. They will be immediately mustered into the service, and be thence under pay, with their $33 to $50 United States bounty, in addition, and will be permitted, also, as long a furlough, before the regiment leaves, as they please, in which to visit their families. These are advantages which no other regiment offers.

abstract: After repeated delays, and misunderstandings as to the time they would arrive, and the route by which they would come, the Eighth Regiment, N.Y. S.M., reached the City by the New-Jersey Railroad yesterday, about 3 o'clock, P.M. The ovation with which they were greeted in Philadelphia, and the extraordinary demand for cars for transporting  the many regiments just now going and returning from the seat of war, is given as the cause of detention.
lead_paragraph: After repeated delays, and misunderstandings as to the time they would arrive, and the route by which they would come, the Eighth Regiment, N.Y. S.M., reached the City by the New-Jersey Railroad yesterday, about 3 o'clock, P.M. The ovation with which they were greeted in Philadelphia, and the extraordinary demand for cars for transporting the many regiments just now going and returning from the seat of war, is given as the cause of detention. Taken in connection with the arrival of the Seventy-first Regiment, the immense outpouring of the people to witness their return, and to do honor to the brave men who have been battling in their country's cause, made the occasion one of the most memorable which New-York has ever seen. The disappointments which occurred on Thursday, only seemed to increase the public interest in the expected ovation, and raise enthusiasm to a higher pitch. Every available spot on Cortlandt street and Broadway for seeing the regiments, was early taken possession of, and many of the fortunate possessors held their position for hours, in order to have a good view of the pageant. The masses which thronged the streets and crowded balconies, windows and house-tops, seemed more like the reception of the Prince of Wales, or the Japanese Ambassadors than like any of the previous military displays which have occurred since the beginning of the war. Standing at the junction of Broadway with Cortlandt-street and looking towards the ferry, the scene was extremely animating and beautiful. From every window of every hotel, store and dwelling the Stars and Stripes fluttered gaily in the breeze, and banners were hung across the street at several places with inscriptions of welcome. The piers adjoining the ferry, the freight sheds, the vessels' decks and rigging were all alive with people. All movement of vehicles was interrupted on West-street near the ferry, and the stages were turned out of their accustomed soutes by the surging masses which blocked up the street. The Washington Grays, Home Guard, under Captain PHILLIPS, which had been on the qui vive since Thursday morning, were stationed on the adjoining pier (No. 14) with their six howitzer battery, to welcome the regiment by a salute. Capt. VARIAN with his troop of bronzed and hardy-looking artillerists were also on the pier with their two guide colors, torn almost to shreds by the enemy's balls during the late engagement. In their eagerness to do the honors in the promptest manner possible, the order to fire was given one boat too soon, and before the mistake was discovered all the ammunition was expended before the boat containing the regiment was near enough for them to hear the report of the guns. The passengers from Jersey City no doubt enjoyed the honor thus accidentally accorded to them. The troop, however, made up the deficiency by drawing up in line and giving them a round of hearty cheers. The regiment responded by waving their caps and by a roll of the drums.

abstract: In response to the requisition from Washington, Gov. MORGAN has issued his proclamation calling for 25,000 additional volunteers to serve for three years or during the war. The teachings of the past will furnish some instructive lessons in regard to the future organ- ization and management of the volunteer forces in this State, at least.
lead_paragraph: In response to the requisition from Washington, Gov. MORGAN has issued his proclamation calling for 25,000 additional volunteers to serve for three years or during the war. The teachings of the past will furnish some instructive lessons in regard to the future organ- ization and management of the volunteer forces in this State, at least. Scenes that have been witnessed at the military depots during the progress of former enlistments, should not be permitted to recur. Recruits without uniforms or arms, unprovided with regular pay or rations, without tents, camp equipage or other accommodations for living or comfort, wandering through the streets or lounging in the grogshops, were the common exhibitions presented not at the State depots alone, but in the villages where recruiting was going on. The volunteers were thus, for weeks, subsisting on their own private means, the voluntary contributions of citizens, or supported at the expense of their officers, until their companies were full, and even then were not mustered into the service of the Government until their regiments had their full quota of men. These again were not accepted until other long weeks had elapsed, during which the process of demoralization, in a military sense at least, was continually progressing. The officers, like the men, in most instances, were wholly unacquainted with military science, without any considerable knowledge of military drill or discipline, and without the presence of United States officers, whose experience could instruct them in the duties and necessities of the service upon which they were entering. These vexatious delays in furnishing equipage and arms, and in being mustered into the service, disheartened the men and discouraged their officers, until the spirit in which they enlisted was permitted to die away under the idleness and inertia of their position. This should not be permitted in the future. Experienced officers belonging to the regular service should be appointed to inspect and receive all who offer and are qualified, the necessary equipage and arms should be furnished, and the volunteers sent at once into camps of instruction and drill, where they could be learning the business of the soldier, free from the temptations which the idleness of waiting throws around them. There should be a camp, or camps, of instruction established without delay, irrespective of the depots at New-York, Albany and Elmira, to which the volunteers should be sent as fast as organized into companies, where they could be under competent officers to superintend their drill and discipline. The military post on Governor's Island, in the Bay of New-York, is admirably adapted to such a purpose. The healthfulness and security of its position, its spacious grounds for drill, and accommodations for a large force, render it one of the very best locations for such a camp that can possibly be selected. It might easily be made the general rendezvouz for instruction of all the volunteers raised under the present call. They might there be placed under the immediate command of experienced officers, who could, in a short time, so far perfect them in discipline and a knowledge of their duties as to make them efficient and reliable soldiers.

abstract: Major BAGLEY, now the commanding officer of the Sixty-ninth Regiment, who has gone to Washington to bring these brave fellows home in triumph, and share the hard-won laurels of the gallant CORCORAN and the brave HAGGERTY, whose place he should have filled whilst living, has until now been quietly and calmly pursuing his profitable business as Alderman of the Seventh Ward, and member of the "ring" in this city, unmindful of message after message from Col. CORCORAN either to resign or to come on and do his duty.

abstract: Some of the Philadelphians and their oracles seem to be greatly exercised about the strictures made in New-York in regard to certain Pennsylvania Generals and other officers who in one or two recent exigencies, have not figured quite as creditably as they might have done.
lead_paragraph: Some of the Philadelphians and their oracles seem to be greatly exercised about the strictures made in New-York in regard to certain Pennsylvania Generals and other officers who in one or two recent exigencies, have not figured quite as creditably as they might have done. They seem to consider such criticism as an impeachment of the courage and patriotism of all Pennsylvania soldiers, and consequently retort upon New-York in genuine provincial schoolboy style, "You're another." One journal says that "Pennsylvania can boast of one thing -- that is, that none of her sons were engaged in the ill-timed assault of Sunday last" -- which, considering the circumstances, is certainly not much to boast of; -- and complacently adds, "Pennsylvania never has lost a battle in which she was engaged" -- of which fact all New-Yorkers are duly proud. Another caustically asks, "Was it the fault of our Pennsylvania troops that the New-Yorkers ingloriously broke and fled? " -- a query which, considering the splendid fighting it is now proved "these New-Yorkers" did before they were broken, and the inglorious inaction of GROUCHY PATTERSON, does not seem to be either annoying or perplexing. The same writer adds: "We'll warrant that if the much-berated Pennsylvanians had been there, we should have seen no flight," -- which is very probable. Others are still more ungenerous, and indulge in petty wranglings with their supposed defamers in New-York, which would be more becoming in boys than in full-grown men. They seem utterly to forget the broad impulses of nationality in the jealousies of local conceit.

abstract: The disappointed thousands who returned despondingly home after the arrival of the Eighth Regi- ment, would have been overjoyed could they have known that the expected Seventy-first would shortly arrive via the Camden and Amboy route. Other thousands and tens of thousands, however, did know the welcome news, and flocked to Pier No. 1, led by one of those mysterious instincts that seem to guide New-Yorkers under difficulties.
lead_paragraph: The disappointed thousands who returned despondingly home after the arrival of the Eighth Regi- ment, would have been overjoyed could they have known that the expected Seventy-first would shortly arrive via the Camden and Amboy route. Other thousands and tens of thousands, however, did know the welcome news, and flocked to Pier No. 1, led by one of those mysterious instincts that seem to guide New-Yorkers under difficulties. The company received telegraphic information at 4 1/2 o'clock, that the regiment had embarked and posted the same at the head of the pier for the information of the army of inquirers. Nothing daunted at the two hours' delay, those who had already borne the scorching sun for half a day in anxious expectation of a momentary arrival, quietly sat themselves down for a patient wait. The crowd augmented in numbers, until Battery-place and even the Battery itself were black with the mass of moving humanity. The friends of the Sixty-ninth were likewise among the number, with their music and regalia, and flags, and children in arms, and tearful eyes and joyful hearts. They, however, were to be disappointed, for the gallant sons of the Emerald Isle were detained behind.

abstract: One of the most remarkable features of the times is the banishment, "Austrian fashion," of this gallant officer to "his estates," at the great crisis in the country's existence, and at the very moment that the services of a General of his acknowledged ability and experience would be supposed to be most needed. The reasons to the ardent friends of Gen. WOOL, and to the public, are inexplicable, but quite explicable to those familiar with the operations of the War Department. The greatest indignation prevails, at the slights, not to say the insults, heaped upon this old soldier, next to Gen. SCOTT in age, rank, service and reputation. Could he be not as safely trusted as our newly-fledged Generals, who never dreamed of service three months ago? Is he not as competent as that civilian from Pennsylvania by whom he was superceded here, as the authority to dispatch troops to the seat of war, purchase munitions, charter ships, and superintend generally the direction of military affairs. One would suppose that the service of such an officer would be invaluable, both on the field, and in the organization of the Army. No one doubts his patriotism, capacity, integrity, or his entire devotion to the cause of the Government; but every one knows that he cannot be made any man's tool, or prostitute an official position for his own personal advantage, or that of his friends. It is well known that Gen. SCOTT desires that he should be in active service. That he is not, is imputed to the Secretary of War -- an imputation under which the Secretary must rest till Gen. WOOL's letter is satisfactorily answered. Till then, creditable motives will not be ascribed, to the head of the Military Department. If the duty of organizing and forwarding troops to the seat of the war had been confided to Gen. WOOL, is there a doubt that a vast amount of discouragement, disappointment and loss, both in contracts for military stores, and the morale of the Army, might have been saved. This business has been intrusted to inexperienced parties, and blundering, to make no graver charge, from the beginning to the end, has been the natural result. The spirit of the nation is not to be kept up by such proceedings. Unless they are speedily stayed, the public voice will reach Washington in no very pleasant tones. Again we ask, why is not General WOOL assigned to some active, honorable and responsible service, either in the organization or command of the National forces.

abstract: The New-Haven Journal has seen a letter from Col. TERRY, of the Second Connecticut Regiment. He says: "The cause of the retreat was the double numbers of the enemy, their superiority in cannon, and the sufferings of our men from hunger and thirst, after their long and fatiguing march." He retreated in good order. His loss in killed and wounded is quite small, though there are a good many stragglers, and doubtless some of them are prisoners. The First and Third Connecticut Volunteers suffered more than the Second. All were under very heavy fire and bore it bravely, but the artillery of the enemy was poorly served, which accounts for the small loss. His letter is, of course, brief and hasty, no time for returns having elapsed, but he says he knows positively of only one man in the Regiment who is killed, though probably there are several others.
lead_paragraph: The New-Haven Journal has seen a letter from Col. TERRY, of the Second Connecticut Regiment. He says: "The cause of the retreat was the double numbers of the enemy, their superiority in cannon, and the sufferings of our men from hunger and thirst, after their long and fatiguing march." He retreated in good order. His loss in killed and wounded is quite small, though there are a good many stragglers, and doubtless some of them are prisoners. The First and Third Connecticut Volunteers suffered more than the Second. All were under very heavy fire and bore it bravely, but the artillery of the enemy was poorly served, which accounts for the small loss. His letter is, of course, brief and hasty, no time for returns having elapsed, but he says he knows positively of only one man in the Regiment who is killed, though probably there are several others.

abstract: In obedience to orders from the War Department, five of the chief officers appointed to the Fifteenth (new) Regiment, U.S.A., reported for duty in Cincinnati, Ohio, on Monday last, to begin the organization of that regiment. They were first directed to proceed to Cleveland, but for some unexplained reason, the order was countermanded. The head-quarters of the Fifteenth is at Wheeling,. Va. Col. FITZJOHN PORTER was named in General Orders No. 33 as its commandant.

abstract: Ten thousand fresh troops have arrived in Washington within the last forty-eight hours. In fact, over since the disaster of Sunday they have been pouring in in almost a continuous stream. On Sunday night, after the result of the battle had become known in Washington, Gov. CURTIN, of Pennsylvania, was telegraphed to for more troops, and in four days afterwards he had sent on ten regiments -- about fourteen thousand men -- composed of men who have had the advantage of two months' experience of camp life. And apparently, this promptitude in assembling a heavy force at the Capital is needed, and the great care should be that its energies are not expended in the wrong direction. An immense amount of labor, our correspondent informs us, is being done upon the fortifications upon the Virginia side of the Potomac; but if all the reports which reach us areto be relied upon, it is not on that side that we are to look for an attack from the rebels, if they intend to make one, -- and that they entertain such an intention now, seems to be admitted. Their plan, according to the best information attainable, is to cross the Potomac about forty miles above Washington, and make the attack from the Maryland side, -- Gen. LEE taking command of the enterprise, while Gen. BEAUREGARD will move forward to engage the attention of Gen. MCCLELLAN on the line of defences at Arlington and Alexandria; JOHNSTON will operate against Gen. BANKS, and columns will be sent against Gen. BUTLER and Gen. ROSENCRANTZ. This is a stupendous programme, but the size of the rebel Army seems to warrant the leaders in undertaking to carry it out.

abstract: Four of the crew of the privateer Sumter, who were placed in charge of the bark Cuba, Capt, SPROUL, after her capture, and who were subsequently recaptured by the crew of the Cuba, and arrived at this port on Sunday last, was brought up for preliminary examination yesterday, before United States Commissioner OSBORN. ALGERNON S. SULLIVAN, Esq., who has been retained by JEFF. DAVIS' oligarchy, appeared for the prisoners; and G.P. ANDREWS. Esq., conducted the examination for the Government. The pirates names are HUDGINS, a Virginian, who acted as Captain; SPENCE, an Englishman, DAVIDSON, a Scotchman; O'BRIEN, an Irishman and DONNELLY, an American.

abstract: We are as willing to be cheered as any body can be, by the animated dispatches that the War Department at Washington is sending out to the country. "A fresh Army of 80,000 men, from the different States, has been accepted." It reads well, but Mr. Secretary CAMERON might as well have stated it a little differently. It might have been said that eighty tenders of regiments have been made and accepted. This would have left a safe margin for the reasonable discount that must follow, when the eighty would-be-Colonels of the regiments, who have telegraphed to the Secretary of War, come to muster in their enlistments and go into camp. We know well enough that regiments are not kept organized in all parts of the country, and ready to march at a day's or a week's notice to any sent of war. Some weeks ago, a vast number of regiments were in such a forward state of organization that they could have been easily filled up and in a short time in camp at Washington. But the disinclination to receive more men discouraged the military spirit of the country, and most of the inchoate regiments have disbanded. In times like these, when men are so pressed to provide themselves and families with the necessaries of living, it is not easy to keep a single company completely organized. When it comes to combining ten such under one head, and in reliable complement and unity, -- it is simply impossible.

abstract: DR. HOOE'S RESIGNATION ACCEPTED. A meeting of the congregation of the Brick Church (Dr.  SPRING'S) was held Thursday morning, under a call of the Session, for the consideration of the resignation of Dr. HOOE, the Associate Pastor. Dr. KREBS was called to preside, and Mr. SAMUEL MARSH was Secretary."
lead_paragraph: DR. HOOE's RESIGNATION ACCEPTED. -- A meeting of the congregation of the Brick Church (Dr. SPRING'S) was held Thursday morning, under a call of the Session, for the consideration of the resignation of Dr. HOOE, the Associate Pastor. Dr. KREBS was called to preside, and Mr. SAMUEL MARSH was Secretary." Dr. SPRING commenced the business of the meeting by reading the minutes of the Session, including the letter of Dr. HOGE, assigning as a reason for his resignation that there existed "a radical difference of opinion on the great question of the day," between himself and his people, that "the discussion of political questions, however absorbing." had been purposely avoided by him in the pulpit; that he was "induced to believe that a minority of the congregation were disposed to placed the Gospel above the National question," but that since it "had become manifest that a difference of political views could not be tolerated in the church, he had concluded to resign. Dr. SPRING stated that the Session had accepted the resignation. Upon motion of Mr. SHANNON, the resignation was accepted by the congregation, and a Commission of three, consisting of NORMAN WHITE, JOHN A. BRYAN and GARDINER SPRING, Jr., was constituted for the purpose of presenting the action of the congregation to the Presbytery, and requesting that body to unite with them in dissolving the pastoral relation. The meeting then adjourned. There is little doubt that the Presbytery will complete the separation. Some surprise was evinced that Dr. HOGE's friends did not oppose the acceptance of his resignation, but it is understood that their action was in compliance with Dr. HOGE's request.

abstract: The reverse at Bull's Run is undoubtedly  the first step of our Government toward the adoption of a competent plan of military oper  ations if not of a well defined policy as to the war; the absence of such policy is the only explanation for our defeat.
lead_paragraph: The reverse at Bull's Run is undoubtedly the first step of our Government toward the adoption of a competent plan of military oper ations if not of a well defined policy as to the war; the absence of such policy is the only explanation for our defeat. Unless a person has some definite object, he wastes his strength in extravagant, futile, and often contradictory efforts, in precisely the same manner that our own has been wasted in the campaign in the Eastern States. In Missouri, Gen. LYON was instructed to clear the State of rebels, which he did in a most summary manner. There were really no difficulties in the way of a skillful commander, because he had a definite object and abundant means for its execution. Common sense was the only other element wanting to insure success; and this Gen. LYON appears to possess in an eminent degree. There was no sufficient motive to thwart him while he was too far from Washington to have his plan of operations interfered with. To Gen. MCLELLAN was confided the task of driving the enemy out of Northwestern Virginia -- a duty which he promptly accomplished, because a straightforward one, to which he could direct his individual energies and skill. In a short month his campaign was brought to a glorious termination, allowing him to be called to duty elsewhere.

abstract: Some months ago the plan of the Confederates for quieting the revolution they were about inaugurating in this country was, to frame a new Constitution for the seceding States, and then let into their league such of the Middle and Western States as, on due contrition for past hostility to Pro-Slavery rule and good promise of dutiful behavior in the future, should be found worthy of Southern association.
lead_paragraph: Some months ago the plan of the Confederates for quieting the revolution they were about inaugurating in this country was, to frame a new Constitution for the seceding States, and then let into their league such of the Middle and Western States as, on due contrition for past hostility to Pro-Slavery rule and good promise of dutiful behavior in the future, should be found worthy of Southern association. But New-England it was thought best to exclude entirely, as sinners too hardened for salvation in the Black Republic.

abstract: Nearly four weeks have clapsed since the day appointed for the opening of the manuscripts sent in to the Committee upon a National Hyma, and impatience is manliesting iteslf in many quarters for the announcement of the expected  award.
lead_paragraph: Nearly four weeks have clapsed since the day appointed for the opening of the manuscripts sent in to the Committee upon a National Hyma, and impatience is manliesting iteslf in many quarters for the announcement of the expected award. Aside from any interest which the public at large may take in the subject, the great number of the competitors -- only a few short of twelve hundred -- makes it inevitable that there are thousands of cager expectants sitting upon the anxious seat in this regard. For it can hardly be that each competitors has less than a dozen friends who are so [???] us for his success. We have there one thought is worth while to inform ourselves as far as possible upon the subject, and we learn that the committee are upon the verge of the conclusion of their labors. They have not yet, however, decided upon making an award; and we remind our readers, that in their advertised conditions of competition, they expressly stimulated that they were not to give the prize to the best hymn [???] in, but that they should reject all, whatever their intrinsic merits, if they found none exactly suited to the purpose.

abstract: Our columns are read by large numbers of the officers at present in service in the volunteer regiments of the United States. We desire, on the part of the public, to address them some sober words under the present crisis. In every great disaster the popular mind always seeks some scapegoat on which to lay the blame.
lead_paragraph: Our columns are read by large numbers of the officers at present in service in the volunteer regiments of the United States. We desire, on the part of the public, to address them some sober words under the present crisis. In every great disaster the popular mind always seeks some scapegoat on which to lay the blame. The people are fast tending to the point of fastening it on the officers of our regiments, since the late defeat. The facts thus far are certainly supporting -- though not fully proving -- this judgment. The men, in large numbers of regiments, testify that they knew and saw nothing of their officers during the battle; they fought, as they expressed it, "on their own book" -- in one instance a Quartermaster leading the regiment. The Army officers -- who, it is true, are not so disinterested witnesses -- all agree that the majority of the volunteer officers were utterly incompetent to their place. But the great and damning fact is, that twenty thousand men, in the moment of victory, were seized with an unaccountable panic, and that so officer had moral control enough over them to hold them back. A single word from some brave officer, in whom they had learned to have confidence, might have turned the whole rout, and saved this nation the greatest disgrace which has ever fallen on its arms. But in the majority of the regiments, the regimental officers either were panic-stricken themselves, or found, in the moment of [???] trial, that they had not the slightest [???] over their men.

abstract: The steamer Transcript, of the Camden and Amboy line, left Amboy at 7 1/2 o'clock yesterday morning, having on board the First Regiment, Rhode Island, and arrived at Pier No. 3, North River, at 10 o'clock A.M. The steamers Bay State and State of Maine, which had been laying at the railroad pier, Jersey City, two days, anticipating the arrival of the Regiment by the New-Jersey Railroad, steamed over to Pier No. 3 about two hours before the troops arrived. The Transcript was secured fast to the two steamers and the soldiers were transferred, with baggage and equipments, to the decks of the latter, and when all was ready the lines were let go and off went the troops to Providence. The Regiment numbered about 950 men altogether, 33 of whom were sick and wounded, and who received the special care and attention of their well comrades during the journey hither. Many of the soldiers expressed a determination to reenlist after a few weeks' respite with their families.

abstract: Thousands of citizens, both of New-York and Brooklyn, were disappointed, yesterday, at the non-arrival of the Twenty-eighth Regiment, known to be en route for home. During the afternoon and evening, the streets of Brooklyn were filled with an anxious and impatient crowd, while at both the New-Jersey Railroad and Camden Depots escorts were in readiness. Among those waiting to do escort duty were portions of the Seventy-first Regiment, the Ringgold Horse Guards, Citizens' Horse Guards, Brooklyn Sharp-shooters, Capt. HARTUNG; Brooklyn Home Guard, under Maj. WM. EVERDELL, and an Engineer Corps of Juvenile Zouaves, together with about seventy-five policemen of Brooklyn, under Deputy-Superintendent POLK. They attracted quite a crowd in Cortlandt-street, and no little excitement was occasioned by the vibration of couriers between the Amboy and Cortlandt-street Depots. The reports were for a time as contradictory as the histories of Bull's Run. The most reliable dispatch, however, was, that the Twenty-Eighth were in waiting at Camden, and would arrive about midnight, or perhaps several hours later. The escort then took up the line of march for home, attracting quite as much attention, perhaps, as the veritable heroes would, had they arrived in time.

abstract: The gallant Irishmen of the Sixty-ninth returned to the City yesterday. They had been expected with impatience for three days, and during that-period there was not an Irish heart in the community but bumped with excitement at the least thump of the drum or the slightest toot of the trumpet. Bitterly disappointed were the thousands who bivouacked in Broadway on Thursday and Friday.
lead_paragraph: The gallant Irishmen of the Sixty-ninth returned to the City yesterday. They had been expected with impatience for three days, and during that-period there was not an Irish heart in the community but bumped with excitement at the least thump of the drum or the slightest toot of the trumpet. Bitterly disappointed were the thousands who bivouacked in Broadway on Thursday and Friday. The Sixty-ninth, for which they pined, was away in Georgetown, in Philadelphia, everywhere except Broadway. Considering the uncertainty that has attended the arrival of this regiment, and the many false alarms on the subject, the aspect presented by our streets yesterday was eminently flattering to our mobocracy. From an early hour in the morning they were packed with a dense throng of expectants. Biddy, having had two holidays in succession on the strength of Patrick's devotion to the flag of his country, was not able to turn out in full force and magnificence yesterday. The Fates or the Furies who reserve house cleaning and marketing for Saturday, objected to her neglecting these points of domestic economy. Hence we missed many of those good-lumpered, kindly and beaming faces which were so plentifully scattered around on the previous day's gatherings. But as the regiment marched on its way up town, it was what is called a "caution" to observe how rapidly these same faces appeared on the scene again. It is much to be feared that the household gods were sacrificed ruthlessly upon this occasion. Certainly it seemed as if every Biddy in the land had suddenly and mysteriously burst into sight for the express gratification of the gallant Sixty-ninth. Some of them, to be sure, presented a rather dishevelled appearance, but there was an eager gladness in their eyes which compensated for defects of toilet.

We have captured eighteen pieces of artillery and taken some three or four hundred prisoners.

abstract: In this country, whether it be to our credit or our shame, defalcation in respect to pecuniary trusts is seldom punished by the law, and is not always visited with that amount of public odium which its wickdness deserves. A bank officer gambles in stocks or launches out into reckless speculations.
lead_paragraph: In this country, whether it be to our credit or our shame, defalcation in respect to pecuniary trusts is seldom punished by the law, and is not always visited with that amount of public odium which its wickdness deserves. A bank officer gambles in stocks or launches out into reckless speculations. His venturesprove disastrous, and to redeem himself, he lays his hand upon the funds intrusted to his care. Stocks go down, or his speculations wane, and he wades in deeper and deeper, until the dread of exposure drives him to the falsification of the books under his charge, to hide his defalcations. The crisis at last comes. The bank explodes, and stockholders and depositors find themselves involved in the ruin his dishonesty has occasioned. He retires from the institution he has swamped, not into prison not info the criminal Courts to answer for his delinquencies, but to live quietly, perhaps under the ban of popular opinion and the loss of his social position, subsisting from the spoil he has secretly saved, in view of the wreck which he alone was permitted to see in the perspective. He is seldom troubled by indictments, and if he is, the chances are, that through the law's delay and its tenderness towards respectable criminals, he will escape all punishment at last. We have in an interior city, instances illustrative of our meaning, where men who have plundered funds intrusted to their keeping, amounting in the aggregate to many hundreds of thousands of dollars, whose dishonesty has carried destitution and ruin to the homes of many families, and who are calmly walking the streets, unmolested by the pursuit of justice, serene and placid in all outward seeming as if they had been guilty of no wrong, but were entitled to the sympathy of the world for having lost their own fortunes in the wild speculations that scattered ruin all around them.

abstract: Baltimore, whose loyalty from the beginning has been of a doubtful character, is just now doubly dangerous. The insurrectionary spirit, [???] by the late repulse in Virginia, is assuming a boldness not to be disregarded. It was [???] a part of the rebel plans, that if the loyal forces were defeated at [???] this shout of triumph from rebel [???] in Virginia should be echoed back by the [???] of insurrection in Baltimore. In view of this, the language used by Congressman [???] in the House of Representatives [???] has a deep significance. The [???] of whom he spoke, as ready to [???] resistance against the Government, are [???] into the daylight. His [???] to the Confederate leaders at Richmond had a purpose, and the [???] of Baltimore, halting between treason, and loyalty, a smouldering volcano that may burst into fury at any moment, may explain it. His previous journey to Washington [???] as a Union member of Congress, he was received with respect, and regarded [???], enabled him to apprise himself fully of the designs of the Government. [???] in possession of information in relation to the position and numbers of the loyal forces, and the probable military movements that were to follow, the communication of which to the rebel leaders, it may well be supposed, enabled them to prepare so thoroughly for our attack upon them at Bull's Run. Baltimore, it is said, is guarded by a probably loyal police, aided by a respectable military force, but these would be powerless against an organized conspiracy, that from all appearances has been ripening for months. Overlooking the city is Fort McHenry, whose guns command the town, and Gen. DIX should notify the people of Baltimore, that if insurrection shall break out in its streets, those guns will not be idle. There has been forbearance enough, tenderness enough exercised towards treason in the chief city of Maryland. So long as it shall remain true to its allegience it should be respected, but if its people shall raise the standard of revolt, or permit it to be raised, swift retribution should be visited upon them. There has been loyal blood enough shed in the City of Baltimore and though its cry for vengetative may have been hushed under the impulses of humanity, yet a renewal of the [???] of the last of April should be answered by the shot and shell from the guns of McHenry, and of this the advocates of rebellion. The conspirators of that city, should be warned by Gen. DIX, in a manner so earnest that they would lay it to heart, and choose between the desolation and ruin that would follow, and their duty as loyal citizens.

abstract: This gentleman, the representative of the State if Georgia to the European Courts, has addressed a communication to the Minister of Commerce of France, which he earnestly requests should be communicated to the Emperor, upon commerical affairs in America, in reply to articles in the TIMES, which have been republished, and have had a wide circulation both in France and England.
lead_paragraph: This gentleman, the representative of the State if Georgia to the European Courts, has addressed a communication to the Minister of Commerce of France, which he earnestly requests should be communicated to the Emperor, upon commerical affairs in America, in reply to articles in the TIMES, which have been republished, and have had a wide circulation both in France and England. We give elsewhere the substance of Mr. KING's argument. It is chiefly made up of those platitudes in which Southern gentlemen are so fond of indulging -- the enormous volume of Southern commerce -- its past value to the Northern States and its future value to France, if she will only accept of the proffered boon.

abstract: The relation which the second volume of the History of Civilization holds to the first is somewhat peculiar. It is a relation, not of continuity, but of Method. Having, in the first volume arrived, by induction, at certain generalizations regarding the laws of historical progress, he devotes the second volume to testing, by deduction, the truth of those generalizations. The inductive defence comprised a collection of historical and scientific facts which suggested and authorized certain conclusions as to the laws of civilization; the deductive defence consists of a verification of those conclusions by showing how they explain the history of different countries and their various fortunes. This second volume, accordingly, may be viewed as a series of pieces justificatives of the principles of the first installment. These principles, which Mr. BUCKLE regards as the basis of the history of civilization, are: First, that the progress of mankind depends on the success with which the laws of phenomena are investigated and on the extent to which a knowledge of these laws is diffused. Second, that before such investigation can begin a spirit of scepticism must arise, which, at first aiding the investigation, is afterwards aided by it. Third, That the discoveries thus made increase the influence of intellectual truths, and diminish, relatively, not absolutely, the influence of moral truths. Fourth, that the great enemy of this movement, and consequently of civilization, is the Protective spirit; that is, the notion that society cannot prosper unless the affairs of life are watched over and protected at nearly every turn by the State and the Church -- the State teaching men what they are to do, and the Church teaching them what they are to believe.

abstract: Let us turn for a moment from the war before us to the treason around us. No fact can be plainer to those who are familiar with the National Capital, than the continued existence of a formidable sccession element there, which it is supposed by many is still to some extent domiciled within the several Bureaux and Departments of the Government.
lead_paragraph: Let us turn for a moment from the war before us to the treason around us. No fact can be plainer to those who are familiar with the National Capital, than the continued existence of a formidable sccession element there, which it is supposed by many is still to some extent domiciled within the several Bureaux and Departments of the Government. There are certainly pretended loyal men in office, who hold such intimate communication with known sympathizers with the rebels, that they are looked upon by observing persons in the District with a suspicion amounting to distrust; while there are others not in office, whose connection with treason is so close that frequently their vague intimations are deemed to be almost prophetic of coming events.
headline: {'main': 'Treason Still in Office.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Treason Still in Office.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The severest trials of the soldier are not those which he undergoes on the field of battle. Marching to meet the foe with drums beating, and trumpets sounding, and colors flying, and a high purpose nerving that fills up the frame of the little picture which the new-fledged flaminge, in full Zouave feather, has hung up in his mind's eye before starting for the wars.

abstract: There have been no military movements of importance at Washington within the last twentyfour hours. Gen. McCLELLAN has not yet taken command of the Army of the Potomac, but is engaged in organizing his Staff, and preparing for active operations. We may expect to hear something from him before long.
lead_paragraph: There have been no military movements of importance at Washington within the last twentyfour hours. Gen. McCLELLAN has not yet taken command of the Army of the Potomac, but is engaged in organizing his Staff, and preparing for active operations. We may expect to hear something from him before long, The Administration, our correspondent states, does not apprehend any attempt on the part of the rebels to capture Washington. It is perhaps not best to be too sure. There are, however, now around the city about thirty-five thousand men who were not in the recent battle, and the artillery force there is much greater than it has been before.

abstract: A fire broke out about 8 o'clock yesterday morning, in the cellar of the warehouse No. 7 Oldslip, occupied by Mr. JAMES TURNER, a dealder in oils  and candles.
lead_paragraph: A fire broke out about 8 o'clock yesterday morning, in the cellar of the warehouse No. 7 Oldslip, occupied by Mr. JAMES TURNER, a dealder in oils and candles. As nearly as can be ascertained, the fire was occasioned by the carelessness of the porter on the establishment, who is believed to have thrown a burning march upon the floor of the cellar, after having lighted the gas. This man left the premises, intending to be absent but a short time, but on his return a dense volume of smoke burst from the cellar and filled the upper portion of the building. Its appearance was the signal for an alarm of fire, and the firemen promptly thronged to the scene and attempted to extinguish the flames. The highly inflammable material with which the building was filled, however, rendered their efforts of little advantage, and finally yielding the structure a prey to the devouring element, their attention was turned toward the contiguous buildings, which by this time were greatly imperiled. Here they were instrumental in saving a large quantity of property.
headline: {'main': 'Disastrous Fire at Old-slip.; A MAN BURNED TO DEATH-- $25,000 WORTH OF PROPERTY DESTROYED.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Disastrous Fire at Old-slip.; A MAN BURNED TO DEATH-- $25,000 WORTH OF PROPERTY DESTROYED.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: CROTON WATER DEPARTMENT. Proposals for regulating and paying streets were opened yesterday and the work given out as follows: For regulating and paying with cobble-stones Tenth-avenue, between Fifth-fourth-street and Broadway, nine bids were received.
lead_paragraph: CROTON WATER DEPARTMENT. -- Proposals for regulating and paying streets were opened yesterday and the work given out as follows: For regulating and paying with cobble-stones Tenth-avenue, between Fifth-fourth-street and Broadway, nine bids were received. The job was awarded to PATRICK LYNCH, at $11997; time 75 days; sureties, JAMES MOORE and ANDREW LEARY. The some work on Forty-first-street, between Tenth and Eleventh avenues -- six bids -- warded to PATRICK LYNCH, at $654 25; time, 10 days; same sureties. Eight bids were received for doing the same work on Corlears and Water streets, at or near the Junction; awarded to PATRICK LYNCH, at $609 75; time, 10 days; same sureties. Ten bids were received for paying with trap-block pavement Washington-street, between Liberty and Spring streets. Awarded to JARDINE and JOHNSON, at $31,355 92; time, 45 days; sureties, N.A. CHILDS and S.W.WHITE.

abstract: Gen. McCLELLAN, it is believed, is to have command of the National troops on both sides of the Potomac.
lead_paragraph: Gen. McCLELLAN, it is believed, is to have command of the National troops on both sides of the Potomac. He has already entered upon his duties as Commander of the Department in Virginia, and on Saturday visited Arlington in company with Secretary CAMERON, and yesterday went to Alexandria with Gen. MCDOWELL, under an escort of cavalry, to inspect the troops and intrenchments. It is believed that Gen. MCCLELLAN's attention will soon be directed to the batteries which the rebels have already erected and are about to erect on the Potomac. Unofficial, though doubtless reliable, information has been received in Washington that, as a part of the general plan of operations, they intend to erect batteries at various points to command the channel. Their operations will no doubt be checked before the work is so far advanced as to give trouble.

abstract: All day yesterday and during the evening the armory of the Sixth Regiment over Centre Market, was crowded with the relatives and friends of the regiment, Col. Jos. C. PINCENCY, momentarily expected to arrive home. But, as in the case of the other regiments, there was no reliability to any of the reports as to the probable hour of arrival. The same scene of disappointment was likewise reenacted along Broadway and among the vast crowd congregated on the Battery and in the vicinity of the Camden and Amboy Railroad depot. The escort was promptly on the ground, and attracted no little attention. First came the Union Fire Company, in open order. Next, the Fifty-fifth Regiment Band, heading a detachment of the Eleventh Regiment. Then came a German Benevolent Society, with a banner --.

abstract: RETURNING REGIMENTS ARRIVAL OF THE SECOND NEW-JERSEY, THE TWENTY-FIFTH NEW-YORK, AND FIRST CONNECTICUT REGIMENTS. The Second Regiment of Hudson County arrived quite unexpectedly in Jersey City yesterday morning.
lead_paragraph: RETURNING REGIMENTS -- ARRIVAL OF THE SECOND NEW-JERSEY, THE TWENTY-FIFTH NEW-YORK, AND FIRST CONNECTICUT REGIMENTS. -- The Second Regiment of Hudson County arrived quite unexpectedly in Jersey City yesterday morning. They reached Trenton on Saturday evening, and it was expected they would remain there until Tuesday, at which time arrangements were made to give them a fitting and well deserved reception. It was however, found inconvenient to quarter them at Trenton, and they were temporally dismissed. Still, though they reached Jersey City almost unexpectedly and unannounced, their reception was enthusiastic in the extreme. As soon as their approach to the city was known, the fire-bells were rung, bringing out the Fire Department in full force. The citizens also assembled in thousands to give a welcome to the returning heroes. The company all came back in good health and excellent spirits, and a large majority express an intention of at once re-enlisting for the war. On Tuesday next they return to Trenton, where they will be mustered out of service, after which they will have a formal reception by the authorities and citizens of Jersey City. On Saturday evening a meeting was held at the Mayor's office for the purpose of making the necessary arrangements. A sufficient sum was promptly subscribed to defray the expense, and a large number of military and civic societies reported themselves ready to participate in the reception; and, from the interest manifested in the matter, there can be no doubt the arrangements will be worthy the occasion.

abstract: "On Wednesday night last a large number of Kentuckians who had joined the troops at Union City, succeeded in passing the lines, the sentinels composing which were Kentuckians, and started at double quick time for Maysfield, Ky., where it was known were some 1,200 stand of arms and 6 field-pieces.
lead_paragraph: "On Wednesday night last a large number of Kentuckians who had joined the troops at Union City, succeeded in passing the lines, the sentinels composing which were Kentuckians, and started at double quick time for Maysfield, Ky., where it was known were some 1,200 stand of arms and 6 field-pieces. These, it was stated, were the objects which attracted them to that section, and had they been permitted to proceed, no doubt they would have returned in triumph. But Gen. CHEATHAM, having by some means obtained information of the movement, and discerning at once the delicate position it would place Tennessee in, immediately dispatched an aid and a small party in pursuit of the expeditionists. They were overtaken a short distance from the line and peremptorily ordered back. A 'council of war' was held by the men, and, after a great deal of discussion, the men reluctantly returned, cursing the fate that led them to enter the service before attaining their object.

abstract: This regiment has been accepted by the Government, is being rapidly filled up and sworn into the service of the United States.
lead_paragraph: This regiment has been accepted by the Government, is being rapidly filled up and sworn into the service of the United States. It will consist of athousand men under the command of Col. R.D. GOODWIN. Col. FISHER, late of the United States Army, has accepted the post of Lieutenant-Colonel, and the post of Major will be filled by Col. WHITNEY, late of New-Hampshire. The position of Adjutant is still open for an experienced officer. Several of the line officers are qualified for their posts by previous experience in the United States Army, or by instruction received at West Point. Two flank companies are now being recruited, one as light infantry and engineers, and the other as artillery. They have the beautiful grounds of Camp Washington on Staten Island for quarters, drills, and parades, where the strictest discipline is observed, and the soldiers are carefully provided with rations and clothing, and in all respects made comfortable. Those of the returning three months' regiments who are desirous of reenlisting can have no better chance. They will be immediately mustered into the United States service and be under pay. Any encouragement which our patriotic citizens may feel disposed to bestow upon this regiment in the way of donations of clothing, haversacks, or other articles necessary to the soldier, will be thankfully received at the officers' head-quarters, No. 596 Broadway. The donations of the citizens of New-York of $101, through Acting-Surgeon LINQUIST and Lieut. GIROUX is thankfully acknowledged. Further donations will be gratefully received at head-quarters. Two hundred recruits of good moral character and physical ability are wanted immediately to complete the organization.

abstract: It becomes more and more evident that the turning event in the great battle, after the arrival of fresh reinforcements to the enemy, was an attack of cavalry on our centre.
lead_paragraph: It becomes more and more evident that the turning event in the great battle, after the arrival of fresh reinforcements to the enemy, was an attack of cavalry on our centre. It was not a very heavy attack, but our troops were thoroughly exhausted with ten hours of fighting and the want of food, and the noise and clamor of this onset was the opening cause of the panic which followed. The Fire Zouaves -- who have no nerves -- received one charge on their bayonets, and, with knife and sword bayonet, nearly annihilated the corps. Spectators report that the cat-like fellows absolutely sprang on the horses' necks and stabbed the riders. But other regiments did not take it so bravely. The clatter and tramp of a few hundred horse alarmed them, and they were disordered, and eventually the fright was communicated to others. One soldier slates that an escaped team horse, clattering down the road afterwards, caused the cry, "The cavalry are coming!" and scattered a whole regiment! This fear of cavalry among raw infantry is not an uncommon occurrence. It was so strong in the Revolution that WASHINGTON was obliged to issue a general order to encourage the infantry to stand against the British dragoons.

abstract: The suspension of telegraphic and postal intercourse with the South might be of serious inconvenience to the rebels, but for labors of their various organs, acknowledged or disguised, in this City.
lead_paragraph: -- The suspension of telegraphic and postal intercourse with the South might be of serious inconvenience to the rebels, but for labors of their various organs, acknowledged or disguised, in this City. The News, the Day-Book and Journal of Commerce fulfill their several parts by misrepresenting Northern sentiments and purposes, and stimulating by every artifice the disposition of the South to resist, with a steady and creditable perseverance, which must win golden opinions from their staveholding masters. But the merit of these mercenaries consists mainly in their facility and hardihood in falsehood; while curiously enough, the Herald, their abler colaborer, is even more serviceable by occasionally furnishing the truth in the shape of reliable information at the right moment to the rebel leaders. The Herald is, in fact, a dangerous masked battery, directed incessantly at the cause of the Union, and doing incalculable damage. Whenever it has the opportunity to pre-announce any advance of our Army, it immediately prints detailed enumerations of the forces to be used in the movement; with the distribution, and disposition of the several detachments; or it exhibits its enterprise in publishing minute diagrams of our positions, intrenchments, and assailable points. The latest evidence of this assiduity in the service of treason was afforded yesterday. After announcing that an attack upon the Army at Newport's News is contemplated by the rebels at Yorktown, it gives a minute and carefully prepared diagram of the position to be attacked, with the distribution of the Union troops, and a useful delineation of all the available approaches. The practical value to the enemy of this information is not to be overrated; and that it finds its way to them there is no reason to doubt. In their abandoned camps in Western Virginia and at Fairfax Court-house copies of the Herald were found, showing that a print of such vital ability to their cause could not be dispensed with by the enemy, and that there are secret traitors enough in New-York and Washington to supply them. It will be a nice little bill the Palinurus of Plum Gut will have to present one of these days to Secretary MEMMINGER. Let us hope it will not all be paid in Confederate Bonds.

abstract: A LIQUOR-DEALER MISSING. The friends of THOMAS MULLIGAN, a liquor-dealer, having a store at No. 735 Third-avenue, are greatly alarmed for his personal safety.
lead_paragraph: A LIQUOR-DEALER MISSING. -- The friends of THOMAS MULLIGAN, a liquor-dealer, having a store at No. 735 Third-avenue, are greatly alarmed for his personal safety. Two weeks since he closed hisplace of business, and nothing has since been heard of him. On Saturday the Police were requested to break open the store, in hopes that some clue to his disappearance might be obtained, but everything within presented an ordinary look. Mr. MULLIGAN was a strict business man, and his singular absence leads to the belief that he has met with foul play.

abstract: "At the time the National forces, under Gen. PATTERSON, entered Charlestown, Va., the regiment of Col. PATTERSON was the first to enter that place after the Cavalry and artillery. The regiment had not proceeded far before they discovered a boy, about 13 years of age, running towards them, and on approaching, he was spoken to by one of the officers. The boy uniformed the officer that his name was WM. RYAN, and that his father had been driven from Charlestown by the Secessionists, and that he had gone to New York and joined a regiment to fight for the Union. The boy then informed Capt. THOMPSON, of Company E. that he would show him where a cannon, powder, &c., were concealed, if he would allow him afterwards to remain with the regiment. His request was quickly granted, and Capt. THOMPSON's company was taken to an engine house in the town, where a six pound iron cannon, six kegs of artillery powder, several kegs and canisters of pistol powder, three uniform coats, and one musket were found. The cannon was mounted upon a carriage, but one of the wheels had been removed, subsequently, however, the missing wheel was found in some bushes near by, Young RYAN at once became a favorite with Capt. THOMPSON's men, and they were lavish in their attentions to his wants. Soon after this occurrence, the father of young RYAN was found in the ranks of the New-York Ninth Regiment, then at Harper's Ferry, and informed of the safety of his son. Capt. THOMPSON proposed bringing the boy to Philadelphia and providing for him, which proposition was agreed to by the father, whose position in the Ninth Regiment prevented him from seeing after his son as he would like to do. Mr. RYAN stated that when the secession fever broke out, his Union sentiments became known, and he was informed that he would be compelled to fight against the Union men. Not relishing this proposition, he managed to make his escape, but was unable to take his son with him. Young RYAN has been faithfully cared for, and be seems delighted with his change of residence. On his arrival here with the regiment, on Thursday, his clothes were much the worse for wear, but, yesterday, he appealed at the armory of Company E in a new suit, much to the delight of himself and his late companions. He has certainly fallen in good hands, Capt. THOMPSON being spoken of by his men in the highest terms.
