abstract: Had the author of Philip Thaxter possessed as much judgment as invention, as well developed powers of analyzation as of description he would have produced a very good novel. As it is, he has not achieved a success, though the book, from its abounding incident and rapid march of events, will undoubtedly find an audience.
lead_paragraph: -- Had the author of Philip Thaxter possessed as much judgment as invention, as well developed powers of analyzation as of description he would have produced a very good novel. As it is, he has not achieved a success, though the book, from its abounding incident and rapid march of events, will undoubtedly find an audience. The major defect of the book is that it seems to have been written with no purpose; it developes no truth, fastens no lasting impression upon the reader's mind. Without at all approaching to anything resembling a sermon, without infringing on the Tract Society's domain, a novel may be instructive. Fiction and truth are by no means so widely separated as the arbitrary signification of the words would imply. The plot of the story, also, is open to the charge of incoherence. The writer seems to have had a variety of dramatic property on hand that he determined to work off -- somewhat as stage managers feel themselves necessitated to use effective scenery, even when it fits loosely and slides heavily in the grooves. Originally it was manifestly his intention to punish faulty folk in this world, and accordingly we find them pinned down by a forked fatality that nothing human could escape. In the further progress of the volume, however, we find this design abandoned, and several wrong doers slip through the fingers of rough retribution. The best part of the book is the scenes and sketches of life in California during the first outbreak of the auriferous fever. They are highly colored indeed, but the first to knock at the Golden Gate will recognize an unmistakeable likeness. The book is published by RUDD & CARLETON.

abstract: Last evening, Dr. HAGUE'S church, corner of Madison-avenue and Thirty-first-street, was occupied by the largest congregation ever before assembled within its walls, in consequence of the announcement...
lead_paragraph: Last evening, Dr. HAGUE'S church, corner of Madison-avenue and Thirty-first-street, was occupied by the largest congregation ever before assembled within its walls, in consequence of the announcement that the Army Committee of the Young Men's Christian Association would present a report of its proceedings at Washington, and that several prominent clergymen would address the meeting upon the importance of ministering to the spiritual wants of the New-York soldiers who were wounded and suffering.

abstract: The Boston Traveler says: "We hear that one of the reporters of the Boston Press, who went out to witness the battle of Sunday, is missing and cannot be found. He was seen upon the field just before the retreat, and then said that he was going to the hospital, since which he has not been heard from. He had not returned to his hotel at Washington on Monday night and it is possible that he may have been taken prisoner by the rebels.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Traveler says: "We hear that one of the reporters of the Boston Press, who went out to witness the battle of Sunday, is missing and cannot be found. He had not returned to his hotel at Washington on Monday night and it is possible that he may have been taken prisoner by the rebels.

abstract: The Alta California of July 2 says: EDWARD CROSS, Esq., who has recently arrived from Arizona, is en route to Washington, where he will report himself for duty to the National Government, he having been proffered a commission in the National Army. As early as 1857 Mr. CROSS transported over the country to Tubac, the first press and printing paraphernalia ever sent into Arizona. For some time, subsequently. Mr. CROSS edited the Arizonian, which paper he sold to Lieut. Mowry. He says the Territory is in a terribly unfortunate condition at present. The Apaches have completely overrun it, and since his departure have massacred many whites in cold blood. Business is completely prostrated, and hundreds are preparing to leave the country. Mr. CROSS is enthusiastically in favor of the proposition to raise a cavalry regiment in California, for the wars. He is confident that no State in the Union possesses such capital material, and he himself would prefer being connected with such a corps, than in any other departmental service. Mounted regiments are needed, and if commanded by skillful officers, the Pacific cavalry would equal MURAT's.

abstract: It is said by those whose experience has taught them, that the excitement of the chase increases and absorbs the soul in its fascinations, exactly in proportion to the size and character of the game hunted.
lead_paragraph: It is said by those whose experience has taught them, that the excitement of the chase increases and absorbs the soul in its fascinations, exactly in proportion to the size and character of the game hunted. To hunt a tiger is one thing; to hunt an elephant or a lion is a very different and far more exciting thing. But the greatest excitement of all is to hunt man in war. The chase after their own kind grows on men, becomes more intense than all other excitements, and finally becomes, if indulged in, the fierce and ruling passion of the soul.

abstract: The Boston Journal, of July 23, says: "Capt. HUTCHINSON, of brig Lincoln, at this port from Martinique, states that on the 6th inst., at 6 A.M., saw a fore and aftschooner to the northwest. Supposed she was bound South, but soon found that she was bearing away for the Lincoln. and not liking her appearance, Capt. HUTCHINSON made all sail to keep clear of her. After setting all his light sails, he soon outsailed the supposed pirate. It being heavy, squally weather, she could not carry sail enough to overtake the Lincoln. At 8 A.M., she gave up the chase and hauled to the southward.
lead_paragraph: The Boston Journal, of July 23, says: "Capt. At 8 A.M., she gave up the chase and hauled to the southward.

abstract: How to make passable, at short notice, the ordinary bridges of which the rebels have destroyed the superstructure and left the piers, and how to rapidly transport guns, stores and horses over chasms which cannot be speedily bridged, are matters of the highest importance, in following up the Vandals.
lead_paragraph: How to make passable, at short notice, the ordinary bridges of which the rebels have destroyed the superstructure and left the piers, and how to rapidly transport guns, stores and horses over chasms which cannot be speedily bridged, are matters of the highest importance, in following up the Vandals. Aregiment or a column, reaching such a position, has one inherent element of success, possessed by no smaller expedition, viz.: a plenty of power; but without proper apparatus to make it available, they are in some cases perfectly helpless, with all their power. If a battery must be transported, within say three hours, to the opposite and precipitate bank of a wide stream which cannot be forded at a practicable point, and near which the materials for rafts are not abundant, the strength of ten thousand men will no more help the matter than that of so many infants. It requires time to make rafts, and to let artillery and horses safely down banks and haul them up precipices, and when expedition is an element of success in the proposed movement, no amount of mere human force can greatly facilitate matters. Any one can imagine a multitude of cases in which important surprises could be effected by crossing streams at points known to be impracticable by the usual means; and others in which the rapid rebuilding of bridges, or the transhipment of guns and stores by machinery that could be got to work before rafts could be constructed and navigated by any amount of men, would effect important movements which otherwise would have to be abandoned for want of the means of immediate execution. While a thousand men have power enough in the aggregate to perform any such work, this aggregate cannot be applied by any improvised means. While the united strength of five hundred men may be necessary to lift a certain weight or transport a certain load in the allowable time, five hundred men cannot get hold of one gun or one stick of timber, nor stand on one pier or one raft, nor exert their united strength in the particular direction and during the particular time required for rapid movements, with hands, shoulders and levers, alone. And on the other hand, the carrying round of derricks, falls, windlasses and machinery, weighing as much as a battery of heavy artillery, would not pay; and again, the setting up and getting into operation of any complex engineering fixture would be likely to take more time than the whole work of transportation by the old-fashioned rough-and-tumble make-shifts usually employed.

abstract: The Alta California of July 3 says: EDWARD CROSS, Esq., who has recently arrived from Arizona, is en route to Washington, where he will report himself for duty to the National Government, he having been proffered a commission in the National Army. As early as 1857 Mr. CROSS transported over the country to Tubac, the first press and printing paraphernalia ever sent into Arizona. For some time, subsequently, Mr. CROSS edited the Arizonian, which paper he sold to Lieut Mowry. He says the Territory is in a terribly unfortunate condition at present. The Apaches have completely overrun it, and since his departure have massacred many whites in cold blood Business is completely prostrated, and hundreds are preparing to leave the country. Mr. CROSS is enthusiastically in favor of the proposition to raise a cavalry regiment in California, for the wars. He is confident that no State in the Union possesses such capital material, and he himself would prefer being connected with such a corps, than in any other departmental service. Mounted regiments are needed, and if commanded by skillful officers, the Pacific cavalry would equal MURAT's.

abstract: "As the crop of cotton will be slow in getting to market the coming season -- if it goes there at all -- it behooves our planters to cast about for every means at their command for supplying themselves with the ready cash necessary for their lesser daily transactions. Due attention should be given to provisions of all kinds, as the surplus will hardly fail to command a remunerating price. There is one article, however, of which large quantities are produced annually, but on account of the difficulty of transportation in its unprepared state, is never sent into market, except in small quantities. We allude to fodder. The entire absence of Northern hay from the southern markets will create a great demand for this article as it substitute, and our planters would do well to look into the expediency of making it an article of trade the coming season. It may be readily compressed in a damp season in bales of three hundred pounds, secured with boards and hickory withes, which are always at hand -- and if thus sent to market, it will pay handsomely, after deducting all expenses.
lead_paragraph: "As the crop of cotton will be slow in getting to market the coming season -- if it goes there at all -- it behooves our planters to cast about for every means at their command for supplying themselves with the ready cash necessary for their lesser daily transactions. abstract: All Saturday afternoon Brooklyn was in a fever of excitement over the anticipated return of Col. BENNETT and his regiment. Fulton-street, from the ferry to the City Hall, was thronged, and its principal buildings gaily decorated with banners and other insignia suitable to the occasion.
lead_paragraph: All Saturday afternoon Brooklyn was in a fever of excitement over the anticipated return of Col. BENNETT and his regiment. Fulton-street, from the ferry to the City Hall, was thronged, and its principal buildings gaily decorated with banners and other insignia suitable to the occasion. Near the City Hall the words "Welcome Home," In large letters, were placed over the street through which they were to pass. The Seventieth Regiment mustered; also the reserve corps of the Thirteenth, the Brooklyn Cadets, the Home Guard, and various German associations and citizens, preparatory to escorting the returning regiment to the arsenal, in Porthland-avenue.

abstract: A great deal of indignant nonsense is still being vented in the Missouri State Convention and elsewhere about the military suppression of the St. Louis State Journal, the chief Western organ of the Southern conspirators and advocate of their plots and plans; and which, previous to its stoppage,...
lead_paragraph: A great deal of indignant nonsense is still being vented in the Missouri State Convention and elsewhere about the military suppression of the St. Louis State Journal, the chief Western organ of the Southern conspirators and advocate of their plots and plans; and which, previous to its stoppage, had given itself up to stimulating the mob of St. Louis to sedition and bloodshed, and inaugurating the reign of anarchy in the city and State. In the course of a heated discussion on Wednesday last, Hon. Mr. WRIGHT, of St. Louis, declared that the act was without a precedent, and said that "England in her most revolutionary period would never dare to suppress any Press for the free expression of opinions" -- assertions which show his utter ignorance of the recent history of England, as well as of the principles of civil and military law. In the Senate, also, the other day, Mr. BRECKINRIDGE denounced the act as a "suppression of the freedom of the Press;" and gave it as one of his proofs that we were "rushing with rapid strides into despotism;" while it has so disturbed the soul of that jealous friend of freedom and his country, VALLANDIGHAM of Ohio, that he has given notice of introducing into the House a bill "to secure the freedom of speech and of the Press." The organs of treason in Baltimore and elsewhere also are enraged about it, and vehemently reiterate the stock platitudes about the liberty of the Press -- as though these had any sort of application to this imperative measure of military police.

abstract: The recruiting for the Army last week, as noticed in the reports to be handed in this morning, exhibits a little improvement. The old Army, whose offices are at Chatham, Cedar and Hudson streets, continues to enlist for "general service;" but the Army, the raising of which Congress recently authorized, enlists for itself alone, to that we are now raising what will soon be known as "a new and an old Regular Army."
lead_paragraph: The recruiting for the Army last week, as noticed in the reports to be handed in this morning, exhibits a little improvement. The old Army, whose offices are at Chatham, Cedar and Hudson streets, continues to enlist for "general service;" but the Army, the raising of which Congress recently authorized, enlists for itself alone, to that we are now raising what will soon be known as "a new and an old Regular Army." The former has recruiting rendezvous now in almost every loyal State in the Union. The heretofore unprecedented sight of a recruiting office for the United States Regulars in country towns, villages, and often on the road-side, is losing its novelty every day, and the farmer and village blacksmith are learning to be more civil to their "help" while so tempting an employer as Uncle Sam is near at hand. From Pittsburgh, Pa., Wheeling, Va., Columbus, Cleveland and Cincinnati, Ohio, St. Louis, Mo., Harrisburgh and other towns in Pennsylvania, Portland, Mo., Portsmouth, N.H., and fifty other places, United States soldiers will soon becoming on to join the "eleven new double-battalion regiments for service" in the States and Territories. In this City, Yorkville and Fort Hamilton, recruits for the Twelfth Regiment of Foot are accumulating slowly. The old regiments got 28 men last week in town, and a few detachments from the country. One from Philadelphia arrived Saturday, and was immediately sent over to Governor's Island.

abstract: It has been said that the war has nothing to do with Slavery, but no one will pretend that Slavery has nothing to do with the war. The war is not made upon Slavery.
lead_paragraph: It has been said that the war has nothing to do with Slavery, but no one will pretend that Slavery has nothing to do with the war. The war is not made upon Slavery. The slaves have not been proclaimed free, and called into the service of the Government; although any foreign nation at war with a slaveholding country would avail itself of so conspicuous an element of weakness. Slavery still exists, with all its constitutional guaranties, in the Border States, and the citizens of these States who are not in open rebellion have repeatedly had their runaway slaves returned to them. It is only in those cases where slaves have run away from rebel masters, who freely lend them to the rebel Government for the construction of fortifications, or for soldiers in the field, that the commanders of our Armies have refused to deliver them up. It is therefore literally true that the war has nothing to do with Slavery, while Slavery has everything to do with the war. But for Slavery the Southern States would be on as good terms with those of the North as Illinois with Massachusetts, and the idea of dissolving the Union, or of a war between the North and the South, would be as preposterous as that of a war between Pennsylvania and Ohio.

abstract: We have shown elsewhere that the value of the recent victory of the rebels depends entirely upon the use they make of it.
lead_paragraph: We have shown elsewhere that the value of the recent victory of the rebels depends entirely upon the use they make of it. They will unquestionably seek to turn it to account in driving back our columns which have been advancing towards Richmond from the Northwestern portion of the State. These columns have already cleared nearly one-half of the State of the enemy. Gen. COX's command is now moving up the Kanawha, and unless speedily driven back, a large additional and very important position will be lost to the rebels. Gen. ROSENCRANZ is moving forward his victorious column, and having driven the enemy from the Northwestern Virginia, will, unopposed, soon form a junction with Gen. COX, when the two commands would be entirely adequate to the subjugation of Southwestern Virginia, and for the relief and protection of East Tennessee. The reinforcements going forward to Gen. BANKS' command will soon swell it to a formidable force, and enable him to act offensively. At present he is weak, and the enemy will naturally suppose, inexperienced. To-morrow he may he overwhelmed-by a force whose attack a fortnight hence he might defy.?

abstract: The reverse of the Union arms before Manassas, at a time when the National heart beat so high for a speedy victory, has occasioned a much greater degree of dejection than the result justifies.
lead_paragraph: The reverse of the Union arms before Manassas, at a time when the National heart beat so high for a speedy victory, has occasioned a much greater degree of dejection than the result justifies. Looked at without reference to the unhappy surroundings of a disorderly retreat and the disorganization of a few regiments, the repulse at Bull's Run proves nothing to the discouragement of the Union cause; while its good effects must be of inestimable value in fixing two rules in regard to the prosecution of the war. One is, that the plan of all campaigns must be left wholly to the judgment of our military men, than whom the world has none more competent. The other is, the absolute necessity of having not only divisions and brigades, but even regiments, battalions and companies constituting an army, under the direction, in every case where it is possible, of men possessing adequate military knowledge.

abstract: We have begun to realize the fearful results of going into battle with empty stomachs; but since this has been the occasional mistake of every campaign durirg the last six thousand years or so, we have not the courage to hope for a reform at this late day.
lead_paragraph: We have begun to realize the fearful results of going into battle with empty stomachs; but since this has been the occasional mistake of every campaign durirg the last six thousand years or so, we have not the courage to hope for a reform at this late day. But there is one reform, of almost equal practical importance, which modern science enables us to institute -- the rapid and economical preparation of wholesome and uniform food in large quantifies. This is a matter of primary importance -- it ranks in advance of rifled-cannon and gun-boats. The gallant Zouave, after all, like other locomotive machines, cannot develop power advantageously under low steam. Not only the character and quality of food, but its timely preparation and distribution demand the most thorough attention of the proper authorities. We are glad to see that the admirable system of SOYER is appreciated by them, and that attempts are making to confer its benefits upon our Army. But still greater and more fundamental and comprehensive reforms and improvements are practicable. We have already referred to a traveling kitchen often suggested by high military authorities, and mentioned more in detail in Col. SCOTT's military dictionary -- a traveling oven, range, etc., which afford a table for the manipulations of the cooks, and at the same time bakes and boils while moving with the regiment, so that no time is lost in long halts, called to prepare food. Had a complement of these kitchens followed up the column, and dispensed a hasty dish of soup, or a fresh loaf, to each fainting soldier, as he temporarily fell back, during a certain conflict within the memory of men still living, some great suffering, some valuable lives, and perhaps something still better would have been saved. Cases will undoubtedly occur during this war, in which some provision of this sort for dispensing a few wholesome and nutritious mouthfuls to soldiers during a day's action, will carry our colors further into the enemy's country than they could be driven by the most improved projectiles; a blood and tissue-making charge, put into the stomach of a brave man, at the right time, is worth a dozen ball-cartridges in the chamber of a hungry man's musket.

abstract: The American people have hitherto escaped any onerous amount of direct taxation.
lead_paragraph: The American people have hitherto escaped any onerous amount of direct taxation. The General Government has sustained itself and paid off its debts from duties on imports, a method of collecting revenue that falls so gently and equably on all, as scarcely to be felt by any, and from the sale of the public lands. The highest State tax, we believe, ever levied in the State of New-York was three and five-seventh mills on the dollar of the assessed valuation of its taxable property. This, with the local taxes, outside of the large cities, would probably carry the amount to about four and a half mills on the dollar. We have not the statistics at hand showing the assessed valuation in all the loyal States, but this we know, that a one mill tax in the State of New-York alone produces the sum of about $1,500,000. Assuming the assessed valuation of New-York to be one quarter of that of the loyal States, a mill tax would produce in them alone, an aggregate of $6,000,000 annually, a sum sufficient to pay the interest on a war loan of $100,000,000; -- or, a mill and a quarter tax would be sufficient to pay the interest on a seven per cent, loan of the same amount, leaving a surplus of $480,000 to provide for contingencies, or make up any deficiency in collections. If the whole $500,000,000 provided by Congress were raised, and the payment of interest made dependent upon a direct tax; it would even then amount to less than five and one-eighth mills, or about one-half of one per cent. on the taxable property of those States. It will thus be seen that with the full debt of $500,000,000 contracted, and the interest required to be paid by direct taxation, the burden would still be trifling compared with that which rests upon the people of almost every other nation in the world, and even that would be temporary. The receipts from the Customs under the present tariff, with such judicious amendment as experience shall indicate, together with those from the public lands, would wipe out the principal long before the expiration of the term fixed for its payment.

abstract: The Boston Traveler says: "We hear that one of the reporters of the Boston Press, who went out to witness the battle of Sunday, is missing and cannot be found. He was seen upon the field just before the retreat, and then said that he was going to the hospital, since which he has not been heard from. He had not returned to his hotel at Washington on Monday night, and it is possible that he may have been taken prisoner by the rebels.

abstract: So quietly has the Imperial party, with whom the yacht Jerome Napoleon entered our Bay last Saturday, come among us, and so overshadowing the importance of our own contemporary History,
lead_paragraph: So quietly has the Imperial party, with whom the yacht Jerome Napoleon entered our Bay last Saturday, come among us, and so overshadowing the importance of our own contemporary History, that New-Yorkers are but now beginning to learn that Prince NAPOLEON and his consort Princess CLOTILDE have really been three days among us, visiting our camps, our churches and our streets. Prince NAPOLEON, first cousin of the Emperor of the French and the Princess CLOTILDE, daughter of the Galant'nome VICTOR EMANUEL, King of Italy -- those are such arrivals as it does not fall to our lot to chronicle every day; and though the event has no "political significance" -- being mainly for the benefit of the Princess' health -- it is yet one that in ordinary times would have made a great sensation in the City.

abstract: The Thirteenth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., Col. BENNETT, will reach here at an early hour to-day, probably about 10 o'clock A.M. The regiment will be received by the City authorities, and all military organizations and civil societies have been invited to participate in the proceedings.
lead_paragraph: The Thirteenth Regiment, N.Y.S.M., Col. BENNETT, will reach here at an early hour to-day, probably about 10 o'clock A.M. The regiment will be received by the City authorities, and all military organizations and civil societies have been invited to participate in the proceedings. The Thirteenth has been in the service a little more than three months, and during that time has been stationed at Annapolis and Baltimore, rendering important service. The Common Council last night made an appropriation to pay the expenses of the reception.

abstract: There is no doubt that, from the most ob- vious necessity, the active force which the rebels can bring into the field is now concentrated in Virginia. It is the battle ground of their own selection, and upon which they have stacked their all.
lead_paragraph: There is no doubt that, from the most ob- vious necessity, the active force which the rebels can bring into the field is now concentrated in Virginia. It is the battle ground of their own selection, and upon which they have stacked their all. We have it from the best authority that within that State they have now at least 175,000 men, most of them well armed, and led by skillful and desperate officers, who see in defeat their own destruction and disgrace. Their Army is composed of the very elite of the South. Once destroyed, it can never be replaced, either in men or material. Only a small portion of it has been drafted from the class of poor whites, who are too listless and degraded to be of any reliance if brought into the field. To fit out this immense host, the finances of the rebels have been completely exhausted. Seizures of arms from our Government, forced loans, and a feeling of hatred to the North, have supplied the means for sending into the field an army which can neither be paid, nor fed, nor clothed, so as to maintain its efficiency, for any length of time, unless a decided success be achieved. This Army never was, nor will it ever be, so fit for action as at the present moment. Its leaders thoroughly understand their position -- that inaction is ruin, and that immediate success is an imperative necessity. That they are acting upon this conviction and necessity there cannot be a doubt. Indeed, our dispatches from all quarters confirm this. Gen. BANKS' command have retreated into Maryland before Gen. JOHNSTON, who has again appeared in great force upon his old ground. Newport's News is threatened with an immediate attack. We have not had time to learn the movement of the rebels westward, to attack Gens. ROSECRANS and COX, but we are confident such movements have been made. In other words, the 175,000 rebels, released from all fear of an immediate attack on their main position, are hurling this vast force against our isolated and unsupported columns, and it will be good fortune or good generalship if we do not sustain another disaster.

abstract: The Brigade of Col. KEYES, of Connecticut, in the battle of Bull Run, consisted of the three Connecticut and the Second Maine Regiments. Its total kiss in killed, wounded and missing was 125. Itceme back in perfect order to the camp at Fall's Church, where it had left its tents standing. It took every dollar's worth of the property left there on starting out for Fairfax Court-house, and moved it to Washington; then fell back to the Ohio camp (of four regiments) and gathered their tents, equipments, &c., and promptly sent them to Washington; also, the tents, &c., of one of the New-York Regiments. This Brigade next marched to Fort Corcoran in full force. This service was performed in thirty-six hours, during which they were entirely without food, and stood the tremendous rain-storm raging while they were performing it. It is worthy of note that they brought back all their wounded, and reached Washington without the loss of a single musket, rifle, or aught else.

abstract: The Sixth Regiment, Col. PINCKNEY, which arrived late on Sunday night, or rather early Monday morning, from the scat of war, had a grand parade yester- day.
lead_paragraph: The Sixth Regiment, Col. PINCKNEY, which arrived late on Sunday night, or rather early Monday morning, from the scat of war, had a grand parade yesterday. They left the armory, over Centre Market, at about 3 o'clock, and proceeded in companies to the Park, where, in front of the City Hall, the regiment was formed. After going through various evolutions, the regiment marched up Broadway to Fourteenth-street; from there down the Fourth-avenue and Bowery, to Broome-street, then to Broadway, and from thence to the Armory, where it was dismissed. In the procession was a wagon, drawn by four horses, and carrying thirty-four little girls, each one dressed in red, white and blue, and bearing the arms of the various States of the Union. As the line passed by Quartermaster LINDEN-MULLER's place on the Bowery a salute was fired, which the regiment acknowledged with cheers. In a day or two it is presumed that the regiment will be mustered out of the service of the United States.

abstract: In compliance with a resolution of the House of Representatives, of July 16, Hon. GIDEON WELLES, Secretary of the NAVY, has transmitted to that body the correspondence relative to the destruction of the United States vessels and other property at the Navyyard at Korfolk, Va.
lead_paragraph: In compliance with a resolution of the House of Representatives, of July 16, Hon. GIDEON WELLES, Secretary of the NAVY, has transmitted to that body the correspondence relative to the destruction of the United States vessels and other property at the Navyyard at Korfolk, Va. It has been printed and a copy lies before us. We are sorry to find that the view taken of the loss of the public vessels and property, by the TIMES, at the time of its occurrence, is fully sustained by this correspondence. The transaction must remain stamped on the page of American history as the most disgraceful that ever befel our Navy, and one of the most disastrous that ever happened to the Government. The blame of the affair will chiefly rest, perhaps, on Commodore MCCAULEY, whose conduct is wholly inexplicable, but seems to be a compound of imbecility, drunkenness and treason.

abstract: The patriotic and well-intentioned effort of our Representative in Congress, Mr. F.A. CONKLING, to reduce, without delay, the enormous and lavish expenditures of the Govern- ment, has already resulted much as we pre- dicted some days ago.
lead_paragraph: The patriotic and well-intentioned effort of our Representative in Congress, Mr. F.A. CONKLING, to reduce, without delay, the enormous and lavish expenditures of the Govern- ment, has already resulted much as we pre- dicted some days ago. He will not be permitted to accomplish his honest purpose. As a young member of the House, he was indulged by the knowing-ones in the passage of his resolution for a Committee of Inquiry, which, indeed, it would not have been politic to openly vote down. The Committee was directed to report "in what manner and to what extent the expenditures of the Government may he reduced, and what offices may be dispensed with." The cardinal object was, not the mere abolition of offices or the reduction of salaries, but to ascertain the manner of expending the money of the Government.
headline: {'main': 'Retrenchment of Government Expenditures.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Retrenchment of Government Expenditures.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: We are assured that the statement regarding Col. TOMPKINS, of the Second New-York Regiment, to the effect that in the bottle of Bull Run he threw away his sword and ran while his regiment stood firm, is entirely incorrect.
lead_paragraph: We are assured that the statement regarding Col. TOMPKINS, of the Second New-York Regiment, to the effect that in the bottle of Bull Run he threw away his sword and ran while his regiment stood firm, is entirely incorrect. He remained with his men until the retreat was ordered, keeping them steadily to their work, and taking them from the field in good order as far as Centreville. Our authority for this statement is Lieut. J.T. WILSON, commanding Company G, of the Second, who fought with Col. TOMPKINS until taken prisoner by the Black Horse Cavalry in their last charge, but who subsequently escaped.

abstract: FREEDOM. Some of the brave men whose arms established constitutional freedom in Italy, now that their services are no longer needed at home, have come to this country with a view of tendering their aid to the Government in its struggles to maintain the Constitution and the Union.
lead_paragraph: FREEDOM. -- Some of the brave men whose arms established constitutional freedom in Italy, now that their services are no longer needed at home, have come to this country with a view of tendering their aid to the Government in its struggles to maintain the Constitution and the Union. Among these are Col. FRANCESCO ORNESI and Capt. FONTANA and DELLA COSTA, now in this City on their way to Washington. These gentlemen have served with distinction under GARIBALDI ,the evidences of which are furnished by their commissions and the honorable badges their gallantry has won. They go to offer their swords and the benefit of their practical experience to the Government. Very recent experience demonstrates the want of such men, and their services should not be rejected. That they are not now familiar with our language, is an objection met by the fact, that GARIBALDI himself laid the foundations of his military renown in South America, where neither he nor his brave followers knew, at the beginning, scarcely a word of the language of the people in whose armies they served. A very short time will so perfect them in this particular as to make their services available. Their patriotism, their loyalty to constitutional government, and faithfulness to free institutions, entitle them to the favorable consideration of those who have the management of the military affairs of the nation. Neither red tape nor official jealousy should be permitted to stand in the way of their patriotic purposes. It is no reproach to our countrymen that they are not proficients in the science of war. More than three-quarters of a century of peace, with the exception only of some four or five years, with a standing army averaging less than sixteen thousand men, have not been productive of general military skill. We have plenty of courage, plenty of energy and power of endurance of the very best material for an army. What we lack is experience. Those brave Italian patriots who have served for years under one of the most distinguished Generals of the age, are greatly needed now, to instruct and perfect our regiments of volunteers in the exercises and duties pertaining to an effective soldiery.
headline: {'main': 'ITALIAN PATRIOTISM FOR CONSTITUTIONAL', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'ITALIAN PATRIOTISM FOR CONSTITUTIONAL', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: A letter from Baden, dated July 14, appears in the Journal des Debats. The writer says: "This morning, between 9 and 10 o'clock, at the moment when the King of Prussia, after his customary walk in the Lichtenthal Avenue, was sealed near the stone fountain, a student of Leipsic approached him, and, leveling a pistol at his breast, pulled the trigger. The force of the charge happily caused the bullet to rise, and the ball only tore the dress, and slightly grazed the King's shoulder. Arrested on the spot by the promenaders who heard the report, the assassin was taken before the chief magistrate of the city, and was examined in the presence of his August Highness the Grand Duke of Bade. It is stated that the student confined himself to the reply, while avowing his crime, that his only object was to free Germany from a prince who was not sufficiently active in the cause of German unity. The population of Baden, where His Majesty is regarded with respect and veneration, heard of the event with a horror which will be shared by all the world. The report runs that the Leipsic student is the son of a Russian Consul in a city on the Black Sea. Others say that he is of Lithuanian orgin."
lead_paragraph: A letter from Baden, dated July 14, appears in the Journal des Debats. The writer says: "This morning, between 9 and 10 o'clock, at the moment when the King of Prussia, after his customary walk in the Lichtenthal Avenue, was sealed near the stone fountain, a student of Leipsic approached him, and, leveling a pistol at his breast, pulled the trigger. The force of the charge happily caused the bullet to rise, and the ball only tore the dress, and slightly grazed the King's shoulder. Arrested on the spot by the promenaders who heard the report, the assassin was taken before the chief magistrate of the city, and was examined in the presence of his August Highness the Grand Duke of Bade. It is stated that the student confined himself to the reply, while avowing his crime, that his only object was to free Germany from a prince who was not sufficiently active in the cause of German unity. The population of Baden, where His Majesty is regarded with respect and veneration, heard of the event with a horror which will be shared by all the world. The report runs that the Leipsic student is the son of a Russian Consul in a city on the Black Sea. Others say that he is of Lithuanian orgin."

abstract: Troops continue to poor into Washington, and under the vigorous measures inaugurated by Gen. MCCLELLAN the city will, doubtless without delay, be placed in a situation to defy any attempts which the rebel leaders, in the flush of recent victory, may be disposed to make upon it. Gen. MCCLELLAN has visited the various intrenchments on the Virginia side, in the short time during which he has had command, and taken such steps as he has considered necessary to make them impregnable. A report was current in Washington, yesterday, that a rebel force of forty thousand men was en route for the Potomac by way of Leesburgh, but our correspondents could not trace it to any reliable source.

abstract: In reviewing the causes of the recent disaster at Bull Run, it may be set down that we suffered most from two extremes of action  the great cowardice and the great courage of regimental officers.
lead_paragraph: In reviewing the causes of the recent disaster at Bull Run, it may be set down that we suffered most from two extremes of action -- the great cowardice and the great courage of regimental officers. All information concurs in the general statement that the held was full of brave men, but that they lost their officers, or lost sight of them, and became utterly disorganized; and so fled, as any great body of men will do in the presence of danger, when they lose the confidence of mutual support. The primary cause of confusion was the break of a regiment or two before a charge of cavalry. If these regiments had been well officered and thoroughly drilled, they, or the remnants of them, might have been re-formed on the field of battle. But there was no rallying point and no recuperative power in these regiments, and when once broken they scattered wildly and spread the contagion in every direction. First one, then another was involved in the tumult, till an entire division of the Army became a flying mob. In the mixed and miscellaneous herd, so many broken regiments and companies conspiring to swell the retreating column, no officer was generally enough known to effect a rally, and so the flight continued. Nevertheless, it is sufficiently in proof that individuals, not by virtue of their command as officers at all, did here and there induce small bodies of men to make a stand and pour steady and effective volleys into the pursuing enemy. These few exceptions were men evidently formed by nature for leaders, and their achievements show that we had true men enough in the fight, but that they were literally driven from the field from the lack of good leadership, and courageous and skillful handling.

abstract: respondents from Minnesota and Wisconsin represent a great scarcity of farm laborers. The harvest of grain is still going on in those States, and good men can readily get from $1 50 to $2 per day. This scarcity of labor to secure the crops is partly owing to the breadth of land put into grain, and partly to the number of active men who have gone into the Army. There will also be a scarcity of hands for the Fall work, and those who might be induced to go to those regions for employment would be pretty certain to find work for months, at least. Female domestics are also scarce, and obtain employment readily at good prices, in almost all the river towns. Those out of employment here should embrace this opportunity to better their condition. -- Missouri Democrat, 26.

abstract: This regiment, Col. SAMUEL C. LAWRENCE which was engaged in the action of Bull Run, arrived in this City yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock en route for Massachusetts. The men arrived by the Camden and Amboy line, and landed at Pier No. 1. North River. They were there received by the Sons of Massachusetts, resident in this City. After marching to the Park Barracks, where the men had rations served them, the officers proceeded to the Astor House, and partook dinner. When the cloth was removed, speeches were made by several distinguished gentlemen, and an address of welcome was spoken by Mr. CHARLES N. EMMERSON. At 6 1/2 o'clock the regiment got again under arms, and marched out, preceded by the Sons of Massachusetts to the foot of Cortlandt-street, where it embarked on board the steamship Commdore for home. Great enthusiasm was manifested along the whole line of march, and the regiment was cheered again and again. The whole of the staff was mounted, and Col. LAWRENCE, although wounded at the battle of Bull Run, rode at the head of his regiment.
lead_paragraph: This regiment, Col. SAMUEL C. LAWRENCE which was engaged in the action of Bull Run, arrived in this City yesterday afternoon at 4 o'clock en route for Massachusetts. abstract: In the House of Commons, on the 16th inst., Mr. T. DUNCOMBE said he wished to know from the noble lord at the head of foreign affairs whether hehad received any fresh complaints of the treatment of British subjects in the secession States, and whether he would make any statement to the House on the subject. He considered he had been rather unfortunately treated by the honorable member for Liskeard and the honorable member for Galway, the other evening when he introduced this subject, who treated his statements as old women's tales. The noble lord, however, partly bore out what he stated. But to get at the facts he wrote to the United States for information, and in reply he received an act passed in the end of May by Mr. JEFFERSON DAVIS and the parliament of the Confederate States, which completely confirmed what he said. He had stated that $20 had been offered for every person dead or alive. It appealed, however, that $25 was the sum offered, and that was the only mistake he made. He was right therefore in calling these people of the South and this Mr. J. DAVIS a set of brutes. [Laughter.] He also complained that a British Consul in the Confederate States neglected to do his duty by British subjects, and he wished to know whether the noble lord had received any communication upon that matter. He had himself received a communication at the last moment, stating that four or five Englishmen who had arrived in New-York, and were on their way to this country, complained that they had not obtained from British Consuls in the Southern States that protection to which they were entitled. They said they had experienced the inutility of a protection of those Consuls. With regard to the case of the tarring and feathering of the Captain of a British vessel, to which he alluded on a former occasion, he was informed that the British Consul at Savannah was present during that occurrence, and wore the secession colors. Surely, that was inconsistent with the neutrality which the English Government had declared they would observe. [Hear, hear.] When a reward was offered for the apprehension of the guilty parties, the ring-leader gave himself up and claimed the reward, and and after being subjected to two or three days' imprisonment was liberated. He (Mr. DUNCOMBE) understood, moreover, that the British Consul at Savannah was a large slave-owner in right of his wife, and, therefore, had a direct interest in the question which agitated the country. It was utterly impossible that justice could be done to British subjects if such a person held the office of Consul. He wished to know whether the noble lord the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs had received any complaint on the subject.

abstract: FIRE IN A FURNISHING GOODS STORE. A fire broke out, about 12 o'clock, on Sunday night, in the ladies furnishing goods store, No. 740 Broadway, owned by Mr. CHARLES H. BAKER. The flames spread rapidly, and the fire was not subdued until after the entire stock had been destroyed.
lead_paragraph: FIRE IN A FURNISHING GOODS STORE. -- A fire broke out, about 12 o'clock, on Sunday night, in the ladies furnishing goods store, No. 740 Broadway, owned by Mr. CHARLES H. BAKER. The flames spread rapidly, and the fire was not subdued until after the entire stock had been destroyed. The loss is estimated at $3,000, and is met by insurance of $5,300 on the stock and fixtures, and $600 on the household furniture, in the following named Companies: Relief, $1,700; Merchants', $1,700, and East River, $2,500. Mr. JOSEPH MERRELL, proprietor of the adjoining gentlemen's furnishing goods store, suffered to the extent of $200 by the wetting of his stock; insured for $1,000 in the Continental Insurance Company. The damage to the building is about $300, and it is covered by an insurance of $4,000 in the Irving Insurance Company. The origin of the fire is not at present known, but the Fire Marshal expects to find it out.

abstract: The Augusta Chronicle says: "It is a shame, and, we think, too, a gross mismanagement, that the flower of Georgia's well-trained volunteer soldier, and only one regiment, was sent into North western Virginia, into the very midst of Tories, away from railroads and reinforcements, to meet LINCOLN's best soldiers -- the Northwestern men -- under LINCOLN's best General -- MCCLELLAN -- and unsupported except by the almost raw Virginia militia."

abstract: TheToronto Leader thinks "the United States are the laughing-stock and scorn of the world." Eighty-six years ago, when the men of the Revolution suffered a Bull Run repulse at Bunker Hill, the British came to a similar conclusion relative to the Colonies, yet Trenton, Saratoga and Yorktown are historical facts over which they have never cared to laugh. It is rare that a war is carried on in which the party having the right does not meet with some reverses, and yet, in the end, if there be anything like fair play, the right prevails. In the present war, a minority of the States of the Confederacy having, in the course of political events, lost control of the Government, it is seeking to overthrow it that (hey may expand a system of despotism over a large portion of the continent, with the ultimate purpose of once more legalizing the African Slave-trade, now under the ban of civilization, and accompanying their rebellion with high-handed acts of theft, robbery. murder and piracy. The United States Government, on the other hand, is struggling for the maintenance of constitutional liberty and public order, and its course since hostilities commenced has been marked, with scarce any violation of the rules of honorable warfare, though it is fighting rebellious States. This attitude of our Government may be a fit subject for laughter in the eyes of the Leader, but its mirth will not be shared by Canadians generally.

abstract: -- The Albany Atlas and Argus, which embraces every opportunity to renew its misrepresentations of our history in alluding to well-authenticated accounts of the cruel butchery of our wounded, and the disfigurement of our dead soldiers by the rebels, at the battle of Bull Run, says that "the Kansas corps of incendiary forgeries and fabricators have been removed to the banks of the Potomac, and are manufacturing horrors in the old style." The grammatical, construction of the sentence is a matter of taste or accident, we care not which, but as that journal never failed in its apologies for the Border Ruffians of Missouri, and over and over again denied the truth of the crimes and outrages committed in Kansas, which are now admitted historical facts, it is quite in keeping with its antecedents for it now to deal generously with the traitors who are repeating on a grander scale, the horrors of the border upon the. defenders of this Government.

abstract: I am afraid the good people of New-York are doing quite as much to demoralize our troops, as did the battle of Bull Run. Idolising runaways, and making heroes of cowards, is not the way to grow true patriots and real heroes. The ovation to some of the returning troops looks at this distance like a mockery of valor.

abstract: Col. FERRY'S regiment, the Fifth, of Connecticut, left Hartford on Monday at 2 o'clock, and proceeded to New-Haven. In the City of Elins the greatest enthusiasm was manifested, and the march through the city was a continued ovation. Leaving New-Haven at about 7 o'clock, Monday evening, in the steamer Elm City, the regiment proceeded to Elizabethport, N.J., where it arrived a little after noon yesterday.
lead_paragraph: Col. FERRY's regiment, the Fifth, of Connecticut, left Hartford on Monday at 2 o'clock, and proceeded to New-Haven. In the City of Elins the greatest enthusiasm was manifested, and the march through the city was a continued ovation. Leaving New-Haven at about 7 o'clock, Monday evening, in the steamer Elm City, the regiment proceeded to Elizabethport, N.J., where it arrived a little after noon yesterday. Col. FERRY's orders are to report himself to Gen. BANKS. The men are a fine, hardy, stalwart set of fellows, all of whom are well armed and equipped, and present a fine martial appearance. In Fairfield County a few friends of Col. FERRY presented him with a very valuable and handsome horse. A band, numbering twenty-four pieces, accompanies the regiment. Gov. BUCKINGHAM presented them with the instruments, at an outlay of $900. The horses, which number seventy-two, and the baggage wagons, were brought down on the steamer Champion. Annexed is a list of the commissioned officers:

abstract: The Hartford Cornet Band, says the Courant, lost all their instruments. The bass drum was completely riddled with balls. Mr. __, the drummer, strapped the drum to his back, and ran with the multitude, in the retreat from Bull's Run, and three or four Confederates fired at him repeatedly, riddling the drum, but fortunately missing the drummer. Mr. KING, the leader, received a bullet on the tip of his rigid elbow. He was standing behind a big tree for protection, and in resting against it, one elbow slightly projected -- just far enough to permit a Confederate bullet to graze it, without hitting the bone. He was also hit by a bullet on the pocket, but his metalic mouth-pieces for the instruments, being in that pocket, took the whole force of the ball and saved his life. They were battered, and he was bruised by the force of the ball. He brings home a Confederate snaredrum as a trophy. His son was hurt by being run over, in the retreat, by a gun-carriage.

abstract: We abandon all hope, we had almost said all desire, of effecting any material change in the tone of the organs of British opinion toward the Government and the loyal people of this country. If what has been done and what has been, said on both sides of this most deplorable, but most inevitable contest, has not convinced those who profess to speak for the British public that it is on the side of the insurrectionists, the attempt of disappointed politicians to destroy what one of them has confessed to be "the most beneficial Government the world ever saw" in the interest of the propagation of Slavery, and on the side of loyal Americans a patriotic defence of that Government in the interests of constitutional liberty, and the restriction of the area of Slavery; -- if the British Press and people cannot now see that the spirit which animates the Northern States and the Union men of the Border States is not "a revengeful desire of military conquests," but one of devotion to the common country and to the right, 'its immediate purpose being to resist the attempt to cut the nation into bits like a worm, in the expectation that each wounded fragment will crawl off by itself, slowly and miserably repairing an independent but low and insignificant vitality -- if they do not or will not see this now, they never can or never will. And so long as the British Government maintains its present attitude, other demonstrations are of little material consequence. It would be pleasant, indeed, and what we much desire, to meet in the mother country with candid consideration, unassuming frank good feeling, and a moral support for the principles of eternal truth and justice; this would be a luxury, but it is not a necessity. We can do well without it. We can rely solely upon our own consciousness of right for moral support, and work out our own national salvation in our own way, although Great Britain, instead of giving us the cheers that we had looked for, breaks her sullen silence only with a sneer.

abstract: From intelligence received from apparently reliable sources, it appears that the rebels are moving from Manassas Junction, apparently with a view to an attack on Washington, although such demonstration may be a feint to draw attention from movements directed elsewhere either against Gen.BANKS ...
lead_paragraph: From intelligence received from apparently reliable sources, it appears that the rebels are moving from Manassas Junction, apparently with a view to an attack on Washington, although such demonstration may be a feint to draw attention from movements directed elsewhere either against Gen. BANKS at Harper's Ferry, or against Gen. ROSECRANS or Cox in Western Virginia. A decided offensive demonstration or movement, we have already shown to be a necessity imposed by their late victory; they must prove this to be something more than a mere repulse of the National forces. They must treat it as a great success in its results, as well as upon the field of battle. To leave it unimproved would be to throw away all its moral effects. The appropriate trophy would be the possession of Washington. In the conviction of the rebels it would secure the triumph of their cause. With such an inducement, and with the belief that we are yet demoralized by our defeat, what is there more probable than an attack upon our capital, so concerted as to cut us off from all communication through Baltimore, and to excite the disloyal sentiment in Maryland to open rebellion, which for the moment would greatly aid their operations, and probably add very materially to their military strength? Although Maryland is nominally loyal, a pretext or occasion may only be wanting to set the whole State in flames. We should count upon no different event. With the Confederates, in force, upon its soil, they may feel assured of such cooperation, whether they receive it or not. With the forces at their command, with the confidence inspired by their late victory, and with the strength of motive they have for the capture of Washington, an attack on that city is not improbable, whatever may be the result. We can hardly believe it could be successful; but the rebels, reasoning from entirely different premises, and possessing great superiority of numbers, may count its capture an easy affair.
headline: {'main': 'The Movements of the Rebels.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Movements of the Rebels.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: On Thursday, 1st August, there will he a sailing and a rowing regatta at Harlem, the boats to start from the Club-house, foot of One Hundred and Fourteenth-street, Harlem River. The first race is for catrigged sail-boats, to sail a course of ten miles, making four turns over the course, thus keeping the contestants in constant view during the entire race. This race will start at 1 o'clock P.M. The second race will be for single-scull row-boats, and will be for a distance of five miles, on the course of the Empire City Regatta Club. Both races will attract a large assemblage of the lovers of aquatic sport.
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, 1st August, there will he a sailing and a rowing regatta at Harlem, the boats to start from the Club-house, foot of One Hundred and Fourteenth-street, Harlem River. Both races will attract a large assemblage of the lovers of aquatic sport.

abstract: The condition of Washington concerns the nation. Whatever disorder and want of discipline there are within its limits reaches the hearthstone of every family in the land. If soldiers are allowed to frequent liquor shops, and officers hotels; if there is no obedience of the one to the other, but all agree in their determination to "have a good time" in the Capital; and if insubordination, habits of...
lead_paragraph: The condition of Washington concerns the nation. Whatever disorder and want of discipline there are within its limits reaches the hearthstone of every family in the land. If soldiers are allowed to frequent liquor shops, and officers hotels; if there is no obedience of the one to the other, but all agree in their determination to "have a good time" in the Capital; and if insubordination, habits of drinking and gambling, general idleness and dissipation begin there, what can the end be but individual ruin and general defeat and disaster?

abstract: MILITARY MATTERS. -- The Second Regiment, from Hudson County, is to be mustered out of the United States service at 11 o'clock to-day, in Jersey City. Two months' wages are due to the men, which they will probably receive on Friday. The Hudson County Artillery, Major HEXAMER, with 150 men and six field-pieces, have received orders to proceed to the seat of war, and will take their departure as soon as possible.
lead_paragraph: MILITARY MATTERS. -- The Second Regiment, from Hudson County, is to be mustered out of the United States service at 11 o'clock to-day, in Jersey City. abstract: -- In Illinois, it is announced that a regiment is being formed to be composed entirely of schoolmasters. Nothing could be more to the purpose. The want of competent teachers in the rebel States is painfully apparent. They are suffering in every department of human education. When the new regiment shall have faithfully and successfully inculcated in the minds of their Southern pupils the duty of obedience to the laws, and brought them to a recognition of the sin of stealing and piracy, its members may then safely substitute the birch for the bayonet, and use their exertions to bring them up to a proper standard in morals and spelling.

abstract: Eighty thousand men, with some military drill, discipline and experience, will have left the ranks of the army before the close of next week. How many of this number, and discipline and experience, will return to the service is a question of the utmost moment. The temptations to the enterprising and daring,...
lead_paragraph: Eighty thousand men, with some military drill, discipline and experience, will have left the ranks of the army before the close of next week. How many of this number, and discipline and experience, will return to the service is a question of the utmost moment. The temptations to the enterprising and daring, held out by the bustling and adventurous life of the soldier, will doubtless secure the re-enlistment of very many. But there are other considerations which will act forcibly in diminishing the number. Of these three are palpable.

abstract: A dispatch was received from Congressman ODELL, at 3 o'clock yesterday afternoon, announcing the gratifying intelligence that Col. A.M. WOOD, of the New-York Fourteenth State Militia, was alive and in good spirits. He had been very generally given up as dead. It seems that he was in the woods four days, with two of his men, before he was taken prisoner, and they were then taken to Centreville, where they are now in the hospital. Drs. HOMISTONE and SWALM are also both safe. All the above information comes from Dr. STEINBERG, U.S.A., in person, to Lieut.-Col. FOWLER, at Arlington.

abstract: The French war steamer Catinel. Commander FABRES, arrived at this port yesterday. She sailed from Breston the 17th of June, and called at Halifax July 27. The Catinel is a side-wheel vessel of 400 tons, carrying 172 men, and 8 guns. She is here as a convoy of the Prince NAPOLEON yacht, and will remain until she takes leave of the port on her return cruise.

abstract: ELECTION DISTRICTS IN THE NINETEENTH WARD  RECEPTION OF PRINCE NAPOLEON AND HIS CONSORT.  A special meeting of the Board was held at noon, yesterday, for the purpose of acting upon an ordinance, passed by the Board of Aldermen, re-dividing the Nineteenth Ward into election districts. Under the new division, the First District includes that portion...
lead_paragraph: ELECTION DISTRICTS IN THE NINETEENTH WARD -- RECEPTION OF PRINCE NAPOLEON AND HIS CONSORT. -- A special meeting of the Board was held at noon, yesterday, for the purpose of acting upon an ordinance, passed by the Board of Aldermen, re-dividing the Nineteenth Ward into election districts. Under the new division, the First District includes that portion of the City bounded by Forty-sixth-street, Third-avenue, Fortieth-street and Sixth-avenue. The Second District is bounded by Forty-sixth-street, East River, Fortieth-street and Third-avenue. The Third District is bounded by Fifty-fifth-street. Third-avenue, Forty-sixth-street, and Sixth-avenue. The Fourth District is bounded by Fifty-fifth-street, East River, Forty-sixth-street and Third-avenue. The Fifth District is bounded by Seventy-ninth-street, Third-avenue, Fifty-fifth-street, Central Park and Sixth-avenue. The Sixth District is bounded by Seventy-ninth-street, East River, Fifty-fifth-street, and Third-avenue. This District also includes Blackwell's Island. The Seventh District is bounded by Eighty-sixth-street, Third-avenue, Seventy-ninth-street and Central Park. The Eighth District is bounded by Eighty-sixth-street, East River, Seventy-ninth-street and Third-avenue. By this division of the Ward three new election districts are created. The Board passed the ordinance without debate.

abstract: Last Saturday, 1,200 men were detailed under Gen. SWEENEY, to break up a secession camp, located at Forsythe a point about fifty miles south of this, and situated at or near the foot of the Ozark Mountains. Monday at starting, we were thirty miles from Forsythe, having only made twenty miles in the two days previous, owing to heavy rains and the consequent almost impassable character of the mountain roads.

abstract: The Government, for the first time since the breaking out of the Great Rebellion, now seems to be really in earnest in its efforts to put it down. Everything at Washington and across the Potomac is being put under the most strict military rule. Our pickets, which are again being gradually extended, have received the most rigid instructions, ...
lead_paragraph: The Government, for the first time since the breaking out of the Great Rebellion, now seems to be really in earnest in its efforts to put it down. Everything at Washington and across the Potomac is being put under the most strict military rule. Our pickets, which are again being gradually extended, have received the most rigid instructions, with a view to preventing communication with, the enemy -- no person being allowed to pass, not even with a permit signed by Gen. SCOTT himself, or purporting to be so signed. With regard to the movements and intentions of the rebels, reports are conflicting. They are already again at Fairfax Court-house in about their original force. Whether they intend to make an attempt to cross the Potomac into Maryland is doubted in some quarters, while in others it is believed. Those who doubt, think the time for such a movement has passed. We shall soon probably understand the matter more definitely.

abstract: -- The law just passed by Congress in relation to the National Military School at West Point, provides that all cadets now in, or who may hereafter enter that institution, shall take the usual oath to support the Constitution, and in addition shall swear that they will maintain and defend the sovereignty of the United States, paramount to any and all allegiances, sovereignty, fealty or country whatever. This oath of allegiance is so framed as to meet the pestilent doctrine of superior allegiance to a State, and leaves no quibble through which treason can justify itself under that dangerous pretext. Hereafter, the graduate of our military school, who shall have been educated at the expense of the Government, if he desert the National flag, will be without excuse. To the dishonor of his treason, will be super-added the guilt of perjury. How far this would have prevented those officers who have taken service in the ranks of secession, from an abandonment of their duty as officers and honorable men, had the same regulation previously existed, we cannot of course now determine; but it is a partial safeguard at least, against the like dereliction in future. The candidate for military education must now make up his mind in advance whether his obligations to his State are secondary to those which he owes to the General Government. If he places his State first, he cannot enter this National institution without being foresworn, and he cannot desert the National flag, no matter by whom assailed, without branding himself as a perjurer.

abstract: The Washington Republican has this story: A likely young colored man, named IGNATIUS SMALLWOOD, who was a servant in the New-York Seventyfirst, and was taken prisoner on Sunday last, escaped from his captors, on Tuesday last, and returned to this city the latter part of the week. He is a young man, apparently not more than twenty-five years of age, and, withal, is very intelligent.

abstract: The Commander-in-Chief of the Army has ordered all the available batteries of United States Artillery now at Harrisburgh. Penn., and elsewhere in that State to the line of the Potomac. Several batteries left yesterday and the day before for that destination. Capt. CAMPBELL, now at Harrisburgh, has been deputed to get ambulance for the conveyance of ordnance and men.
lead_paragraph: The Commander-in-Chief of the Army has ordered all the available batteries of United States Artillery now at Harrisburgh. Penn., and elsewhere in that State to the line of the Potomac. Several batteries left yesterday and the day before for that destination. Capt. CAMPBELL, now at Harrisburgh, has been deputed to get ambulance for the conveyance of ordnance and men.

abstract: A week to-day the Army of the Union marched on Manassas with the joy as battle-cry of "On to Richmond," and a week to-night this same Army marched back with the wild cry of "Retreat on Washington." The venerable Mr. STOCKTON, the Chaplain of the House, took occa- sion this morning to administer a rebuke to the Government, and he did it manfully and unhesitatingly.
lead_paragraph: Correspondence of the New-York Times.

abstract: Since the disastrous affair at Bull Run, we are again on the defensive. Our Army is back to its old position on the Potomac, strengthening itself against apprehended attack from the enemy, as it was three months ago.
lead_paragraph: Since the disastrous affair at Bull Run, we are again on the defensive. Our Army is back to its old position on the Potomac, strengthening itself against apprehended attack from the enemy, as it was three months ago. Twenty millions of people, abounding in wealth, in enterprise, full of energy, having the best material in the world for an army, with an exuberance of the means of supply, are beleaguered by five millions, without credit and without money, lacking, save in the prosecution of the present war, that energy and enterprise in all that pertains to physical progress which characterizes the North. Who is responsible for this strange anomaly we do not now propose to inquire. We speak only of a fact which is painfully evident to all -- one which never should have been, and ought not to be permitted one day longer than imperious necessity may require. The position of things should be changed at the earliest possible moment. The might of the loyal States should be at once aroused to the vindication of the Government, and to the wiping out of the perpetual insult that a rebel army in sight of the Capital is continually inflicting. If we have underrated the number and courage of the enemy -- if we have reposed in security under the delusion that an army, weak in proportion to our actual strength could crush the gigantic treason of the South by the suppression of the present revolt, let us neither deceive not permit ourselves to be longer deceived. We must now, whether we will it or not, view this rebellion is all its vast proportions, and realize the fact that we must exert what energy and strength we have to overcome it; or we must be content to see the Union fall to pieces, and the great American Republic topple into ruins before its exulting march.

One of the villains seized the horse by the reins and kept hita steady, while his confederate...
lead_paragraph: HIGHWAYMEN IN WESTCHESTER. -- Mr. RICHARD HAMILTON, residing at West Farms, Westchester County, while riding in a carriage toward Fordham at an early hour Sunday morning, encountered two highwaymen, who sprang from behind a clump of trees at the roadside. One of the villains seized the horse by the reins and kept hita steady, while his confederate presented a pistol at Mr. HAMILTON's face and demanded his money. As Mr. H. had no funds with him he could hot comply with the imperative order but the robber would not be put off without booty, and obliged his victim to deliver his gold watch and chain are he released him. During their colloquy Mr. H. had been noting well the appearance of the high-wayman, whose face was partially masked, and as quickly as possible he returned to his house, where he loaded a gun, and, accompanied by his father, started in search of the rogues. Driving across Harlem Bridge, he met two of the Twelfth Precinct Policemen, to whom he narrated what had happened, and described the general appearance of the men. The officers at once joined in the search, and soon found two fellows in one of the Third-avenue cars, whom they arrested on suspicion. At the Station-house the prisoners were searched, and one of them had Mr. HAMILTON's watch and chain in his possession. They also had two loaded pistols, a file ground to a sharp point, and a counterfeit $50 bank note. Both are young men, and they give the names of CHARLES CARROLL and ABRAHAM SECOR. They were delivered into the custody of a Westchester County Magistrate, who committed them for trial.
